webTitle: Charlton 2 - 1 Derby

fields.headline: Jensen's burst roasts the Rams
fields.trailText:
Charlton 2 - 1 Derby
Jensen's burst roasts the Rams.
fields.body:
Derby's assistant manager Colin Todd said earlier this month that he wanted seven points from the games against Middlesbrough, Manchester City and Charlton. That the club end the sequence with just one after this defeat sums up their problems.

Although it needed a memorable run by Claus Jensen to decide the match, Derby can have few complaints at the outcome. How different they will feel it might have been had Craig Burley not missed a penalty at 1-1 just before half-time.

They remain three points clear of the relegation zone having played a game more than their closest rivals. Only Mart Poom's agility kept them in touch early on and their failure to create more does not bode well for the run-in.

That they were beaten by Jensen's thrilling dribble and Scott Parker's finish was fitting. The pair, rested at the weekend, were at the centre of much of Charlton's best work.

Jim Smith described the defending which led to the winner as "amateur" but the Dane's acceleration and skill were decisive. Holding off Darryl Powell, Jensen embarked on a run of 70 yards, cut inside a Derby defender in the area and seemed to have jinked his way past Poom only to be denied by the keeper. Parker was on hand to knock in the loose ball.

With 36 points Charlton have equalled the total they were relegated with in their first Premiership season. That year Derby finished eighth but those days seem a long way off and Smith's worries have been heightened by the failure of Taribo West to reappear from Nigeria, where he played for his country at the weekend.

"I don't know what church he is in," Smith said of his religious defender. "We have to wait and see what the explanations are. We expected him at the hotel yesterday [Monday]. Even his agent was there waiting for him and he didn't have a clue where he was."

For the first half-hour Derby were just as lost in the face of Charlton's attacks. Horacio Carbonari had already sliced a clearance against a post when Matt Svensson headed in a Jensen corner via Youl Mawene, and it needed two fine stops by Poom to keep it at that.

Derby, though, equalised with their first meaningful effort in the 35th minute, Burley bending a free-kick beyond Dean Kiely as the goalkeeper was organising his wall.

Eight minutes later a Mark Fish error led to Kiely bringing down Malcolm Christie to concede a penalty. Burley struck the kick firmly but the Ireland goalkeeper saved impressively.

"He shouldn't have been on the pitch," Smith said, feeling Kiely should have been sent off. As it was, a groin strain forced his half-time withdrawal but his replacement Tony Caig was little tested.

"You can't rely on set-plays and a penalty," Smith said. "You have got to create more than we did and defend better."

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: TV and Radio: Rod Liddle's diary

fields.headline: Rod Liddle's diary
fields.standfirst:
Hear no evil, speak no evil

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: It seems that we at Radio 4's Today programme are about to sack our presenter, Edward Stourton, because he's too posh. Not just too posh, mind, but - according to the writer AN Wilson in his local newspaper - "well born", too.
fields.body:
It seems that we at Radio 4's Today programme are about to sack our presenter, Edward Stourton, because he's too posh. Not just too posh, mind, but - according to the writer AN Wilson in his local newspaper - "well born", too.

I'm not sure how the concepts of "well born" and "posh" differ, being neither myself, but the rumour has spread across the diary columns of Fleet Street like drug abuse through the dormitories of a minor public school. And it doesn't matter how much you attempt to refute the absurd allegation, it bounces back the next week, with greater self-righteousness and indignation.

The truth is, I never knew that Ed WAS posh, still less "well born". My idea of posh was someone who had antimacassars and a special tin for biscuits - so Edward's impeccable manners at table and charming company were rather wasted on me. There was no monocle, fob or plus fours and he never expressed an approval of fox hunting. So just how does one know?

I dropped a line to Mr Wilson when the stories first appeared saying you're wrong, Ed's staying. He's a superb journalist, wonderful broadcasting voice, etc, etc. And two days ago I received a letter, written with a quill pen in a spidery, purplish handwriting, congratulating me on granting Edward a reprieve "as a result of my article". I assume this is AN's take on irony.

As you read this Edward will be speeding towards Brussels to present a Today programme special examining the case for withdrawal from the EU - the whole business of his upbringing a matter of mild bemusement. He's since admitted to me that in truth he is quite well born . He has a signet ring with his family crest on it, which beats a chunky gold sovereign in my book. Loyalue Serai Durant Ma Vie. No, me neither.

But while he dozes in his economy Eurostar seat and the dismal Belgian countryside flashes by, it will perhaps be a comfort to him to know that somewhere, back in Britain, a few people are still fighting the last few rounds of the class war, and Today is in the front line.

It's all there in AN Wilson's rather good novels, where the lower-class people are simply ghastly and called things like Spittle and Widger and the toffs are quite decent - but weary, and heading for defeat.

It's a view of Britain best described by John Betjeman:

Think of what our Nation

stands for,

Books from Boots and

country lanes,

Free speech, free passes, class

distinction,

Democracy and proper drains

But those lines were written 60 years ago, and meant as satire even then.

 Rod Liddle is editor of BBC Radio 4's Today Programme. His column will appear every Wednesday.

webTitle: Tube strike in doubt after court injunction

fields.headline: Tube strike in doubt after court injunction
fields.standfirst: Special report: Transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Tube passengers may not be facing a strike on Monday after London Underground was tonight granted a high court injunction blocking threatened strike action by members of the Rail, Maritime and Transport union.
fields.body:
Tube passengers may not be facing a strike on Monday after London Underground was tonight granted a high court injunction blocking threatened strike action by members of the Rail, Maritime and Transport union.

Mr Justice Gibbs granted the injunction against RMT, preventing members walking out next Monday. The RMT - and the train drivers' union Aslef - have planned three one-day strikes on successive Mondays.

The judge ruled that there had been "non-compliance" by the union with statutory provisions, and he will rule tomorrow on whether the strike ballot itself will have to be rerun.

After today's decision, the RMT's assistant general secretary, Bob Crow, said the union would await the judge's full ruling tomorrow before making any comment on whether the strike scheduled for Monday would be called off or whether the union would launch an appeal.

Earlier, Mr Jeffrey Burke QC, for London Underground, told the judge the injunction was being sought against the RMT on the basis that the union had failed to comply with compulsory provisions of trade union law.

LU claims the union's industrial action ballot was "invalid". Mr Burke said that the union had failed to provide basic information about the number, category and workplace of the employees concerned which were believed to number more than 6,000.

"The purpose of the requirement is to help the employer makes plans so as to avoid or reduce the impact of the proposed industrial action," he said.

The RMT says all the information legally required to be supplied has been given to LU and the claim that it has not complied with the law is "completely without justification".

Mr Burke said the disruption which would be caused by strike action involved 3m passenger journeys each day with a loss of £3m in revenue each day.

An LU spokeswoman said afterwards: "We are saddened that we have had to come to court. "We still have talks with the unions tomorrow and we are still hoping that we can resolve this dispute so we can provide a full service for our three million daily passengers."

webTitle: Week 9: Wanaka to Dunedin (New Zealand)

fields.headline: Jumping for joy
fields.standfirst: Continuing  to explore the best of New Zealand's outdoor activities, Sam does an accidental bungee jump, and, best of all, finds himself kayacking with  a pod of dolphins for company
fields.trailText: Continuing to explore the best of New Zealand's outdoor activities, Sam does an accidental bungee jump, and, best of all, finds himself kayacking with a pod of dolphins for company
fields.body:
I take back all my griping about New Zealand's weather. The last few days have been almost perfect. Clear blue skies and warm reviving sunshine. I have made the most of the weather and so this is a bit of a long report. It's worth hanging in there for the dolphins though.

My week started with a very pleasant couple of days in the lakeside town of Wanaka. It's a small place but with a good selection of bars and cafes and it's in a beautiful setting, nestled among the mountains of the Southern alps. There are a number of good walks you can do along the lakeshore or in the surrounding hills. I had been planning to climb Mount Roy. But while strolling around the western shore I stumbled across the tiny Rippon Vineyards where you could do wine tasting for NZ$3 (about £1).

After a few glasses of the local riesling, a little sleep in the sun among the vines seemed a much more relaxing option than climbing mountains.

That evening I treated myself to a trip to the pictures. The movie was a laughably bad Dennis Quaid vehicle called Frequency. But the film didn't really matter because Wanaka cinema was such a delight. About the size of a village hall, the seating was a motley assortment of armchairs and sofas with a convertible Morris Minor thrown in for good measure.

Halfway through, the film stopped and we had a short interval. Everyone went outside to the adjoining cafe and got freshly baked cookies (still warm), homemade ice cream or a beer and then settled back into their armchairs. This is how all cinemas should be. It was more like being round someone's house.

I reluctantly left Lake Wanaka and travelled on to Queenstown. On the way we stopped at Kawarau Suspension Bridge. This is the home of the original and most famous bungy jump venue in the country, with a 43m drop to the fast-flowing river below.

Before arriving in New Zealand I had no intention of doing a bungee jump but the combined onslaught of hard-sell promotion, peer pressure and a feeling that I didn't want to be left out, had weakened me. So 10 minutes after I had signed up and parted with NZ$125, I was sitting on the bridge having elastic cord tied round my ankles.

I declined the offer of being dunked headfirst in the water and then gingerly hopped on to the platform over the river.

It was a long way down.

You are supposed to perform an elegant swan dive but standing there on the edge I lost my nerve and basically fell off. I had a brief sensation of hanging in the air. I felt like I was in one of those cartoons where the animated character has run off the cliff and his legs are whirring over nothing. Then I was plummeting down towards the river. Then I was bouncing back up to the bridge. Then I was falling back down again.

This went on for some time.

I was doing a little upside down pirouette when I heard a voice calling "Grab the pole". There was a dinghy below me with a couple of guys in it, one of whom was holding a pole. I eventually got hold of it, and he hauled me into the boat. In no time I was back at the top of the gorge, being cheered by my fellow travellers.

You can see the video of my performance on the website. This was beautifully shot by Katy Bradbury who is not only an excellent camerawoman but also coped admirably when we thought the camera hadn't worked and she had missed the whole thing. It was just as well it did work because I won't be doing it again.

Queenstown was another lakeside alpine city in a stunning setting with just about every conceivable activity on offer from white water rafting to skydiving. It's also the party capital of New Zealand and that evening I went out to test some of the bars.

I bumped into Steve who I'd last seen on the Franz Josef Glacier. This is the great thing about travelling on an organised tour like the Magic Bus - it's really easy to meet people. You are all travelling in the same direction and going to roughly the same places, so there's a good chance that when you get on the bus in the morning there will always be somebody you know there.

Steve had just done the Nevis Highwire Bungy - a huge 134m fall from a glass bottomed cabin strung across a river - so we headed off to have a number of pints of Speights (the local brewery) to celebrate our survival.

Early next morning, nursing a delicate hangover, I headed on to Fiordland and Lake Te Anau.

Fiordland National Park sits at the bottom of New Zealand's west coast. There are a number of world famous hiking routes here (tramps as the Kiwis call them) including the popular Milford Track, access to which is booked up months in advance. I can see why, the scenery is breathtaking with high mountain lakes, deep empty fiords and a rugged rain-swept coastline.

I had enjoyed my earlier one-day sea kayaking excursion in Abel Tasman so much that I had decided to do a more adventurous trip, and secured the last available place on a two-day guided tour into Doubtful Sound run by Fiordland Wilderness Experiences. This company, run by Daphne Taylor and Bill Gibson, is one of the few to do kayaking trips into Doubtful Sound, which is considerably less accessible than the better known Milford Sound some 100km further up the coast.

I met up with Daphne and the rest of my group at their base in Te Anau. Daphne briefed us on the details of the tour and what we needed to bring (this was mainly food as pretty much everything else is provided). She promised what sounded like a fantastic wilderness trip. We would spend two days exploring the quiet reaches of the Sound and spend the night in a small bush camp. Jeremy our guide would pick us all up from our hostels at 6am tomorrow.

I stocked up with provisions at the local supermarket. I wasn't going to have to carry it for miles on my back this time, so I got a few luxuries including a date and walnut cake and fresh pasta. I also bought plenty of bug repellent - the sandflies are legendary round here and Daphne had warned us about them.

Next morning, Jeremy drove us across to Lake Manapouri. A motorboat took us 30km across the rolling lake - it was really cold and there was snow on the peaks - this was supposed to be summer!

We landed in an empty bay next to a hydoelectric power station. After packing all our gear into a huge four-wheel drive landcruiser we set off on the 24km steep drive over Wilmot Pass and down to Deep Cove at the end of Doubtful Sound (see what I mean about it being inaccessible?).

We carried the kayaks down to the waterside and loaded them up. Jeremy handed out all our equipment: wetsuits, thermal tops, waterproof jacket, life jacket, suncap, camera bag, etc. He then ran through the various safety measures and emphasised that we really were out in the wilderness here and would need to work as a team and rely on each other if anything went wrong.

And then we were out on the calm waters, paddling. It was beautiful. Snow-capped mountains rose up all around us. Waterfalls cascaded down the towering sea cliffs. Seals played with each other or sunbathed on rocky outcrops. There was no-one about but us, not a fishing boat, a plane or even any other kayaks.

I was in a double kayak with Thabea from Germany. She was happy for me to sit in the back and do all the steering. This was a mistake as it took me a while to get used to the rudder controls and our early path was a bit erratic. However I managed to avoid crashing into the others and soon we were enthusiastically paddling along the shore at a good pace (too enthusiastic actually as Jeremy had to keep calling us back when we got too far away from the rest of the group).

We spent a lovely day exploring Hall Arm off the main reach of the Sound. Jeremy stopped to show us local wildlife and geology. We paddled under glittering waterfalls. The water was completely pure and you could hold out your hand to catch and drink it as it fell.

We stopped for lunch in a little rocky cove and then headed up the shallow river mouth of the Arm. In late afternoon we landed at the campsite and hauled the kayaks up well clear of the tide.

The campsite was right in the bush with spaces for the tents and a larger space for an insect shelter where we could do cooking and relax in the evening. I set my tent up next to a little rushing stream.

We had a few drinks down by the shore as the sun began to set. But the sandflies were out in force, and after a while we had to retreat to the shelter. Jeremy pulled out a cask of wine to help the evening along and we spent the evening eating, drinking, telling jokes and listening to the birds calling around us.

We got up early the next day and were in the middle of breakfast when Jeremy popped his head into the shelter and asked we wanted to see something special. We followed him down to the shore. It was a beautiful morning. The water was completely still and the mountains were reflected in its surface. A few hundred metres off near the other shore, a small pod of bottlenose dolphins was working its way up the Arm. You could see their explosive breath like little steam engines blowing out of the water as they slowly rose and dipped.

We rushed back to the camp and packed up the tents so we could get out on the water. We did this as quickly as possible but it was still a slow process and by the time we were struggling to carry the heavy kayaks out, the dolphins had turned back and were now a long way off at the entrance to the Arm. We had missed a rare opportunity to paddle with these amazing creatures. We were all terribly disappointed, but Jeremy pointed out that we were really lucky to have even seen them at all.

Thabea and I were out on the water first and Jeremy was just explaining that we might still catch them up when Thabea interrupted him pointing ahead of us, "Look!". There was another pod of about seven dolphins coming straight towards us.

We quickly paddled out. Jeremy cautioned us not to approach the group but let them come to us if they wanted. As they got closer to us the pod dived. For a moment everything was still. Then Jeremy cried out "One's just gone right under me". And the next moment the dolphins were playing all around us. They jumped over each other. They raced us. They dived under the kayaks. They swam alongside us. Two leapt out of the water either side of me.

It must have only lasted a few short minutes but what an incredible emotional experience. I will never forget it.

The dolphins could easily outpace us and they soon moved on up the Arm leaving us slow coaches behind. We saw another similar sized group soon afterwards, but they dived under us and kept moving. They were probably chasing a shoal of fish and didn't have time to stop and play.

The rest of the morning slipped by on the tranquil waters as we slowly moved back out into the main reach of the Sound. We stopped for lunch on a little beach. While we were brewing coffee the wind picked up. It was still clear and sunny but the wind was now rushing down the Sound. Before we got back into the kayaks, Jeremy briefed us on how to tackle the next stretch. We needed to get across the Sound to the far side of Elizabeth Island but the strengthening breeze would make this a lot tougher than the easy cruising we had been doing so far, and we would need to angle ourselves into the wind and paddle hard.

Off we went, and almost straight away I was drenched by a big wave. Shaking the water out of my eyes, I dug my paddle in and our now rather small and vulnerable kayak pushed out into the middle of the reach. It was pretty rocky for a while - that wasn't the only wave to soak me, but it was more exciting than dangerous. Jeremy was darting from one kayak to another making sure we were ok and keeping the group together.

By the time we made it to the shelter of the island we were all out of breath. So we formed the kayaks into a raft, rigged up a sail and coasted back down the reach with the wind at our backs.

There was a little time for some surfing too before we were back at Deep Cove and unpacking the kayaks.

It was a fantastic couple of days, and I would recommend it to anyone. It was infinitely better than the commercialised cruise on Milford Sound surrounded by a flotilla of boats that I took the next day.

Thanks for everyone's emails this week. I particularly liked Charlotte's and Carolyne's tips on Africa - I'm planning on taking their advice on board.

Tomorrow I'm off to Dunedin (the Edinburgh of the South apparently) and then Christchurch from where I fly out to Sydney in one week's time. However, I've still got a couple of New Zealand adventures up my sleeve, so tune in next week.

I had enjoyed my earlier one-day sea kayaking excursion in Abel Tasman so much that I had decided to do a more adventurous trip, and secured the last available place on a two-day guided tour into Doubtful Sound run by Fiordland Wilderness Experiences. This company, run by Daphne Taylor and Bill Gibson, is one of the few to do kayaking trips into Doubtful Sound, which is considerably less accessible than the better known Milford Sound some 100km further up the coast. I met up with Daphne and the rest of my group at their base in Te Anau. Daphne briefed us on the details of the tour and what we needed to bring (this was mainly food as pretty much everything else is provided). She promised what sounded like a fantastic wilderness trip. We would spend two days exploring the quiet reaches of the Sound and spend the night in a small bush camp. Jeremy our guide would pick us all up from our hostels at 6am tomorrow. I stocked up with provisions at the local supermarket. I wasn't going to have to carry it for miles on my back this time, so I got a few luxuries including a date and walnut cake and fresh pasta. I also bought plenty of bug repellent - the sandflies are legendary round here and Daphne had warned us about them. Next morning, Jeremy drove us across to Lake Manapouri. A motorboat took us 30km across the rolling lake - it was really cold and there was snow on the peaks - this was supposed to be summer! We landed in an empty bay next to a hydoelectric power station. After packing all our gear into a huge four-wheel drive landcruiser we set off on the 24km steep drive over Wilmot Pass and down to Deep Cove at the end of Doubtful Sound (see what I mean about it being inaccessible?). We carried the kayaks down to the waterside and loaded them up. Jeremy handed out all our equipment: wetsuits, thermal tops, waterproof jacket, life jacket, suncap, camera bag, etc. He then ran through the various safety measures and emphasised that we really were out in the wilderness here and would need to work as a team and rely on each other if anything went wrong. And then we were out on the calm waters, paddling. It was beautiful. Snow-capped mountains rose up all around us. Waterfalls cascaded down the towering sea cliffs. Seals played with each other or sunbathed on rocky outcrops. There was no-one about but us, not a fishing boat, a plane or even any other kayaks. I was in a double kayak with Thabea from Germany. She was happy for me to sit in the back and do all the steering. This was a mistake as it took me a while to get used to the rudder controls and our early path was a bit erratic. However I managed to avoid crashing into the others and soon we were enthusiastically paddling along the shore at a good pace (too enthusiastic actually as Jeremy had to keep calling us back when we got too far away from the rest of the group). We spent a lovely day exploring Hall Arm off the main reach of the Sound. Jeremy stopped to show us local wildlife and geology. We paddled under glittering waterfalls. The water was completely pure and you could hold out your hand to catch and drink it as it fell. We stopped for lunch in a little rocky cove and then headed up the shallow river mouth of the Arm. In late afternoon we landed at the campsite and hauled the kayaks up well clear of the tide. The campsite was right in the bush with spaces for the tents and a larger space for an insect shelter where we could do cooking and relax in the evening. I set my tent up next to a little rushing stream. We had a few drinks down by the shore as the sun began to set. But the sandflies were out in force, and after a while we had to retreat to the shelter. Jeremy pulled out a cask of wine to help the evening along and we spent the evening eating, drinking, telling jokes and listening to the birds calling around us. We got up early the next day and were in the middle of breakfast when Jeremy popped his head into the shelter and asked we wanted to see something special. We followed him down to the shore. It was a beautiful morning. The water was completely still and the mountains were reflected in its surface. A few hundred metres off near the other shore, a small pod of bottlenose dolphins was working its way up the Arm. You could see their explosive breath like little steam engines blowing out of the water as they slowly rose and dipped. We rushed back to the camp and packed up the tents so we could get out on the water. We did this as quickly as possible but it was still a slow process and by the time we were struggling to carry the heavy kayaks out, the dolphins had turned back and were now a long way off at the entrance to the Arm. We had missed a rare opportunity to paddle with these amazing creatures. We were all terribly disappointed, but Jeremy pointed out that we were really lucky to have even seen them at all. Thabea and I were out on the water first and Jeremy was just explaining that we might still catch them up when Thabea interrupted him pointing ahead of us, "Look!". There was another pod of about seven dolphins coming straight towards us. We quickly paddled out. Jeremy cautioned us not to approach the group but let them come to us if they wanted. As they got closer to us the pod dived. For a moment everything was still. Then Jeremy cried out "One's just gone right under me". And the next moment the dolphins were playing all around us. They jumped over each other. They raced us. They dived under the kayaks. They swam alongside us. Two leapt out of the water either side of me. It must have only lasted a few short minutes but what an incredible emotional experience. I will never forget it. The dolphins could easily outpace us and they soon moved on up the Arm leaving us slow coaches behind. We saw another similar sized group soon afterwards, but they dived under us and kept moving. They were probably chasing a shoal of fish and didn't have time to stop and play. The rest of the morning slipped by on the tranquil waters as we slowly moved back out into the main reach of the Sound. We stopped for lunch on a little beach. While we were brewing coffee the wind picked up. It was still clear and sunny but the wind was now rushing down the Sound. Before we got back into the kayaks, Jeremy briefed us on how to tackle the next stretch. We needed to get across the Sound to the far side of Elizabeth Island but the strengthening breeze would make this a lot tougher than the easy cruising we had been doing so far, and we would need to angle ourselves into the wind and paddle hard. Off we went, and almost straight away I was drenched by a big wave. Shaking the water out of my eyes, I dug my paddle in and our now rather small and vulnerable kayak pushed out into the middle of the reach. It was pretty rocky for a while - that wasn't the only wave to soak me, but it was more exciting than dangerous. Jeremy was darting from one kayak to another making sure we were ok and keeping the group together. By the time we made it to the shelter of the island we were all out of breath. So we formed the kayaks into a raft, rigged up a sail and coasted back down the reach with the wind at our backs. There was a little time for some surfing too before we were back at Deep Cove and unpacking the kayaks. It was a fantastic couple of days, and I would recommend it to anyone. It was infinitely better than the commercialised cruise on Milford Sound surrounded by a flotilla of boats that I took the next day. Thanks for everyone's emails this week. I particularly liked Charlotte's and Carolyne's tips on Africa - I'm planning on taking their advice on board. Tomorrow I'm off to Dunedin (the Edinburgh of the South apparently) and then Christchurch from where I fly out to Sydney in one week's time. However, I've still got a couple of New Zealand adventures up my sleeve, so tune in next week.

webTitle: Cash rules force Labour to halve poll spending

fields.headline: Cash rules force Labour to halve poll spending
fields.standfirst: Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Labour will be able to spend no more than £14.4m on its election campaign if, as expected, the poll takes place on May 3, the Home Office disclosed yesterday.
fields.body:
Labour will be able to spend no more than £14.4m on its election campaign if, as expected, the poll takes place on May 3, the Home Office disclosed yesterday.

The £14.4m cap, part of a raft of measures designed to clean up British politics, is less than half the total the party spent in its 1997 election.

If the Conservatives contest 18 seats in Northern Ireland, William Hague will be able to spend up to £14.8m.

Under the formula announced yesterday each political party will be able to spend £22,500 per constituency contested if the election is called within the next three months.

The parties must also submit quarterly returns on all donations worth more than £5,000 accepted by the party's central organisation.

Under the guidelines issued yesterday political parties' spending is fixed on a sliding scale related to the time between February 16, when the Political Parties Act comes into force, and the polling date. The scale goes up to £19.77m if an election is called 12 months after February 16.

Tories and Labour have recently announced multi-million pound donations, and will have little difficulty raising the necessary cash. Both parties' recent ad campaigns will not be covered by the spending caps since they precede the February 16 starting point.

webTitle: New target voters may dash Hague hopes

fields.headline: New target voters may dash Hague hopes
fields.standfirst:
Mondeo man led the way, then Worcester woman - now poll hopes are pinned on Pebbledash people

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Mondeo man led the way, then Worcester woman - now poll hopes are pinned on Pebbledash people.
fields.body:
The Pebbledash people came to their mock Tudor doors yesterday and warned that Conservative election canvassers were going to face a pretty gruelling time.

The latest Tory strategy for electoral success involves targeting middle income families in around 180 key marginal seats, typically living in pebbledashed three bedroom semi-detached houses.

"Pebbledash person" is the latest personification of a group of voters both main parties have seen as crucial to election success. Previous models included Mondeo man and Worcester woman, courted by Labour at the last election.

Pebbledash people, who may have voted Conservative in 1992 but then left the party in 1997, are likely to receive phonecalls from a team of 60 volunteers at Conservative central office in the run-up to the election, widely expected to be on May 3.

Spotted - and rather loftily nicknamed - by William Hague's strategists as key target voters, the aficionados of cement/gravel cladding were definitely miffed at the idea.

"Makes us sound like summat out of Disneyland," snorted Peter Stockdale, a Yorkshire electrician who initially seemed a good bet for restoring Tory power in Shipley, Sir Marcus Fox's lost domain in West Yorkshire.

The whole of Hinchcliffe Avenue heard him telling a Labour MP, on a visit to boost the party: "Get away. I'm not right impressed by your lot."

But this heir to Mondeo Man and Worcester Woman, one of 2.5 million PPs confidentially identified by Conservative central office in 178 target seats, is not good news for Mr Hague.

Mr Stockdale and his wife were, and are, Liberal Democrats, just as their equally pebble-dashed neighbour, Chris Lees, remains a safe bet for Shipley's marginal Labour MP, Chris Leslie, who won a slender 2,996 majority on a 13.8% swing at the last election.

"Tories? No chance," said Mr Lees, dashing understandable hopes that a 33-year-old sales administrator with a can-making firm might be wavering, especially one who drives a petrol hungry Mazda MX5. "I'm probably old before my time, having pebbledash, but I'll definitely stay with Labour while Hague's in charge."

The red roses twining up another bit of thirties décor on Mr Lees's bungalow, the stained glass window panels, might be a warning to canvassers. But his real reason is that sleaze memories - "You just can't trust the Conservatives," he says - are not yet four years old.

Across the road, Colin Woodhead's recall goes back a lot further. "I was on short time working at the foundry under Thatcher," he says. "I don't somehow think they're going to win me back."

Mr Woodhead and his wife Maria have more pebbledash than anyone else in the avenue, and with teenage children and worries about health, crime and getting speed bumps to put off rat-runners, they fit the leaked central office picture. Aged 43 and 40, concerned about the euro and standards in education, they sound like the prime (35-50, married with kids at state school, generally a bit uneasy) Pebbledashers in the Tory blueprint.

But no. Mrs Woodhead says: "It's taking time to get things right, but then it does. There's a shortage of doctors, but you don't train a doctor in two or three years. We expected change when we voted for Blair, but we know it'll take a good few years for everything to work out."

Gordon Soothill was the avenue's one possible crumb of comfort, although Shipley Conservatives will have to act quickly to make sure he isn't on holiday when the poll comes. "It's quite likely," he says, admitting to being open to persuasion but only if any one of the three parties tries especially hard.

And even this is not over-encouraging for Mr Hague. Mr Soothill is a retired textile company manager, a type whose support for past Conservative leaders was seldom soft. "Maybe ready for a change," is as far as he'll go at the moment; while across the road Mr Stockdale is still rumbling at the pebbledash tag.

"Maybe they meant people with that other stuff you can have on your houses, that looks like crazy paving," he said. "It's as bad as the council people who said we'd have to wait for speed bumps till they'd got them in central Bradford, because out here we're supposed to be 'high class'."

webTitle: No outsiders for BBC entertaiment

fields.headline: No outsiders for BBC entertaiment
fields.trailText: 5.15pm The BBC appears to have given up hope of replacing head of light entertainment David Young before he leaves in March, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The BBC appears to have given up hope of replacing its outgoing head of light entertainment, David Young, before he leaves the corporation in March.

Alan Yentob, the director of drama, entertainment and children, told staff today he has appointed a senior BBC producer, Jonathan Glazier, to take over his duties until a permanent successor is found.

Mr Glazier joined the BBC in January from ITV where he had worked on Stars in their Eyes, Blind Date and This Morning.

At the BBC he has produced and directed The Generation Game and will work with Ian Wright on the new series of Friends Like These.

The BBC has approached a number of outside candidates, including Granada's Duncan Gray and Ruth Wrigley, the series producer on Channel 4's Big Brother. Ms Wrigley is seen as the front-runner, but Channel 4 does not want to lose her.

"We are talking to a number of possible candidates to replace David Young," Mr Yentob said in an email to staff today.

One insider said it was unlikely that a replacement would be found before March 8, when Mr Young departs for Hat Trick.

Mr Glazier becomes acting editor, light entertainment, and will take over Mr Young's slate of duties when he leaves.

webTitle: Dispatch from Paris: New man poised to take gay Paree

fields.headline: New man poised to take gay Paree
fields.standfirst: Paris is poised to elect a mayor who will not only be the first socialist in the post in 130 years, but also France's first openly gay politician, writes Jon Henley
fields.trailText: Paris dispatch: Paris is poised to elect a mayor who will not only be the first socialist in the post in 130 years, but also France's first openly gay politician, writes Jon Henley.
fields.body:
With less than six weeks to go before French local elections in March, a political upheaval of cataclysmic proportions seems increasingly on the cards: the socialists look set to win control of the capital for the first time since the bloody uprising of the Paris Commune in 1871.

A leftwing victory would represent a crushing setback for President Jacques Chirac's corruption-tainted RPR party. It has run Paris ever since 1977, which was when the French government decided that the perennially unruly Parisians could once more be trusted to elect an executive city council and mayor.

But it would also mark a wider revolution in French politics: the man who would take over the helm at Paris's palatial and ornate city hall - a mild-mannered but passionate local politician called Bertrand Delanoë - would become the first openly gay man to occupy a high-profile political position in France.

Two separate opinion polls this week showed the right's chances fading in more than half the capital's 20 arrondissements, prompting speculation even in the staid Le Monde that the socialists could no longer lose what is by far the most powerful and prominent post up for grabs in the nationwide local elections.

A socialist victory in Paris would also give a monumental boost to the hopes of Lionel Jospin, the socialist prime minister, in his widely expected challenge to Mr Chirac for the French presidency in 2002. In the words of one analyst, it would be a "political earthquake".

The right's campaign has been dogged since the start by mounting evidence that under the RPR, Paris city hall - where the current president was mayor from 1977 to 1995 - was turned into a vast illicit funding machine for the conservative neo-Gaullist party and its 18-year bid to propel Mr Chirac into the Elyseé palace.

Each fresh allegation of financial corruption and cronyism, some of them implicating Mr Chirac himself, has bolstered Delanoë, whose cleverly chosen campaign slogan - "Pour un changement d'ère" - calls for both "a change of era" and "a change of air".

The polls show the socialists and their green and communist allies gradually spreading their power base from the traditionally working-class arrondissements of north-eastern Paris into the wealthier south-east, and even making inroads into the bourgeois centre and west. Both the 9th and 15th arrondissements, once unassailable conservative strongholds, now appear to be teetering towards the left.

The right's campaign has also been hampered by the deep and bitter division in its ranks between the supporters of the outgoing mayor Jean Tiberi, who is running as an independent after the RPR designated him as scapegoat for the financial scandals, and those of Philippe Séguin, an RPR heavyweight "parachuted" in as the official Gaullist candidate to boost the party's ailing image.

Mr Séguin, a morose man who wears an air of permanent exhaustion, has embarked on a bizarre campaign, choosing to run in the solidly working class 18th arrondissement and deliberately placing himself only in fourth place on the right's list there (the mayor is elected by the city council, made up of councillors from each arondissement).

While he insists that this is because he considers that if he cannot get himself elected as a humble councillor in the 18th, he does not deserve to be mayor, the tactic has driven his supporters close to despair. "If his campaign doesn't take off this week, we've as good as lost the election," one senior member admits.

All of which is excellent news for Mr Delanoë, who has run a determinedly local campaign based on nearly two decades in local politics as a socialist councillor. His big issues for Parisians are mainly about the quality of life and the environment: more green spaces, fewer cars, turning the banks of the upper Seine into protected zones for pedestrians, bicycles and rollerbladers.

He also wants Paris to recover the air of cutting-edge cultural vitality it lost during the Chirac years - when the capital became something of a bourgeois, tourist-oriented museum piece - and he cites London as a prime example of a city with the right mix of economic and artistic life.

He is upfront about his sexuality since coming out on a live television show two years ago, but refuses to make a big deal of it, arguing that he is not a "gay politician", but a politician who happens to be gay.

He hopes, he says, that the people of Paris will be intelligent and open-minded enough to understand the difference. So far he has not been proved wrong.

webTitle: Funding council commits to medium-rated research grants

fields.headline: Funding council commits to medium-rated research grants
fields.standfirst: Special report: The Research Assessment Exercise
fields.trailText: Medium-rated research departments in English universities will definitely receive grants after the next research assessment exercise even though the results are not yet known, funding chiefs announced this week.
fields.body:
Medium-rated research departments in English universities will definitely receive grants after the next research assessment exercise even though the results are not yet known, funding chiefs announced this week.

In an unprecedented step, the Higher Education Funding Council for England has said that departments rated 3a and 3b in the next assessment will receive block grants. It is the first time the council has committed to fund such departments before the results of the assessment are revealed.

Academics are usually kept guessing about the funding decisions, but now the council has decided to adopt a more open approach.

At this weekÍs board meeting, the council says that the level of grants to departments with lower ratings of 3a and 3b - which have some research of national reputation - will be decided after the RAE results are known at the end of the year. The council also reiterated its intention to protect funding for the top-rated departments.

webTitle: 'Help second best too', funders urged

fields.headline: 'Help second best too', funders urged
fields.standfirst: Special report: The Research Assessment Exercise
fields.trailText: Middle-ranking university research departments should retain funding after the next Research Assessment Exercise, the vast majority of academics believe.
fields.body:
Middle-ranking university research departments should retain funding after the next Research Assessment Exercise, the vast majority of academics believe.

Nearly nine out of ten responses to a consultation on future research policies for English universities argued that grants should be allocated to departments judged to have some projects of national standing.

The results of the consultation by the Higher Education Funding Council for England was presented by chief executive Sir Brian Fender yesterday during the council's annual conference, held at the University of Manchester Institute of Science & Technology.

Only 57% of respondents agree with the council's plans to prioritise funds for the highest rated departments in the 2001 assessment. Submissions to the latest assessment are due in by the end of March. But the funding council does not decide final ratings and grants for departments until the end of the exercise. The problem the council faces is that it does not have the resources to support every university research group.

There was, however, near universal support for the RAE from academics responding to the consultation. The assessment, which produces research ratings for departments every four to five years, has been criticised for dominating academic life to such an extent that teaching activities are marginalised.

Sir Brian, who steps down as head of the council in September, told university heads about the council's latest activities, including research and teaching support, efforts to widen access onto university degree courses, the development of the e-university, and a drive to improve equal opportunities among academic staff.

The council is considering whether it needs to rationalise the six separate funding schemes for widening participation currently in operation.

The academic sector needed to develop closer links with the business world, urged Sir Brian..

Another concern he raised was the lack of university research into higher education, one of the proposed topics of the council's £12m pedagogic research programme, being coordinated by the Economic and Social Research Council. "We have not seen strong programmes for research into post-16 education. This is not just a concern for university education departments."

webTitle: 'Macho' Cambridge dons maintain work inequality

fields.headline: 'Macho' Cambridge dons maintain work inequality
fields.standfirst:
Education Unlimited
Read the report
fields.trailText: Cambridge university yesterday accepted a report which identified it as having a "tough macho culture" defined by senior white male academics.
fields.body:
Cambridge university yesterday accepted a report which identified it as having a "tough macho culture" defined by senior white male academics.

In the university's first "equality audit", 23% of the 3,000 staff surveyed said bullying by managers had prevented them from getting ahead in their careers. Two-thirds of female lecturers and 81% of disabled and 74% of ethnic minority staff said they had felt excluded from the culture at some point.

"The culture has been de scribed as 'a tough macho culture' where 'intimidation is by culture rather than by individual persons'," says the report, by consultants Schneider-Ross.

Only 6.25% of Cambridge professors were female, putting it 69th in a league table of 81 universities.

Three-quarters of all those surveyed said equal opportunities at the university had to improve.

But 70% said the university was a good employer.

The university has drawn up an action plan to implement the report's 30 recommendations. A second survey will be carried out in 2003.

webTitle: Watchdog raps C4

fields.headline: Watchdog raps Channel 4
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: Three Channel 4 shows including a John Lennon documentary have been criticised by TV watchdogs, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Channel 4 has been ticked off about three programmes, including a John Lennon documentary that included offensive language.

The Broadcasting Standards Commission upheld complaints against John Lennon documentary Shine On, Buffy spin-off Angel and cult cartoon South Park after 10 viewers lodged protests.

The BSC said the Shine On documentary, shown on September 30 last year, used swearing that "exceeded acceptable boundaries for broadcast".

It ignored Channel 4's protests that the language was used in a "non-aggressive manner".

It also ruled that an episode of Angel shown on September 29 - which showed the lead character being stabbed with hot skewers - broke pre-watershed boundaries.

The BSC also rapped Channel 4's knuckles for failing to edit out references to paedophilia in the programme, which was broadcast at 6pm.

However, the most predictable judgment concerned the non-PC cartoon series South Park.

The BSC said an episode shown on August 11 contained detailed descriptions of necrophilia that went beyond acceptable boundaries for the 9.30pm slot.

Channel 4 claimed South Park was well established and had gained a reputation for being "irreverent, preposterous and, at times, obnoxious".

webTitle: Union will press on with Llanwern bid

fields.headline: Union will press on with Llanwern bid
fields.trailText: Britain's main steel union yesterday vowed to press ahead with a Rover-style consortium to buy the Llanwern steel plant in south Wales from Corus, the Anglo-Dutch group which is expected soon to announce its part closure under a restructuring plan.
fields.body:
Britain's main steel union yesterday vowed to press ahead with a Rover-style consortium to buy the Llanwern steel plant in south Wales from Corus, the Anglo-Dutch group which is expected soon to announce its part closure under a restructuring plan.

Ignoring an initial rebuff from Sir Brian Moffat, Corus chairman and acting chief executive, the ISTC union said it planned to make its bid, which has backing from cabinet ministers and former steel industry executives, once Sir Brian had disclosed his plans.

The cash-rich union refused to give details of the consortium in which it would take a stake but it is understood to mirror the team put together by John Towers, the former Rover chief executive, to buy the bulk of the car group and its main Longbridge plant for a nominal £10 last year.

No cash would change hands because the ISTC-backed consortium would take over all liabilities at Llanwern.

Corus insisted yesterday it had received no formal offer or cash terms from the union. But Mick Leahy, general secretary of the ISTC, told Sir Brian in a letter: "We are formally seeking discussions with you to explore in a cooperative spirit making Corus an offer to take ownership of the plant from you."

Mr Leahy said Sir Brian had rejected the bid because Corus "does not want competition".

The Corus chairman told him: "Additional competition in the present market scene would totally undermine the objective of the proposed restructuring and all the people who will remain employed by us in the UK."

Corus explained that the plan was designed to deal with overcapacity, particularly among the strip products that are Llanwern's output. A takeover of the Welsh plant would simply exacerbate that problem.

webTitle: Scrap BBC Online says Labour MP

fields.headline: Scrap BBC Online says Labour MP
fields.standfirst: Special report: The BBC
fields.trailText:
5pm BBC Online should be scrapped or transformed into an advertising-funded service, a leading Labour MP said today. By Amy Vickers.
Jan 30: BBC admits ad-funded website plan More BBC stories
fields.body:
BBC Online, the public service internet operation of the BBC, should either be scrapped or be transformed into a entirely advertising-funded service, a leading Labour MP said today.

Gerald Kaufman, chairman of the influential culture select committee, said the BBC should no longer be permitted to use licence payers' money on something that is provided by the commercial sector.

The BBC's "third" division after TV and radio has been running since 1997 and has consumed more than £100m of licence-payers money.

BBC Online is widely regarded as one of the best in the world, but Mr Kaufman said he believed the BBC should stick to educational and programme-support services.

The rest, he said, should be hived off into BBC Worldwide, the commercial arm of the corporation.

"I see no reason why the BBC can't have online services although it competes on extremely unfair basis with commercial organisations," said Mr Kaufman.

"And that's why we recommend that online be hived off into worldwide and not funded by the licence fee.

"It's never been clear what the licence fee funds anyway," he added.

At today's hearing on the communications white paper, the British Internet Publishers' Alliance said moving BBC Online into Worldwide would be "disastrous".

BIPA spokesman Hugo Drayton said it would distort the marketplace. He said the BBC Online should cease its commercial activities.

BIPA put forward a number of proposals it thought had been overlooked in the white paper.

It wants the BBC's new service plans be put under the control of Ofcom, which would scrutinise the commercial impact of the BBC's internet activities.

BIPA chairman Rob Hersov voiced his disquiet over the BBC's continuing internet expansion. He said its search for commercial revenues to fund them was crowding out the competition and stifling diversity for consumers.

"BBC Online needs to be scrutinised with a regulatory framework put in place as soon as possible to comment on and steer new BBC internet ventures," said Mr Hersov.

He cited BBCNews.com and another planned BBC commercial venture - a classical music website - as reasons to rein in the BBC.

Derek Wyatt, Labour MP for Sittingbourne and Sheppey, agreed said BBC Online was overstepping its public service remit.

"It might be better all round to just say no to Online for the BBC and put it out of the market altogether," he said.

Even representatives of BIPA thought this was too extreme.

"We're not saying close it down, we're just saying we want it regulated," said Mr Drayton.

What seems more likely is a suggestion put forward by Mr Wyatt that would make the BBC justify what it needs public money for.

"The licence fee would go to Ofcom first, then there would be a discussion of what the BBC should be doing with its money. It seems wrong that they should just take the money without question," he said.

webTitle: Disney Channel loses marketing chief

fields.headline: Disney Channel loses marketing chief
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: Marketing director Thom Noble is quitting after two years with the UK TV channel, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The Disney Channel has parted company with one of its most senior executives.

Director of marketing Thom Noble agreed a severance deal today and is leaving after two years with the broadcaster.

Mr Noble is understood to have been put on gardening leave before Christmas.

He joined the Walt Disney Company's UK TV channel in December 1998 and was previously vice-president of Diageo's Pierre Smirnoff division.

A Disney Channel spokeswoman said Mr Noble had left to pursue his own interests.

However, sources close to the company claim he has been "edged out".

Mr Noble reported directly to Disney Channel managing director Paul Robinson, who joined the company at same time.

Mr Robinson had previously worked at Talk Radio.

The spokeswoman added that Mr Robinson would oversee marketing until a successor was found.

webTitle: Student earners lose out twice

fields.headline: Student earners lose out twice
fields.trailText: A quarter of students doing part-time work while at university are earning below the national minimum wage and their academic work is suffering, MPs were told yesterday.
fields.body:
A quarter of students doing part-time work while at university are earning below the national minimum wage and their academic work is suffering, MPs were told yesterday.

According to a report presented by Professor Claire Callendar from South Bank University, three in five students now take paid work during academic courses, working an average of 11 hours a week. But 40% of those using part-time jobs to finance their studies reported that their academic performance had suffered as a consequence, and 25% were paid below the national minimum wage.

The comments came during the latest hearing of the House of Commons education committeeÕs inquiry into the factors affecting student drop out rates.

The committee heard that as many as two fifths of mature students without A-levels drop out of university courses in engineering, maths, computing and the physical sciences.

A submission to the inquiry from the Higher Education Funding Council for England argues that the main factors influencing student drop out rates before 1997 were A-level grades, age of students and degree subjects. Mature students with no A-levels for example are twice as likely to drop out than average in science and engineering subjects.

The committee heard concerns that the governmentÕs interpretation of loans as extra income for students was completely out of touch with the views of students themselves who see loans as extra debts.

There have been suggestions that the Department for Education and Employment tried to hush up some of the more damaging conclusions of the Professor Callendar's report originally published last month. The DfEE-commissioned study found that student debts had trebled, and nearly nine out of ten students now face financial difficulties. Yet the DfEE summary of the report focused on the extra income available to students.

"Whether it [the DfEE statement] reports the overall findings of the report is open to question," Professor Callendar told the MPs. "My concern is that there is enough evidence that suggests that they [students] view loans as debts."

Professor Callendar said she was "deeply concerned" that the move from grants to loans in the student funding system would deter students from going to university. She complained that there was no research available that looked at the impact of student finances on university access and drop out rates over time. She added that her study suggested strong links between academic achievement, debt and financial hardship.

webTitle: AWOL, SAA, and BUD

fields.headline: AWOL, SAA, and BUD
fields.trailText: GONE WEST
fields.body:
GONE WEST

Taribo West has gone on a 25-mile hike for the Duke of Edinburgh's Gold Award. Taribo West is dressed up in tights and performing in a six-hour mime show. Taribo West is involved in some three-way action with members of Atomic Kitten. Any, all, and indeed none of these statements could be true. Because, this afternoon, Derby's Nigerian international defender is more lost than Kelly Brook in a production of King Lear.

Taribo failed to return to England after Nigeria's World Cup qualifier against the Sudan last weekend, missing Derby's 2-1 Premiership defeat at Charlton last night. "I can't say for sure but I hear he's on his way back," Taribo's agent Ian Anderson insisted this afternoon. "To be honest, we're all in the dark together," he went on, cupping his hand over his mouth like a spy. "I haven't spoken to Taribo personally. But I am fairly certain he will be with the club tomorrow."

That's "fairly" reassuring. Particularly when Taribo's teammates N****wo Kanu and Celestine Babayoro, who both played in the Sudan game, made it back to England a couple of days ago. Derby boss Jim Smith remains laconic about his absent preacher-cum-sweeper, however. "I don't know which church Taribo's in," said the god-fearing boss. "We'll have to wait and see what happened with Taribo, what the explanations are. He's got a mobile phone but it's switched off." Aren't they just always?

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

STAN UP

The Fiver was ready to let go. It really was. But can any self-respecting voyeur walk on by when they see the beaten-up wreck of Stanley Victor Collymore's career twitching in the gutter? Of course they can't. Which is why the Fiver was first on hand today to help Stan's career to its feet, dust it down and bundle it off in the direction of Real Oviedo, the Spanish club who have finally signed Stan on a free transfer.

"The Spanish league is a big league with big teams and some of the best players in the world," a wide-eyed Stan told reporters in Madrid. "Oviedo are a good club, with a new stadium, and young players. I can score goals and do very well there." Collymore's sentiments were shared by his new coach, Raddy Antic, who has signed him on an 18-month contract. "He may have had his problems in the past," he chirped in a style reminiscent of more than one manager in the past, "but I am confident he will recapture his enthusiasm for the game here in Spain".

The Fiver only wishes it could share Antic's optimism. Because no sooner had Collymore got on a plane to Oviedo than it was forced to return to Madrid because of turbulence. Surely a sign? Not according to the club, who are expecting him to arrive by car later today for a medical before meeting the press at 7pm tonight. But the Fiver is not convinced - which is why the Fiver has got the number for the Spanish AA right in front of us.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTES OF THE DAY

"We would not want to have the same protection for sportsman as we do have for presidents, but it is a difficult one. We may have to camouflage coaches and camouflage cars so that people have no idea who is in them, but I believe that would be a sad reflection on how bad things have got" - Gordon Taylor, "head" of the PFA, responds in all seriousness to Beckhamhavinghiscarrockedgate. And hang on, there's more

"They're living in a goldfish bowl at the minute and I think it has already been said that they attract as much interest as Princess Diana did" - Please spare us Mr Taylor, we're welling up.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

WHAT'S IN A NAME?

The way things are going, the poor old members of the Premier League will soon be on their uppers. Because no matter how hard they try, they just can't find anyone to give them loads of money for old rope. The other week, current sponsors Carling pulled out of the running to put their name to next year's Premiership, and now Budweiser - who had been hotly tipped by highly-paid media analysts to replace them - have said they're not going to bother either. Why does nobody apart from Manchester United want to be associated with this exciting product?

Amid cries of "cripes, we're off!" and "come back you pesky capitalists!", the marketing director of Anheuser-Busch - who make everybody's favourite bile-inducing beverage - today announced his company's withdrawal. "Budweiser is committed to supporting football on a global scale," said Kerry Bebe. "Contrary to rumours and speculation, we were not involved in the final bidding process for the Premier League sponsorship."

Premiership chairmen need not drown their sorrows in filthy lager-flavoured chemicals quite yet, however. Bass - the makers of Carling - are seemingly prepared to re-enter the fray now that Bud have buggered off and taken their "delicious" product with them. And Pepsi - the makers of Pepsi - are rumoured to be waiting in the wings with an offer. Which will ensure the presence of Coca-Cola in the bidding war, say highly-respected media experts. The Panda Pops Premiership it is, then.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Liverpool scouts are watching Sedan's 29-year-old left-midfielder Olivier Quint, according to the French press.

Derby are tracking Las Palmas midfielder Thordur Gudjonsson.

Newcastle have resurrected their interest in the young Salamanca forward Ariza Makukula.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Fabien Barthez has admitted he tried to con Paolo Di Canio out of scoring the goal that knocked Manchester United out of the FA Cup. "I wanted to fool Di Canio. I knew he was on-side. I had seen that the linesman had not put his flag up," Barthez told French TV. "If he had just taken his eye off the ball for one second, I would have grabbed it. But he didn't fall for it and we are out."

Steve Froggatt has admitted he could be forced to retire. The Coventry winger has undergone surgery to rebuild his left ankle but conceded: "I have not given up all hope but this is actually threatening my career, there is no doubt about that."

Wolves have completed the signing of Sunderland defender Paul Butler for a £1m.

Ian Rush has joined Barnsley's backroom staff as the strikers coach.

Blackpool's new 15,000 stadium has finally received the go-ahead and preparatory work will start in the next few days.

Several top Italian football players have been linked to an investigation into a high-class prostitution ring operating on the internet, Milan police said today. Taribo failed to return to England after Nigeria's World Cup qualifier against the Sudan last weekend, missing Derby's 2-1 Premiership defeat at Charlton last night. "I can't say for sure but I hear he's on his way back," Taribo's agent Ian Anderson insisted this afternoon. webTitle: Interview: My life behind bars

fields.headline: Interview: My life behind bars
fields.trailText:
Sharon Corzon, 26
Sentence: five years
Crime: GBH
fields.body:
Sharon Corzon, 26
Sentence: five years
Crime: GBH

This was my first sentence and I got the maximum you could get for GBH because I'm black and the girl I attacked was white. That's what I think. The three prisons I've been in have all been prejudiced against black people.

White girls can be so rude to the officers - they can swear at them, they can be really insulting and give the officer no respect, and they can get away with it. But if you just say "no" and you're black, you're in trouble.

As a black person you have to hold back. You have to pretend. You have to creep. You have to keep quiet. You have to be so humble and stupid to survive as a black person in prison, and that's just not me. That's not my personality. I wasn't going to pretend to be something I wasn't.

It's the officers rather than the inmates who are racist. Black officers are few and far between. In Holloway there are more because it's in London, but the sad thing is that because they're in the minority they don't speak out against the racism. In fact, I've found they are more prejudiced against the black people.

Racism is institutionalised. Who can you complain to? You can't complain to the officer that's being horrible to someone. She'll just make your life hell. You can't complain to the governor because it's his job to back up the officer. You can't complain to the board because it's their job to back up the governor. You're fucked.

I took my prison to court because they were trying to take my baby away from me. After about five months being pregnant in the mother and baby unit, I was told I wasn't allowed to keep my baby because they thought I would endanger other mothers because of my temper. It was insulting and they were proved wrong because I won my court case and was allowed to keep my baby. I was sure that was racist as well because the board saw three pregnant black girls in the same week as me and they all got refused permission to keep their babies.

The threat of having my baby taken away was always hanging over me from then on. It was always: "If you do that again, you have to hand your child over." Meanwhile, white girls were fighting left, right and centre, and it was ignored. A lot of the black girls just let it go because they want to get their parole and go home early. It shouldn't be like that.

Andrew Evans, 45
Sentence: life (overturned)
Crime: murder (wrongly convicted)

A part of me had to die to survive in prison. When you first come in you see somebody being beaten up and the instinct is to help. In prison you realise you can't. Your normal social awareness has to be disposed of. You have to let the horrors of prison wash over you, or you go insane. It's a psychological and emotional bludgeoning that goes on every day. You hear the screams at night when you first go into prison and it terrifies you because you think: "What the hell's going on?" After a while you realise that it's people cracking up because they can't take it any more.

Occasionally the guards will be fed up with someone or will have had a bad day with the wife and want to take it out on someone. That's the way they are.

Whatever crime somebody commits isn't the problem. That's the symptom. Until society gets to grip with that there will never be a reduction in crime. The problem is why they commit the crime in the first place. People say, "Oh, it's because they're short of money." That's one reason. But the reason they are short of money is because they can't fit into what everyone considers normal society. So the only way for them to cope is to opt out of the system - into this other system called crime.

What society needs to start thinking about is how to stop all these people opting out. They come into prison after going to the boys' home, the girls' home, the foster home; they've been abused and maltreated from the day they were born. It's like a cycle - they have kids and their kids start coming in. And for the people there now there is no rehabilitation. The only thing prison does is remove the problem from society for a while - and then place it back in society worse than it was before.

There is some education in prison and it does benefit some people. But what the hell are people supposed to do when they get out? They can't get a job. It's hard enough getting a decent job without a record, let alone with.

webTitle: Interviews: Prisoners on their life in jail

fields.headline: Interviews: Prisoners on their life in jail
fields.trailText:
Duncan Williams, 36
Time served: six months on remand
Crime: arson and criminal damage (acquitted)
fields.body:
Duncan Williams, 36
Time served: six months on remand
Crime: arson and criminal damage (acquitted)

On arriving at HMP Wandsworth the first thing that strikes you is the dark and doom- ridden architecture. Then comes the oversized, tattered clothing. That gives the prison officers in the "reception area" a reason to yell at you to: "Tuck your fucking shirt in, fella, you look like a sack of fucking horse shit!"

The constant bullying from officers creates contempt, defiance and hatred. It is wrong to suggest that every prison officer is an uncaring, unintelligent sadist; there are many men and women working hard to do a difficult job as best they can. But thanks to underfunding, overcrowding, understaffing, poor training and old-school attitudes, there are far too few of them. By the time the majority of men are ready for release from Wandsworth they are - if they weren't before - bitter, hate-ridden individuals with little in the way of a future. Many are back within months of release.

While I was there, most of us were not engaged in any constructive activity during the day. We spent 23 hours out of 24 hours locked in a tiny 8x12ft cell, two sharing. It was mind-numbing.

I made at least three applications for educational courses within the first few days of arriving and never heard a reply. The nearest I came to education was when a group of 20 or more inmates were herded into a small holding room and issued with scraps of paper that we were told were an "educational standard" test. The pages had been photocopied so many times that the typeface was barely readable. Most people didn't care. They were grateful to get out of the cell for a few minutes.

I used to read letters out to one man who was illiterate. He never got any assistance to learn to read and write throughout his stay. He was only in for three months for some drunken crime, but surely some better use could have been made of his time there?

Drugs and addiction are the evil behind most crimes and the abuse does not stop inside. Heroin has replaced cannabis as the drug of choice because it stays in the system for less time, so it's harder to trace. Despite claims to the contrary, Wandsworth is awash with drugs. I remember sitting in a cell with one poor soul who had attempted to smuggle a large quantity of narcotics into the prison by secreting a stash up his backside; unfortunately, the condom he had packed the stash into burst. He fell into a deep coma and had to be rushed to hospital.

Suicide is also rife in prison. Six men were found dead in Wandsworth by midsummer of 2000. In July, I was moved into a cell where a Spanish inmate had attempted suicide the night before. The cellmate told me the man had been beaten by someone and was in a state of total fear. He woke to find the man choking on a noose tied to a metal hinge. He pulled the man down in the nick of time and he was rushed to hospital. In this instance the police were called, but no charges were brought and no statements made.

I left Wandsworth in December with nothing but a plastic sack, uncomfortable memories and the clothes on my back. I'd lost my flat, my job and my self-respect.

webTitle: Quake survivors found, 12,000 bodies recovered

fields.headline: Quake survivors found, 12,000 bodies recovered
fields.standfirst: Special report: Natural disasters
fields.trailText: More survivors were today pulled from underneath the rubble of the Indian earthquake, as the Gujarat state government confirmed that 12,000 bodies had now been recovered and the eventual death toll was likely to reach 25,000.
fields.body:
More survivors were today pulled from underneath the rubble of the Indian earthquake, as the Gujarat state government confirmed that 12,000 bodies had now been recovered and the eventual death toll was likely to reach 25,000.

The estimate - much lower than an earlier announcement by the Indian defence minister of a potential 100,000 fatalities - is based on the number of bodies covered, those reported missing, an approximate number still lying under debris and other reports gathered by government agencies.

Haren Pandya, home minister of Gujurat, said: "The figure I am giving you today is closest to the truth". The statement was made an hour after the state's emergency control room had said 7,162 corpses had been recovered.

The statistics emerged after rescue teams managed to pull more survivors out alive, as bulldozers and explosives experts began clearing away the rubble.

22-year-old Kuntal Thakkar was rescued in the town of Bhachau after a Russian rescue team heard her screaming when a bulldozer smashed down a wall in her three-storey apartment building. They also found her husband alive, five days after the earthquake struck.

In Bhuj, close to the epicentre of earthquake, an army team rescued a 12-year-old girl named Viyanka and rushed her to hospital.

A demolition team breaking up an Ahmedabad apartment block found 55-year-old Joytosna Gandhi still alive. She was discovered, in critical condition with kidney trouble, next to the body of her teenage son. Both her legs and one hand had been crushed by concrete beams and had to be amputated, doctors said.

"I don't know how she stayed alive with her dead son next to her," said neighbour Promila Ranadive.

As earthquake efforts switch from rescue to relief, India faces increased need for food, clothing and shelter for survivors. The number left homeless in the state of Gujurat, hit hardest by the quake, was estimated at 200,000 by the United Nations.

Countries and groups sent aid as foreign rescue teams made their final rounds with trained dogs and seismographs. A UN World Food Program flight left for India yesterday with 41 tons of much-needed cargo, including health kits and power generators.

Pakistan, India's traditional adversary, is due to send a second plane-ful of aid tomorrow, loaded with tents and blankets. The Red Cross is mounting an international field hospital operation in Bhuj, with 310 beds and capacity for 2,000 walk-in patients a day.

Kenzo Oshima, UN undersecretary-general for humanitarian affairs, yesterday confirmed that a UN disaster assessment team was working with the Indian government to coordinate international assistance teams.

Aftershocks continued to rock India early today, bringing fears that more buildings could topple. The strongest of three tremors was recorded at 4.5 on the Richter scale by India's meteorological department. No further injuries were reported.

Total damage from the earthquake has been estimated at up to $5.5bn [£3.8bn].

Pakistan, India's traditional adversary, is due to send a second plane-ful of aid tomorrow, loaded with tents and blankets. The Red Cross is mounting an international field hospital operation in Bhuj, with 310 beds and capacity for 2,000 walk-in patients a day. Kenzo Oshima, UN undersecretary-general for humanitarian affairs, yesterday confirmed that a UN disaster assessment team was working with the Indian government to coordinate international assistance teams. Aftershocks continued to rock India early today, bringing fears that more buildings could topple. The strongest of three tremors was recorded at 4.5 on the Richter scale by India's meteorological department. No further injuries were reported. Total damage from the earthquake has been estimated at up to $5.5bn [£3.8bn]. webTitle: John Brown bags AA contract

fields.headline: John Brown bags £5m AA magazine contract
fields.trailText: 5pm: John Brown Publishing is to publish the Automobile Association's bi-monthly title, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
John Brown Publishing has snapped up the contract to publish the Automobile Association's bi-monthly magazine, estimated to be worth £5m.

The AA terminated its contract with previous publisher Redwood after opening the contract to tender.

Redwood gave the magazine a facelift towards the end of last year but this was not enough to prevent John Brown winning the contract.

The AA magazine is the UK's highest-circulation contract title.

It has an ABC certified circulation of more than 4.3m.

The AA win follows a major coup last year, when John Brown Publishing's contract division swiped a lucrative contract to publish 24 magazines for WH Smith.

webTitle: Welsh police to pay out damages after assault

fields.headline: Welsh police to pay out damages after assault
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: A black father of two yesterday won damages against police who racially abused and assaulted him as they arrested him after a fight six years ago.
fields.body:
A black father of two yesterday won damages against police who racially abused and assaulted him as they arrested him after a fight six years ago.

Darren Hoole, 24, a former steelworker, sued South Wales police after an officer grabbed him, saying: "I'm going to rip your throat out, you black bastard." He was punched and injured by blows to his back.

Yesterday Judge Graham Jones ruled that a sergeant, Leighton Rogers, and a constable, Mike Kersey, used unlawful force while taking Mr Hoole to the station. Terence Williams, a custody officer, and other officers also hit him.

Mr Hoole was arrested during a gang fight in Neath in May 1995 and jailed for nine months for causing an affray. He may now appeal against conviction.

The judge ruled yesterday that Mr Hoole had been unlawfully denied his legal rights. Police officers lied in their evidence about an injury to his neck. But allegations of assault and racist behaviour in an earlier incident were not proved. Mr Hoole was found to have spat at officers and called them "bastards" and "pigs".

The damages will be decided at later court hearing.
