webTitle: Met says it's sorry for harassing black activist

fields.headline: Met says it's sorry for harassing black activist
fields.standfirst: Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: A Metropolitan police officer yesterday apologised to a black activist who was the victim of serial harassment by officers in Haringey, north London.
fields.body:
A Metropolitan police officer yesterday apologised to a black activist who was the victim of serial harassment by officers in Haringey, north London.

The Met's assistant commissioner, Michael Todd, told Delroy Lindo he was "truly sorry" for what he and his family had been subjected to and acknowledged that the force had "not got everything right".

Mr Lindo, 41, was stopped 37 times by police over an eight-year period and was the victim of three unlawful arrests. A report into Mr Lindo's complaints by a deputy assistant commissioner, Tarique Ghaffur, concluded he had been the the victim of harassment as a result of racial stereotyping.

The inquiry found that the collective failures of the Met had put the force at serious risk of undermining the confidence of minority ethnic communities in Haringey.

Mr Todd also apologised to Mr Lindo for including his address in the report which was published on the internet on Monday night.

He said the Met had been reluctant to release the report and put it on the internet in haste when it was realised it was likely to be published elsewhere.

But Mr Lindo will have to wait for a public apology from the deputy commissioner, Ian Blair. The report recommended that he should receive one but Mr Todd said: "He will decide when and how and in what venue an apology should be given."

Responding to an emotional challenge from Mr Lindo during a Metropolitan Police Association press briefing, Mr Todd said Scotland Yard had launched an inquiry into leaks that have occurred since the inquiry team delivered their findings in November.

Of particular concern to Mr Lindo was how a comment - apparently made at a private meeting - that he was seeking £1m in damages had been leaked to the press.

Challenged by reporters on why no officers were facing disciplinary action over the three unlawful arrests, Mr Todd said the police were still waiting for reports from the police complaints authority.

The report has provoked a backlash within the Met. Officers who came into contact with Mr Lindo feel harshly treated as they were not interviewed by the inquiry team.

Mr Todd said he accepted that officers had not been given an opportunity to put their view to the inquiry, but this was because it had been compiled in a "groundbreaking style" which had examined organisational procedures based on written reports.

The MPA chairman, Toby Harris, said the group had asked the Met to submit an action plan addressing the report's recommendations.

"We need to be open about what has gone on, and it is now important that the MPA works with the Met, the Lindo family and the community to ensure that the recommendations are implemented as speedily as possible," he said.

"Too many people have been waiting too long to see progress in this particular case, and there are major issues highlighted by the report that need to be urgently addressed."

webTitle: Stone's basic instincts scare off Cronenberg

fields.headline: Stone's basic instincts scare off Cronenberg
fields.trailText: The director of The Fly has reportedly walked out on the sequel to Basic Instinct after furious rows with Sharon Stone
fields.body:
The beleaguered sequel to Basic Instinct has suffered yet another setback this week with the departure of the latest director attached to the project David Cronenberg after furious rows with leading lady Sharon Stone.

According to entertainment site People News, filming on the follow-up to the 1992 thriller was due to start in New York next month but a source close to the film claimed the 41-year-old actress had been up to her old tricks again. "Sharon has proved mightily difficult to deal with. The film has had huge problems getting under way."

Cronenberg, whose directing credits include Crash and The Fly, apparently quit the £50m project because of "vicious fights" with the difficult actress. Film industry experts believe both Stone and Cronenberg could be preparing to sue producers Mario Kassar and Andrew Vajna for the debacle

The latest setback comes just weeks after MGM seemed on the point of abandoning the project due to alleged difficulties finding a male lead prepared to star alongside Stone. Original co-star Michael Douglas flatly refused to reprise his role as detective Nick Curran, while Robert Downey Jr also declined. According to the latest rumours however, Kurt Russell has stepped into the breach for $5m (£3.42m).

Stone's spokesman has denied that the temperamental actress, who is being paid a reported £10m to reprise the character of Catherine Tramell, is ready to walk away from the project as well. "Sharon is still excited and committed to making the movie," he claimed.

webTitle: Taribo is out of Africa

fields.headline: Taribo is out of Africa
fields.trailText: The agent of Derby defender Taribo West has insisted that his missing client is on his way back to Pride Park, after the big defender went absent without leave for the club's match at Charlton last night.
fields.body:
The agent of Derby defender Taribo West has insisted that his missing client is on his way back to Pride Park, after the big defender went absent without leave for the club's match at Charlton last night.

West had been on international duty at the weekend, playing in Nigeria's 3-0 World Cup qualifying victory over Sudan. But he failed to join his club team-mates on Monday night, ahead of the Premiership clash which Derby lost 2-1.

"I can't say for sure but I hear that Taribo is on his way back," said agent Ian Anderson.

"I don't know why he was not here yesterday but it is notoriously difficult getting in and out of Africa. To be honest, we're all in the dark together."

As Arsenal striker Kanu (who also played in Nigeria's match) made it back in time for his club's 2-0 victory over Bradford yesterday and Chelsea's Celestine Babayaro also returned to his club as scheduled it would seem West has some explaining to do.

West, who initially signed from AC Milan for a three-month loan period, was said last week to have agreed a contract to remain at the club until the end of the season. However, that contract is yet to be signed and awaits him on his arrival back in the country.

Since West joined the club earlier this season telling supporters that it was God's will that he helps them, the club has climbed out of the relegation places after a desperate start to the season, although fans are attributing this more to the arrival of Colin Todd as Smith's assistant.

Last night Smith said: "I don't know which church he's in. He's got a mobile phone but it's switched off."

webTitle: Interview: My life behind bars

fields.headline: Interview: My life behind bars
fields.trailText:
Jay Bharat, 22
Sentence: three months
Crime: theft
fields.body:
Jay Bharat, 22
Sentence: three months
Crime: theft

I was sentenced to three months and spent my time in two young offenders institutes, Hindley and Thorncross. It wasn't the best experience, but obviously I did learn from it.

At the time of being sentenced I was at university and I was quite lucky because they decided to keep me on. If they had thrown me out then I would have been in trouble and it would have achieved nothing because obviously, with a criminal record, I wouldn't have been employable. The head of my department was very supportive and sent me details of the weekly tutorials to keep me up to date. Without that, I know that I would have just started a life of crime when I came out.

When I left prison I was still very worried about my employment prospects and having a criminal record. I spoke to my probation officer about it and she advised me to just be honest when asked. I've had quite a few temporary jobs in retail, and a lot of the time they don't ask, but there were places which found out and didn't want me to stay.

There was one shop where they offered me a permanent position which I accepted, but when they found out about my record they withdrew it, saying it was because of unsatisfactory references from previous employers. They had to say that because it's against the law to discriminate because of a criminal record. I knew the real reason and sought legal advice but didn't pursue it. With the graduate positions that I'm looking at now, a lot of them don't ask. But if they did, I reckon I'd have to be honest.

I tried to keep myself to myself when I was inside, so I didn't experience much racism. When I arrived on the first day there were some people having a go, but I just tried to ignore it.

In Thorncross, some of the other Asian lads had got into a lot of trouble because of racist attitudes from other inmates, but basically it wasn't dealt with as racism because it always resulted in a lot of fighting. People would attack the Asians, they would have to fight to defend themselves, and then it was the Asians who were given extra days on their sentence and sent to the block as punishment.

There's not really anyone you can turn to about that sort of thing, and if you do start to report racism because of the mentality in prison you're just seen as a grass.

webTitle: Prisoners on their life in jail

fields.headline: Interviews: Prisoners on their life in jail
fields.trailText:
Grace Hall, 40
Sentence: life
Crime: murder
fields.body:
Grace Hall, 40
Sentence: life
Crime: murder

I was 21 when I got convicted in 1982. It was my first sentence. I served 18 years and saw a lot of changes in that time. When I got my sentence there wasn't much help available; they just put you in jail. I'd been in six months when I stumbled across Alcoholics Anonymous. They were holding meetings in the chapel. My friend, Patsy, and I had gone to look for communion wine but we heard voices from the meeting and ended up joining in. Nobody had recommended I go, it wasn't set up that way in those days. Prison was about containment, especially for the lifers like me. It wasn't until I reached about eight or 10 years into my sentence that they started rehabilitating us.

Patsy was a short-termer and when she finished her sentence she went out and died of a drug overdose. So many die like that.

It was ridiculous that nobody tried to give me treatment for my addictions. My crime was alcohol- and drug-related because I killed my ex-boyfriend when I was totally high. I kept up my drug habit inside for 11 years. Drugs were easier than booze to get hold of. Towards the end of my sentence I started on heroin because it was harder to pick up in the mandatory drugs test, which really upped the number of heroin users in the system. The figures say drug use has gone down. The reality is smack use has gone up.

But what's disturbing is that, in some prisons, the governor wants to prove she's got a drug-free prison so the prison officers just don't test people. My friend and I once set up an experiment. We told a prison officer about eight people who'd been using heroin that evening and they busted one of them. That's typical. It's their way of fiddling the figures so they look drug-free.

More prison courses and treatments started in the late 80s and early 90s, so now there are more options available. But there's still problems. For a start, there aren't enough courses because mostly the officers are running these things and they are needed for discipline.

Towards the end of my sentence I became a born-again Christian. An ex-lifer came in, she had a job with a Christian organisation and used to come in and talk to me. Then one day, I totally stopped my drinking and drugs and I haven't had anything for nearly eight years.

The religion helped me more than prison, but prison gave me an environment where I was kept safe until I could find a way to stop. If I'd been on the street I would have been dead before I found a way to stop, like my friends. Prison saved my life until I was able to get straight enough to find a way.

webTitle: Appalling conditions in 'failing' jail laid bare

fields.headline: Appalling conditions in 'failing' jail laid bare
fields.standfirst: Snap inspection condemns Brixton jail as filthy and dangerous
fields.trailText: The full extent of the appalling conditions inside Britain's first "failing" jail is revealed in a report published today by the chief inspector of prisons
fields.body:
The full extent of the appalling conditions inside Britain's first "failing" jail is revealed in a report published today by the chief inspector of prisons.

Sir David Ramsbotham says that far from making progress, standards at Brixton prison, south London, have deteriorated since his previous inspection, and included practices that were "totally unacceptable in any jail".

He says his inspection team found that the facilities for patients in the jail's healthcare centre were "without doubt the worst that we have seen anywhere in England and Wales".

The snap inspection was carried out last June, eight months after the prisons minister, Paul Boateng, had named Brixton as the first failing prison in the country. It was given a year to improve or face the threat of privatisation.

Sir David agrees that it is a failing prison but says it has been failed by everyone in the prison service - from the ministers and the prisons board who had failed to provide the necessary resources to the "too many poorly performing staff at Brixton who are failing to pull their weight in regard to their duties, or to do a day's work for a day's pay".

The management had simply allowed officers to get away with being lazy, dangerous and irresponsible.

He says that unlike every other local prison in England and Wales, at the time of his inspection Brixton had no workshops, no educational facilities which were worthy of the name, no gymnasium available to the vast majority of prisoners.

"In short," says the report, "there is virtually nothing with which to occupy prisoners in purposeful activity."

The director general of the prison service, Martin Nearey, last night acknowledged there were fundamental problems with the management of the prison, which holds up to 800 inmates.

The jail now has a new governor, its fourth in four years, and bids will be invited next month from reluctant private prison companies to take over the jail.

Brixton is already under investigation by the commission for racial equality for being "institutionally racist" but some of the findings by the chief inspector will cause even greater concern about what has been going on inside the prison.

These findings include:

 The system by which inmates contact staff in an emergency had been sabotaged by staff on more than one wing - this betrayed "a disgraceful attitude by staff towards those in their care". The excuse that the alarms were "too loud" was wholly unacceptable, he said.

 Standards in the healthcare centre were "nothing short of scandalous" - "filth and neglect there showed a breakdown in the chain of command".

 Meals were prepared in a kitchen which had been condemned by the environmental health authorities.

 An unofficial and unlawful "reflections" system of punishing prisoners was used by staff under which inmates were locked in their cells so they could "reflect" on their misdemeanours. The inspectors wondered how long this had gone on unnoticed or condoned by managers.

 Staff on suicide watch in the healthcare centre were falsifying their entries on monitoring sheets. At 2.45pm the inspection team found observations already entered for 4pm - "a despicable practice, displaying both a lack of care and worrying certainty that no manager would check the malpractice".

 Medicines were dispensed without signed prescriptions to inmates who had not been properly identified - condemned by the report as "highly dangerous and illegal".

Sir David says the inspectors were told that part of the difficulty was the shortage of staff but, although 10 of the 36 officers on A wing were on sick leave, the group still owed 140 hours to the prison in time for which they had been paid but had not worked.

Mr Narey said it had been announced in July, after Sir David's snap inspection, that Brixton would be market tested and in the meantime it had a new management team specifically appointed to quicken the pace of improvement. "There is a great deal more work to be done at Brixton," he said.

"I was as concerned as Sir David about the conditions in the healthcare centre and I have personally monitored performance in this area."

The new governor, Stephen Twinn, said yesterday there was now an education activities centre at the prison and, of the 86 recommendations in the chief inspector's report, work to tackle some 20% of them had already been implemented.

The healthcare centre is to undergo a refurbishment in April.

The director general of the prison service, Martin Nearey, last night acknowledged there were fundamental problems with the management of the prison, which holds up to 800 inmates. The jail now has a new governor, its fourth in four years, and bids will be invited next month from reluctant private prison companies to take over the jail. Brixton is already under investigation by the commission for racial equality for being "institutionally racist" but some of the findings by the chief inspector will cause even greater concern about what has been going on inside the prison. These findings include:  The system by which inmates contact staff in an emergency had been sabotaged by staff on more than one wing - this betrayed "a disgraceful attitude by staff towards those in their care". The excuse that the alarms were "too loud" was wholly unacceptable, he said.  Standards in the healthcare centre were "nothing short of scandalous" - "filth and neglect there showed a breakdown in the chain of command".  Meals were prepared in a kitchen which had been condemned by the environmental health authorities.  An unofficial and unlawful "reflections" system of punishing prisoners was used by staff under which inmates were locked in their cells so they could "reflect" on their misdemeanours. The inspectors wondered how long this had gone on unnoticed or condoned by managers.  Staff on suicide watch in the healthcare centre were falsifying their entries on monitoring sheets. At 2.45pm the inspection team found observations already entered for 4pm - "a despicable practice, displaying both a lack of care and worrying certainty that no manager would check the malpractice".  Medicines were dispensed without signed prescriptions to inmates who had not been properly identified - condemned by the report as "highly dangerous and illegal". Sir David says the inspectors were told that part of the difficulty was the shortage of staff but, although 10 of the 36 officers on A wing were on sick leave, the group still owed 140 hours to the prison in time for which they had been paid but had not worked. Mr Narey said it had been announced in July, after Sir David's snap inspection, that Brixton would be market tested and in the meantime it had a new management team specifically appointed to quicken the pace of improvement. "There is a great deal more work to be done at Brixton," he said. "I was as concerned as Sir David about the conditions in the healthcare centre and I have personally monitored performance in this area." The new governor, Stephen Twinn, said yesterday there was now an education activities centre at the prison and, of the 86 recommendations in the chief inspector's report, work to tackle some 20% of them had already been implemented. The healthcare centre is to undergo a refurbishment in April.

webTitle: Ad revenue slump hits AOL Time Warner

fields.headline: Ad revenue slump hits AOL Time Warner
fields.trailText: AOL Time Warner has become the latest company to fall victim to the worldwide slump in advertising revenue growth, writes Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
AOL Time Warner has become the latest media company to fall victim to the worldwide slump in advertising revenue growth.

The world's largest media group grabbed the headlines last year when US internet firm AOL and Time Warner merged in a £68bn blockbuster deal, but its maiden results have seen the company get off to a shaky start.

AOL Time Warner said fourth quarter losses had widened by a staggering 80% to £740m, although revenues increased by 8% to £6.9bn.

It blamed the deficit on slowing advertising growth and falling earnings at its music and cable divisions, although the group also lost £360m on share investments.

Gerard Levin, chief executive of AOL Time Warner, said the business would benefit from the cross-promotional opportunities created by the merger.

"By bringing the power of the internet together with the world's most potent and trusted information and entertainment brands, we have created a one-of-a-kind company positioned for sustainable high growth," he said.

To underline his point, Mr Levin unveiled a new promotional service that will allow web users to download songs by Warner Music artists from the AOL service.

AOL Time Warner has also signed up three big advertisers - Nortel Networks, Cendent and Compaq Computer - to buy advertising space in both its online and offline operations.

Analysts and investors will be looking for similar initiatives over the next few months in order to restore their faith in the merger and buck the current advertising trend.

But the harsh climate in the advertising market is set to worsen, with the US economy heading towards a full-blown recession some advertisers already exercising cancellation options.

webTitle: Blair appoints e-envoy

fields.headline: Blair appoints e-envoy
fields.trailText: Tony Blair today officially appointed Andrew Pinder - a former IT director at the Inland Revenue - as e-envoy, giving him four years to ensure universal access to the internet and to put all government services online.
fields.body:
Tony Blair today officially appointed Andrew Pinder - a former IT director at the Inland Revenue - as e-envoy, giving him four years to ensure universal access to the internet and to put all government services online.

Mr Pinder said he will be dealing with "an industrial revolution in the civil service and the wider economy" as the UK tries to establish itself as an internet heavyweight.

A former civil servant, Mr Pinder first took over as temporary e-envoy when Alex Allan resigned from the post in October, citing personal reasons. Like Mr Allan before him, Mr Pinder will concentrate on moving the government itself into the internet age.

He said: "We want to be customer focused. It's not just about putting a form online, it's about changing the business practices that lie behind that form."

He admits that the transformation is still in the early stages, but defended the government's record up to now. On Friday the Cabinet office launched a secure online transaction system, Government Gateway, a project that he pointed out had come in on time and under budget. The gateway will form the basis for future online transactions between businesses, members of the public and government.

Mr Pinder spent 18 years in the Inland Revenue, becoming the director of IT, before moving to the private sector as the director of operations and technology at Prudential Corporation. He also worked as the European head of operations and technology at Citibank investment bank.

Since 1999, he has been a partner in both an internet startup, Willregister.com, and a small venture capital firm.

His experience within the turbulent internet startup culture has made him sensitive to the needs of small businesses, he said, and he hopes to make it easier for small companies to communicate with government.

He also hopes that the civil service will be able to learn from the internet economy. "We will see some slow changes in the civil service. It will take a long time, but then to turn around a big company like IBM or Ford takes a long time.

"This week we had permanent secretaries coming to listen to Michael Dell speak about his experiences. So there is a willingness to change within the civil service," Mr Pinder added.

Welcoming Mr Pinder's decision to take on the job fulltime, Mr Blair said: "We are determined to meet the goals of our UK Online campaign, putting this country at the forefront of the knowledge economy. Andrew can play a leading role in achieving that."

webTitle: Children with imprisoned parents

fields.headline: Visiting mum in prison
fields.standfirst: How do children cope when a parent is sent to jail?  Maggie O'Kane travels to Low Newton prison with the daughter of one inmate
fields.trailText: How do children cope when a parent is sent to jail? Maggie O'Kane travels to Low Newton prison with the daughter of one inmate
fields.body:
Lisa Peel was supposed to be smacked up, but she has been clean for a while - been through the "rattle". There can't be many worse places to go through the rattle than a housing estate outside Middlesbrough. High-gloss pink kitchen walls; cold turkey in the afternoon in the corner of the sitting room where Lovejoy leaps about the screen with Joanna Lumley.

Outside, the atmosphere on the estate is heavy with heroin. It's in the agitated gait of the young men hurrying by as if they are going to miss the last train to somewhere important. It's in the rigid, heads-down march of two women across the road hoping that if they push their prams fast enough their kids won't be infected.

Ms Peel's life of addiction, abuse and confusion may have nothing to do with her mother's life spent in and out of prison. She certainly doesn't blame her mother, although she does wish she had been around more. "The first time my mum went into prison I was two and a half. I remember going to see her with my dad. He told me that she was in hospital but I kept asking where the bed was. Then, after the visit, she went back through a door to the cells and they said 'kids aren't allowed in there'."

This year, around 44,000 children will lose their mother, or father, to Her Majesty's prisons. Ms Peel's mother, Julie Miller, has already served six sentences for everything from driving while banned to cheque-book fraud, and is halfway through a seventh. "I committed child abuse by leaving her," she says.

Ms Peel is softer on her mother. "She was a heroin addict and she had mental health problems. She needed help, my mum."

Diagnosed as a paranoid schizophrenic in 1991, Miller, now 37, was a regular at St Luke's psychiatric hospital in Middlesbrough. The day before her last crime, she arrived at St Luke's in an agitated state and was sent home with 60 sleeping tablets. Once home, she added diazepam (tranquillisers) and crack cocaine to the mix and went out to rob the local Spar with a kitchen knife. Her sister was behind the till; she held the knife to her throat. She got four and a half years.

She began her sentence on her daughter's 18th birthday. That was the night Ms Peel started on the path to heroin addiction. "I'd tried it three times before, but that night I just wanted to get wasted. I'm not blaming my mum - I might have ending up doing it anyway. But that's when it really started.

"I was on my own in the house with £42 a week. Social services didn't know anything about me. The night the police arrested my mother they boarded up the doors. I said to them: 'Hey, I live here,' and they said: 'We'll give you some time to get your stuff out.' After that I always [saw] people around who were taking it. I could do what I liked, she was locked up."

Ms Peel remembers the second time her mother went to jail. She was six or seven years old. "They told me she was 'working away'. She got 22 months for driving while banned. I had to stay with her girlfriend. I think she was jealous of the love my mum had for me and she hit me. I didn't tell my mum she was beating me then because Heather said she'd kill me if I told and I believed her.

"She went into prison for the fifth time when I was 16. She was really sick then. She was on heroin and crack. When she went inside that time, I just stayed in the house.

"I dropped out of college. I would probably have stayed on if she was around. But word got out that my ma was inside. People started saying she was a smackhead and I was living in a smack house. So I stayed at home. I really missed her then. We were close, me and my ma: there was only 17 years between us. We used to go to the pub together."

Miller is serving out her sentence in one of the country's more progressive prisons, Low Newton, near Durham, where the drug-rehabilitation programme is the only one of its kind in Britain. It is 2.45pm; visiting time. Inside the main gates a drug-sniffing spaniel is circling the 20 or so children who have been brought in to see their mothers. For the most part it seems to be the grandmothers and sisters, not the men, who have brought the kids.

The women and children sit around white Formica tables in the prison's old dining room. The walls are painted yel low, and there is a play area for children.

Tracy Lally, 32, has five children. She has been a heroin addict since she was 16 and hasn't seen her kids for over a year. "Two of my kids are up for adoption and I'm happy about that. Their foster mother is great. It's my eight-year-old, Kyle, I worry about. He was four and a half when I was taken from him and he said: 'Ma, why don't you just climb over the fence? They can't keep you in here, they are not your ma and da.' "

Low Newton's governor, Mike Kirby, surveys the scene. He has worked in some of the country's harshest prisons. One of his worst memories was of a scene in the visiting room at Warrington in Cheshire. "The father came in with the son. I think he was about five and he didn't understand that his mother was in a prison and she wasn't leaving with them. At the end of visiting time he grabbed her waist and wouldn't let her go. He started screaming that he didn't want to leave her. It was tragic, really tragic. It upset everyone."

Diana Rogan, 32, is with her two children, aged 11 and 13. A former heroin addict serving five years for supplying heroin, she is due to be released at the end of 2002. Her son says: "The other kids used to come up and say, 'Your ma is in prison,' but now they've stopped. Sometimes I had to shout at them. I like coming to see my ma and I never cry because it upsets my ma."

For some children, keeping their parent's imprisonment hidden is a burden. Jill remembers taking her son to Durham prison to see his father for the first time. "I didn't know the way, so I asked someone in the street and my son, Owen, said to me after: 'Ma, why did you have to go and do that? Now everyone will know my da is in prison.'"

Owen often tried to make excuses not to go and see his father. Durham, a high-security prison, can be a traumatic place for children. "They get stressed out. They think their dad is working there and ask me: 'Do you work here with my dad, do you drive the big white van [the prison transfer van] like my dad?' " says Christine Slassor of the North-East Prison After-Care Society (Nepac). "When they go in they are searched - shoes, coats, everything. They take off their watches and belts and go through a scanner. Then they have to stand in line while sniffer dogs search them for drugs."

The biggest problem for most kids is understanding where and why their mother has gone. "When I was about seven and she went back in," says Ms Peel, "I couldn't understand why she had just gone and left me."

Joshua was eight when his mother was sent to Low Newton. "She said she was going to her friend's. She called a taxi, and the taxi just came and drove her here."

Joanne Moss is also on the drug rehabilitation programme at the prison. "My son, who's four, took it very bad. He started taking his shoes off and hiding them to get attention. Or taking off his clothes. I went on home leave and he never left my side; he was holding on to me all the time. When he comes to see me there are tantrums and I wonder sometimes if it would be better for him not to come, but I'm desperate to see him. It's hard."

In October, Britain's prison service will offer an alternative to prison for some addicts - compulsory treatment in the community. The drugs testing and treatment order is, says the Howard League for Penal Reform, "a big step in the right direction".

Twenty years ago, such a programme might have given Lisa Peel back her mother. "I did nothing wrong. I know she had to suffer for what she did, but the kids shouldn't have to suffer as well. I have never been in trouble with the police - never had a caution, never. I don't care what anybody says, you need your mum."

Help for children of imprisoned parents is available from the Federation of Prisoners and Family Support Groups on 020-8741 4578. It has links to a national support network.

webTitle: Parents: Nicholas Lezard on child benefits

fields.headline: Child benefits
fields.standfirst: £150 a week to stay at home with the kids? Nicholas Lezard prepares his invoice
fields.trailText: £150 a week to stay at home with the kids? Nicholas Lezard prepares his invoice.
fields.body:
It was very welcome to see that Harriet Harman had proposed that parents should be given "generous financial support" to stay at home and look after their children - £150 a day being the sum suggested by what my newspaper vaguely calls "family groups". A fair rate, I thought, considering that governments have to be stingy in such matters: Margaret Hodge, the education and employment minister, may have warned that the entire package, mooted more in the spirit of wishful thinking than hard-nosed political reality, was "extremely expensive", but then ministers say that about anything that involves a reversal of the usual direction of cash flow from citizen to government.

I then rechecked the news item and saw that what was being suggested was £150 per week, not per day. Oh well, another dream shattered. Still, it's better than 75p a week for pensioners, and it at least pays lip service to Churchill's remark (or was it Lloyd George's?) that there was no finer investment than putting milk into babies. Although, in Lloyd George's case, the remark intended may have been more along the lines of putting babies into women. But I stray, as ever, from the point.

The point is that someone, however marginally connected to the levers of power, is finally floating the idea of putting a price on a mother's care of her own children. I assume the proposals are directed towards the primary carer, which is usually - how to put this most tellingly? - "'er indoors".

Slack Dad, it has to be said, salutes the idea. He just hopes that this cheque from the Bank of Dreamland will recognise his own struggle to bring up his children semi-decently in the face of his own inertia and selfishness. On the grounds that altruism, dedication and goodwill come naturally to those inclined to such qualities, and so should hardly be worth our notice, the efforts of the terminally decadent even to point themselves in the general direction of the moral high ground, never mind approach it, should be applauded.

Let us go back to that figure of £150 a week. Never-Never Land, which is where Harman and those "family groups" now live, contains, as do all imaginary realms, recognisable trace elements from the world of grinding quotidian reality, so that £150 can presumably be broken down into constituent parts. It is not a figure that has been plucked out of the air now, is it? Of course not. So let me now imagine that Slack Dad's efforts can be given a financial value; and let me prepare an invoice.

Item: taking howling three-year-old to nursery school on freezing cold mornings, Tuesdays and Thursdays (NB why not au pair doing this? What's wrong with experiencing crisp, bracing English weather?): £25.

Item: preparing pre-dawn breakfasts in sub-arctic kitchen for three children with wildly varying tastes, Saturday and Sunday (baby gloop for baby, proper porridge for three-year-old, astonishingly complex cocktail, like something from infantilised James Bond novel, of all available cereals plus some varieties of yoghurt, for six-year-old): £30.

Item: scraping residue of above off self, table, floor, children: £15.

Item: cleaning and changing nappy of ordure-caked baby during vile Sunday morning hangover: £75.

Item: unconvincingly pretending one knows the way to creepy-crawly section of Natural History Museum, South Kensington: £15.

Item: unconvincingly pretending one knows fast, reliable route to public toilets in above: £25.

Item: wrestling with questions such as "Is a triangle a number?" or "Did you go to the museum with us?", 20 minutes after family's return from museum: £10 per minute.

I don't know how much that comes to - along with so much else, my capacity for mental arithmetic has been shot to pieces. But if Harman or the "family groups" that shadow her add it all up and send me a cheque care of this paper, I'm sure I'll get it eventually.

I assume the proposals are directed towards the primary carer, which is usually - how to put this most tellingly? - "'er indoors". Slack Dad, it has to be said, salutes the idea. He just hopes that this cheque from the Bank of Dreamland will recognise his own struggle to bring up his children semi-decently in the face of his own inertia and selfishness. On the grounds that altruism, dedication and goodwill come naturally to those inclined to such qualities, and so should hardly be worth our notice, the efforts of the terminally decadent even to point themselves in the general direction of the moral high ground, never mind approach it, should be applauded. Let us go back to that figure of £150 a week. Never-Never Land, which is where Harman and those "family groups" now live, contains, as do all imaginary realms, recognisable trace elements from the world of grinding quotidian reality, so that £150 can presumably be broken down into constituent parts. It is not a figure that has been plucked out of the air now, is it? Of course not. So let me now imagine that Slack Dad's efforts can be given a financial value; and let me prepare an invoice. Item: taking howling three-year-old to nursery school on freezing cold mornings, Tuesdays and Thursdays (NB why not au pair doing this? What's wrong with experiencing crisp, bracing English weather?): £25. Item: preparing pre-dawn breakfasts in sub-arctic kitchen for three children with wildly varying tastes, Saturday and Sunday (baby gloop for baby, proper porridge for three-year-old, astonishingly complex cocktail, like something from infantilised James Bond novel, of all available cereals plus some varieties of yoghurt, for six-year-old): £30. Item: scraping residue of above off self, table, floor, children: £15. Item: cleaning and changing nappy of ordure-caked baby during vile Sunday morning hangover: £75. Item: unconvincingly pretending one knows the way to creepy-crawly section of Natural History Museum, South Kensington: £15. Item: unconvincingly pretending one knows fast, reliable route to public toilets in above: £25. Item: wrestling with questions such as "Is a triangle a number?" or "Did you go to the museum with us?", 20 minutes after family's return from museum: £10 per minute. I don't know how much that comes to - along with so much else, my capacity for mental arithmetic has been shot to pieces. But if Harman or the "family groups" that shadow her add it all up and send me a cheque care of this paper, I'm sure I'll get it eventually.

webTitle: Parents: The panel on sex education

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: The Question: A preschool nursery has been accused of giving sex education lessons to three-year-olds. Should children be older than that before they find out about sex?
fields.trailText: The Question: A preschool nursery has been accused of giving sex education lessons to three-year-olds. Should children be older than that before they find out about sex?
fields.body:
Rita Howe-Douglas
Principal of Catherine House Day Nursery, Birmingham

My nursery is the one accused of giving children sex education lessons with Claire Rayner's The Body Book. In fact, we have given no such lessons; we have topics such as "growing" or "my body". If the children ask questions about sex as a result of our topics or because someone they know is pregnant, we always answer them honestly and simply. Often they don't want to know any more than that a baby comes from mummy's tummy. I used The Body Book with my children and they have grown up into happy, well-adjusted adults who don't go in and out of sexual relationships lightly.
Verdict: No

Claire Rayner
Agony aunt and author of The Body Book

Basically, you answer a child's question when a child asks it rather than sitting down with them at the age of three, or even older, and giving them a talk about sex. If you are relaxed and comfortable with yourself, a very small child will look at you and point to a breast or a penis and ask what it is. What is important is that children know about sex before their own hormones kick in and sex becomes a subject of giggles and embarrassment. The younger they are, the more normal and natural sex seems, but you don't have to give them every single nut and bolt.
Verdict: No

Jim Richards
Director of the Catholic Children's Society

The sexual act must be seen as part of the loving relationship between parents. That should be the starting point and the moral framework in which to respond honestly to children's questions. For a three- or four-year-old who asks where they came from, it might be enough to say "from mummy's tummy". Parents shouldn't elaborate beyond the intellectual capacity of the child. If a parent responds openly to a child's early questions, the child will feel able to return to the subject. Parents need to know what the school's sex education curriculum is and be happy with it.
Verdict: No

Simon Blake
Director of the Sex Education Forum

A clear and simple sex education book designed for children is a good way to introduce them to sex. What is really worrying for children is when adults skirt around the issue of sex and talk about storks and gooseberry bushes. We can't afford to let another generation grow up with the guilt and embarrassment that previous generations have had. We must answer children honestly to bring about a shift in culture. In places where sex education begins earlier, there are lower rates of teenage pregnancy and young people are less likely to have sexual experiences that they regret afterwards.
Verdict: No

Tuppy Owens
Spokesperson for the Sexual FreedomCoalition

I think sex education for children should be gradual, continual and responsive to their questions. My whole family has always been very open about sex. I remember my mum called it "having it"; I called it "having it off"; and my brother called "having it up", which made us all laugh. It's important to laugh with children about things like that. Older children should learn that sex under 16 is illegal and how to say no to sex. It is incredibly damaging to make sex a naughty, dirty taboo where children are concerned.
Verdict: No

Sheila Wolfendale
Professor of educational psychology at East London Uni

What is important is that children's questions are answered in an age-appropriate way, mindful of the gender of the child and sensitive to their situation. There should be as much honesty as they can cope with at the developmental stage they are at. There's no point in fobbing them off with myths about fairies because that will only rebound on the adults later on. If you talk to young children about babies being made by mummies and daddies who love each other, you have to bear in mind that many children come from single-parent families.
Verdict: No

webTitle: Parents: Simon Bebbington on raising triplets

fields.headline: Trebles all round
fields.standfirst: Raising one child can be hard work, so what is it like to bring up triplets? As his pass their first birthday,  Simon Bebbington reports
fields.trailText: Raising one child can be hard work, so what is it like to bring up triplets? As his pass their first birthday, Simon Bebbington reports.
fields.body:
Five thousand nappies. More than 6,500 bottles of formula milk. Clothing studs popped 40,000 times. The numbers involved with rearing three babies for the first year of their lives are daunting enough, but nothing matches living through it, as we have just done.

One morning last week our triplets became one-year-olds. At 9.43, I fell into a melancholy weep. A year to the minute after my three babies were born, the memories flooded back. The emergency caesarean, two months premature. Peeping through the crack in the operating theatre doors. The blood. The cries. The placentas (huge!). Then following the incubators to the neonatal unit.

How different everything is now from then. The teeth, the talking, the crawling, the walking. At 9.43, I cuddled one boy to sleep and fed milk to the other while my slightly mad daughter cackled at the stripes on the sofa, as Holst's Jupiter played in the background. Jupiter - joy bringer - was the music playing in the car when they came home from hospital, the music that signified the end of life as we knew it.

For years, my partner Diane had looked forward to nurturing a baby, cuddling and feeding and loving it. Then IVF sprang a surprise on us and we got three at once. Everyone said coping with one baby was the toughest thing possible. We had been braced for twins - they run in Diane's family - but triplets? Triple the work, but also triple the joy, surely? Triple the work, yes. But joy - not at first. It was utter hell.

We had the first inkling of what it was going to be like after the kids had spent a month in the neonatal unit. We could take them home, they said, after we had cared for them for a week in a side room off the ward - with the safety net of the nurses being just outside the door.

That first night we were constantly jolted awake by our trio's collection of farmyard noises - the sheep, the goat, the creaking gate. It was the same when we got them home, except that we had our own room to sleep in. Not that we spent much time in it.

We took turns to spring out of bed and answer their hungry cries, moving fast to stop them waking the others. We jumped out of bed so frequently that neither of us was getting enough rest. So we started sleeping in shifts, five hours each, crossing paths at 2am. Finally, we alternated the nights, one sleeping until morning, the other getting up six times a night.

Some days, friends would come to help Diane while I was at work. And two trainee nursery nurses did placements, making things a bit easier. But it could be so hard when she was on her own that I took a baby to the office twice, letting them sleep on my chest or in the crook of my arm while I tapped at my computer in a very unergonomic pose. But Diane was still there, day in, day out. After seven months she cut short her maternity leave and went back to work while I became house dad and administered most of the week's 100 nappies.

We were never party animals, but we liked to go out with friends and lie in all weekend. My pet hates were being tired, hungry and unwashed. Now I am all three simultaneously. If we ever get near hot water, it is in a bath so we can get at least one of the children clean as well. And my clothes are invariably smeared with rusk, milk and sick. We have lost touch with people. There is no time for phone calls or letter writing, and visitors only get half a conversation as we dash around.

We have been out only twice since the kids came home from hospital - we need two experienced babysitters to cope. Even now it takes two hours to clear up after they have gone to bed at 8.30pm - sterilising bottles, washing dishes, clearing fallen food from the floor, tidying away toys. Going out is not really feasible. And we do not usually get our food until 9pm, but at least it is now recognisable as a meal rather than the peanut butter on toast that featured heavily in my diet for the first six months.

Apart from the logistics of day-to-day living, the biggest problem is getting out with the triplets. Living on the fourth floor of a block with no lift means a quick trip to the swings is not on the cards. It usually takes two adults to carry the trio and their bag downstairs, although one person can do it at a push, using car seats to ferry them down a landing at a time. But the run-up to getting out of the door is crucial, as it takes an hour to get them changed and packed. The trick is to judge their hunger, tiredness and bowel movements so they will allow you to strap them into their buggies without shouting the block down.

When we do get out, the places we can go are limited - the park and a couple of supermarkets and larger shops. The likes of Mothercare do not feature on our list, as friends have given us all the kids' clothes and most of their toys. Our main outlay was for their transport: £900 in total for quad, twin and single buggies so they can go out in any permutation.

Plywood has also made a dent in our single income: I am rebuilding the kitchen. I had intended to fix it in the three months I had taken off work before their due date. But Diane was rushed into hospital for a two-month stay and I spent the time visiting her, and later the kids. The DIY has been restricted to weekends, when the kids could be taken out, so it is still unfinished. Meanwhile, the rugrats have become more mobile, so we have had to convert the living area into a giant playpen, with everything now above shoulder height.

But things are getting easier as the kids get older. Instead of bottles eight times a day each, main meals are taken in highchairs at the table. They still need bottles of milk, but two like feeding themselves, so there is not as much screaming as a few months ago when they could not hold anything and all wanted a bottle at once.

They also entertain themselves, so we do not have to go to a playgroup to find someone for them to chase around the floor. But they do get jealous, especially if they are all hungry, or tired, or both. Then a quiet life relies on juggling their needs and self-feeding capabilities while judging who will fall asleep (and more importantly stay asleep) first.

The trio have wildly different personalities and are good at different things, which is great as they learn from each other. Whenever one does anything new - rolling over, holding bottles, talking, crawling - the others are sure to follow within a week or two. The final one to crawl did so because the others kept stealing his toys. Now we are having a laugh as they start to walk, staggering round like a bunch of old drunks. The Pythonesque face slapping when two are annoyed with each other is a giggle, too.

We have coped simply because there has been no other option, and now they are toddlers things are going to get easier, kind of. For them, their birthday was just another day. For us, it was a liberation. Now we can chuck the steriliser and give them ready-made foods containing salt, and they are close to sleeping through. And in a year they can start their potty training. Only another 5,000 nappies to go.

webTitle: Parents: Lyn Gardner's children books selection

fields.headline: Off the shelf
fields.standfirst: Building a library for your child
fields.trailText: Building a library for your child.
fields.body:
Book of the month

Bloodtide by Melvin Burgess (Penguin, £5.99; CultureShop price £4.99)

What's the difference between Melvin Burgess and many other writers for children and young adults? The difference is that Burgess doesn't just tell rollicking good stories; he writes brilliantly, too. There is a real passion here, and he spares the reader nothing.

As with Burgess's most notorious book, Junk, this is a warts-and-all tale about human nature. Loosely based on the Volsunga saga - written in the 13th century in Icelandic - it tells of teenaged twins Siggy and Signy, the offspring of Val Volson, who owns half of London and enters into a treaty with his archenemy Connor.

Set a century or so hence, after the government has moved out of London, leaving the city to be fought over by warring gangs, this is a terrifying, gruesome and utterly compelling story of human cruelty, the struggle for power, the urge for revenge and our need for love.

There is no sense that Burgess has censored himself; instead, he has been driven by his own hurtling imagination and the urgency of the story. A bone-hard, brilliant book.

Ages 0-3

Hug by Jez Alborough (Walker, £9.99; CultureShop price £7.99)

A book for anyone who has ever felt they needed a hug. Bobo the little chimp wants a hug. Everywhere he turns in the jungle, he sees mummies and babies - elephants, giraffes and lions - having hugs. Even the hippos are snuggling. But the lost Bobo has nobody to hug him. Then his mum finds him again and soon the entire jungle is having a giant cross-species hug-in.

The word hug is almost the only text in this clever little book; the big, bright pictures dance off the page with such exuberance that you can't help but feel happy while you are looking at it. Even the expressions on the faces of the animals are all subtly different. As fine a demonstration as you can get that books are not just about reading, but about feelings.

Really Brave Tim by John Prater (Red Fox, £4.99; CultureShop price £3.99)

A neat little picture book that explores the things that scare us in a gently humorous fashion. In Tim's den, Millie, Suki and Billie are boasting about how brave they are. When Billie tells of his adventure in the dark forest, Millie tells how she swam with sharks and Suki recounts climbing to the top of the world, Tim keeps quiet because he is afraid of the dark, water and heights. But there is one thing that everyone else is afraid of and Tim isn't: spiders.

A simple text is complemented by atmospheric illustrations. But the best thing about this book is the way it combines the strange with the everyday - so you never really know whether there might be goblins playing football in the woods or dragons waiting outside sweetshops to snaffle your extra-strong mints.

Ages 4-7

The Boy Who Became an Eagle by Kathryn Cave, illust. by Nick Maland (Dorling Kindersley, £8.99; CultureShop price £6.99)

This wonderful book has the enduring feel of a myth or a fable and leaves you with a pang in your heart and a sense of loss. It concerns a shepherd boy who discovers that he can fly. Something inside him tells him it would be wise to keep it a secret, but a travelling showman discovers his gift and puts the boy in his show. The boy is a sensation, but he longs for his family and home; then he has the misfortune to be kidnapped by thieves who want to discover the secret of flight.

Cave's prose is as spare as winter and has a restrained icy beauty while it niggles away at ideas about freedom and the need for a home. Maland's brilliant, detailed drawings conjure up a sense of both claustrophobia and wide open spaces where the imagination can soar.

Tiger and Me by Kaye Umansky, illust. by Susie Jenkin-Pearce (Red Fox, £4.99; CultureShop price £3.99)

We speak of childhood being a time of freedom, yet most small children spend their lives being coerced into doing things they don't really want to. We may ask them what they want for tea but we seldom assume this age group has opinions about the world.

This book suggests children can change how the world is. The simple poem tells of a little girl who goes to the jungle. There, a tiger tells her how unbearable his life has become since his brothers were captured and sent to the zoo. She returns home, tells his story to anyone who will listen and starts a campaign to free the tigers and send them back to the jungle.

This is a simple but empowering book, particularly for children who have just started school and been turned into little conformists.

Ages 8-11

Spellfall by Katherine Roberts (The Chicken House,£10.99; CultureShop price £8.99)

Natalie sees what she thinks is a leaf in the supermarket car park. But the leaf turns out to be a spell and puts Natalie, who has powers she did not know about, in enormous danger.

This is a thrilling tale of kidnap, unlikely friendship, magic and sheer pluck, as Natalie finds herself a pawn between two worlds: the mysterious, magical world of Earthaven, the original home of her dead mother, and that of the exiled spellmage who wants to use her power for his own purposes.

Like so much of the current output of children's publishing houses, this is not great literature but is a great read: Roberts knows exactly how to rack up the tension and create parallel universes. Here there are unicorns and huge trees that talk, and everything seems as believable as our own world.

My Brother's Ghost by Allan Ahlberg (Penguin Puffin, £3.99; CultureShop price £3.99)

Buy this book, and not just for your children and teenagers. Grans, grandads, mums and dads will appreciate this slim ghost story that is also a beautiful evocation of a grim 1950s childhood.

The traditional paperback format may not be quite as enticing as the hardback version, which was like a little jewel, but what is inside remains wondrous: a tender story about how being haunted can save your life, about the ties that bind and how being an orphan isn't a bit like being Harry Potter.

Ahlberg's novella is strongly autobiographical: he writes about childhood with a distance that somehow brings it into sharp focus, so that you can smell the gasworks, see the glitter of November rain on the headstones in the cemetery and feel the shock of the cold, scummy canal water.

Ages 12+

Bluebeard's Castle by Gene Kemp (Faber and Faber, £4.99; CultureShop price £3.99)

Psychologist Bruno Bettleheim suggested that fairy tales teach children how to live. The old stories live on, but the best writers - including Gene Kemp - find new ways to frame them.

Sharon, the eldest sister of three kids from London's east end - Marie, Gary and Ems - becomes the teenage bride of Magnus Moore, a famous millionaire and movie-maker. When the younger children are invited to stay at his castle at the Wonderland theme park, they discover something very nasty in the dungeons. It takes all their courage and ingenuity to save their sister and bring Magnus to justice.

Kemp's racy read takes Perrault's tale and puts it firmly in the here and now - a world of single-parent families, absent fathers, celebrity mania, kids who talk back and stroppy heroines.

Noughts and Crosses by Malorie Blackman (Doubleday, £10.99; CultureShop price £8.99)

Who reached the north pole first? Matthew Henson. Who pioneered blood banks? Dr Charles Drew. Who performed open-heart surgery first? Dr Daniel Williams. Heard of any of them? Probably not - almost certainly because they are black.

Blackman cleverly plays with these names in this Romeo and Juliet-style story set in a segregated world in which blacks (known as Crosses) rule over whites (known as Noughts), who have turned to terrorism to survive.

If the writing lacks poetry, the plotting certainly doesn't lack drive. The narrative develops in a wholly credible way as teenagers Sephy (a Cross) and Callum (a Nought) find themselves facing infinitely more difficult obstacles than Shakespeare's lovers and have to choose where their loyalties lie.

fields.bodyText: Book of the month Bloodtide by Melvin Burgess (Penguin, £5.99; CultureShop price £4.99) What's the difference between Melvin Burgess and many other writers for children and young adults? The difference is that Burgess doesn't just tell rollicking good stories; he writes brilliantly, too. There is a real passion here, and he spares the reader nothing. As with Burgess's most notorious book, Junk, this is a warts-and-all tale about human nature. Loosely based on the Volsunga saga - written in the 13th century in Icelandic - it tells of teenaged twins Siggy and Signy, the offspring of Val Volson, who owns half of London and enters into a treaty with his archenemy Connor. Set a century or so hence, after the government has moved out of London, leaving the city to be fought over by warring gangs, this is a terrifying, gruesome and utterly compelling story of human cruelty, the struggle for power, the urge for revenge and our need for love. There is no sense that Burgess has censored himself; instead, he has been driven by his own hurtling imagination and the urgency of the story. A bone-hard, brilliant book. Ages 0-3 Hug by Jez Alborough (Walker, £9.99; CultureShop price £7.99) A book for anyone who has ever felt they needed a hug. Bobo the little chimp wants a hug. Everywhere he turns in the jungle, he sees mummies and babies - elephants, giraffes and lions - having hugs. Even the hippos are snuggling. But the lost Bobo has nobody to hug him. Then his mum finds him again and soon the entire jungle is having a giant cross-species hug-in. The word hug is almost the only text in this clever little book; the big, bright pictures dance off the page with such exuberance that you can't help but feel happy while you are looking at it. Even the expressions on the faces of the animals are all subtly different. As fine a demonstration as you can get that books are not just about reading, but about feelings. Really Brave Tim by John Prater (Red Fox, £4.99; CultureShop price £3.99) A neat little picture book that explores the things that scare us in a gently humorous fashion. In Tim's den, Millie, Suki and Billie are boasting about how brave they are. When Billie tells of his adventure in the dark forest, Millie tells how she swam with sharks and Suki recounts climbing to the top of the world, Tim keeps quiet because he is afraid of the dark, water and heights. But there is one thing that everyone else is afraid of and Tim isn't: spiders. A simple text is complemented by atmospheric illustrations. But the best thing about this book is the way it combines the strange with the everyday - so you never really know whether there might be goblins playing football in the woods or dragons waiting outside sweetshops to snaffle your extra-strong mints. Ages 4-7 The Boy Who Became an Eagle by Kathryn Cave, illust. by Nick Maland (Dorling Kindersley, £8.99; CultureShop price £6.99) This wonderful book has the enduring feel of a myth or a fable and leaves you with a pang in your heart and a sense of loss. It concerns a shepherd boy who discovers that he can fly. Something inside him tells him it would be wise to keep it a secret, but a travelling showman discovers his gift and puts the boy in his show. The boy is a sensation, but he longs for his family and home; then he has the misfortune to be kidnapped by thieves who want to discover the secret of flight. Cave's prose is as spare as winter and has a restrained icy beauty while it niggles away at ideas about freedom and the need for a home. Maland's brilliant, detailed drawings conjure up a sense of both claustrophobia and wide open spaces where the imagination can soar. Tiger and Me by Kaye Umansky, illust. by Susie Jenkin-Pearce (Red Fox, £4.99; CultureShop price £3.99) We speak of childhood being a time of freedom, yet most small children spend their lives being coerced into doing things they don't really want to. We may ask them what they want for tea but we seldom assume this age group has opinions about the world. This book suggests children can change how the world is. The simple poem tells of a little girl who goes to the jungle. There, a tiger tells her how unbearable his life has become since his brothers were captured and sent to the zoo. She returns home, tells his story to anyone who will listen and starts a campaign to free the tigers and send them back to the jungle. This is a simple but empowering book, particularly for children who have just started school and been turned into little conformists. Ages 8-11 Spellfall by Katherine Roberts (The Chicken House,£10.99; CultureShop price £8.99) Natalie sees what she thinks is a leaf in the supermarket car park. But the leaf turns out to be a spell and puts Natalie, who has powers she did not know about, in enormous danger. This is a thrilling tale of kidnap, unlikely friendship, magic and sheer pluck, as Natalie finds herself a pawn between two worlds: the mysterious, magical world of Earthaven, the original home of her dead mother, and that of the exiled spellmage who wants to use her power for his own purposes. Like so much of the current output of children's publishing houses, this is not great literature but is a great read: Roberts knows exactly how to rack up the tension and create parallel universes. Here there are unicorns and huge trees that talk, and everything seems as believable as our own world. My Brother's Ghost by Allan Ahlberg (Penguin Puffin, £3.99; CultureShop price £3.99) Buy this book, and not just for your children and teenagers. Grans, grandads, mums and dads will appreciate this slim ghost story that is also a beautiful evocation of a grim 1950s childhood. The traditional paperback format may not be quite as enticing as the hardback version, which was like a little jewel, but what is inside remains wondrous: a tender story about how being haunted can save your life, about the ties that bind and how being an orphan isn't a bit like being Harry Potter. Ahlberg's novella is strongly autobiographical: he writes about childhood with a distance that somehow brings it into sharp focus, so that you can smell the gasworks, see the glitter of November rain on the headstones in the cemetery and feel the shock of the cold, scummy canal water. Ages 12+ Bluebeard's Castle by Gene Kemp (Faber and Faber, £4.99; CultureShop price £3.99) Psychologist Bruno Bettleheim suggested that fairy tales teach children how to live. The old stories live on, but the best writers - including Gene Kemp - find new ways to frame them. Sharon, the eldest sister of three kids from London's east end - Marie, Gary and Ems - becomes the teenage bride of Magnus Moore, a famous millionaire and movie-maker. When the younger children are invited to stay at his castle at the Wonderland theme park, they discover something very nasty in the dungeons. It takes all their courage and ingenuity to save their sister and bring Magnus to justice. Kemp's racy read takes Perrault's tale and puts it firmly in the here and now - a world of single-parent families, absent fathers, celebrity mania, kids who talk back and stroppy heroines. Noughts and Crosses by Malorie Blackman (Doubleday, £10.99; CultureShop price £8.99) Who reached the north pole first? Matthew Henson. Who pioneered blood banks? Dr Charles Drew. Who performed open-heart surgery first? Dr Daniel Williams. Heard of any of them? Probably not - almost certainly because they are black. Blackman cleverly plays with these names in this Romeo and Juliet-style story set in a segregated world in which blacks (known as Crosses) rule over whites (known as Noughts), who have turned to terrorism to survive. If the writing lacks poetry, the plotting certainly doesn't lack drive. The narrative develops in a wholly credible way as teenagers Sephy (a Cross) and Callum (a Nought) find themselves facing infinitely more difficult obstacles than Shakespeare's lovers and have to choose where their loyalties lie.  Off the shelf can be used with the Guardian website Books Unlimited to build a library of children's classics. webTitle: Parents: Profile of writer Jennifer Lauck

fields.headline: A lost childhood
fields.standfirst: She cared for her semi-paralysed mother at six and was orphaned at 10. Then it got worse.  Markie Robson-Scott meets the author of the bestselling memoir Blackbird
fields.trailText: She cared for her semi-paralysed mother at six and was orphaned at 10. Then it got worse. Markie Robson-Scott meets the author of the bestselling memoir Blackbird.
fields.body:
"'If I tell people my mother died when I was eight, and my father died when I was 10, and then I was abandoned by my stepmother, they just look at me and say, 'That can't be you; come on, you're so normal.' And I really wanted to be normal." Until Jennifer Lauck, 37, wrote her bestselling memoir, Blackbird: A Childhood Lost, she hardly spoke of, or even thought about, her childhood. She spent the early years of that childhood looking after her adored, terminally ill mother, Janet: "She saw me in the way that a mother really should see a child and often doesn't."

Growing up with her brother, BJ, in Nevada and California, Lauck was changing her mother's catheter bag, washing the soiled bed linen and saving her mother from overdosing when she was six or seven. Instead of dwelling on the experience, Lauck "put on a tough attitude" and got a life. She married at 19, though the relationship did not last, and, after university, won several awards for TV news journalism. Then she moved into PR and ran a company in Portland, Oregon, where she lives with her second husband Steve, an auctioneer, and their three-year-old son, Spencer.

"In my early 30s I came to a stop. I was pretty much burned out career-wise," she says. "And that's when everything seemed to catch up with me. It was the first time I'd slowed down enough to investigate the causes of my mother's death. At first I did it like a reporter, getting medical records from the hospital. It was never intended to be a book; more a journal of sorts.

"But when I got pregnant on the anniversary of my mother's death - I was 33, the same age that she was when she died - I said to my husband, 'This is a sign, an invitation.' Then six weeks before my son was due, my waters broke on Mother's Day, May 11, my mother's birthday. She really didn't want to be forgotten. Writing the book became a pilgrimage to her, to reclaim this beautiful woman."

These coincidences, which went down well on Oprah, would be less impressive if Lauck's memoir were not so riveting. Through the child's eyes, we see Lauck as a five-year-old carrying coffee and toast through to her mother on a tray each morning, and learning about make-up and clothes as her mother gets ready - "put together", she calls it - in the style of Jackie Kennedy.

There are bad days when Janet (left semi-paralysed by a botched operation to remove a tumour from her spine) can't get out of bed at all, and these days get worse once Lauck's father decides that she should see new doctors in California. She is admitted to hospital and the family moves to Los Angeles to be near her.

For Lauck, school is peripheral; friends are not on the cards because if your mom is sick and cannot pick you up you are not normal. The workaholic dad is hardly around at all. Janet dies in 1971, on BJ's 10th birthday. A few days before that, Lauck learns that she is adopted. Can it get worse? Yes - their father has already started an affair with another woman, the cold, obsessive Deb, and soon they are living with her and her three children. Life is grim - but not half as grim as when the father dies of a sudden heart attack and Deb abandons Lauck, leaving her to earn her keep, aged 10, in a Freedom Church commune in LA. "Figure it out ... it's called survival," says Deb as a parting shot.

This is not a grisly Californian self-help memoir-as-therapy. Lauck, a driven journalist, knows how to write and structure. She used her mother's medical reports as a preface because she felt the beginning of the book, when she describes her day at home, could be boring (it isn't) if the reader did not already know that something terrible was going to happen. "It's a good lead. Don't bury your lead."

But what about the shrinks, the drugs, the Alcoholics Anonymous meetings, the depression? Apparently there has been none of that, or not that much. She did a little therapy, "in and out for about three or four years, just talking with this really wonderful man".

Remarkably, it wasn't until then that she "realised what depression feels like. It really sucks. Now I understand why people take antidepressants. It's like an underlayer you can't surface from." She started Blackbird (as in "Take these broken wings and learn to fly") when Spencer was four months old, and finished it 14 months later. Compared to the writing, therapy sounds easy.

"I studied creative writing under this writer who uses a technique called 'dangerous writing'. It's brutal: you sweat and cry. He pushes you to the place you don't want to go: sometimes you've skimmed over it and he says, 'Stop right there.' That's where those scenes with the overdose, the pee bag and messed-up sheets came from. It's like the most concentrated form of analysis. I so wanted to get through it."

Lauck says she is ready to move on. "I was so committed to telling my mother's story. But I'd like to stop being the daughter for a while, just be myself." In fact it is Lauck's spirit, fortified by her mother's love, that resonates in Blackbird. On the last page she is reunited, aged 11, with her paternal grandparents.

I am dying to know what happens next. Surely everything will be all right now that her family has reclaimed her? Lauck has already started writing the sequel, tentatively called Into the Fire (as in out of the frying pan). She lets me have a few juicy details and I see that there is a long way to go before anything is remotely all right - which makes Jennifer Lauck's thriving all the more remarkable.

webTitle: Pay rises for dot.com executives as shares slump

fields.headline: Pay rises for dot.com executives as shares slump
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Internet executives are demanding huge pay increases to make up for the collapsing value of their share options, a survey has discovered.
fields.body:
Internet executives are demanding huge pay increases to make up for the collapsing value of their share options, a survey has discovered.

The chief executives of quoted dot.com firms have received pay rises of up to 60% in the past 12 months - and have bagged twice the number of share options previously held. An executive of a floated business is paid, on average, £170,000, only 10% less than a chief executive of an offline company.

The rapid changes in the way technology bosses are rewarded - a direct result of the crash in hi-tech shares in the past year - means there is now little difference between their pay and that of bosses of more traditional companies.

The survey, conducted by ePay for recruitment company Futurestep and compensation company SCA Consulting, found British internet executives the best paid in Europe.

The study, which surveyed more than 2,000 senior executives in nine European countries, said that internet companies had been forced to restructure their pay packages to prevent executives moving on to less risky companies.

"Salary and bonus compensation has increased substantially in the last six months and in many instances by 50%. Internet executives predict that salaries will further increase by 10% this year," the survey said.

Francesco Benincasa, chief executive and founder of ihavemoved.com, an internet company that notifies services about a change of address, says there is no longer a scrum for an extra 1% of stock options.

webTitle: It ain't over 'til it's over

fields.headline: It ain't over 'til it's over
fields.standfirst: The fat lady may be clearing her throat. But Sunderland can give the rest of the Premiership some hope if they beat Manchester United tonight, argues Sean Ingle
fields.trailText: OK, so the fat lady is clearing her throat. But Sunderland can give the rest of the Premiership some hope if they beat Manchester United tonight, argues Sean Ingle.
fields.body:
The Premiership race is over. Manchester United have won it again. That was the crux of Peter Reid's eve-of-game press conference ahead of Sunderland's match against the Red Devils tonight.

At least he had the decency to wait until the end of January to wave the white flag. David O'Leary, Gerard Houllier and most other Premiership managers gave up in mid-November.

Of course, they were all probably right. And so are bookies Blue Square, who are now offering 25-1 on any team but Manchester United winning the league. But the true football lovers out there - those of us who appreciate United's brilliance but scrunch our fists in frustration at the timidity of their rivals - are desperately hoping for something more than a repeat of last year's Premiership procession.

We want there to be some sort of contest. And Sunderland tonight offer our last hope.

If the Black Cats win, all bets are back on. United's lead would be cut to ten points, and after two successive defeats the doubts might just start to appear. After all, in 1998, Sir Alex Ferguson's side were 12 points ahead of Arsenal - who admittedly had two games in hand - and blew it. It could happen again, especially as fortress Old Trafford has begun to look less secure after home defeats by Liverpool and West Ham.

United's forthcoming fixture list provides further grounds for optimism. After Saturday's formality of a home match against Everton, United's next five Premiership games are against Chelsea, Arsenal, Leeds, Leicester and Liverpool. Squashed into that lot are two tough Champions League fixtures against Valencia as well as a hostile away tie at Panathiniakos.

Admittedly, it's still hard to see anything other than United winning their seventh Premiership trophy in nine years. They still have the best manager, the best squad and an incredible, insatiable lust for trophies.

But Sunderland can give this Premiership season a much-needed kiss of life tonight. And with an estimated 130m people in 30 countries across the world watching the game live, they have the perfect stage to do it. Let's hope they take the opportunity.
