webTitle: Lockerbie verdict: Libyan given life

fields.headline: Lockerbie verdict: Libyan given life
fields.standfirst:
 Abdelbaset Al Megrahi found guilty unanimously
 Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah not guilty

Timeline
Special report: Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: Libyan intelligence agent Abdelbaset Al Megrahi was today sentenced to life for the Lockerbie bombing. The judges recommended a minimum sentence of 20 years in view of the "horrendous nature of this crime."
fields.body:
Libyan intelligence agent Abdelbaset Al Megrahi was today sentenced to life for the Lockerbie bombing. The judges recommended a minimum sentence of 20 years in view of the "horrendous nature of this crime."

He had earlier been found guilty of murder unanimously, while his co-accused, Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, was found not guilty.

Presiding judge Lord Sutherland told Megrahi that the 20 year period was "substantially less" than the court would have recommended were it not for Megrahi's age and the fact that he will be serving his sentence in a foreign country.

Megrahi has 14 days to lodge an appeal against conviction and Libyan television said this was his intention. He would serve his sentence in a Scottish jail if his appeal failed.

Families of victims of the Lockerbie bombing finally learnt the outcome of the biggest mass murder trial in British history at the specially constructed court. Dr Jim Swire, whose daughter Flora died in the bombing, collapsed in court and was taken away by paramedics.

Many of the relatives said they saw today as a turning point in their search for the full truth about the mass murder of 270 passengers, crew and Lockerbie residents in the UK's worst peacetime atrocity.

The outcome follows 84 days of evidence from 230 witnesses at the trial of Megrahi and Fhimah, which began last May.

The three trial judges, sitting without a jury, retired to consider their verdict nearly a fortnight ago. Under Scottish law, they had three verdicts to choose from - guilty, not guilty and not proven.

Lord Sutherland delivered the verdicts shortly after 10.00 GMT after being prompted by the clerk of the court. The whole proceedings took around 17 minutes.

A gasp went up from the dozens of relatives from the United States and Britain who were in the public gallery. Several brothers and sisters of the two defendants were also present.

The appeal hearing for Megrahi will take place at Camp Zeist before a panel of five judges. Until it is complete, he will remain in prison at Camp Zeist.

Mr Fhimah is free to return to Libya immediately and arrangements are being made by the Dutch authorities for his repatriation, although it is not known how quickly this will be done.

An international manhunt involving Scottish police and CIA investigators led to Al Megrahi, 48, and Fhimah, 44. They denied planting the bomb which caused the tragedy.

Outside court, following the judgment, bereaved relative Betty Thomas, from Wales, said she was "elated with one of the verdicts and very disappointed at the second".

Asked if the court's decision would end the matter for her, she said: "No, I want to find out who was behind this. These are just the jokers in the pack."

She added that would not be satisfied until it was revealed "who organised them and who paid for them".

The prime minister, Tony Blair, was "glad that justice has been done" in the Lockerbie case, a spokesman said.

Britain now expects Libya to take responsibility for the actions of its official and pay at least the £478m compensation already awarded by the courts, added Downing Street. "The Libyan government now has to respond to the verdict," the spokesman said.

The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, told the Commons this afternoon that in order for sanctions against Libya to be lifted, there were "two key steps: to accept responsibility and pay compensation".

There had been "some compliance" from Libya, he said, such as handing over the two suspects.

But he continued: "The Libyans need to take every opportunity to convince the international community they have definitively renounced terrorism."

Mr Cook went on: "The bombing stands with the most brutal acts of mass murder more than 400 parents lost a child."

He added that there had been no decision to rule out a public inquiry. However, he said that now - with an appeal forthcoming - was not the time to make that decision and that any inquiry would have to reveal information beyond that gleaned from the trial.

At first, the Libyan leader, Colonel Muammar Gaddafi, refused to hand the men over for trial, but eventually a diplomatic deal led to the trial being held on neutral territory under Scottish law.

fields.bodyText: Libyan intelligence agent Abdelbaset Al Megrahi was today sentenced to life for the Lockerbie bombing. The judges recommended a minimum sentence of 20 years in view of the "horrendous nature of this crime." He had earlier been found guilty of murder unanimously, while his co-accused, Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, was found not guilty. Presiding judge Lord Sutherland told Megrahi that the 20 year period was "substantially less" than the court would have recommended were it not for Megrahi's age and the fact that he will be serving his sentence in a foreign country. Megrahi has 14 days to lodge an appeal against conviction and Libyan television said this was his intention. He would serve his sentence in a Scottish jail if his appeal failed. Families of victims of the Lockerbie bombing finally learnt the outcome of the biggest mass murder trial in British history at the specially constructed court. Dr Jim Swire, whose daughter Flora died in the bombing, collapsed in court and was taken away by paramedics. Many of the relatives said they saw today as a turning point in their search for the full truth about the mass murder of 270 passengers, crew and Lockerbie residents in the UK's worst peacetime atrocity. The outcome follows 84 days of evidence from 230 witnesses at the trial of Megrahi and Fhimah, which began last May. The three trial judges, sitting without a jury, retired to consider their verdict nearly a fortnight ago. Under Scottish law, they had three verdicts to choose from - guilty, not guilty and not proven. Lord Sutherland delivered the verdicts shortly after 10.00 GMT after being prompted by the clerk of the court. The whole proceedings took around 17 minutes. A gasp went up from the dozens of relatives from the United States and Britain who were in the public gallery. Several brothers and sisters of the two defendants were also present. The appeal hearing for Megrahi will take place at Camp Zeist before a panel of five judges. Until it is complete, he will remain in prison at Camp Zeist. Mr Fhimah is free to return to Libya immediately and arrangements are being made by the Dutch authorities for his repatriation, although it is not known how quickly this will be done. An international manhunt involving Scottish police and CIA investigators led to Al Megrahi, 48, and Fhimah, 44. They denied planting the bomb which caused the tragedy. Outside court, following the judgment, bereaved relative Betty Thomas, from Wales, said she was "elated with one of the verdicts and very disappointed at the second". Asked if the court's decision would end the matter for her, she said: "No, I want to find out who was behind this. These are just the jokers in the pack." She added that would not be satisfied until it was revealed "who organised them and who paid for them". The prime minister, Tony Blair, was "glad that justice has been done" in the Lockerbie case, a spokesman said. Britain now expects Libya to take responsibility for the actions of its official and pay at least the £478m compensation already awarded by the courts, added Downing Street. "The Libyan government now has to respond to the verdict," the spokesman said. The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, told the Commons this afternoon that in order for sanctions against Libya to be lifted, there were "two key steps: to accept responsibility and pay compensation". There had been "some compliance" from Libya, he said, such as handing over the two suspects. But he continued: "The Libyans need to take every opportunity to convince the international community they have definitively renounced terrorism." Mr Cook went on: "The bombing stands with the most brutal acts of mass murder more than 400 parents lost a child." He added that there had been no decision to rule out a public inquiry. However, he said that now - with an appeal forthcoming - was not the time to make that decision and that any inquiry would have to reveal information beyond that gleaned from the trial. At first, the Libyan leader, Colonel Muammar Gaddafi, refused to hand the men over for trial, but eventually a diplomatic deal led to the trial being held on neutral territory under Scottish law. webTitle: Britain sees end of UN sanctions against Libya soon

fields.headline: Britain sees end of UN sanctions against Libya soon
fields.standfirst: Special report: Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: The Foreign Office predicted today that United Nations sanctions against Libya could be lifted within weeks provided its leader, Muammar Gadafy, agrees to outstanding demands in connection with the Lockerbie bombing.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill, diplomatic editor, and Richard Norton-Taylor, security editor
fields.body:
The Foreign Office predicted today that United Nations sanctions against Libya could be lifted within weeks provided its leader, Muammar Gadafy, agrees to outstanding demands in connection with the Lockerbie bombing.

The way was opened for an end to sanctions by the completion of the trial of two Libyans accused of planting a bomb on Pan Am flight 103 in December 1988. The stiff economic sanctions were imposed in 1992 in the wake of the bombing and were suspended in 1999 after Libya handed over the two men.

Meetings between US, British and Libyan diplomats to discuss sanctions are scheduled within the next 48 hours in the Libyan capital, Tripoli, and at the UN headquarters in New York.

A Foreign Office spokesman said: "We must now reflect on the verdict, study the reasoned judgment carefully and assess whether Libya has complied with the will of the international community as laid down in the UN resolutions."

The key resolution made six demands on Libya: that it cease all forms of terrorism, surrender the two men for trial, disclose all it knows about the Lockerbie bombing, accepts responsibility for the actions of Libyan officials, pays appropriate compensation and cooperates in a French investigation into another terrorist action. "Libya must comply with all these requirements," the Foreign Office spokesman said.

If there is an appeal against the verdict, the lifting of sanctions could be delayed; it would then be a matter of months rather than weeks.

While Col Gadafy has already complied in handing over the two Libyans, the Foreign Office will not advocate the lifting of sanctions until compensation is paid and, more difficult, Libya accepts responsibility. The Libyans have already indicated they will pay the compensation.

The view of the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, since taking office in 1997 is that it is better to engage with countries such as Libya and others formerly classified as "rogue" states rather than leave them isolated. He restored relations with Libya in 1998 after a 15-year break. Against that background, Britain will be keen to see sanctions lifted.

The view of the US is more complex. It maintains a tougher individual position towards Libya. The US state department shares the British view that UN sanctions should be lifted provided Col Gadafy complies with the remaining conditions.

A US diplomat at the UN, John Cunningham, sat in last week on initial discussions at the UN with the British ambassador, Sir Jeremy Greenstock, and Libya's UN ambassador, Abuzed Omar Dorda.

But the new US administration is made of hawks who may prove less amenable. The US secretary of state, Colin Powell, said Tuesday that regardless of the verdict, "there are other things that the Libyan government will be expected to do" regarding the UN sanctions.

"It would also be important to note that there are US sanctions that predate the UN sanctions that were not affected by the outcome of this trial," Mr Powell said.

American sanctions include restrictions on trade and travel and a ban on US oil companies from operating there.

Lifting the UN embargo will require a new security council resolution and the support - or abstention - of its five permanent members.

"The body language of the Libyans is that they will accept the verdict and want to move on," said a senior Foreign Office official. Speaking before today's ruling, he added: "We are assuming Libya is still operating in a positive spirit and will put Lockerbie behind it whatever the verdict."

Foreign Office officials say there is no evidence that Libya is involved now in acts of terrorism - a judgment which the US may not be willing to accept.

Though they remain concerned about Col Gadafy's attempts to import or develop long-range missiles - an EU-wide arms embargo remains in place - one of the officials said: "We have no illusions about aspects of Libya. But our assessment of Britain's strategic national interest is to have a dialogue."

Foreign Office officials speak of a "reasonable expectation" Libya will meet UN conditions for the lifting of sanctions.

fields.headline: Full text of Stuart Etherington's speech
fields.standfirst: The full text of the speech given by Stuart Etherington, chief executive of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations, at the annual Kingston Smith charity lecture in London
fields.trailText: The sector is more prominent, more recognised than it has perhaps ever been. At the national level we have a compact negotiated between government and the voluntary sector. This contains principles aimed at securing a better understanding between the sector and government.
fields.body:
The sector is more prominent, more recognised than it has perhaps ever been. At the national level we have a compact negotiated between government and the voluntary sector. This contains principles aimed at securing a better understanding between the sector and government.

The compact sets the scene for more joint working. This is within a policy framework that emphasises the importance and value of the sector in service delivery but also as a vehicle for participation, active citizenship and "community building'"(now a very popular term).

Similarly, we see at the international level, and perhaps here it is even more pronounced, a growing awareness of the importance of NGOs. This is based on their role in policy formulation, acting as a check and balance against big money or narrow national interests.

So the sector is now more feted than in has ever been. But it is also more subject to criticism. We are in this respect victims of our own success.

In the good or bad old days, depending on your perspective, when we were perceived as the David challenging Goliath we could do no wrong. In these days of heightened media interest it sometimes feels as if we can do little right.

Journalists of my acquaintance explain their changed attitude by emphasising that we can not expect to be treated differently from powerful public or private interests. They point to the many charities which are multi million pound businesses, and how ICT makes it relatively easy and inexpensive for us to undermine consumer conscious multi nationals or poll sensitive politicians. We are therefore deemed to have power. More notably we cause concern because our power is not checked by accountability to a mass electorate - as if this were the only accountability that matters.

For the last four years NCVO has been engaged in a programme of work looking at trust and confidence in charities and other voluntary organisations. We believe based on our work that generally public trust and confidence in charities is high. However, the public now raise issues that we need to address if we are to sustain a high approval rating. The public are concerned about: fundraising practice; regulation; independence/distinctiveness.

Fundraising practice, other operational issues and distinctiveness I will come back to later. I would like to start by saying a little about regulation.

Regulation: There is a perception among the public that the sector is insufficiently regulated. This has perhaps been promoted by media stories which focus on particular cases of abuse. A recent example was War Child. The media often suggests that the cases come to the attention of the papers are simply the tip of the iceberg - that abuse is likely to be rife on the basis of a low level of reporting to the charity commission.

We know that this isn't the case - cases like War Child are luckily relatively rare. They often first see the light of day, as in this case, because a trustee approached the charity commission to express concern.

Further on the question of non reporting, it should be remembered that the vast majority of charities are not required to report because they are too small and also that levels of charity reporting are not necessarily any worse than those for purely commercial concerns.

Many would argue that the sector does not necessarily need more regulation but more effective regulation and perhaps greater investment in self regulation.

The problem could better be formulated perhaps as follows: There is no evidence of any scale of fraud and abuse in charities - rather the contrary. People generally have good instincts towards charity and would not seek to undermine it. Which does n't mean an extremely hard line should not be taken when fraud is detected, rather the contrary, since it constitutes a very serious abuse of trust.

For me the issue for the sector and for NCVO is how can we support each other in developing the highest standards of practice in key areas such as fundraising, collaboration and consultation.

Distinctiveness, fundraising and other operational issues

NCVO public attitudes research published in 1998 revealed that the public want to support the sector because it is distinctive. It also indicated some concern about a blurring of boundaries between the sectors. The public respond to the belief that the voluntary or charitable sector has a different ethos, that it often meets urgent needs. It raises funds to enable it to do this. However, the research also pointed to some disquiet among the public about perceived increasing competitiveness for funds and aggressive fundraising.

Part of our strength as a sector is that we are passionate about the causes that we pursue. This of course is a good thing but it does mean that sometimes some of us believe that the ends justify the means - this can lead to fundraising behaviour which might be questioned by independent observers.

Malcolm Dean recently wrote in the Guardian about the NSPCC Full Stop campaign. He commented that the campaign set an unobtainable goal, that facts were distorted to add drama to the appeal. He also suggested that it caused confusion with another high profile campaign with which the NSPCC was involved - Children's Promise.

For him the lessons were: 1. The importance of transparency. 2. Marketing departments should be kept under control and 3. Some action needs to be taken on fundraising and campaign costs. Malcolm Dean suggested that the ball was in the Charity Commission's court. I think we, as a sector, need to get our acts together and respond to these issues before the regulator feels obliged to.

We tend to see ourselves as the critics, able to point to bad practice in the public or private sectors, seeing our own organisations as immune from criticism. This is now untenable. As local authorities attempt to improve their practice, in part through the implementation of best value, and as public authorities generally take on board human rights and anti -discrimination legislation, we may find that we are left behind. We do not have the same resources for review and change in our practices but we will need to find them. As the public sector becomes better at consultation, and providing services more tailored to local needs, as the private sector becomes more interested in social responsibility, our distinctiveness will be further called into question.

Government no longer tolerates questions about its funding or consultation habits without asking what voluntary organisations intend to do to improve their practice on a range of issues: diversity; partnership working; implementation of quality standards; involvement of beneficiaries. We are no longer assumed to be a good thing because we are voluntary or charitable, we need to demonstrate good practice across a range of operational issues. In part this comes from a climate in which sector (or legal structure) does not matter, what matters is acceptable process, effectiveness and results.

So how are we to respond to this environment? We should not assume that harking back to an era when the sector was less professional, less entrepreneurial will do us any good. To survive in the current climate and to secure the best possible services for beneficiaries we need to be both professional and entrepreneurial.

However, we need to make sure we are clear about the sort of commercial decisions we take and how they relate or impact on our charitable mission. A small scale research project undertaken by NCVO with younger people demonstrated that they admire entrepreneurialism in the voluntary or charitable sector when it is directed to a good social end (and perhaps we might add when the activity does not undermine this end as has sometimes been the allegation in relation to some sponsorship deals).

We need perhaps to think more critically about our contracting behaviour and how we relate to the statutory sector. For example, we as charities, if we are contracting with government for the provision of statutory services must be sure that the work falls within our mission and that costs are fully covered from the contract price. We need to ensure that charitable activity enhances or is additional to that provided by the state. While this is not technically a requirement of charity law, it is recommended practice by the charity commission in the interests of promoting public confidence in charitable giving.

There has been a tendency in voluntary sector literature to simplify some of the issues at stake here. Some peddle the view that joint working between voluntary organisations and government is by its very nature corrosive, that it erodes independence. I would argue that there have never been watertight boundaries between the sectors and that joint working between the sector and government is to be encouraged where it is likely to provide a better service for beneficiaries. We operate in a complex and fast moving environment and old certainties around voluntary sector good, government and the private sector bad have been eroded.

It is true that more joint working with government and more entrepreneurial or businesslike activity blurs the boundaries between the sectors so far as members of the public are concerned. However, we always need to keep in mind our independent and distinctive missions. We also need to build public understanding and awareness of the sector, how it works and and what it contributes. Many older people continue to have a very outdated view of who we are and how we operate.

Charities and other voluntary organisations need to think carefully about where their organisation is most at risk of having its reputation challenged or undermined. This is not alarmism but simply a reality of modern life and one that most trustees or management committee members are fully aware of.

This sort of challenge might take a variety of forms. It might relate to the ethical standards of an organisation, to standards of service provision or to operational policies and practices deemed not to be of the best.

We need to share and learn from best practice on employment, diversity, consultation, user involvement, quality standards. We are if anything expected to have higher standards in these areas than organisations in the public and private sectors. Disappointment when we are shown wanting is therefore greater and more damaging to our reputations.

I raised the issue of donors earlier - we also need to think carefully about our relationship with donors. Our research suggests that the information that we provide to the public is deemed inadequate. We might argue that there is a lot of it but perhaps it is the wrong information, in the wrong format. Again this is not an easy one to crack, many of you will say that marketing budgets are already overstretched. But perhaps it isn't about doing more but thinking more creatively about doing better.

Our work suggests that greater clarity and transparency is needed. We also need to increase public awareness of some basic facts:
 That it costs money to raise money.
 That new, small organisations will of course be spending a larger proportion of their income on fundraising because of the need to develop an income base. And in turn that these organisations are important because they can provide more appropriate, sensitive services - the old plaint that there are too many charities is a basic misunderstanding.
 That it costs money to run services and that cheeseparing may simply result in poor services or worthwhile organisations going bust at great cost to beneficiaries.

Statutory sector funders have a different take on it of course. However, increasingly they are asking questions about whether for example there is too little collaboration between voluntary organisations and therefore duplication and waste. They are asking whether we have become divorced from missions around exclusion and social justice, becoming organisations that simply chase whatever funding is available. Much of this is uninformed criticism of course but like all myths it has an element of truth.

Are we as good at collaborating as we might be? Until relatively recently it could be argued we were encouraged to compete - many years of competitive bidding for funds and shortage of money saw to that. Nonetheless, I have heard people in the sector hark back to happier times in the 1970s and the 1980s when the strong in the sector were more inclined to share resources with the weak. Maybe this is rosy nostalgia but nonetheless perhaps some of us could be doing more to support other smaller, less experienced voluntary organisations.

This isn't to say that the picture is bleak- of course it isn't - I am immensely proud of the sector and the contribution that it makes to society. I would not otherwise be doing the job that I do. In all the areas I have discussed particular organisations are developing and promoting excellent practice. But we should all look critically at ourselves and see if there are areas in which we might do even better.

There are some sectoral initiatives which have been developed by NCVO and others to help support orgganisations tackle some of the issues I have identified -
 The Quality Standards Board
Projects on Diversity being developed by NCVO and ACEVO
 The Giving with Confidence project which is examining fundraising ethics and seeks to promote public trust and confidence. (ICFM, CAF, ACEVO and NCVO are involved in this.)

Lets not be complacent - if we want to continue to grow in power and influence, able to do more and better for the people we were set up to serve than we can always to try to do a little better what we already do well.

We have a lot to celebrate, we are now in an enviable position compared to say 15, 20 years ago but this means more pressure on us rather than less, expectations are sky high. This also means more scrutiny and we need to be prepared for this.

In part this comes from a climate in which sector (or legal structure) does not matter, what matters is acceptable process, effectiveness and results. So how are we to respond to this environment? We should not assume that harking back to an era when the sector was less professional, less entrepreneurial will do us any good. To survive in the current climate and to secure the best possible services for beneficiaries we need to be both professional and entrepreneurial. However, we need to make sure we are clear about the sort of commercial decisions we take and how they relate or impact on our charitable mission. A small scale research project undertaken by NCVO with younger people demonstrated that they admire entrepreneurialism in the voluntary or charitable sector when it is directed to a good social end (and perhaps we might add when the activity does not undermine this end as has sometimes been the allegation in relation to some sponsorship deals). We need perhaps to think more critically about our contracting behaviour and how we relate to the statutory sector. For example, we as charities, if we are contracting with government for the provision of statutory services must be sure that the work falls within our mission and that costs are fully covered from the contract price. We need to ensure that charitable activity enhances or is additional to that provided by the state. While this is not technically a requirement of charity law, it is recommended practice by the charity commission in the interests of promoting public confidence in charitable giving. There has been a tendency in voluntary sector literature to simplify some of the issues at stake here. Some peddle the view that joint working between voluntary organisations and government is by its very nature corrosive, that it erodes independence. I would argue that there have never been watertight boundaries between the sectors and that joint working between the sector and government is to be encouraged where it is likely to provide a better service for beneficiaries. We operate in a complex and fast moving environment and old certainties around voluntary sector good, government and the private sector bad have been eroded. It is true that more joint working with government and more entrepreneurial or businesslike activity blurs the boundaries between the sectors so far as members of the public are concerned. However, we always need to keep in mind our independent and distinctive missions. We also need to build public understanding and awareness of the sector, how it works and and what it contributes. Many older people continue to have a very outdated view of who we are and how we operate. Charities and other voluntary organisations need to think carefully about where their organisation is most at risk of having its reputation challenged or undermined. This is not alarmism but simply a reality of modern life and one that most trustees or management committee members are fully aware of. This sort of challenge might take a variety of forms. It might relate to the ethical standards of an organisation, to standards of service provision or to operational policies and practices deemed not to be of the best. We need to share and learn from best practice on employment, diversity, consultation, user involvement, quality standards. We are if anything expected to have higher standards in these areas than organisations in the public and private sectors. Disappointment when we are shown wanting is therefore greater and more damaging to our reputations. I raised the issue of donors earlier - we also need to think carefully about our relationship with donors. Our research suggests that the information that we provide to the public is deemed inadequate. We might argue that there is a lot of it but perhaps it is the wrong information, in the wrong format. Again this is not an easy one to crack, many of you will say that marketing budgets are already overstretched. But perhaps it isn't about doing more but thinking more creatively about doing better. Our work suggests that greater clarity and transparency is needed. We also need to increase public awareness of some basic facts:  That it costs money to raise money.  That new, small organisations will of course be spending a larger proportion of their income on fundraising because of the need to develop an income base. And in turn that these organisations are important because they can provide more appropriate, sensitive services - the old plaint that there are too many charities is a basic misunderstanding.  That it costs money to run services and that cheeseparing may simply result in poor services or worthwhile organisations going bust at great cost to beneficiaries. Statutory sector funders have a different take on it of course. However, increasingly they are asking questions about whether for example there is too little collaboration between voluntary organisations and therefore duplication and waste. They are asking whether we have become divorced from missions around exclusion and social justice, becoming organisations that simply chase whatever funding is available. Much of this is uninformed criticism of course but like all myths it has an element of truth. Are we as good at collaborating as we might be? Until relatively recently it could be argued we were encouraged to compete - many years of competitive bidding for funds and shortage of money saw to that. Nonetheless, I have heard people in the sector hark back to happier times in the 1970s and the 1980s when the strong in the sector were more inclined to share resources with the weak. Maybe this is rosy nostalgia but nonetheless perhaps some of us could be doing more to support other smaller, less experienced voluntary organisations. This isn't to say that the picture is bleak- of course it isn't - I am immensely proud of the sector and the contribution that it makes to society. I would not otherwise be doing the job that I do. In all the areas I have discussed particular organisations are developing and promoting excellent practice. But we should all look critically at ourselves and see if there are areas in which we might do even better. There are some sectoral initiatives which have been developed by NCVO and others to help support orgganisations tackle some of the issues I have identified -  The Quality Standards Board Projects on Diversity being developed by NCVO and ACEVO  The Giving with Confidence project which is examining fundraising ethics and seeks to promote public trust and confidence. (ICFM, CAF, ACEVO and NCVO are involved in this.) Lets not be complacent - if we want to continue to grow in power and influence, able to do more and better for the people we were set up to serve than we can always to try to do a little better what we already do well. We have a lot to celebrate, we are now in an enviable position compared to say 15, 20 years ago but this means more pressure on us rather than less, expectations are sky high. This also means more scrutiny and we need to be prepared for this.

webTitle: Penguin cuts jobs

fields.headline: Penguin cuts jobs
fields.trailText: Penguin Books announced yesterday the loss of a further 120 jobs following its takeover of children's publishers Dorling Kindersle
fields.body:
Penguin Books announced yesterday the loss of a further 120 jobs following its takeover of children's publishers Dorling Kindersley.

This will bring the total number of redundancies since the merger was announced last May to over 300. The latest round of job losses mostly affect Penguin's children's publishing imprint Ladybird whose creative departments will merge with those of Dorling Kindersley. Ladybird's UK marketing and publicity teams will also be reorganised to make room for staff from DK.

Although the Ladybird name will survive, its Nottingham office will be closed with the loss of 11 jobs. Penguin also plans to merge the sales teams of the two companies, a move which will lead to the loss of around 40 jobs. The remaining cuts will be announced when the Penguin and DK offices are closed and the new joint offices in the Strand open later this year.

Chief executive of the Penguin Group Anthony Forbes Watson said the redundancies were "regrettable."

webTitle: Charities told to prepare for media scrutiny

fields.headline: Charities told to prepare for media scrutiny
fields.trailText: A charity chief has warned the voluntary sector today to smarten up its act. Stuart Etherington, chief executive of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO), said charities would be subject to increasing media scrutiny and that they needed to prepare for this.
fields.body:
A charity chief has warned the voluntary sector today to smarten up its act. Stuart Etherington, chief executive of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO), said charities would be subject to increasing media scrutiny and that they needed to prepare for this.

He told delegates at the annual Kingston Smith charity lecture in London that this was the flipside of a higher profile: "We are now in an enviable position compared to, say, 15 or 20 years ago but this means more pressure on us rather than less. Expectations are sky-high. This also means more scrutiny and we need to be prepared for this."

Journalists will treat charities in the same way as private or public bodies. "When we were perceived as David challenging Goliath, we could do no wrong," said Mr Etherington. But now that some voluntary organisations are operating as multimillion pound businesses, they are seen as being more powerful. In contrast to the public sector, he noted: "We cause concern because our power is not checked by accountability to a mass electorate."

To counter this potential criticism, Mr Etherington explained that NCVO had been working on a four-year programme examining trust and confidence in charities. From this research, he said: "The public now raises issues that we need to address, if we are to sustain a high approval rating." These key issues, he believes, are regulation, fundraising practice, independence and distinctiveness.

Mr Etherington said the public's perception that the sector is insufficiently regulated was unfair. "This has perhaps been promoted by media stories that focus on particular cases of abuse." He cited the recent coverage of financial irregularities at the charity War Child UK, which were exposed in The Guardian. He added: "Cases like War Child are, luckily, relatively rare."

Instead of more regulation being imposed from outside, Mr Etherington believes the sector should invest in self-regulation and develop high standards of practice in areas like fundraising.

NCVO's research has shown that the public wants to support charities because they are distinctive, but people are concerned that boundaries are becoming blurred. "There is also some disquiet about perceived increasing competitiveness for funds and aggressive fundraising," said Mr Etherington.

He told delegates that as the public sector becomes better at consultation and the private sector becomes more socially responsible, the distinctiveness of the voluntary sector could be further called into question.

Charities also need to demonstrate good practice in areas such as diversity and partnership working and be clear about commercial decisions. "We need to be both professional and entrepreneurial."

In relation to contracting with the statutory sector, Mr Etherington stated that charities must be sure that the work falls within their mission and that costs are fully covered from the contract price.

He urged bigger charities to do more to help smaller charities, sharing resources and collaborating on projects.

He also said that charities should think carefully about their relationship with donors. NCVO's research suggests that the public doesn't think the information charities provide is adequate. Mr Etherington acknowledged that marketing budgets are tight but said: "Perhaps it isn't about doing more, but thinking more creatively about doing better."

Overall, Mr Etherington said he was proud of what the sector had achieved but added that it did need to take a critical look at itself. "If we want to continue to grow in power and influence... we can always try to do a little better what we already do well."

 SocietyGuardian.co.uk will be providing full coverage of the NCVO annual conference on Wednesday, Feburary 7

webTitle: SAG nominations point to wide-open Oscar race

fields.headline: SAG nominations point to wide-open Oscar race
fields.trailText: With no film dominating the nominations for the Screen Actors Guild Awards, this year's Academy Award winners are becoming increasingly impossible to predict
fields.body:
Tuesday night's nominations for the Screen Actors Guild Awards failed to anoint a favourite in what is now shaping up as the most open Oscars in years. No fewer than five films - Almost Famous, Gladiator, Chocolat, The Contender and Britain's Billy Elliot - tied for first place with three nominations apiece. Erin Brockovich, Quills and Traffic lined up just behind, all sharing two nominations.

Alongside the Golden Globes, awarded earlier this month, the SAG awards are viewed as the most important Oscar indicators, with winners almost invariably going on to take the statues at the Academy Awards. The fact that Ridley Scott's Gladiator (pictured) appears to be duplicating its run of form at the Globes, where it took the Best Film Award, in the SAG nominations will no doubt encourage its supporters.

But the dark horse in the Oscar field remains the foreign-language Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon. Ang Lee's breakthrough martial arts picture was ruled out of the running for Best Film at the Globes (it took Best Foreign Film instead) and is ineligible for SAG riches. But some insiders are still tipping it to take the coveted Best Picture statue on Oscar night.

The SAG awards, which are given for acting prowess only, will be presented in Los Angeles on March 11. This year's nominations are as follows.

Best Actor: Russell Crowe (Gladiator), Geoffrey Rush (Quills), Tom Hanks (Cast Away), Benicio Del Toro (Traffic), Jamie Bell (Billy Elliot)

Best Actress: Joan Allen (The Contender), Juliette Binoche (Chocolat), Ellen Burstyn (Requiem For a Dream), Laura Linney (You Can Count on Me), Julia Roberts (Erin Brockovich)

Best Supporting Actor: Jeff Bridges (The Contender), Gary Oldman (The Contender), Willem Dafoe (Shadow of a Vampire), Albert Finney (Erin Brockovich), Joaquin Phoenix (Gladiator)

Best Supporting Actress: Kate Hudson (Almost Famous), Frances McDormand (Almost Famous), Kate Winslet (Quills), Julie Walters (Billy Elliot), Judi Dench (Chocolat)

Overall Cast: Almost Famous, Billy Eliot, Chocolat, Gladiator, Traffic

webTitle: Pret launches charm offensive

fields.headline: Pret launches charm offensive
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: Pret a Manger has unleashed a charm offensive as it prepares for criticism for selling a third of its business to McDonald's. By Julia Day.
fields.body:
Trendy sandwich bar Pret a Manger has unleashed a charm offensive on its customers as it prepares for an avalanche of criticism for selling a third of its business to McDonald's.

Visitors to Pret a Manger branches are being handed leaflets featuring a message signed by Julian Metcalfe, the chain's co-founder, outlining why he and partner Sinclair Beecham have linked with McDonald's, one of the world's most vilified brands.

In the leaflet, Mr Metcalfe seeks to reassure customers that the company, renowned for its corporate responsibility policies such as distributing unsold sandwiches to the homeless, has not sold out.

"Some may say we have sold out and that milkshakes and quarter pounders are on the way. This is of course, rubbish," he said.

"Our style of food, our people and culture will remain at the heart of what we do. It is unique and will remain that way."

The leaflet explains the reason for the deal: "We believe Pret could thrive beyond the UK, but every new country will be an enormous challenge. And it's not just about money. Knowledge and experience of new markets are as important.

"After a long search we have found how to build Pret a Manger overseas - in partnership with the parent company of McDonald's in Chicago.

But there was speculation in the City that McDonald's may seek to increase their stake, building up to an eventual takeover.

webTitle: Union attacked by Kaufman

fields.headline: Union attacked by Kaufman
fields.trailText: 3.15pm: Broadcasting union Bectu has been attacked by Gerald Kaufman over its "Luddite" attitudes concerning the BBC , writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Broadcasting union Bectu came under fire today from Gerald Kaufman, chairman of the culture, media and sport select committee, over its "Luddite" attitudes.

Mr Kaufman, refusing to mince words, said Bectu was trying too hard to defend the status quo and suggested the union had become the "defending council for the BBC".

He was speaking at the select committee hearings on the communications white paper during a representation from the union.

Throughout the Bectu session Mr Kaufman was seen yawning and barely able to keep his eyes open.

Bectu talked of an underfunded BBC that had a duty to fulfil its public service remit, and said it saw value in niche services.

Mr Kaufman questioned the union's resolve to defend public service broadcasting.

"Why do we need to be, in 2001, that protective about public service broadcasting, especially when the BBC is not that het up about protecting it itself?" he asked.

Bectu maintained that public service broadcasting retained a central role in the future of British broadcasting. However, the union did call for a more accountable BBC and a tighter public service broadcasting remit.

Bectu's submission to the committee was little more than a one-page series of bullet points, although Bectu president Tony Lennon did apologise for this, pointing out that the full submission was still being agreed upon internally.

The influential select committee was holding hearings to gauge industry reaction to last year's white paper.

Their findings will be presented to Chris Smith and the DCMS once all hearings have been concluded.

webTitle: Vodafone appoints cost-cutting chief

fields.headline: Vodafone appoints cost-cutting chief
fields.trailText:
2.15pm: Vodafone has appointed a chief operating officer who will take charge of cost-cutting measures, writes Dan Milmo.
Jan 31: Vodafone hands ad account to WCRS
fields.body:
Mobile phone giant Vodafone has appointed a chief operating officer who will take charge of cost-cutting measures at the group.

Julian Horn-Smith has been told to boost efficiency at Vodafone and find cost-saving initiatives.

Vodafone has spent billions of pounds on acquisitions and mobile phone licences over the past year, and is looking to recoup some of the costs.

"The strengthened management structure that we are putting in place, and the quality and experience of the team will ensure that Vodafone remains at the forefront of its industry," said Chris Gent, chief executive of Vodafone.

Despite today's announcement, Vodafone is unlikely to scale back on its strategy of bold acquisitions, with development of the Japanese market still a big priority.

webTitle: Crime crackdown targets repeat offenders

fields.headline: Crime crackdown targets repeat offenders
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Half of all crime in the UK is committed by around 100,000 persistent offenders, most of whom are unemployed hard drug users, according to Home Office research released today.
fields.body:
Half of all crime in the UK is committed by around 100,000 persistent offenders, most of whom are unemployed hard drug users, according to Home Office research released today.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, said that catching, prosecuting and sentencing "hardcore" offenders could cut crime in half and restore Britain's faith in the criminal justice system. He promised tougher sentences for persistent offenders, an expansion of the national DNA database and a £45m programme to deal with young offenders.

Mr Straw's comments follow the publication of the British crime survey 2000, which found that violent crime had risen by 8% although overall crime had fallen slightly over the last year.

In a speech to the Social Market Foundation today, Mr Straw said: "We have made radical reforms to the criminal justice system, including reforming the probation service to improve the effectiveness of community sentences, introducing new police powers to deal with offenders and making prisons work by teaching individuals basic skills to increase their employability.

"Our key aim remains to stop young people becoming persistent offenders in the first place, cutting the flow by tackling poor school behaviour, exclusion and truancy," he added.

Researchers found that most persistent offenders share a common profile. Half are under 21, nearly two-thirds are hard drug users, more than a third were in care as children, half have no qualifications and three-quarters are unemployed.

Within two years of starting a community sentence or finishing their prison sentence, over half of offenders are back in court to be convicted for further offences, the research shows. That number rises to nearly 80% for those with more than 10 previous convictions.

Mr Straw announced that a number of measures to tackle persistent offenders are being implemented, including a £45m investment over the next three years to set up a new intensive supervision and surveillance programme to deal with 2,500 of the most persistent young offenders.

He also wants to record every active offender on the national DNA database by 2004.

The main bulk of the British crime survey 2000 has already been published but findings relating to public confidence in the criminal justice system and policing were released for the first time today.

The statistics show that only 20% of people believe that the police do "a very good job" compared to 24% two years ago and the same number two years before. In 1982 the figure was 43%.

"Crime is down by 10% since 1997, but our criminal justice system has to become much more effective in dealing with crime and offenders if we are to make sustained reductions in the level of offending," Mr Straw said today.

The director general of the prison service, Martin Narey, said that he was confident that the system could cope with the increase in inmates which Mr Straw envisaged.

Mr Narey said although the prison service has some overcrowding, two new prisons at Ashford and Peterborough have relieved pressure. He added that government investment will allow for about 3,000 additional places in current prisons.

webTitle: TF1 pays £220m for Eurosport

fields.headline: TF1 pays £220m for Eurosport
fields.trailText: 2.30pm: French commercial broadcaster TF1 has taken full control of the Eurosport channel in a £220m deal, reports Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
Leading French commercial broadcaster TF1 has taken full control of the Eurosport channel in a £220m deal.

But the acquisition of a 49% stake from pay-TV rival Canal Plus was overshadowed by full-year results for TF1, which showed a downturn in advertising revenue growth in the final quarter of 2000.

TF1 said advertising revenues had grown by 16.2% last year, but analysts pointed out that ad income fell away in the last three months of the year, following 18% growth in the first nine months.

The broadcaster gave no predictions for the advertising market over the next 12 months, sparking a 2% fall in its share price in early trading.

Media companies have been queuing up since the end of last year to announce a fall in advertising growth, leading to a slump in confidence in media stocks.

This has been compounded by uncertainty over how long the downturn will continue.

However, TF1 said full-year, pre-tax profit rose 58% to £158m, in line with analysts' expectations and consolidating its position as the leading commercial television group in France.

The company is controlled by French telecoms firm Bouygues, which recently withdrew from the contest for next-generation mobile phone licences in France.

webTitle: TV ratings: January 30

fields.headline: Movie premiere pushes up C5 figures
fields.trailText: 5.15pm TV overnights: The terrestrial premiere of US Marshals helped C5 to its best daily viewing share of the year, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The terrestrial premiere of movie US Marshals last night helped Channel 5 to its best daily viewing share of the year to date.

The action thriller, which stars Tommy Lee Jones on the trail of Wesley Snipe's escaped murderer, went out in Channel 5's long-established 9pm movie slot.

US Marshals had 3.4m and a 19% share, according to unofficial overnights.

It was followed at 11.35pm by repeated documentary Murder Detectives, which drew a healthy 1.2m and an 18% share.

Overall, Channel 5 had a 7.9% share of viewing yesterday.

BBC2 natural history documentary Congo, billed as the BBC's first ever wildlife series from Central Africa, debuted strongly at 9pm last night.

The lavish documentary about the weird and wonderful creatures that inhabit the river Congo and the jungle wilderness surrounding it drew 3.6m and a 15% share.

BBC1's Clive Owen police drama Second Sight continues to struggle in the 9-10pm slot.

Last night it drew only 4.6m - fewer than one in five viewers - against ITV's Peak Practice, which took 8m.

webTitle: BBC in Lennox Lewis coup

fields.headline: BBC claims coup with Lennox Lewis deal
fields.standfirst: Special report: The BBC
fields.trailText:
2.15pm: The BBC is hailing its latest deal as a major broadside against Sky and ITV, reports Jessica Hodgson.
Jan 31: BBC confirms deal
Special report: The BBC
fields.body:
The BBC is claiming a major coup with its deal for exclusive live coverage of Lennox Lewis's heavyweight boxing title fight against Hasim Rahman.

"At last the nation as a whole will see the undisputed heavyweight champion of the world return to our living rooms," said BBC controller of sport Peter Salmon.

However, the contract does not cover what is expected to be the biggest box-office fight in Lewis's career - a bout with Mike Tyson.

The BBC deal is thought to be worth up to £1m per fight - a record for the corporation.

"It is not comparable to anything else," said Mr Salmon.

Lewis's decision to switch to the BBC comes after a seven-year relationship with Sky Sports.

However, it emerged today that the corporation did not launch a dawn raid on Sky, where interest in the boxer had waned.

Mr Salmon said Lewis suggested the idea of a move himself, when they met at last year's TV Sports Personality of the Year awards.

"At the awards last year, Lennox challenged me to bring boxing back to the BBC," he said.

BBC chiefs are touting the move as a major broadside against Sky and ITV.

The rival broadcasters have left the BBC's sports department in tatters after a series of raids over the past five years.

Last year, the corporation suffered its most crushing defeat with the loss of Premier League highlights to ITV.

Before that, it lost their biggest its sports star - Des Lynam - to ITV.

The corporation has also lost cricket, formula one and home Rugby Union matches.

However, Mr Salmon was less certain of the prospects of securing rights to the fight between Lewis and Mike Tyson.

That bout, if agreed, is likely to go to a satellite broadcaster because of the lucrative pay-per-view revenues that will be shared with the fighters and their promoters.

But Mr Salmon remained in bullish mood. "We've shown we can be competitive," he said. "I realise the Tyson-Lewis fight is in a different league but strange things can happen in sport."

The BBC will also televise Audley Harrison's first professional fight after his Olympic win on live TV last April.

Mr Salmon, who was previously controller of BBC 1, was brought in by BBC director-general Greg Dyke who has made the recapture of valuable sports rights one of his key goals.

webTitle: Lib Dems campaign

fields.headline: Lib Dem campaign claims moral high ground
fields.trailText: 3.45pm: The Liberal Democrats have 'jumped on injustice' in their first pre-election ad, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats have kicked off their pre-election campaign with an ad that shows party leader Charles Kennedy taking the moral high ground.

In an undisguised dig at rivals Tony Blair and William Hague, Mr Kennedy is pictured beside the line, "I jump on injustice, not bandwagons".

The poster, created by the Liberal Democrats' ad agency BANC, sets out the party's intention to fight an honest campaign based on real issues.

"The Liberal Democrats realise a schoolboy scrap is not advancing the cause of democracy," said BANC chairman Robert Bean.

"Charles and the party are taking a leadership stance with this message by setting a more relevant agenda."

The Liberal Democrats appointed BANC last month to handle all their pre-election communications.

fields.headline: The case verdict: extracts
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Lockerbie trial
Full text of the judges' verdict (pdf file)
fields.trailText:
Extracts from the verdict
"It is not disputed, and was amply proved, that the cause of the disaster was indeed the explosion of a device within the aircraft The matter at issue in this trial therefore is whether or not the crown [prosecution service] have proved beyond reasonable doubt that one or other or both of the accused was responsible for the deliberate introduction of the device."
fields.body:
Extracts from the verdict
"It is not disputed, and was amply proved, that the cause of the disaster was indeed the explosion of a device within the aircraft The matter at issue in this trial therefore is whether or not the crown [prosecution service] have proved beyond reasonable doubt that one or other or both of the accused was responsible for the deliberate introduction of the device."

"The evidence which we have considered up to this stage satisfies us beyond reasonable doubt that the cause of the disaster was the explosion of an improvised explosive device, that that device was contained within a Toshiba radio cassette player in a brown Samsonite suitcase along with various items of clothing, that that clothing had been purchased in Mary's House, Sliema, Malta, and that the initiation of the explosion was triggered by the use of an MST-13 timer."

"From the evidence which we have discussed so far, we are satisfied that it has been proved that the primary suitcase containing the explosive device was dispatched from Malta, passed through Frankfurt and was loaded onto PA103 at Heathrow."

Evidence against Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah, found not guilty
"The principal piece of evidence against him comes from two entries in his 1988 diary The crown maintained that the inference to be drawn from these entries was that the second accused had obtained Air Malta interline tags for the first accused, and that as an airline employee he must have known that the only purpose for which they would be required was to enable an unaccompanied bag to be placed on an aircraft.

"There is no doubt that the second accused did make the entries in the diary to which we have referred. In the context of the explosive device being placed on KM180 at Luqa in a suitcase which must have had attached to it an interline tag to enable it to pass eventually on to PA103, these entries can easily be seen to have a sinister connotation, particularly in the complete absence of any form of explanation.

"While therefore there may well be a sinister inference to be drawn from the diary entries, we have come to the conclusion that there is insufficient other acceptable evidence to support or confirm such an inference, in particular an inference that the second accused was aware that any assistance he was giving to the first accused was in connection with a plan to destroy an aircraft by the planting of an explosive device."

Evidence against Abdelbaset Al Megrahi, found guilty
"We are aware that in relation to certain aspects of the case there are a number of uncertainties and qualifications. We are also aware that there is a danger that by selecting parts of the evidence which seem to fit together and ignoring parts which might not fit, it is possible to read into a mass of conflicting evidence a pattern or conclusion which is not really justified.

"However, having considered the whole evidence in the case, including the uncertainties and qualifications, and the submissions of counsel, we are satisfied that the evidence as to the purchase of clothing in Malta, the presence of that clothing in the primary suitcase, the transmission of an item of baggage from Malta to London, the identification of the first accused (albeit not absolute), his movements under a false name at or around the material time, and the other background circumstances such as his association with Mr Bollier and with members of the JSO or Libyan military who purchased MST-13 timers, does fit together to form a real and convincing pattern.

"There is nothing in the evidence which leaves us with any reasonable doubt as to the guilt of the first accused, and accordingly we find him guilty of the remaining charge in the Indictment as amended."

On whether there was Palestinian involvement in the bombing
"The clear inference which we draw from this evidence is that the conception, planning and execution of the plot which led to the planting of the explosive device was of Libyan origin.

"While no doubt organisations such as the PFLP-GC and the PPSF were also engaged in terrorist activities during the same period, we are satisfied that there was no evidence from which we could infer that they were involved in this particular act of terrorism, and the evidence relating to their activities does not create a reasonable doubt in our minds about the Libyan origin of this crime."

webTitle: Collymore signs for Oviedo

fields.headline: Collymore signs for Oviedo
fields.trailText: Stan Collymore has signed for Spanish club Real Oviedo from Bradford on a free transfer.
fields.body:
Stan Collymore has signed for Spanish club Real Oviedo from Bradford on a free transfer.

Collymore, who finally agreed a one-and-a-half year contract after 12 hours of negotiations yesterday, will be unveiled at a news conference tonight after undergoing a medical.

There was a slight delay in proceedings when Collymore's flight was forced to return to Madrid because of turbulence. However, the club are expecting him to arrive in Oviedo by car later today.

An Oviedo spokesman said: "Collymore has signed for this season and next. He will be presented to the media at 7pm."

Oviedo hope Collymore will make his debut for them in Sunday's game at Las Palmas. The club, who are coached by former Luton midfielder Raddy Antic, currently 13th in La Liga.

webTitle: 'There has been no great sense of anticipation'

fields.headline: 'There has been no great sense of anticipation'
fields.standfirst: On the day of the fateful verdict, the town ripped apart by Pan Am 103 is eschewing resentment and looking ahead to the future, says Kirsty Scott in Lockerbie
fields.trailText: On the day of the fateful verdict, the town ripped apart by Pan Am 103 is eschewing resentment and looking ahead to the future, says Kirsty Scott in Lockerbie.
fields.body:
There is no sense of triumph in this town today. The pain of the past and the desire to move on are too strong for rejoicing or recrimination.

In truth, the dry words of the judgment had little impact in Lockerbie. This quiet market community does not dwell on the past even though it lives always with the memories and it has kept itself remote from the global intrigue of the trial.

"There has been no great sense of anticipation of this," said Marjory McQueen, one of the two local councillors who witnessed the disaster. "We stand always in the shadow of the relatives. It is them who have fought for this and pushed for this. All our thoughts are with them today and we hope for some it might bring closure."

In his home on the edge of town close to the garden of remembrance where the names of all 270 who died are etched in cold, grey granite, Jim Manson listened quietly as the verdict was announced live on radio. On the night of December 21, 1998, he was called out with his mountain rescue team to scour the countryside for victims.

He did not have to look far. Lockerbie had been engulfed by a storm of noise and fire and wreckage and bodies, and much of what he saw is beyond imagining. He found 20 victims lying in fields around Tundergarth farm where the nose cone of the Maid of the Seas came to rest.

He had brought his first aid kit in case there were any survivors but used the bandages as macabre makeshift flags to mark where the victims lay. "I don't feel anything about this judgment, really," he said "It may mean a lot to some of those who had relatives on the plane. They are the ones that you feel for. I don't think it will be an end of all of this but I hope the town will be left alone to move on."

Eleven Lockerbie residents died when their houses were destroyed by the wreckage of Pan Am 103. The craters have been filled in and new homes built and up at Dryfedale cemetery where the dead of the disaster are remembered, there is work to dig new graves as life moves relentlessly on.

"We have a whole primary school of children who were not even born when this happened," said Marjory McQueen. "We are 12 years on and Lockerbie is a normal market town which is working away as it did before that night in December we need to be left now to carry on with our lives."

webTitle: Carling to rejoin Premier League action

fields.headline: Carling set to rejoin Premier League action
fields.trailText:
2pm update: Carling is set to re-enter talks to sponsor the Premier League but faces stiff competition from Pepsi, writes Julia Day.
Jan 31: Budweiser pulls out
fields.body:
Carling is set to re-enter talks to sponsor the Premier League but faces stiff competition from soft drinks giant Pepsi.

Bass-owned Carling, the league's existing sponsor, pulled out of negotiations to renew its deal two weeks ago, blaming "protracted" negotiations.

But Bass head of sponsorship Stephen Cain said that if the Premier League approached Carling with a fresh proposal it would be considered.

Mr Cain said Carling was already considering other ways of spending its £30m marketing budget for the coming year.

The company is to increase its spend on TV advertising along with greater investment in music sponsorship - it currently sponsors the Reading and Leeds music festivals and the NME Carling Awards.

Mr Cain said football would remain part of the brand's strategy and that new deals were being considered.

But sports marketing sources believe Carling pulled out of the Premier League deal in order to drive the price down, and a return to the negotiating table could be imminent.

Pepsi is also believed to be a hot contender for the sponsorship deal. It would also challenge arch-rival Coca-Cola, which is involved in football sponsorship.

Anheuser-Busch brand Budweiser is understood to have pulled out of its bid to become the next sponsor of the Premier League after concerns about lack of control over advertising at football grounds.

But Anheuser-Busch marketing director Kerry Bebe said: "Budweiser is committed to supporting football on a global scale. Contrary to rumours and speculation, we were not involved in the final bidding process for the Premier League sponsorship."

A Premier League spokesman said the body was entering the final stages of negotiation for the sponsorship with a number of companies but refused to identify them.

webTitle: Charities flourish online

fields.headline: Charities flourish online
fields.trailText: While the commercial world is littered with dot.gones, the charity world still has reasons to be cheerful, writes Nicola Hill
fields.body:
While the commercial world is littered with dot.gones, the charity world still has reasons to be cheerful. Last week, the Charities Aid Foundation (CAF) announced that it had raised £1m through its websites. Next week, a new website is launched to help cut charity costs and another site has been launched as a precursor to a charity recruitment event in August.

The CAF website had already brought in £700,000 before the umbrella organisation launched its All About Giving site four months ago, and has now netted a further £300,000 for charities. The new site explains how donors can give to charities in a tax-efficient way and allows charities to sign up even if they don't have their own website.

Charities add themselves to the online database and sign up to accept donations through CAF's CharityCard and Give As You Earn scheme.

The head of new media at CAF, Sarah Hughes, said: "All About Giving enables donors to identify a particular charity, to learn more about its work and ultimately to make a donation. In turn, it allows charities to build close and more fruitful relationships with donors."

Next Wednesday, charitybuyer goes live. It aims to be a one-stop shop detailing goods and services to the voluntary sector from telecoms to travel. The site allows users to exchange personal recommendations of good suppliers and give them a rating.

Director of charitybuyer, Matthew Nimmo, said: "Charity staff are always under pressure to get three quotes for every purchase. Now they can find out which suppliers are recommended by other charities. Over time we will put pressure on businesses to provide better deals."

Meanwhile, those who haven't achieved their new year's resolution of finding a job can click on to forum3, from February onwards, to search for a vacancy and learn about a charity recruitment event to be held in August this year.

Hosted by Charity People, the recruitment fair will feature a keynote speaker, Meredith Belbin, who will talk about getting and keeping the right staff. Other seminars will cover career development, global opportunities and HR issues. If these are full, delegates will be able to attend "virtual seminars" through a cyber area.

Charities with vacancies will be exhibiting at the event, so candidates can talk to potential employers, and some will be conducting interviews on the day.

Whether its shopping, job hunting or giving - there is a site out there waiting for your clicks.

webTitle: Lockerbie: the Palestinian dimension

fields.headline: Lockerbie: the Palestinian dimension
fields.standfirst: As 12 years of political manoeuvring over the Lockerbie bombing came to an end at Camp Zeist today, Derek Brown looks at the Middle Eastern loose ends
fields.trailText: As 12 years of political manoeuvring over the Lockerbie bombing came to an end at Camp Zeist today, Derek Brown looks at the Middle Eastern loose ends
fields.body:
In the byzantine world of Palestinian paramilitary politics, few players are as obscure, or as ruthless, as Ahmed Jabril, leader of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine-General Command (PFLP-GC).

The preposterous title reveals something of the constantly shifting, often murderous world of Palestinian exile guerrilla groups. The PFLP is one of the oldest of such groups. The '-GC' is to distinguish Jabril's faction from the parent body, led by his one time mentor, George Habash.

Fingers of suspicion have pointed at the PFLP-GC ever since the Lockerbie disaster. Jabril, in a rare public pronouncement, flatly denied involvement only days after the blast, but disturbing questions remain.

Not the least of these centre on the attitude of British and American officials who seem obsessively concerned to divert suspicion from Syria, where Jabril is based, and Iran, where the regime gives him a good deal of backing.

The west has been keen for years to woo Damascus and Tehran. They want to isolate Saddam Hussein of Iraq, who is seen as the most destabilising influence in the region. Blaming Jabril's outfit for the Lockerbie blast would draw attention to his close dependency on the Damascus regime.

Jabril's very life mirrors the mad tangle of Middle East affairs and the region's constantly shifting loyalties. He was born in what is now Israel, in a village close to the Mediterranean port of Jaffa, but his family were driven into exile during the first Arab-Israeli war in 1948.

They eventually settled in Syria, near Quneitra on the Golan Heights, from which the young Jabril could have gazed down on the Zionist enemy.

He completed his education in a military academy, graduating as an officer skilled in explosives. But after brief service with the Syrian army, he took up his life's vocation of fighting for Palestine.

He formed the National Front for the Liberation of Palestine in the early 1960s, but then was drawn to the revolutionary rhetoric of the PFLP in 1967.

Within a year he broke away, disillusioned by the group's constant politicking. Jabril wanted action.

He believed then, and there is not a shred of evidence that he has tempered that view, that Israel must be destroyed by military action, where necessary against civilian targets.

His small group - most analysts speak of a membership of "several hundreds" - does not hesitate to mount attacks within Israel. Once they achieved notoriety by sending in a suicide squad dangling from motorised hang gliders.

Jabril is a stalwart of the so called Rejection Front - the hardline Palestinian groups, both Islamist and secular, which reject any compromise with Israel and repudiate the leadership of Palestinian president Yasser Arafat.

Another of those groups, even more shadowy than Jabril's, is the Palestinian Popular Struggle Front (PPSF). It, too, is headquartered in Damascus, where it enjoys the protection, if not the patronage of the Syrian regime.

The Lockerbie court heard that PPSF member Mohammed Abu Talb, presently in prison in Sweden, was a bomb expert who had close links with PFLP-GC activists in Germany.

During police raids on the homes of the latter group, several bombs were found, similar to the device which destroyed Flight 103.

webTitle: BBC confirms Lewis fight deal

fields.headline: BBC confirms Lewis fight deal
fields.standfirst: Special report: The BBC
fields.trailText:
1pm: The BBC has confirmed its deal to cover Lennox Lewis's heavyweight title fight against Hasim Rahman in April.
Jan 31: BBC set to win Lennox deal
Special report: The BBC
fields.body:
The BBC has confirmed its deal for exclusive live coverage of Lennox Lewis's world heavyweight title defence against Hasim Rahman in April.

And the corporation has also "taken an option on other fights" after his date with Rahman on April 21.

Lewis-Rahman will be broadcast live on BBC1, Radio 5 Live and BBC Sport Online, and repeated in full on BBC TV.

"Millions of fight fans will be delighted to get the chance to see their hero, already a legend in the heavyweight championship story, free of charge and uninterrupted for the first time," said BBC director of sport Peter Salmon.

"The BBC has backed up its commitment to primetime boxing by making Lennox a boxing and promotional offer that he could not refuse," added Lewis's business manager Adrian Ogun.

The deal represents a return to big-time boxing for the BBC, which, in former days, used to show delayed coverage of Britain's top bouts on its Wednesday Sportsnight programme.

Live coverage of top fights has been off terrestrial screens since 1995 when promoter Frank Warren left ITV and took his boxers to BSkyB.

Lewis first linked up with BSkyB in April 1992 with coverage of his British, European and Commonwealth title clash with Derek Williams at the Royal Albert Hall.

Since then BSkyB has covered Lewis right through until his last title defence against David Tua in Las Vegas in November.

The only exception was Lewis's sole professional defeat against Oliver McCall at Wembley in September 1994.

That period of satellite coverage included Lewis's two fights with former champion Evander Holyfield, the second bout giving Lewis the heavyweight crown.

"I'm delighted that the BBC has given me a wonderful opportunity to give back to all these loyal British fans and licence-fee payers who have supported me at home and abroad," Lewis said.

The BBC recently signed Olympic champion Audley Harrison in a two-year deal covering at least 10 fights. Harrison, after recovering from a hand operation, looks set to have the first of those in the spring.

webTitle: US network to screen live births

fields.headline: US TV network to screen live births
fields.trailText: 1.30pm: ABC is to make broadcasting history by televising the first live childbirth next week, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
A major US TV network is hoping to make broadcasting history by screening the first live childbirth next week.

The move pushes the boundaries of reality TV to a new limit.

ABC has persuaded three US hospitals to allow cameras into their delivery rooms next Tuesday morning.

The producers of ABC show Good Morning America are hoping they will be able to televise several deliveries during the two-hour slot.

To be sure of success, the producers have chosen to conduct the broadcast on a Tuesday, the day of the week when women are statistically most likely to give birth.

One of the three hospitals involved in the project, Parkland Memorial Hospital in Dallas, has the highest number of births in the US, according to ABC.

ABC originally hoped to broadcast the deliveries in November. However, the broadcasts were postponed because of the extended coverage of the presidential election.

Seven mothers gave birth during the slot originally scheduled for the November broadcast.
