webTitle: Refugees dumped in unfit homes

fields.headline: Refugees dumped in unfit homes
fields.standfirst: A shocking new report by housing charity Shelter reveals that many asylum seekers have been placed in appalling housing
fields.trailText: A shocking new survey by housing charity Shelter reveals that many asylum seekers have been placed in appalling housing
fields.body:
Mr Rachman is back, and he's letting out rooms to asylum seekers. That is the damning conclusion of a new report from Shelter which details the appalling housing conditions that many refugees who have fled to the UK are living in.

The study is based on results collected by environmental health officers from five local authorities in the course of their inspections. They found that one in six of the dwellings visited was unfit for human habitation, mostly because the properties were in a poor state of repair and had unsatisfactory cooking facilities. But the officers also found adolescent girls lodged in hostels with adult men and children living without adults to care for them.

Carlena Thomas, chairwoman of the Chartered Institute of Environmental Health's working party on asylum issues, said her colleagues across the country have discovered instances of asylum seekers living in damp infested homes with little or no heating, where the walls are lined with black mould giving rise to breathing problems.

Deborah Garvie, who wrote the Shelter report, said the decision to undertake the study was triggered by the charity's housing advice centres reporting an upsurge in the number of asylum seekers using their services. "We heard increasing stories of asylum seekers being housed in sub-standard accommodation," she said.

Between 1997-98 and 1999-00, the number of refugee clients nearly tripled from 1,276 to 3,365. This increase occurred after the 1996 Asylum and Immigration Act, which denied refugees access to social housing, began to bite.

The near Victorian standards uncovered by the council officers tended to be concentrated in bedsits and houses in multiple occupation (HMOs). Nearly nine out of ten HMOs and around half of bedsits housing asylum seekers and inspected were deemed to be unfit, with 80% of the former exposed to unacceptable risk of fire.

In nearly a third of cases, the report says there were more individuals sleeping in a home than beds to accommodate them.

The report also says that asylum seekers, who are fresh to this country, may be less wary than their UK counterparts about the hazards lying in wait in unfit housing. These include faulty gas appliances and flammable furniture, two of the biggest causes of death by fire. To compound the problem, language barriers may lead to delays in evacuating buildings when fires break out. But the oppressive conditions that refugees have fled from make many too frightened to complain.

Their legal position gives them good cause for concern. Under the support arrangements introduced in last year's Asylum and Immigration Act, refugees have no security of tenure or protection from eviction. As a result, those who leave the accommodation because it is sub-standard can be deemed "intentionally destitute" and therefore no longer entitled to housing.

The report blames the depth of the problem on the fact that, following the 1996 Asylum and Immigration Act, responsibility for housing asylum seekers was transferred from housing departments to their colleagues in social services. It says: "The wealth of experience and knowledge developed by local housing authorities and other housing providers has been bypassed."

Many departments, particularly in the south-east and London where housing is expensive, entered into contracts with private landlords in other parts of the country to house their clients. Rental payments were guaranteed by social services department. "It's an absolutely ideal opportunity for landlords to make money," said Garvie. This is partly because they have fewer rights than other private tenants, and so are less likely to complain.

The housing of refugees far from the council responsible for them means that in many cases few checks have been conducted to ensure that the accommodation they are being sent to is up to scratch.

The poor conditions that asylum seekers are forced to accept also has the unintended consequence of undermining efforts by environmental health officers to drive up standards in the sector, the report says. Ms Garvie said: "Good local authorities have been trying to clean up the private rented sector and they had got to the point that landlords were finding it difficult to let sub-standard property. Now the landlords are finding a new market for these properties."

The report was based on evidence collected when the 1996 Asylum and Immigration Act introduced by the last government was still in place. But it warns that the situation may not get any better with the introduction of the new National Asylum Support Service (NASS), set up following last year's act. Based in Croydon, NASS has the job of procuring and allocating accommodation for asylum seekers nationwide.

The new agency, which is responsible for implementing the controversial policy of dispersing asylum seekers throughout the UK, still intends to rely on the private rented sector to house destitute refugees. The report says: "There is a danger that NASS may repeat the mistakes previously made by local authorities which have been graphically illustrated in this report."

NASS has signed contracts with a number of public and private bodies, including private landlords, to provide accommodation. Small landlords could be signed up to become sub-contractors without any checks being made of their past record.

In addition, the very policy of dispersal threatens to replicate the conditions of overcrowding that the report finds many asylum seekers are living in now. "Forced dispersal may only serve to create a hidden population of homeless and badly housed asylum seekers in the capital," the report says.

Evidence collected by the Local Government Association shows that many asylum seekers are reluctant to leave the capital for housing provided elsewhere in the country. Between December and March 2000, nearly half of all households offered resettlement in other parts of the country refused offers of accommodation with the result that they forfeited their right to housing. The result, says Shelter, is that many asylum seekers are living in overcrowded private rented accommodation with friends and family.

Alison Fenney, head of policy at the Refugee Council, said there were simply not enough mechanisms in place to ensure that dispersed asylum seekers do not continue ending up in poor housing conditions. She is not hopeful that the appalling conditions detailed in the report will improve: "We don't have much evidence that things are getting any better."

The result, says Shelter, is that many asylum seekers are living in overcrowded private rented accommodation with friends and family. Alison Fenney, head of policy at the Refugee Council, said there were simply not enough mechanisms in place to ensure that dispersed asylum seekers do not continue ending up in poor housing conditions. She is not hopeful that the appalling conditions detailed in the report will improve: "We don't have much evidence that things are getting any better."

webTitle: Obituary: John Prebble

fields.headline: John Prebble
fields.standfirst: Historian and writer who dramatised Scotland's struggles
fields.trailText: Historian and writer who wrote the script for the 1964 film Zulu, about the defence of the Rorke's Drift mission in Natal in 1879 by a small group of British soldiers facing 4,000 Zulus
fields.body:
When the journalist, historian and novelist John Prebble, who has died aged 85, was a young soldier in the British army during the second world war, he carried in his paybook the proud words of a 17th-century agitator who had also been in the army: "If we had not a right to the kingdom we were mere mercenaries." It was the explanation both of his then membership of the Communist party, and a vivid illustration of his readiness to let history - especially the brutalities of the English against the Scots, and the Scots against the Scots - into his work and everyday affairs.

Though Prebble was born in Middlesex, spent much of his boyhood in Canada, and latterly lived in London and Surrey, it was his books on the Culloden massacre, and other bloodstained episodes of Scottish history engineered by Cromwell and a succession of English monarchs, that were his chief claim to fame and literary achievement.

He acknowledged that academics distrusted his methods, which entailed face-to-face interviews, visits to battlefields and the minute examination of forgotten tombstones, in order to personalise and dramatise the past. He also acknowledged that the events of the Scottish past sprang more easily to his mind than events in his own personal history.

He could link his own experiences of invading Germany with the brutalities centuries previously of the English rich forcing poor crofters off the Highlands to make way for lucrative sheep grazing - the subject of his 1963 book, The Highland Clearances - without affectation or bathos. His cold head and hot passion may have been uneasy companions, but produced a high order of exact description of places and events, mixed with telling human concern.

With nearly 20 published books, selling millions - and some in print for more than 30 years - Prebble was perhaps one of the last dual masters of newspaper journalism and literature. He kept pace with the times by also writing and filming for television.

Probably his greatest impact on the popular imagination came through the 1964 film, Zulu, about the defence of the Rorke's Drift mission, in Natal, in 1879, by a small group of British soldiers facing 4,000 Zulus. The director, Cy Endfield, got the idea from reading an article by Prebble, and invited him to co-write the film.

Prebble came originally of Scottish stock. After the Reformation, the Prebbles became dissenters; Abraham Prebble fled to America in 1636. John's own father, a naval man who became an unskilled labourer and a Smithfield porter, took his family to Saskatchewan in 1921 in the hope of better things, when the boy was six.

They did not arrive: all America was going into the great depression. Prebble and his family returned back in Britain with the help of a high anglican vicar, who had married them in Shoreditch and offered to employ them as caretakers in his Earls Court church hall. Prebble sensed a condescending implication that God was in a social class rather above their own, and became a non-believer.

Though he had a short story published in the Boy's Own paper for nine guineas - on the mummified head of Roderick Mackenzie, at one time thought to be that of the Prince Charles Edward - Prebble had no further successs at that time.

On leaving Latymer school, for which he had gained a scholarship, he took a job as clerk with a south London estate agent. Having to collect rents from slum properties pushed him towards communism. But when he offered his services to the republicans in the Spanish civil war, he was told not to bother: the Communist party had lost many middle-class people like him and now needed working-class martyrs - a cynicical attitude that Prebble well remembered when he broke with the party some years later.

Answering a Daily Telegraph advertisement in 1934, he joined Century Press as a reporter on what was to be a rival to the Draper's Record. Using classic reporters' wiles, without realising he was doing so, he found out where the influential Sears Roebuck fashion buyer was staying in London, and interviewed him. He stayed for four years and was then conscripted into the forces.

Prebble's was a strange war. A bespectacled communist culture-vulture with a serious manner and chilling politeness, he was not a likely soldier, but seems to have had an indestructable, if not charmed, life.

Sent to an anti-aircraft training regiment in North Wales, he found the camp a bizarre home-from-home for much of the war - in the course of which, with the Royal Artillery, he switched to radar engineering; returned to his unit from an officers' training course at his own request; was arrested for possible sedition - a charge later reduced to conduct prejudicial to good order and discipline - for signing a petition demanding a second front to ease the pressure on Russia; and was looked at askance for creating the first wallpaper in the British army, for selling copies of the Daily Worker and for organising political debates among the men.

In 1945, unsupervised on secret radar work, Prebble jumped aboard an invasion boat heading for Holland and worked his way through to Germany with the army. This gave him the inspiration to write. He mistrusted the role of conqueror and noted with bleak compassion and dry, almost imperceptible, humour the ways of both conquerors and conquered.

Irma Grese, the sadistic Nazi concentration camp officer, spat in his face after luring him to the wire fence of the camp in which she herself was now confined: Prebble's description of the incident gained from his apparent lack of emotion. Much of all this was thought too "serious" for the Soldier newspaper, though some of his material was used; he joined the British army newspaper unit in Hamburg at the end of the war as sergeant-reporter.

His decency and lack of easy sentimentality shone through his war writings, and gave the impetus for two war novels and his first published novel, Where The Sea Breaks, in which the crew of a German aircraft take over a small Scottish island on which they have crashed. The book did not bring fame or fortune.

Briefly, Lord Beaverbrook advanced Prebble's journalistic career, employing him either despite, or mischeviously because, he was a communist. Spirited to what he called "this dissembling little man's" south of France villa, and told to write a story for the Daily Express about the rebirth of Monaco after the war, Prebble started his story with the blunt statement that the only building in Monaco that did not look rundown was the offices of the Communist party.

Beaverbrook queried it, but published the piece. Later, an editor who had not been consulted about his appointment fired him. Prebble, not an easy subject for seduction, was glad to go. "I cannot say I ever liked this man," was Prebble's curt dismissal of Beaverbrook.

But he had got his foot into Fleet Street, and worked for the Daily Mail and others as columnist, feature writer and reporter until 1960, when his books and dramatisations for radio and television, mainly on Scotland and its troubles, took over. He was widely praised for helping to restore Scottish self-worth. His semi-autobiography, Landscapes and Memories, won the McVitie's Prize for 1993 Scottish Writer of the Year.

In 1936, he married Betty Goldby, by whom he had two sons and one daughter. In 1994, after his first wife's death, he married Jan Reid, who survives him.

 John Prebble, writer and historian, born June 23 1915; died January 30 2001

webTitle: Boy George slams 'safe' radio stations

fields.headline: Boy George slams 'safe' radio stations
fields.trailText: 11.45am: Commercial radio stations have come under fire from pop stars for putting out 'safe' material, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Commercial radio stations last night came under fire from pop stars and senior record industry executives for putting out "safe" material.

Emap Performance managing director Dee Ford was accused by former Culture Club frontman Boy George of "putting out some really safe stuff".

"Radio stations have a responsibility to be creative," George added. "You are in the middle of the process. You get to decide what audiences get to hear."

Steve Strange, formerly lead singer with new romantic band Visage, spoke of the need for radio stations to give more airplay to bands that have grown organically, rather than being created by record industry executives.

"It's about time we had another band like the Sex Pistols who make us proud to be British," he said.

But Ms Ford defended the commercial radio sector against accusations that they favour bland manufactured music over "real" pop.

"Commercial radio stations don't have a responsibility to break acts," she said.

The row erupted at GM:Pop, a debate about manufactured pop bands and their role in the music industry, organised by the producers of Popstars, the hit ITV show about the creation of a manufactured group.

webTitle: FDA approves metal heart

fields.headline: FDA approves metal heart
fields.standfirst: 20 years' research may have produced transplant breakthrough
fields.trailText: A US biotechnology company has won permission from regulators to implant metal hearts in a handful of critically ill patients, in a unique trial which could lead to a breakthrough for transplant technology.
fields.body:
A US biotechnology company has won permission from regulators to implant metal hearts in a handful of critically ill patients, in a unique trial which could lead to a breakthrough for transplant technology.

Massachusetts-based Abiomed has been working for 20 years on its heart, called AbioCor. The organ is made of titanium and plastic, and is about the size of a grapefruit.

News that the food and drug administration has given the go-ahead for trials in five patients sent Abiomed's shares up more than $6 (410p) to just over $25 in early trading, adding $120m to the company's market value. Ed Berger, Abiomed's vice-president of external relations, said: "As far as we know, it will be the first time an implantable artificial heart has been tried in a clinical study."

The FDA said one other firm had permission to transplant an artificial heart, although it refused to disclose the identity of the company.

Most previous man-made hearts had involved connecting the body to an external machine "about the size of a refrigerator". This technology is still occasionally used by patients awaiting a transplant.

More than 100,000 critically ill patients would benefit from a heart transplant each year in the US. However, only about 2,000 hearts are donated annually for operations.

Mr Berger said: "Hospitals want to use the hearts available as frugally and effectively as possible - which means they tend to be reserved for the healthiest people. People who are older, or have other medical conditions, often lose out."

Abiomed already sells a less sophisticated implant, called BVS5000, which helps weak hearts to pump blood around the body. That was launched after tests on just 31 patients, and Mr Berger said he believed AbioCor could reach the market after a similar number of trials.

"We need to demonstrate that it extends life, and that it improves the quality of life," he said.

Abiomed is yet to put an exact price on its hearts, although they are likely to cost tens of thousands of dollars. Mr Berger said the company aimed to make a transplant with an artificial heart no more expensive than an operation involving a human heart - which, including after-care, typically amounts to between $150,000 and $200,000.

Kurt Kruger, an analyst at Bank of America in New York, said: "Medical companies have been trying this for decades and this looks like one that's going to make it."

webTitle: Obituary: Jean-Pierre Aumont

fields.headline: Jean-Pierre Aumont
fields.standfirst: Heart-throb French actor with a string of film hits
fields.trailText: Heart-throb French actor with a string of film hits.
fields.body:
In 1934, the tall, handsome, blond-haired and blue-eyed Jean-Pierre Aumont, who has died aged 92, auditioned for the lead in Marc Allégret's Lac aux Dames. As the role was that of a swimming instructor at a mountain lake resort, the director and his lover, André Gide, felt justified in asking the young French actor to strip. Aumont was immediately offered the part that made him a star. In the film, he is involved with three women; a former girlfriend, a rich socialite and a mysterious child of nature, Simone Simon.

It reflected Aumont's own life, in which he had the reputation as a ladies' man. While in Hollywood, he had brief flings with Joan Crawford, Grace Kelly and Barbara Stanwyck, and was engaged to Hedy Lamarr. His three marriages were to actresses Blanche Montel, Maria Montez and Marisa Pavan.

Born Jean-Pierre Salomons into a wealthy Parisian French family - his father owned a chain of department stores - Aumont followed his actress mother's calling at the age of 16, studying drama at the Paris Conservatory and making his stage debut at 21. His first film, a year later, was Jean de la Lune (1931), and his career took off in 1934 with Lac aux Dames, and as Oedipus in the first production of Jean Cocteau's La Machine Infernale.

In the next few years, Aumont worked with some of the great names of French cinema: Madeleine Renaud and Jean Gabin in Julien Duvivier's Maria Chapdelaine (1934), Harry Baur in Taras Bulba (1936), and Michel Simon and Louis Jouvet in Marcel Carné's Drôle de Drame (1937), set in Edwardian London, in which he played an amorous milkman. Carné cast him again in Hotel Du Nord (1938), where he and Annabella were immensely touching as a young couple in a suicide pact.

Just as he was becoming established, war broke out. Aumont served with the Free French forces in Tunisia, Italy and France, earning the Légion d'Honneur and the Croix de Guerre for his bravery. By 1943, he had moved to Hollywood, where he got a series of unchallenging roles as archetypal Frenchman. His first was in Assignment In Brittany (1943), as a pilot sent to occupied France to pose as a Nazi agent of which Variety magazine commented: "Aumont is good looking enough to suit the femmes, and he underplays agreeably." In the same year, he appeared in The Cross of Lorraine, playing a French soldier in a German prisoner-of-war camp.

In 1946, Aumont married Montez, with whom he had a daughter, Tina Aumont, who became an actress. Aumont himself starred in an outrageously camp biopic, Song Of Sheherazade (1947), in which he played mariner Rimsky-Korsakov, writing melodies for a dancer (Yvonne de Carlo) in a Moroccan nightclub. "Me, oh, my, sounds like the buz- zing of a bee," she says of one of his numbers.

A year later, he and Montez co-starred for the only time in Siren of Atlantis. Aumont played a legionnaire who falls hopelessly in love with Montez as the cruel ruler of a legendary lost city.

After the tragically premature death of Montez at the age of 31, Aumont retired from acting for two years. He returned in Lili (1953), as the dashing magician who infatuates waif Leslie Caron. From then on, he became an international star, moving easily between Europe and America. He was in two of Sacha Guitry's all-star historical comedies, Si Versailles m'était Conté (1954) and Napoléon (1955), in the epic John Paul Jones (1959) with his third wife, Marisa Pavan, and supported Spencer Tracy and Frank Sinatra in The Devil at 4 O'Clock (1961).

In 1962, Aumont played opposite Vivien Leigh in the Broadway musical, Tovarich. Though neither was a skilled dancer or singer, they got by on sheer personality in the roles of Russian royals exiled in Paris. Leigh was in one of her blackest periods, and Aumont helped her through until the run ended because of her mental breakdown.

Few of Aumont's films were particularly distinguished over the next decades, some exceptions being Sidney Pollack's Castle Keep (1969), in which he played an impotent aristocrat, and François Truffaut's Day For Night (1973), where he was the charismatic male lead who dies during the shooting. He also dies halfway through Claude Lelouche's Cat And Mouse (1975), playing Michèle Morgan's philandering husband.

Aumont continued to work through the 1990s, appearing in James Ivory's Jefferson In Paris (1995) and in Ismail Merchant's The Proprietor (1996), still exuding the dignity and charm for which he was known in real life.

From then on, he became an international star, moving easily between Europe and America. He was in two of Sacha Guitry's all-star historical comedies, Si Versailles m'était Conté (1954) and Napoléon (1955), in the epic John Paul Jones (1959) with his third wife, Marisa Pavan, and supported Spencer Tracy and Frank Sinatra in The Devil at 4 O'Clock (1961). In 1962, Aumont played opposite Vivien Leigh in the Broadway musical, Tovarich. Though neither was a skilled dancer or singer, they got by on sheer personality in the roles of Russian royals exiled in Paris. Leigh was in one of her blackest periods, and Aumont helped her through until the run ended because of her mental breakdown. Few of Aumont's films were particularly distinguished over the next decades, some exceptions being Sidney Pollack's Castle Keep (1969), in which he played an impotent aristocrat, and François Truffaut's Day For Night (1973), where he was the charismatic male lead who dies during the shooting. He also dies halfway through Claude Lelouche's Cat And Mouse (1975), playing Michèle Morgan's philandering husband. Aumont continued to work through the 1990s, appearing in James Ivory's Jefferson In Paris (1995) and in Ismail Merchant's The Proprietor (1996), still exuding the dignity and charm for which he was known in real life.  Jean-Pierre Aumont, actor, born January 5 1909; died January 30 2001.

webTitle: Letsbuyit slashes workforce

fields.headline: Letsbuyit to lay off 200 staff
fields.standfirst: Special report: Dot.coms and dot.gones
fields.trailText:
11.30am: Online retailer Letsbuyit.com is making massive job cuts to stave off bankruptcy, writes Dan Milmo.
Jan 19: Reprieve for Letsbuyit.com
Special report: Dot.coms and dot.gones
fields.body:
Letsbuyit.com, the struggling online retailer, has announced massive job cuts as it attempts to stave off bankruptcy.

The UK-based company said it would lay off 200 of its 350 staff and close its operations in several countries.

Letsbuyit was dramatically pulled back from the brink last week.

A German investment firm run by a former computer hacker supplied the £2.5m needed to guarantee the company's immediate future.

However, it needs £25m to take it through to profitability and Letsbuyit said it was still in talks with potential investors.

The lack of good news sent Letsbuyit's share price tumbling 26% in Frankfurt, with over 6m shares being traded in the early morning as investors fled the stock.

Recently, the stock climbed as much as 200% on the back of more positive news from the company.

Analysts say Letsbuyit is an attractive buy because of the parlous state of its shares.

However, there is still enormous doubt over the viability of the company's business model.

Letsbuyit brings customers together to boost their buying and bargaining power over the web.

However, the company spends more on subsidising free delivery of goods than it makes in profit.

webTitle: Tories promise to cut controls on schools and NHS

fields.headline: Tories promise to cut controls on schools and NHS
fields.trailText: William Hague last night pledged a Conservative government to succeed in revitalising schools and hospitals where Labour has so far failed - by combining extra state funds with growing freedom from state management or provision.
fields.body:
William Hague last night pledged a Conservative government to succeed in revitalising schools and hospitals where Labour has so far failed - by combining extra state funds with growing freedom from state management or provision.

In a vision which conjured up a restoration of the pre-war patchwork of "free" schools and hospitals as well as universities and museums freed from government control, the Conservative leader argued that "monopoly provision by huge bureaucratic providers cannot work".

To overcome the handicaps of "central planning and monopoly supply" - which are strangling schools and the NHS with paperwork, he said - Mr Hague would create a new class of school, financed by the state but owned or managed privately.

He was more cautious about NHS provision, a notoriously dangerous territory for Tory politicians. He said there would be "no privatisation, no retreat to a core service, no compulsory health insurance", but made it equally plain that private hospitals and voluntary insurance will be encouraged, not least via tax breaks.

It was enough to prompt a vicious Labour response in what will be a crucial election battleground this spring.

The Treasury's chief secretary, Andrew Smith, insisted: "No one will believe Tory promises on public services when they won't tell the truth about their hidden agenda to privatise and cut public services. Their privatisation agenda for the NHS is exposed by their determination to force people to take out insurance instead of using the NHS. Their agenda for pensions is exposed by their plan to destroy the basic state pension through privatisation."

But Mr Hague was undeterred yesterday. He argued that he was not seeking to vilify public sector workers in the row over poor services. Instead he would create public/private partnerships involving public sector workers.

In a speech to the Politeia thinktank in London the Tory leader claimed that schools, the police and the NHS were in "an almost permanent state of crisis" under Labour because ministers had not grasped that "greater public service investment is necessary, but not sufficient, to improve the quality of provision".

webTitle: Down on Skid Mews

fields.headline: Down on Skid Mews
fields.standfirst: Skid Row, so famously downtrodden that it's entered general parlance, is about to get a facelift. Is the procedure going to be carried out in the city's inimitable style with the ugly remnants of the past swept out of sight once again, wonders Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles?
fields.trailText: Skid Row, so famously downtrodden that it's entered general parlance, is about to get a facelift. Is the procedure going to be carried out in the city's inimitable style with the ugly remnants of the past swept out of sight once again, wonders Duncan Campbell in Los Angeles?
fields.body:
One of the most striking and memorable sights in Los Angeles at the moment is not the observatory at Griffith Park, or the Hollywood sign, or the preparations going on at the Shrine auditorium for the Oscars, but a section of downtown LA that has always been known as Skid Row.

There can be nowhere in the United States quite so close to a big city's downtown where there are quite so many, quite so desperate people as those who have made their homes in Skid Row, LA. Many people in the city may never have actually seen it and those that have often drive through it with their car doors firmly locked, but it acts as a spectacular reminder of how great the disparity between rich and poor still is.

Skid Row is in focus now for the two reasons. This week, that fine Canadian actress Margot Kidder, star of Superman, has been in town to receive the Courage in Mental Health Award from the California women's mental health policycouncil for speaking out about her own mental illness.

She has talked about suffering a breakdown and finding herself walking the downtown LA streets when two homeless men pushing shopping trolleys asked her if she wanted to come with them because they thought she looked confused. She ended up sharing a cardboard box. "It didn't matter to them that in was, in common terms, 'cuckoo'. They had compassion and understanding," said the now recovered Kidder.

Downtown LA itself is a strange mixture of old civic buildings, crumbling but magnificent old cinemas, and Skid Row itself. The life of the city long ago moved to West Hollywood or East LA, to Santa Monica or Los Feliz. But now there are plans underway to change all that - the second reason Skid Row's been thrust out of the shadows. Chief architect of the change is Tom Gilmore, a former New Yorker who believes that the core of old LA is ready to be revived.

He and his partners are spending $170m [£116m] to convert old buildings into the kind of loft apartments that will attract the hip young away from their old haunts. Other cities - whether London or San Francisco, Barcelona or Edinburgh - have, of course, seen developments in their more desolate and unfashionable areas become the place of aspiration for young house-hunters.

But in LA, less of a conventional city in that no one is quite sure where its centre is, is different. Gilmore told Frances Anderton of the New York Times that: "LA's been a movie set for long enough, now it's time to become a real city."

Alice Callaghan, who works with the homeless on Skid Row and who used to work with the homeless in London, worries that the gentrification will mean that the current residents of Skid Row will be pushed away and that the property developers, having got their properties cheaply because of the very proximity of Skid Row, will want to sweep it out of sight.

What Margot Kidder found, as any visitor to Skid Row finds, is that almost everyone there has a remarkable tale to tell and that many have travelled great distances either geographically or socially before they ended up there. What we will find out over the next few months is what happens when Skid Row feels that even it is on the skids.

webTitle: G2: Dear Anna

fields.headline: Dear Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner.
fields.body:
About Time

What ever can be going on at Time Computers? We have so far spared you the multitude of moans that have been arriving since last August, but a disturbing similarity between them means this reticence must end. A recent Which? survey found that only one in seven Time computer owners would recommend the brand to friends, compared to four out of five Apple owners.

From various readers' experience it would seem that this is not so much due to faulty equipment, non-deliveries and mysterious charges, but the frequent inability of customer services and the £1-per-minute helpline to assist (or even answer the phones). Alex Anderson was unable to use his new Time machine to connect to the internet because the modem was incompatible with the device driver. It cost him £300 to find this out as Time's helpdesk, on the rare occasions when he managed to make contact, failed to identify the problem. Time, however, has refused to address the issue of liability in writing.

A faulty computer was delivered to Daniel Taylor of Leamington Spa and eventually Time arranged for it to be collected. The wrong monitor was delivered on three occasions, two of them to the wrong address, and Taylor's finance company, which tried to assist, reported that it was "unable to obtain satisfactory contact with the retailer".

Time collected the faulty PC received by Nick Noakes of London, then lost it. He was told that Time's finance company could not cancel his credit agreement until it had heard from Time and Time refused to get in touch until it had examined the computer it had lost.

John Bradbeer of Portsmouth and Cynthia Parnaby of Stokesley, N Yorks, both cancelled their orders after their computers failed to turn up, but both were harassed for payment none the less. Kalpesh Intwala, of London, had £1,248 debited from his account although he had cancelled his order, and P Meinert of Redditch, Worcs, found her order had been cancelled without notice or explanation by Time itself. Joanne Perry bought her machine on interest-free credit but three payments were deducted from her account immediately. Time couldn't help so she cancelled the agreement then found herself pursued for arrears.

K Taylor of Farnham, Surrey received isolated components of his new equipment (without his delivery advice), but not the bulk of it, although his payment was cleared with contrasting promptness. Roger Sutton overran his credit deadline and was charged interest which worked out at 34%. He paid off the loan and queried the penalty, but the only reply he received was a new bill demanding an extra, unexplained £346. His letters asking for a breakdown have gone unanswered.

 Consumer contacts Time's amiable, but leisurely, press officer in September and weekly coaxings do nothing to prompt a reply. "We'd better be upfront," he says, finally, a month later, "We're investing in new systems to speed things up which means that we are responding more slowly and having trouble tracking the orders of some customers."

Exhausted by this effort, he falls silent for another five weeks then vanishes. He is replaced by an equally amiable, equally leisurely person who requires a month and a half to get back to us. Meanwhile, it is announced that Time is in urgent refinancing talks with its bankers, having overestimated its market and Trading Standards says it has received complaints.

As for our sufferers: Anderson has been given a new modem but is still £300 out of pocket; Parnaby, Noakes and Intwala have been promised a refund; Daniel Taylor, having been told by Time to seek legal aid, was given a refund when Consumer raised his case; Sutton's account was found to be in credit after all and is to be refunded; and Bradbeer's order has at last been cancelled. Alas for the others, we're still waiting for Time to get in touch ...

No guarantee

Joan Samuels of Barton-on-Sea, Hants, bought an iron last June. It developed a fault in November and the retailer replaced it under the guarantee. However, she was told that the year-long maker's guarantee did not apply to her new iron.

 There is no law governing guarantees for replacement goods, says a spokesman for the Institute of Trading Standards. "If you have a year's warranty on an item which goes wrong after 11 months, say, it is not reasonable to expect another year's warranty."

If, however, the replacement packs up after a few months you might expect a partial refund based on the amount of use you had had from it.

Burning question

It is a frequently aired injustice that airlines oblige us to surrender our luggage at check-in then shrug off the blame if it is mishandled. Bruno Martelli's designer bag was returned to him with a large hole burned into it, so he rang British Airways and was told to write to customer relations. A fortnight later he received a letter advising him that there was a backlog of complaints; a fortnight after that, he had a further letter telling him that he should have addressed his woe to baggage claims, not to the address he had been given.

As baggage claims needed to receive complaints within seven days and those seven days had long since elapsed, BA absolved itself of responsibility.

 BA says that it has not been able to trace Martelli's records because he had not supplied a "complaint report" (mysteriously, this does not prevent the press office from identifying him) and had ignored three requests for one. Martelli says he never received such a request. "He has still not provided documentation confirming the value of the luggage, but we have now accepted the claim in order not to prolong the matter further," says a spokeswoman. "We've sent him £70 in full settlement."

On his bike

Simon Bateson of Brentwood, Essex, checked in his new bike, dismantled, wadded and packed in a bike bag, before boarding a Virgin Express flight to Milan. At no point, he says, was he asked to sign a disclaimer notice, accepting liability if the item was damaged. He arrived safely but his bag was nowhere to be seen. When it turned up a day later, the £80 bike bag was covered in footprints, the reinforced fabric was holed and the bike inside dented. Virgin promised to refer his details to its insurance company but weeks later claimed it held no responsibility for fragile or valuable items. Bateson therefore decided to claim for the bag only, but has so far met with silence.

 Virgin Express points out that its conditions of carriage absolve it from responsibility for fragile, valuable, perishable or oversized luggage, although under the terms of the Warsaw Convention it pays out the splendid sum of £18 per kilo (a figure arrived at in 1929, as regular Consumer readers will know) if ordinary bags are lost or damaged. "However, something has clearly gone wrong," says a spokesman. "As a goodwill gesture we'll give Mr Bateson £80 to buy a new bag."

 Write to us at119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, phone us on 020-7713 4731, send a fax on 020-7239 9933 or email us at consumer@theguardian.com.

webTitle: In brief: Bush builds bridges for 13 Days

fields.headline: Bush builds bridges for 13 Days
fields.standfirst: Plus: Jason Priestley ordered to have alcohol counselling; Buscemi joins Travolta in thriller; Heather Graham and Marisa Tomei get it on with sex guru
fields.trailText: Plus: Jason Priestley ordered to have alcohol counselling; Buscemi joins Travolta in thriller; Heather Graham and Marisa Tomei get it on with sex guru
fields.body:
 President George W Bush will tomorrow night be joined by members of the Kennedy clan for a special White House screening of 13 Days, the Kevin Costner picture which examines JFK's handling of the Cuban missile crisis. Bush has personally invited Rep. Patrick Kennedy, Maryland Lt. Governor Kathleen Kennedy Townsend and Massachusetts senator Ted Kennedy (JFK's brother) to the White House as part of a bridge building exercise between the left and right in the wake of November's controversial election. Since then Ted Kennedy has led the fight against Bush's choice of attorney general and Patrick Kennedy has charged the president with stealing the election. On Thursday night, sources insist, those grievances will be sat on at least for the two-and-a-half hours that the movie is screening.

 Actor Jason Priestley has been ordered to attend six months of alcohol counselling as part of a conviction for drink-driving which resulted from the December 1999 accident that trashed his Porsche and fractured a friend's arm. The star of TV's Beverly Hills 90210 and the art-house film Love and Death on Long Island completed a five-day work release jail program in Los Angeles earlier this month and has had his driving license suspended for a year.

 Snaggle-toothed Steve Buscemi has signed on for a meaty supporting role in Paramount's Domestic Disturbance, which began shooting this week in North Carolina. Directed by Harold (Sea of Love) Becker, the film tells the tale of a suspicious man (played by John Travolta) at odds with his son's new stepfather (Vince Vaughn). Buscemi, who will take the role of a character from Vaughn's shady past, recently completed work on Tom DiCillo's Double Whammy and Terry (Crumb) Zwigoff's movie Ghost World. In the meantime, his second film as a director Animal Factory opens in the UK in April.

 Heather Graham and Marisa Tomei are in negotiations to co-star in Working Title's satirical comedy The Guru of Sex, to be directed by Daisy Mayer. Scripted by Tracey Jackson, the film will star the actresses as the two main women in the life of an ambitious Indian dreamer who becomes a Karma Sutra-style sex guru to the wealthy urbanites of modern-day Manhattan. The titular role has yet to be cast but the film is scheduled to roll before the cameras in April.

webTitle: 'CJD in blood' sparks therapy boycott

fields.headline: 'CJD in blood' sparks therapy boycott
fields.trailText: The government was last night facing the embarrassing prospect of a "treatment strike" by growing numbers of haemophiliacs seeking to shame ministers into paying for safer blood clotting agents.
fields.body:
The government was last night facing the embarrassing prospect of a "treatment strike" by growing numbers of haemophiliacs seeking to shame ministers into paying for safer blood clotting agents.

As the government sought to calm protests over the way haemophiliacs, as late as 1997, had been exposed to potential infection from the human form of BSE, the Department of Health said patients should first consult their GPs.

People with haemophilia are furious that for the third time in just over three years patients are being told that they have used products that have been found to include material from a variant CJD victim.

The news, first reported in the Guardian this month, has forced ministers to consider whether to give adult haemophiliacs in England access to laboratory-made alternatives, as happened for children in Britain, and for adults in both Scotland and Wales.

The Haemophilia Society said it had heard more patients were refusing treatment with clotting factor from human sources and joining networks that allow patients who do get the synthetic type, called recombinant, to send part of their dose to others without it.

This is almost certainly illegal. But one patient who did this in the autumn forced his local health authority to pay for the more expensive recombinant factor.

Karin Pappenheim, director of the Haemophilia Society, said it was not clear how many people might be affected by the postcode lottery over access to clotting treatment, but it could be as high as 2000.

The government ordered the import of most blood plasma products two years ago because of the theoretical risk of infection by donors who had vCJD. Thirteen of the 88 known vCJD victims had been blood donors. A spokeswoman for the Department of Health said that the risk of vCJD from existing clotting factors was "unsubstantiated".

webTitle: Vodafone hands ad account to WCRS

fields.headline: Vodafone hands ad account to WCRS
fields.trailText: 11.15am: Vodafone has handed its £47m UK ad account to WCRS, the agency that built up rival brand Orange, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Mobile phone giant Vodafone has handed its £47m UK ad account to WCRS, the agency that built up rival brand Orange.

Vodafone is expected to confirm later today it has ditched existing agency BMP DDB, but sources say WCRS discovered last night it had won the account.

The move is part of a wider review of Vodafone's marketing - last year the company appointed McCann-Erickson to handle a global campaign.

The news will come as a major blow to BMP, which had handled the account for five years.

But it is unlikely to have been a surprise, given that the agency failed to secure Vodafone's global ad account in a pitch against McCann last year.

WCRS chairman Robin Wight kicked off an aggressive campaign to fill the gap left by Orange, after the company awarded its advertising account to rival agency Lowe Lintas last summer.

The agency's "The future's bright, the future's Orange" campaign is widely regarded as one of the most successful in recent advertising history.

When it lost the Orange account last year, WCRS placed an ad in industry magazine Campaign that featured in orange type on a black background the words "hello" and "goodbye".

Underneath in small type, a few words explained that in 1994 when Orange appointed the agency it was worth nothing, but by 2000 the brand was worth £28bn.

Vodafone is currently the UK market leader with about 11.7m mobile phone customers compared with BT Cellnet's 10.2m, Orange's 9.8m and One2One's 8.3m.

webTitle: Blanchett on board for Shipping News

fields.headline: Blanchett on board for Shipping News
fields.trailText: Cate Blanchett is the latest star to sign up for the film version of E Annie Proulx's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel
fields.body:
Cate Blanchett is reported to be in final negotiations to join the star cast (see earlier story) in the Miramax production The Shipping News. Directed by Swedish film-maker Lasse Hallstrom (Chocolat, My Life as a Dog), the film is adapted from the 1994 Pulitzer Prize-winning novel by E Annie Proulx.

The Shipping News follows the fortunes of Quoyle (Kevin Spacey), a social misfit who takes a job on a local paper at a remote Newfoundland fishing village. Blanchett will play the role of Quoyle's faithless wife, Petal Bear, whose death spurs him finally to action.

The star of Elizabeth and the forthcoming The Gift recently completed her work on the eagerly anticipated Lord of the Rings and may have to juggle her Shipping News schedule around her lead role in Warner Bros' Charlotte Gray. In last week's Guardian interview at the NFT, acclaimed performer and director Liv Ullmann described Blanchett as the finest actor of her generation.

webTitle: Activist farmer Bové beats expulsion bid

fields.headline: Activist farmer Bové beats expulsion bid
fields.trailText: The French farming activist who last year won fame for his stand against McDonald's yesterday won a brief reprieve from an expulsion order in Brazil, where he has taken part in the destruction of genetically modified crops.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos  in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
The French farming activist who last year won fame for his stand against McDonald's yesterday won a brief reprieve from an expulsion order in Brazil, where he has taken part in the destruction of genetically modified crops.

José Bové was arrested on Monday night for his participation in the destruction of a soya crop on Monsanto premises near southern Porto Alegre.

After spending a short time in police custody he was given 24 hours to leave the country. But his lawyers yesterday succeeded in winning him habeas corpus, meaning that he was free to stay in Brazil until his flight today, when he had planned to leave anyway.

The judge said the expulsion order had been "abusive" and represented "mere reprisal" by the authorities.

Mr Bové said his activism had brought attention to the plight of Brazil's poor, rural workers: "What happened to me is little compared to Brazil's thousands and thousands of rural poor who fight for land and are killed every day by the police and landowners."

"This [the expulsion order] was a political act," Bové said of the deportation order. "It shows the will of the government to discredit those who support land reform in Brazil."

The row marked the end of the inaugural World Social Forum in Porto Alegre, billed as the "anti-Davos" forum in reference to the World Economic Forum in Switzerland. The Brazil forum brought together more than 9,000 people from groups opposed to unfettered economic neo-liberalism.

Mr Bové told supporters: "Today we are here to say we want to build a different world. If the 21st century started in Seattle, the third millennium started in Porto Alegre."

webTitle: Analysis: Devolution gathers support in cabinet

fields.headline: Divide and rule
fields.standfirst: The benefits of regionalism are beginning to attract some heavyweight support in the government as they look enviously northward
fields.trailText: The benefits of regionalism are beginning to attract some heavyweight support in the government as they look enviously northward.
fields.body:
Until recently English regionalism was the policy that dare not speak its name. The very mention of devolution, to match the transfer of power to Scotland and Wales, set alarm bells ringing. Tony Blair dismissed talk of a north-south divide as a dangerous over-simplification. End of story.

But the party faithful in Labour's heartlands became restless as old industries closed and the economic riches of the south failed to trickle down. In local elections, once-solid Labour towns - such as Peter Mandelson's Hartlepool - went Tory. Soon Blairites such as trade secretary Stephen Byers joined John Prescott, a long-standing advocate of English devolution, in preaching the virtues of strong regions.

The deputy prime minister and chancellor Gordon Brown began challenging the Downing Street line by publicly acknowledging north-south inequalities and calling for bolder initiatives to bridge the regional divide. In the spending review last July and then in autumn's pre-budget statement, Mr Brown underlined the importance of the eight regional development agencies (RDAs) created in 1999. These are the business-led quangos designed to improve the economic performance of underperforming regions. Mr Brown promised them a £500m budget increase to £1.7bn by 2003-4 and flexibility in how they spend it.

Insiders noted the emergence of a Prescott-Brown axis while Mr Prescott's aides began raising the stakes in the internal battle to commit the party to a strong regional dimension in its forthcoming manifesto. Late last year Richard Caborn, the trade minister and a close friend of Mr Prescott, told a Fabian Society meeting in York: "I believe the radical programme of constitutional change we embarked on in 1997 is incomplete without an answer to the so-called English question. Regions need a clear voice to promote economic development and that in my view is best achieved through (elected) regional assemblies".

This week, in more measured tones, Gordon Brown came close to saying much the same thing - although his message was more about creating a regionally-based American-style enterprise climate, underpinned with tax incentives and government grants, than an Old Labour subsidy culture propping up time-expired industries. The chancellor, once Labour's regional policy spokesman, knows that RDAs, for all their resources, cannot buck the global market place. But he also knows that strong regional policies north of the border over the past 30 years - latterly considerable pump-priming by a national development agency - have transformed the Scottish economy from basket case to one the brighter stars in European information technology.

Ever a politician with keen antennae, Mr Brown is well aware that south of the border passions are running high, particularly in north-east England - political home of Tony Blair, Mr Byers, and a clutch of other senior ministers. This region is one of the UK's poorest performers. Its MPs look enviously northwards at a rapidly diverging political culture, Scotland where there are no student tuition fees, the prospect of free-nursing care for the elderly, higher wages for teachers and a hands-on industrial policy pumping tens of millions annually into hi-tech industry. The less favoured regions of England are seen to be falling further behind. The voters are restless.

Speaking at the start of a pre-budget consultation in Manchester this week, Mr Brown spoke warmly of the deputy prime minister deserving congratulations for delivering the RDAs. He portrayed the regional agenda as a cornerstone of his American-style philosophy. He talked of giving the agencies new powers to foster innovation, develop skills for the 21st century economy and build an enterprise cul ture. Other ministers were also praised. Downing Street was not mentioned.

Significantly, Mr Brown entered the wider debate about English governance by saying the growing network of non-elected regional chambers, comprising councillors and businessmen, should be strengthened as a prelude to democratic assemblies. His was "a Britain of regions and nations" blessed with a new dynamism where diversity can become a source of "new energy and national strength".

Where all this leads is far from clear. Research at the centre for urban and regional development studies at Newcastle University shows a "highly uneven" pattern of public interest in regional government with the north east (closest to Scotland) registering strongest support. Perhaps this implies an incremental approach: areas that can demonstrate strong support such as the north-east and Yorkshire moving further ahead than, say, the south-east.

Battle is now being waged to commit Labour to move forward in its manifesto. Against the wishes of Downing Street, the party's policy forum last July wanted to recognise the "legitimate aspirations" of the regions. Decoded, that means referenda to test support for devolution, which would require legislation.

Mr Prescott would not disagree with pressure group calls to "create the conditions in which elected regional assemblies will be in place by consent within the next five years". This might appear over-optimistic. But, as Gordon Brown showed this week, it is no longer a pipe dream.

webTitle: 'UK jobs are safe' says Amazon

fields.headline: 'UK jobs are safe' says Amazon
fields.standfirst: Special report: Dot.coms and dot.gones
fields.trailText:
10.45am: The UK arm of Amazon.com has insisted that all UK jobs are safe, despite cutbacks in the US, reports Amy Vickers.
Jan 31: Amazon cuts workforce by 15%
Special report: Dot.coms and dot.gones
fields.body:
The UK arm of Amazon.com has insisted that all UK jobs are safe, despite cutbacks in the US.

The Seattle-based online retailer yesterday said it was cutting 15% of its workforce - some 1,300 staff - in order to stem losses, which reached £61.8m last year.

However, the firm's revenues for 2000, at £1.89bn, beat Wall Street expectations. Amazon.co.uk said UK jobs were not at risk. The company refused to give an exact figure for its UK staff, but said it had more than 500 employees in this country.

Other reports have suggested there could be as many as 800 Amazon UK employees, split between offices in Slough and Milton Keynes.

A spokesman for Amazon.co.uk said it was too early to say where other cuts would happen, or whether the company's UK marketing budget would now be slashed.

Amazon launched into the UK just over two years ago.

webTitle: School pay goal for college lecturers

fields.headline: School pay goal for college lecturers
fields.trailText: With school teachers expecting above inflation pay increases to be announced this week, the main further education union has threatened industrial action in colleges an effort to catch up.
fields.body:
With school teachers expecting above inflation pay increases to be announced this week, the main further education union has threatened industrial action in colleges an effort to catch up.

Teachers' pay in schools was now 10% ahead of college lecturers', said Natfhe which represents 65,000 academic staff in further education colleges in England, Wales and Northern Ireland.

The union submitted a claim to the employers' body, the Association of Colleges, for a £3,000 flat rate pay rise for all further education lecturers and managers. It is also calling for a pro-rata rise for all part-time staff, an additional award phased over four years to bring lecturers' pay in line with that of school teachers. The claim opposes the introduction of performance related pay.

Natfhe intends to ballot members on a one-day national strike on May 1 if no progress is made. "Our members are angry and frustrated," said Paul Mackney, the union's general secretary. "Lecturers have watched school teachers' pay outstrip theirs by more than 10 per cent. That pay gap is to widen even further with the additional pay rises for teachers this year."

The association expressed sympathy for the lecturers' situation but said the best way to raise pay was through the government's teaching pay initiative worth £50m this year and £100m in 2002/3.

Jocelyn Prudence, of the association, said over two years most lecturers would gain £2,000 under the initiative which is linked to professional qualifications and development, and contributing to student retention and performance.

The union is suspicious of linking pay to performance in this way. "It would be foolish to lose the opportunity of this initiative and £2,000 in most teachers' pockets for the sake of ideology," she said.

This year's report from the School Teachers Review Body, due out on Friday, is expected to recommend a 3.7% basic increase with 5% and more for new teachers. An increase in the London allowance of about one third, plus £2,000 threshold payments will give some London teachers a rise of more than 10%.

Mr Mackney said lecturers were running out of patience. "Workloads are excessive and low pay, unequal pay, discriminatory practices, extensive use of fixed-term contracts, and agency staff are rife. The low rewards and all-pervading stress are driving experienced lecturers out and discouraging people from taking up a career in colleges.

"College staff have had lots of promises of improved pay, and not much else. The government has now put over £150 million for lecturers' pay into the system, so the excuses are wearing thin," he said.

webTitle: Polly Toynbee: Universal childcare?

fields.headline: So easy it's child's play
fields.standfirst: The government should pledge to introduce universal childcare. That would trounce the Tories
fields.trailText: The government should pledge to introduce universal childcare. That would trounce the Tories.
fields.body:
The cabinet was brainstorming yesterday. For two and a half hours - a long time in cabinet politics - they talked manifesto. Radical or steady-as-she-goes? Great leap forward or trudging solid step-by-step? We wait to see if it will be a bold proclamation of Labour's true values or a third way shuffle, another nervous unfocused bid for an imaginary middle England. The truth about middle England is that like everyone everywhere, it harbours a host of pluralist contradictions, hopes and fears, generosities and meannesses, depending which way the question is put. It is for politicians to offer strong leadership and clear choices, drawing out the best of impulses, rejecting the worst.

In all parties seasoned manifesto writers look back enviously to Margaret Thatcher's 1979 single pledge that was dazzlingly radical yet sublimely simple. It was the sale of council houses to their tenants. At a stroke a policy affecting relatively few voters struck a chord even among those who had never set foot in a council estate. It spoke eloquently of the best Conservative values: freedom from state servitude, upward aspiration for all, the Englishman's home as his castle, a property-owning democracy, concern for the respectable self-improving working class. It left Labour trapped in an old ideology that locked people into council housing for ever. It exposed Labour's dislike for upward mobility. A killer election-winner, Labour was toast.

Every party is now seeking their magic carpet policy - the one totemic winner that conveys the essence of an entire ideology, the very best of all they stand for. As it happens, Labour had one delivered to its doorstep this week, though the cabinet yesterday may not have recognised this jewel in its palm. It is the universal right to affordable childcare. The national childcare commission, assembled by the Day Care Trust, chaired by Harriet Harman and including rightwing Tory MP Edward Leigh, came up with proposals that would transform life for families.

"Motherhood and apple pie," said one sceptic yesterday. Just so and why not? This is the apple-pie vision. Rolling out from the poorest places first, every district will have a neighbourhood children's centre to house playgroups, mother and toddler groups, a creche, a nursery, antenatal clinics, health visitors, Sure Start programmes, after-school clubs and homework clubs for older children - a home from home with all children's services in one place. Imagine a state of the art, beautiful building as a hub for the local community where parents assemble regularly, breathing new life into community activity. Isolated mothers meet here to learn and train with New Deal advisers to find them jobs.

"Blue sky thinking is very useful," said one tentative but wistful Labour minister, keen but anxious about the cost. It would be very expensive - 8,000 centres at £10bn or more. Add to that the cost of the commission's other radical proposal - that every mother should be allowed to draw down the cost of childcare for the first three years, and either keep it to stay at home or spend it on a creche or childminder. Currently low-paid working mothers can claim up to £70 childcare a week - a sum that could be there for all to work or not. What the commission report shows -blindingly obvious to anyone who bothered to ask - is that even mothers high up the social scale (Daily Mail middle England heartland) struggle miserably with the lack of childcare, high cost and hard to find. It causes desperate anxiety to most of the 75% of mothers who now go out to work. Commissioners listened to women cry as they reported handing over tiny babies to minders they didn't trust to go back to long hours to pay their mortgages. At the same time 65% of mothers who stay at home want to work but can't find or fund the childcare. The current system where the state subsidises anyone but the mother to care for a child makes no sense: choice is all.

Childcare is the gaping hole in the cradle-to-grave welfare state. Like health and education it cannot be provided privately: at £180 a week it is way beyond most pockets. There is no other solution but public provision. For years the Tories tried to get employers and the private sector to do it, but it never worked. Left-behind Britain still thinks it is not the state's business, though Germany, France, Italy, Denmark and the others have had excellent nurseries for decades. Founding the NHS was a monumental public good -very expensive, very daring and very popular. By promising a radical expansion of the welfare state, Labour would underline its profound belief in public services for those things that the private sector cannot do.

Politically, it would trump the Tories. They plan tax incentives for marriage as their family policy. Universal children's centres would be far too expensive for them. Copying Labour spending on health and education (though for how long?), they could not pretend to follow here. A high spending, high profile promise is just what Labour needs. It would leave them floundering - and voters with a clear choice. Tiny tax incentives for marriage will look pathetic beside a mighty promise for what families really need.

Today the Institute for Fiscal Studies green budget will probably again discover the chancellor's surplus is far greater than he admits. "Surplus, what surplus?" Gordon Brown says crossly when anyone asks. But he is sitting on more than enough to pay for universal childcare. As Michael Jacobs of the Fabians wrote in these pages, we are £45bn underspent by the EU average. The government does have a national childcare strategy already spending sizeable sums, but with negligible political impact. It has no brand and no resonance, with excellent programmes but so far only for the poor. To promise a universal system for every baby and child would be a very different matter. If people don't know about Labour's childcare, that is because inheriting virtually none there is still only one childcare place (private or public) for every seven young children and after-school club places for only one in 14 school children.

Will it happen? The cabinet doesn't quite get its powerful potential. One obstacle, as ever, is stone-age David Blunkett who yesterday left Labour MPs spitting with fury when he said he opposed any further help as it might encourage young girls to have babies. Thinking he'd been misquoted, I checked, but his office was adamant: that is his fixed view. Under-fives' minister, Margaret Hodge, on the other hand, was touring the studios giving broad encouragement to children's centres - a natural extension of what she is doing. Will they see that universal childcare is the magic family policy the Tories can never match?

webTitle: Gladiator, Crouching Tiger do battle in Bafta nominations

fields.headline: Gladiator, Crouching Tiger do battle in Bafta nominations
fields.trailText: Ridley Scott's Roman epic and Ang Lee's martial arts romance have both been nominated for 13 awards at this year's Baftas
fields.body:
Two action epics dominate this year's Bafta's as Ridley Scott's Gladiator and Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (pictured) head the race for this year's awards with a hefty 14 nominations apiece. The acclaimed British drama Billy Elliot finished second with 11 nods.

The nominations, announced this morning by Stephen Fry at Bafta's London headquarters, largely reflect the choices of a rash of other, mainly American, film award ceremonies in the run-up to Oscar night. The sole blip appeared to be the lack of Steven Soderbergh's Traffic in the list of candidates for Best Film. Traffic has been tipped in some quarters for a possible Best Film Oscar in March. Instead the Bafta's nominations went to Almost Famous, Billy Elliot, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, Erin Brockovich and Gladiator.

Best British Film, meanwhile, will go to either the inevitable Billy Elliot, Chicken Run, Terence Davies's much-praised The House of Mirth, The Last Resort or the gangster saga Sexy Beast.

The nominations for Best Actor are Jamie Bell (Billy Elliot), Russell Crowe (Gladiator), Michael Douglas (Wonder Boys), Tom Hanks (Cast Away) and Geoffrey Rush (Quills).

The award for Best Actress will be fought out by Juliette Binoche (Chocolat), Kate Hudson (Almost Famous), Julia Roberts (Erin Brockovich), Michelle Yeoh (Crouching Tiger) and Hilary Swank (Boys Don't Cry). Swank, in fact, won last year's Oscar for her role in Boys Don't Cry but because the film was not released in the UK until April 2000 it now qualifies for this year's Baftas.

The Best Director nominations made some amends for Traffic's failure to appear in the Best Film category by nominating Soderbergh twice, for Erin Brockovich as well as his much-acclaimed drug saga. Other nominees are Stephen Daldry (Billy Elliot), Ang Lee (Crouching Tiger) and Ridley Scott (Gladiator). Meanwhile the late, almost great Oliver Reed now has a chance at posthumous glory. The legendary hell-raiser is nominated in the Best Supporting Actor category for his swansong role in Gladiator.

The nominations in full:

Best film Almost Famous; Billy Elliot; Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon; Erin Brockovich; Gladiator

Outstanding British film Billy Elliot; Chicken Run; The House of Mirth; Last Resort; Sexy Beast

Most promising British newcomer Stephen Daldry (Billy Elliot); Lee Hall (Billy Elliot); Pawel Pawlikowski (Last Resort); Simon Cellan Jones (Some Voices); Mark Crowdy (Saving Grace)

Best director Stephen Daldry (Billy Elliot); Ang Lee (Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon); Steven Soderbergh (Erin Brockovich); Ridley Scott (Gladiator); Steven Soderbergh (Traffic)

Best original screenplay Almost Famous (Cameron Crowe); Billy Elliot (Lee Hall); Erin Brockovich (Susannah Grant); Gladiator (David Franzoni/John Logan/William Nicholson); O Brother, Where Art Thou? (Ethan Coen/Joel Coen)

Best adapted screenplay Chocolat (Robert Nelson Jacobs); Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (James Schamus/Wang Hui-ling/Tsai Kuo-jung); High Fidelity (DV de Vincentis/Steve Pink/John Cusack/Scott Rosenberg); Traffic (Stephen Gaghan); Wonder Boys (Steve Kloves)

Best actress Juliette Binoche (Chocolat); Kate Hudson (Almost Famous); Julia Roberts (Erin Brockovich); Hilary Swank (Boys Don't Cry); Michelle Yeoh (Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon)

Best actor Jamie Bell (Billy Elliot); Russell Crowe (Gladiator); Michael Douglas (Wonder Boys); Tom Hanks (Cast Away); Geoffrey Rush (Quills)

Best supporting actress Judi Dench (Chocolat); Frances McDormand (Almost Famous); Lena Olin (Chocolat); Julie Walters (Billy Elliot); Zhang Ziyi (Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon)

Best supporting actor Benicio del Toro (Traffic); Albert Finney (Erin Brockovich); Gary Lewis (Billy Elliot); Joaquin Phoenix (Gladiator); Oliver Reed (Gladiator)

Achievement in music Nancy Wilson (Almost Famous); Stephen Warbeck (Billy Elliot); Tan Dun (Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon); Hans Zimmer/Lisa Gerrard (Gladiator); T-Bone Burnett/Carter Burwell (O Brother, Where Art Thou?)

Best foreign language film Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (Bill Kong/Hsu Li-kong/Ang Lee); The Girl on the Bridge (Christian Fechner/Patrice Leconte); Harry, He's Here to Help (Michel Saint-Jean/Dominik Moll); In the Mood for Love (Wong Kar-wai); Malena (Harvey Weinstein/Giuseppe Tornatore/Carlo Bernasconi)

Best cinematography Brian Tufano (Billy Elliot); Roger Pratt (Chocolat); Pater Pau (Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon); John Mathieson (Gladiator); Roger Deakins (O Brother, Where Art Thou?)

webTitle: He stripped the organs from every dead child he touched

fields.headline: He stripped the organs from every dead child he touched
fields.standfirst: Special report: Alder Hey hospital
fields.trailText: The pathologist at the heart of the Alder Hey scandal may face criminal prosecution after a devastating report revealed yesterday that he had stripped the organs out of every dead child who came into his hands over a period of seven years, whether the parents had consented or not.
fields.body:
The pathologist at the heart of the Alder Hey scandal may face criminal prosecution after a devastating report revealed yesterday that he had stripped the organs out of every dead child who came into his hands over a period of seven years, whether the parents had consented or not.

Dick van Velzen, the Dutch pathologist who is already facing charges over organ storage in Canada, took the brunt of the criticism from the Redfern inquiry, which reported yesterday. He was responsible for the collection of children's body parts at the Liverpool hospital, but the hospital trust and Liverpool University, which appointed and failed to oversee him, also came in for savage criticism.

A second report published yesterday by the chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, revealed that thousands of children and adults have had organs removed at autopsy without the knowledge of relatives, who have unsuspectingly buried incomplete bodies.

A census of hospitals and medical schools found that at least 105,000 organs, foetuses and stillborn babies have been kept for research and education purposes. "We need to regain a lot of public trust," Professor Donaldson said. "If we don't, the benefits of teaching and research are going to be lost."

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, yesterday told the Commons he was setting up an independent commission to help relatives who wanted to find and reclaim the remains of their loved ones.

The retention of organs without full consent stemmed from a paternalism the NHS was determined to end, Mr Milburn said. Most doctors failed to broach the matter to avoid causing further grief. But what went on at Alder Hey showed the danger of assuming that the benefits of research were self-evident to all.

"During Van Velzen's time at Alder Hey between 1988 and 1995 he systematically ordered the illegal and unethical stripping of every organ from every child who had a postmortem," Mr Milburn said.

"He ignored parents' wishes even when they told him explicitly that they did not want a full postmortem, let alone the retention of any of their child's organs. According to the report, Van Velzen lied to parents. He lied to other doctors. He lied to hospital managers. He stole medical records. He falsified statistics and reports and he encouraged other staff to do the same."

Mr Milburn slammed the hospital and Liverpool University for "incompetence and insensitivity" once the scandal became known. The hospital was overwhelmed by events while the university "simply turned its back on parents".

Some families had to endure several funerals as body parts were returned piecemeal.

The acting chairman of the hospital trust and two non-executive directors immediately resigned, while four NHS staff, including the chief executive, were suspended.

Professor Van Velzen has been reported to the General Medical Council and copies of the Redfern report have been sent to Merseyside police and the director of public prosecutions. The GMC will decide on Friday whether to suspend Prof Van Velzen from practising as a doctor in Britain. He is now living in the Netherlands.

Mr Milburn also announced a raft of radical measures. The law will be changed to ensure doctors obtain full and informed consent before the removal of organs from dead children. All hospitals will have to employ bereavement counsellors before the year's end to help and champion relatives. The home secretary has set in train a review of the coroner's system, to learn the lessons of Alder Hey and of the Shipman case.

Yesterday Alder Hey parents demanded an apology from the hospital and Liverpool University. "The last 17 months have been harrowing and have had a devastating effect on all the families involved," said Ed Bradley of the parents' support group, Pity II.

"The fact is that the parents have had to deal not only with the removal and retention of their child's organs but the disgraceful manner in which they have been treated."

Parents said they wanted further inquiries into organ retention from the period before Prof Van Velzen took up his post. The Redfern report gave shocking details of children's heads kept in bottles from the 1960s.

Robin Makin, solicitor for some of the families, accused the government of failing to act early enough and said the hospital had been thrown to the wolves to protect ministers.

Philip Love, vice-chancellor of the University of Liverpool, tried to distance it from the "quite appalling activities attributed to Prof Van Velzen". "The university would wish to emphasise that it had responsibility for overseeing and regulating his academic activities and not for his activities as a hospital pathologist," Professor Love said.
