webTitle: Murdoch pushes ahead with Sky Global flotation

fields.headline: Murdoch to press ahead with Sky Global flotation
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Rupert Murdoch is set to push ahead with the flotation of Sky Global Networks, writes Dan Milmo.
Jan 29: News Corp in running for DirecTV stake
fields.body:
Rupert Murdoch is set to push ahead with the flotation of Sky Global Networks - even if he fails to strike a deal with US target DirecTV.

The head of News Corporation is willing to launch a stripped-down version of his satellite TV company on the market.

However, he still hopes to give Sky Global a US foothold.

Mr Murdoch is still negotiating the acquisition of DirecTV from owner General Motors. But he is determined this will not delay the flotation of Sky Global Networks beyond the summer.

"We are talking to satellite broadcasters, including DirecTV in the US, and one option for us is to merge our satellite interests with a publicly listed company such as DirecTV," said a News Corp spokesman.

"But if that does not happen, we will not be perfectly happy to go ahead and list Sky Global, which is all of our existing global satellite assets."

The existing satellite TV assets of News Corp include 38% of BSkyB, 100% of Asian broadcaster Star TV and 50% of Italian station Stream.

But if Mr Murdoch cannot clinch a deal with DirecTV, he still intends to press ahead with the float.

"It will just not be a US company," said the spokesman.

"We would prefer to have a US satellite presence but it is not essential to the success of Sky Global."

Pressure is piling on Mr Murdoch to produce some good news for shareholders in time for results announcements for News Corp and BSkyB next week.

Merrill Lynch analyst Jessica Reif Cohen has warned News Corp will be hit by a marked slump in ad revenue in the US market, where it makes 70% of its revenues.

Negotiations for the sale of DirecTV and its holding company, Hughes Electrics, are ongoing, with General Motors denying reports that News Corp has fallen in the pecking order of bidders.

The News Corp spokesman said the much-delayed flotation of Sky Global was still planned for the beginning of the year.

The slimline Sky Global would then float on a volatile US market, which is unlikely to react favourably to the lack of a north American presence.

However, plans to launch Sky Global in its existing form throw the spotlight onto French media giant Vivendi Universal, which is selling its 22.7% stake in BSkyB.

Vivendi boss Jean-Marie Messier said he was in no hurry to sell the £4.4bn holding.

But he does not want to sour his already fractious relationship with Mr Murdoch.

The future of the BSkyB stake must be settled if Sky Global is to be floated with the UK digital and satellite broadcaster as its centrepiece instead of DirecTV.

US cable company Liberty Media, which has a 20% interest in News Corp, is the favourite to acquire the holding.

Jan 29: News Corp in running for DirecTV stake
fields.bodyText: Rupert Murdoch is set to push ahead with the flotation of Sky Global Networks - even if he fails to strike a deal with US target DirecTV. The head of News Corporation is willing to launch a stripped-down version of his satellite TV company on the market. However, he still hopes to give Sky Global a US foothold. Mr Murdoch is still negotiating the acquisition of DirecTV from owner General Motors. But he is determined this will not delay the flotation of Sky Global Networks beyond the summer. "We are talking to satellite broadcasters, including DirecTV in the US, and one option for us is to merge our satellite interests with a publicly listed company such as DirecTV," said a News Corp spokesman. "But if that does not happen, we will not be perfectly happy to go ahead and list Sky Global, which is all of our existing global satellite assets." The existing satellite TV assets of News Corp include 38% of BSkyB, 100% of Asian broadcaster Star TV and 50% of Italian station Stream. But if Mr Murdoch cannot clinch a deal with DirecTV, he still intends to press ahead with the float. "It will just not be a US company," said the spokesman. "We would prefer to have a US satellite presence but it is not essential to the success of Sky Global." Pressure is piling on Mr Murdoch to produce some good news for shareholders in time for results announcements for News Corp and BSkyB next week. Merrill Lynch analyst Jessica Reif Cohen has warned News Corp will be hit by a marked slump in ad revenue in the US market, where it makes 70% of its revenues. Negotiations for the sale of DirecTV and its holding company, Hughes Electrics, are ongoing, with General Motors denying reports that News Corp has fallen in the pecking order of bidders. The News Corp spokesman said the much-delayed flotation of Sky Global was still planned for the beginning of the year. The slimline Sky Global would then float on a volatile US market, which is unlikely to react favourably to the lack of a north American presence. However, plans to launch Sky Global in its existing form throw the spotlight onto French media giant Vivendi Universal, which is selling its 22.7% stake in BSkyB. Vivendi boss Jean-Marie Messier said he was in no hurry to sell the £4.4bn holding. But he does not want to sour his already fractious relationship with Mr Murdoch. The future of the BSkyB stake must be settled if Sky Global is to be floated with the UK digital and satellite broadcaster as its centrepiece instead of DirecTV. US cable company Liberty Media, which has a 20% interest in News Corp, is the favourite to acquire the holding. Relevant stories Jan 29: News Corp in running for DirecTV stake

webTitle: Daylight Robbery format sold to US

fields.headline: Daylight Robbery format sold to US
fields.trailText: 9.45am: The format for ITV Michelle Collins drama Daylight Robbery has been sold to US cable channel USA Network, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
The format for ITV Michelle Collins drama Daylight Robbery has been sold to leading US cable channel USA Network.

USA Network has optioned initial eight episodes of the drama, which was produced by UK indie Hewland International for ITV.

In a deal brokered by UK distributor Target, Daylight Robbery producer and director Cameron McAllister will be consulting producer of the US version.

Daylight Robbery, which drew an average audience share of 41.5% on ITV, featured Collins as one of four Essex housewives who become armed robbers to make ends meet.

"Following our sale of Popstars to Warner Bros, we have been increasingly strengthening or position in the US over the last year and we're confident Daylight Robbery will be a hit with USA Network viewers," said Target managing director Alison Rayson.

The UK distributor has also sold Hewland reality format Wanted to the Fox network in the US.

fields.trailText: THE GUARDIAN

THE GUARDIAN

The BBC is close to signing a deal with Lennox Lewis, bolstering the corporation's plan to improve its reputation for sports rights. P7

Channel 4 is having to pay thousands to a fire safety officer who thought a comic character from Peter Kay's Phoenix Nights was based on him. P8

A Trigger Happy TV devotee has been fined £100 for a prank involving a postman and two teenagers backfired. The man said Dom Joly was his God. P10

Matthew Norman reveals that Mirror hack Des Kelly, Carol Vorderman's new chap, has a new nickname: "Two consonants and a vowel". P22

Thus has pulled its plans for ADSL through BT's local exchanges. P25

Internet executives are demanding huge pay increases to make up for their collapsing share options. P28

Amazon cuts its workforce by 15%, laying off 1,300 people. P28

THE FINANCIAL TIMES

Amazon is cutting 1,300 workers, 15% of its workforce. P1

Tony Blair will name Andrew Pinder this week as the new e-envoy. Pinder, a former director of IT at the Inland Revenue, has been acting e-envoy since October. P4

British internet executives are the best paid in Europe, with an average salary of £172,000. P5

Telewest increases internet customers. P27

Today is game over for Dreamcast, as Sega is set to announce the end of its production. P36

THE WALL STREET JOURNAL EUROPE

Amazon slightly beat Wall Street's expectations for its fourth quarter, pulling in full-year revenues of $2.76bn, but it still has to cut back 15% of its workforce. P4

Emap is paying for the US magazine company Petersen with undervalued shares. P12

THE TIMES

A figure of fun has won £10,000 compensation from Channel 4. P10

Amazon is cutting 1,300 jobs and closing warehouses and customer service centres. P26

BBC boss Greg Dyke is set to land his first punch for sports rights with the expected announcement today of coverage of Lennox Lewis's heavyweight title bout. P36

THE INDEPENDENT

Channel 4 has agreed to pay £10,000 to a council worker who claimed he was the unwitting victim of a Peter Kay comedy show. P10

Amazon cuts hundreds of jobs after $90m loss. P13

Thus has ditched plans to roll out ADSL through BT's exchanges. P16

DAILY TELEGRAPH

The BBC has been criticised by its governors for broadcasting a tasteless sexual remark about David and Victoria Beckham on They Think It's All Over. P6

Keith Laird has won £10,000 compensation from Channel 4 after he recognised himself as Peter Kay's Keith Lard. P7

Sarah Ferguson has become the new face of broker Charles Schwab, urging investors to "build their own castle". P35

EMI has passed its self-imposed deadline for merger talks with Bertelsmann to conclude. P36

Budweiser has reportedly ended talks with the Premier League about taking over from Carling as the new title sponsors from next season. P48

DAILY MAIL

Sarah Ferguson is spearheading an ad campaign for one of the world's largest investment houses. P5

After more than 1,300 workers at Bolton Council took the mickey out of Keith Laird, Channel 4 has said it is unlikely that Peter Kay will ever play Keith Lard again. P21

Rory McGrath has been told by BBC bosses that his joke on They Think It's All Over went too far. P41

EMI may have to stay single as nothing has been decided with Bertelsmann. P79

DAILY EXPRESS

Why Keith Laird is not amused by TV's Mr Lard. P11

TV watchdogs have attacked Channel 4 for allowing swearing, violence and references to paedophilia. P11

Sarah Ferguson is giving Americans advice on managing money in a new ad campaign. P23

Rowan Atkinson is to star as a villain in a new film about Scooby Doo. P27

THE SUN

Popstars' Darius was not plastic enough to make it, says Garry Bushell. P11

THE MIRROR

EastEnders Mel and Lisa are heading for a bitter feud over Phil Mitchell. P13

Mobile phone users went crazy at Christmas, sending more than 1m messages an hour during December. P17

Fergie stars in finance ads. P19

Corrie couple Roy and Hayley are to finally foster a child. P21

THE STAR

EastEnders is thrashing Corrie in the mobile phone tone war - more users are downloading EastEnders as their ring tones. P3

Peter Kay has cost Channel 4 £10,000. P5

Mr Bean star is to earn £3m as a baddie in Scooby Doo. P6

AND FINALLY...

Someone is going to have to do a good PR job on Labour in time for the next election, after a poll revealed Labour is seen as more 'sleazy' than the Tories. Are Trevor Beattie and Alastair Campbell up for the task? Telegraph. P1

webTitle: Why many SMEs are holding back from outsourcing IT

fields.headline: No more do it yourself
fields.standfirst: Outsourcing IT is supposed to be cheaper and easier than managing it in-house. Yet many SMEs are holding back. Guy Clapperton asks why
fields.trailText: Outsourcing IT is supposed to be cheaper and easier than managing it in-house. Yet many SMEs are holding back. Guy Clapperton asks why
fields.body:
Imagine a world in which every business is responsible for its own telecommunications system. Not just for paying the bill, but for buying, installing, arranging a maintenance contract and operating the telephone systems. Add to this the notion that every company would have to take care of its own money; there would be no banks, just a mattress in the managing director's office into which numerous fivers would be sewn.

The ideas sound ludicrous, yet this is exactly what the vast majority of companies do with their computer installations, which can be equally complex. It is into this space that the application service provider (ASP) has emerged. The idea is straightforward enough: the customer pays to have all of their applications and information on an ASP's system, which they access via the internet (see box below). It started in the corporate world but stalled somewhat, as Butler Group's director of research Mike Thompson explains: "We always said we didn't feel that size of organisation would be happy to have their applications and their data outside their direct control." In addition to this, although there are cost savings to be had from the ASP idea, most if not all blue-chip companies already had their IT under the management of in-house specialists.

Clearly, the same was not true of small to medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). These organisations, previously denied the analytical power of such high-end offerings as Walker's financial systems, were suddenly able to rent time on these sorts of systems without having to buy the servers or configure the systems. Maybe it is a little odd, then, that the market still hasn't really taken off.

There are a number of reasons for this, the first of which is likely to be the sheer conservatism of SME managers. In most cases an attempt at selling them the idea of farming their technology out to a third party will meet with a blank stare and a question as to why they should spend time and money fixing their systems when basically they work.

There is also the issue of trust. "My advice to ASPs is to get some sturdy systems and service level agreements in place. The ones that do this have the upper hand as they're ensuring customers get value for money," says Simon Robinson, Europe, Middle East and Africa marketing manager at e-commerce infrastructure specialist NetIQ.

Other companies - mostly ASPs themselves that have vested interests - have commissioned independent research on why the ASP model isn't capturing people's imagination. Interliant, for example, found five major reasons for using ASPs: the cost/headcount ratio improved; technical support was good; skill shortages were largely eliminated; implementation was fast, and the service level agreement - the document guaranteeing a certain standard of performance - was better than most internal IT departments could offer. The reasons people weren't using the services included already having a tailor-made system in place, already having the right skills in-house, and a feeling that the applications were already managed properly in-house. "What was most interesting from the research was the disparity between difficulties expected when using an ASP from those actually experienced," says David Yuile, Interliant UK managing director. "For example, while only 15% of respondents expected that there would 'no problems' at all if they used an ASP, an enormous 46% reported there actually being 'no problems' when they did use an ASP."

Perceptions are not the only inhibitor. Everything an ASP does will be delivered via an internet connection, and in the UK a constant, reliable connection is not cheap - leased lines, which are among the most reliable forms of connection, start at £3,000 per annum, and it is worth repeating that ASPs at the moment are asking their customers to replace an internal system which is basically working.

Nevertheless, many analysts believe ASPs will become increasingly important, and the market is already showing signs of segmenting to fuel that growth. International Data Corporation is forecasting an ASP market worth £480 million by 2004, and many large software companies are developing a strategy in which their products can be delivered in this way. Sean O'Reilly, vice-president of marketing for ASP Netstore, says: "The implementation of an ASP strategy by some of the world's largest software vendors - for example, Microsoft, Sun and Oracle - demonstrates that this software delivery method is increasingly seen as a business reality."

The segmentation is evident in the emergence of the Internet Business Services initiative (IBSi). A spokeswoman explains: "The mission of the IBSi is to separate its members from 'traditional' ASPs, which it believes are simply retro-fitting expensive, cumbersome, packaged software for the internet as opposed to developing applications from the ground up for delivery over the web."

Whatever the truth of this, ASPs are showing signs of growth in certain markets. John Wilmott, managing director of analyst NelsonHall, suggests the business hasn't grown as quickly as the early predictions had suggested. He points to the difficulties in offering a 'one-to-many' (one ASP host with many clients) service for businesses when they actually want a more tailored service. There are two areas in which he suggests there will be faster than average growth, though: "The best opportunities for one-to-many remain in areas close to the IT infrastructure such as traditional ISP services, back-ups and so on," he says. "Start-ups are more likely to buy ASP services than established organisations since they require cost-effective speed to market and have less of a business process history."

The idea of importing a specialist to handle complex technical problems must- as long as it is done right - ultimately make sense. The difficulty facing ASPs is to persuade a market used to hype and hollow acronyms that they can offer a service of genuine value.

What is an ASP?

An application service provider (ASP) will tell you the service they offer is brand new, but this is not absolutely true. We've been here before, from 1960s-style 'bureaux' to 'outsourcing partners' with high-flying corporate clients. In many ways there is little difference between outsourcing - in which a company pays an independent company to send staff to install, maintain and manage systems and remain on site in lieu of support staff - and an ASP. The key difference is that the ASP's work takes place on its own site.

An ASP at its most basic is an organisation that rents space on its computer systems, into which customers can dial and access their applications - everything from a word processor to a complex suite of financial applications can be run independently through a web browser.

There are many advantages in this. Smaller businesses have access to business tools they would otherwise not have. Lotus Notes, hitherto aimed at the corporate environment, requires dedicated computers called servers to run and staff dedicated to its management.
The financial outlay required is reduced because the ASP will be handling more than one company's systems. Fewer software licences are needed because users will only dial into, for example, the accounting system when they need it rather than running effectively redundant copies on different workstations.

Many software systems companies have responded to the emergence of ASPs by offering cut-down versions of their systems. Enterprise resource planning organisations - the likes of SAP, which makes an integrated manufacturing, distribution and financial application - typically took months if not years to configure their systems correctly. Now, elements of it can be rented from an ASP with vastly reduced set-up time and costs.

The idea also carries a number of negative points, though more psychological than technical and involving the security of an ASP's system and the soundness of the ASP's business. Most small businesses regard their customer data as their main asset and the idea of storing that information on someone else's computer can be problematic. Many analysts are convinced the advantages outweigh the drawbacks and the business as a concept will succeed. However, John Serle, chair of the Society of IT Management's best practice committee, remains unconvinced. "The problem before with the model was that providers relied on a return on investment period that proved unrealistic. In today's volatile IT market this is likely to be even more of a challenge," he says.

EquIP gets back to basics

EquIP was established last year to supply internet infrastructure products, usually through channel partners. When the company was set up it intended to sell to application service providers (ASPs) as well as other organisations. For consistency, therefore, it elected to farm all its computer applications and infrastructure out to London-based ASP Pasporte.
The impetus to use an ASP came partly from the need to save money but also to prevent problems arising when the company needed to grow - if someone else was responsible for networking and other technical infrastructure as the company grew, the company itself could concentrate on its core business.

Joint managing director Neil Ledger says EquIP has been delighted with the results so far. "The financial director in particular is pleased because we're using systems we couldn't have had otherwise," he says. The complete system includes a Sage accountancy system, Business Objects intelligence software and Lotus Notes Domino for messaging and web services. Pasporte installed the systems over a weekend and included

remote diagnostic and monitoring tools so that if a problem arises it can be fixed without a site visit wherever possible, taking the maintenance task away from EquIP altogether.
Security and constant availability are crucial in an agreement like this, so one of the first things EquIP did was to inspect Pasporte's equipment; as a company with a background it knew what to look for to gain reassurance. The other issue the company considered important was the paperwork. "We have a written service level agreement," says Ledger. This outlines how the service works and what the compensation will be if it fails.

The end result is that EquIP has the use of systems that would normally be associated with far larger businesses, with none of the expense or time of maintaining and upgrading it. The costs are per user and per month, so the charges will be entirely predictable.

webTitle: Why many SMEs are holding back from outsourcing IT

fields.headline: No more do it yourself
fields.standfirst: Outsourcing IT is supposed to be cheaper and easier than managing it in-house. Yet many SMEs are holding back. Guy Clapperton asks why
fields.trailText: Outsourcing IT is supposed to be cheaper and easier than managing it in-house. Yet many SMEs are holding back. Guy Clapperton asks why
fields.body:
Imagine a world in which every business is responsible for its own telecommunications system. Not just for paying the bill, but for buying, installing, arranging a maintenance contract and operating the telephone systems. Add to this the notion that every company would have to take care of its own money; there would be no banks, just a mattress in the managing director's office into which numerous fivers would be sewn.

The ideas sound ludicrous, yet this is exactly what the vast majority of companies do with their computer installations, which can be equally complex. It is into this space that the application service provider (ASP) has emerged. The idea is straightforward enough: the customer pays to have all of their applications and information on an ASP's system, which they access via the internet (see box below). It started in the corporate world but stalled somewhat, as Butler Group's director of research Mike Thompson explains: "We always said we didn't feel that size of organisation would be happy to have their applications and their data outside their direct control." In addition to this, although there are cost savings to be had from the ASP idea, most if not all blue-chip companies already had their IT under the management of in-house specialists.

Clearly, the same was not true of small to medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). These organisations, previously denied the analytical power of such high-end offerings as Walker's financial systems, were suddenly able to rent time on these sorts of systems without having to buy the servers or configure the systems. Maybe it is a little odd, then, that the market still hasn't really taken off.

There are a number of reasons for this, the first of which is likely to be the sheer conservatism of SME managers. In most cases an attempt at selling them the idea of farming their technology out to a third party will meet with a blank stare and a question as to why they should spend time and money fixing their systems when basically they work.

There is also the issue of trust. "My advice to ASPs is to get some sturdy systems and service level agreements in place. The ones that do this have the upper hand as they're ensuring customers get value for money," says Simon Robinson, Europe, Middle East and Africa marketing manager at e-commerce infrastructure specialist NetIQ.

Other companies - mostly ASPs themselves that have vested interests - have commissioned independent research on why the ASP model isn't capturing people's imagination. Interliant, for example, found five major reasons for using ASPs: the cost/headcount ratio improved; technical support was good; skill shortages were largely eliminated; implementation was fast, and the service level agreement - the document guaranteeing a certain standard of performance - was better than most internal IT departments could offer. The reasons people weren't using the services included already having a tailor-made system in place, already having the right skills in-house, and a feeling that the applications were already managed properly in-house. "What was most interesting from the research was the disparity between difficulties expected when using an ASP from those actually experienced," says David Yuile, Interliant UK managing director. "For example, while only 15% of respondents expected that there would 'no problems' at all if they used an ASP, an enormous 46% reported there actually being 'no problems' when they did use an ASP."

Perceptions are not the only inhibitor. Everything an ASP does will be delivered via an internet connection, and in the UK a constant, reliable connection is not cheap - leased lines, which are among the most reliable forms of connection, start at £3,000 per annum, and it is worth repeating that ASPs at the moment are asking their customers to replace an internal system which is basically working.

Nevertheless, many analysts believe ASPs will become increasingly important, and the market is already showing signs of segmenting to fuel that growth. International Data Corporation is forecasting an ASP market worth £480 million by 2004, and many large software companies are developing a strategy in which their products can be delivered in this way. Sean O'Reilly, vice-president of marketing for ASP Netstore, says: "The implementation of an ASP strategy by some of the world's largest software vendors - for example, Microsoft, Sun and Oracle - demonstrates that this software delivery method is increasingly seen as a business reality."

The segmentation is evident in the emergence of the Internet Business Services initiative (IBSi). A spokeswoman explains: "The mission of the IBSi is to separate its members from 'traditional' ASPs, which it believes are simply retro-fitting expensive, cumbersome, packaged software for the internet as opposed to developing applications from the ground up for delivery over the web."

Whatever the truth of this, ASPs are showing signs of growth in certain markets. John Wilmott, managing director of analyst NelsonHall, suggests the business hasn't grown as quickly as the early predictions had suggested. He points to the difficulties in offering a 'one-to-many' (one ASP host with many clients) service for businesses when they actually want a more tailored service. There are two areas in which he suggests there will be faster than average growth, though: "The best opportunities for one-to-many remain in areas close to the IT infrastructure such as traditional ISP services, back-ups and so on," he says. "Start-ups are more likely to buy ASP services than established organisations since they require cost-effective speed to market and have less of a business process history."

The idea of importing a specialist to handle complex technical problems must- as long as it is done right - ultimately make sense. The difficulty facing ASPs is to persuade a market used to hype and hollow acronyms that they can offer a service of genuine value.

What is an ASP?

An application service provider (ASP) will tell you the service they offer is brand new, but this is not absolutely true. We've been here before, from 1960s-style 'bureaux' to 'outsourcing partners' with high-flying corporate clients. In many ways there is little difference between outsourcing - in which a company pays an independent company to send staff to install, maintain and manage systems and remain on site in lieu of support staff - and an ASP. The key difference is that the ASP's work takes place on its own site.

An ASP at its most basic is an organisation that rents space on its computer systems, into which customers can dial and access their applications - everything from a word processor to a complex suite of financial applications can be run independently through a web browser.

There are many advantages in this. Smaller businesses have access to business tools they would otherwise not have. Lotus Notes, hitherto aimed at the corporate environment, requires dedicated computers called servers to run and staff dedicated to its management.
The financial outlay required is reduced because the ASP will be handling more than one company's systems. Fewer software licences are needed because users will only dial into, for example, the accounting system when they need it rather than running effectively redundant copies on different workstations.

Many software systems companies have responded to the emergence of ASPs by offering cut-down versions of their systems. Enterprise resource planning organisations - the likes of SAP, which makes an integrated manufacturing, distribution and financial application - typically took months if not years to configure their systems correctly. Now, elements of it can be rented from an ASP with vastly reduced set-up time and costs.

The idea also carries a number of negative points, though more psychological than technical and involving the security of an ASP's system and the soundness of the ASP's business. Most small businesses regard their customer data as their main asset and the idea of storing that information on someone else's computer can be problematic. Many analysts are convinced the advantages outweigh the drawbacks and the business as a concept will succeed. However, John Serle, chair of the Society of IT Management's best practice committee, remains unconvinced. "The problem before with the model was that providers relied on a return on investment period that proved unrealistic. In today's volatile IT market this is likely to be even more of a challenge," he says.

EquIP gets back to basics

EquIP was established last year to supply internet infrastructure products, usually through channel partners. When the company was set up it intended to sell to application service providers (ASPs) as well as other organisations. For consistency, therefore, it elected to farm all its computer applications and infrastructure out to London-based ASP Pasporte.
The impetus to use an ASP came partly from the need to save money but also to prevent problems arising when the company needed to grow - if someone else was responsible for networking and other technical infrastructure as the company grew, the company itself could concentrate on its core business.

Joint managing director Neil Ledger says EquIP has been delighted with the results so far. "The financial director in particular is pleased because we're using systems we couldn't have had otherwise," he says. The complete system includes a Sage accountancy system, Business Objects intelligence software and Lotus Notes Domino for messaging and web services. Pasporte installed the systems over a weekend and included

remote diagnostic and monitoring tools so that if a problem arises it can be fixed without a site visit wherever possible, taking the maintenance task away from EquIP altogether.
Security and constant availability are crucial in an agreement like this, so one of the first things EquIP did was to inspect Pasporte's equipment; as a company with a background it knew what to look for to gain reassurance. The other issue the company considered important was the paperwork. "We have a written service level agreement," says Ledger. This outlines how the service works and what the compensation will be if it fails.

The end result is that EquIP has the use of systems that would normally be associated with far larger businesses, with none of the expense or time of maintaining and upgrading it. The costs are per user and per month, so the charges will be entirely predictable.

webTitle: Learning difficulties ad

fields.headline: JWT unveils Special Olympics ad
fields.trailText: 9.30am: JWT London has launched an ad to to tackle prejudices about people with learning difficulties, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
A powerful commercial designed to tackle prejudices about people with learning difficulties was launched this week by J Walter Thompson London.

The ad is designed to promote the forthcoming Special Olympics European Week of Football.

The Special Olympics is a year-long international programme of sports training and competition for people with learning difficulties.

The star of the film is Barry Cairns, a 35-year-old man with Down's Syndrome, who begins by talking about the way people react to him.

"People look at you. They stare. They point at you. They shout. They make you feel different," he says.

But his final words, "It's fantastic", reveal that far from trying to elicit our sympathy, Mr Cairns is describing the uplifting experience of competing in the Special Olympics.

The ad ends with him being carried, smiling, through a crowd of cheering supporters.

"Everyone on the set was won over by Barry's intelligence, his uncomplicated attitude to life and his sheer niceness," said Charles Hendley, who directed the ad.

"While dealing with some tough issues that individuals with mental handicaps face, the advertisement's celebratory closing shots can't fail to leave you with a positive uplifting mindset that confirms the philosophy underlying the Special Olympics movement."

JWT is now seeking free airtime for the film across Europe through its sister media agency, MindShare.

The agency became involved in the project through WPP chief executive Martin Sorrell, who is on the board of the Special Olympics.

webTitle: Budweiser pulls out of Premier League bidding

fields.headline: Budweiser pulls out of Premier League bidding
fields.trailText:
9.15am: Budweiser is said to have pulled out of its bid to become the next sponsor of the Premier League, writes Julia Day.
Jan 19: Carling boots out Premier League
fields.body:
Budweiser is said to have pulled out of its bid to become the next sponsor of the Premier League.

The Anheuser-Busch brand is believed to have had concerns over lack of control over advertising at football grounds, according to a report today.

The brand, whose ad campaign has put the words "Whassup?" on every schoolboy's lips, was expected to pay £20m a year to sponsor the league.

The decision to back down from the sponsorship is a potential disaster for the Premier League.

Only two weeks ago, current sponsor Carling has abandoned talks about renewing its sponsorship, blaming "protracted" negotiations.

The shock decision ends an eight-year association between the two parties, with Carling's current four-year deal worth £36m.

Bass, the brewery that owns Carling, made the decision after a meeting of Premier League club chairmen failed to give a verdict on a renewed deal.

Budweiser then became hot favourite to clinch the deal.

webTitle: Lockerbie verdict today

fields.headline: Lockerbie verdict today
fields.standfirst:
Lockerbie verdict today to decide fate of Libyans

Special report: Libya and the Lockerbie trial
fields.trailText: The two Libyans accused of the 1988 Lockerbie bombing will learn their fate today when the panel of judges at the Scottish court sitting in the Netherlands returns its verdict.
fields.body:
The two Libyans accused of the 1988 Lockerbie bombing will learn their fate today when the panel of judges at the Scottish court sitting in the Netherlands returns its verdict.

After deliberating on the eight months of evidence before the court the judges will decide whether Abdelbaset Al Megrahi and Al Amin Khalifa Fhimah are guilty of the biggest act of mass murder in British history.

The judges retired almost two weeks ago to consider the hugely technical evidence in this long-running case: their deliberations span more than 230 witnesses, 10,232 pages of court transcripts and more than 3m words.

But when the court reconvenes at Camp Zeist this morning the verdict on the sole charge of murder faced by the Libyans will be delivered in a few familiar phrases: guilty, not guilty or the Scottish peculiarity of not proven. The judges will then release the reasons for their verdict in a written judgment.

If the verdict is either not guilty or not proven the men will be free to leave their cells in the specially constructed £12m compound. The UN has already arranged for a fighter plane to guard the Libyans on their journey back to Tripoli.

If the verdict is guilty the judges, led by Lord Sutherland, have only one option: they must sentence the Libyans to life imprisonment. It is expected, however, that if this is the outcome the men will seek - and be granted - leave to appeal.

While awaiting the outcome they would remain in Camp Zeist. If the appeal was unsuccessful they would serve their sentence in Scotland.

The Libyans have always denied they planted the bomb which blew up Pan Am flight 103 over Lockerbie on December 21 1988, killing all 259 passengers and crew on board and 11 people on the ground.

The prosecution admits its case is wholly circumstantial. Richard Keen QC, counsel for Fhimah, said the case was built simply on "inference after inference". William Taylor QC, counsel for Megrahi, also claimed there was insufficient evidence. The prosecution says the bomb was planted at Maltaís Luqa airport on an Air Malta plane , then transferred onto the Pan Am jumbo at Frankfurt.

Both Megrahi and Fhimah worked for Libyan Arab Airlines at Luqa airport. Megrahi is alleged to have been working undercover for the Libyan security services, the JSO, and Fhimah is alleged to have helped him get the bomb on board the aircraft.

Mr Keen and Mr Taylor are relying on a special defence of incrimination which blames the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine General Command, among others, for the atrocity. The defence says this Damascus-based group blew up flight 103 in retaliation for the attack on an Iranian airbus by the USS Vincennes in the Gulf in July 1988.

The families of those who died say they will seek more answers about the bombing - in US courts and through a public inquiry in Britain.

webTitle: 'Everyone has a right to lay the dead to rest'

fields.headline: 'Everyone has a right to lay the dead to rest'
fields.standfirst:
Parents tell of fresh grief on finding out the true scale of the organ removal

Special report: Alder Hey hospital
fields.trailText: Phillip (3 months)
fields.body:
Phillip (3 months)

Phillip was one of twins. He died in his pram in 1988 apparently from sudden infant death syndrome. His body was taken to hospital and removed from his parents by a nurse. They were not told where the body was held for four days.

During this time a coroner's postmortem examination was carried out without their knowledge. All the organs, including the heart and brain, were retained without parental consent.

When the family saw Phillip in the mortuary the autopsy had caused his features to drop to the back of his head. His mother described his appearance as horrible.

Subsequently, at a Foundation of Infant Deaths conference, they met Professor Van Velzen, who had carried out the postmortem examination. He said that Phillip's organs were normal and there was no explanation for his death. He said it was "rather like buying a light bulb and the shop testing it before taking it home yet when the bulb was fitted at home it failed".

Phillip's twin was detained in hospital on and off for three months and underwent very extensive, distressing tests. In the end there was no obvious conclusion.

In December 1999 his parents discovered that Phillip's organs had been retained. Initially they were told of partial retention, from brain to reproductive organs. A second burial took place in January 2000. It had always been their desire to bury their child intact.

They now feel that they were told lies by Alder Hey in December 1999. This has left them with concerns about whether Phillip's other organs have been used for pharmaceutical research and whether his eyes were removed. They were incredulous at the retention of his reproductive organs and this in itself raised their suspicion.

Their overriding concern is why the organs were retained. If some useful research had been carried out it might have comforted them.

Kathryn (15 years)

Kathryn had Hodgkin's disease and died at Alder Hey in 1993. Less than one hour after her death the clinician asked for permission for a postmortem examination.

Her parents were told that small tissue samples only would be taken, through a restricted incision, from the lung, liver and kidney.

They consented to a limited postmortem examination and signed a handwritten consent form which read as follows: "We, the parents of Kathryn, give permission for removal of tissue for diagnostic and other purposes other than transplantation."

Before her death, Kathryn had been deteriorating under her chemotherapy regime for more than seven weeks. On 19, 20, 22 and 23 August 1993 Kathryn and her parents requested that she be allowed home but this was refused.

Her parents feel that had she been allowed home she would not have been stripped of her organs and she would have been buried with respect and dignity.

On 8 December 1999, her parents were informed by Alder Hey that Kathryn's heart, chest and abdomen organs had been retained.

On 20 December 1999 they received a letter from Hilary Rowland, the chief executive at Alder Hey, indicating that the heart, lung, liver, spleen and kidneys had been retained. The parents remain concerned that other organs may have been retained. They do not trust the management at Alder Hey.

Their view is that parents are generous when a child dies. Even now they want to make things better. They do not want others to go through what they have been through.

Ross (5 months)

Ross was born prematurely at 27 weeks and died in 1990 at Liverpool maternity hospital. The cause of his death was cardio-respiratory arrest consequent upon chronic lung disease.

His parents consented to a postmortem examination to determine the cause of death if it would help other children who had the same disease. No steps were taken to explain the consent form to them.

They were never told that whole organs would be removed and retained. They thought they had buried their son intact whereas in fact they buried a husk. They insist on the need for fully informed consent.

In November 1999 the whole of Ross's organs were returned by Alder Hey and buried. As they interred the organs they discovered that the casket bore the inscription for a child of four years, two months yet Ross was only five months old when he died. This caused additional unneccessary grief. His parents are angry that there was never any discussion following death of the desire or intention to retain organs. Had they been asked for retention of the heart and lungs to investigate chronic lung disease they would have agreed.

Claire (14 years)

Claire died in 1988 from a paracetamol overdose. There was a coroner's postmortem and an inquest. Her parents thought they had had buried their daughter's remains intact, they were not told that organs would be retained. However, they say their treatment at Alder Hey at the time of the loss was extremely sensitive and sympathetic.

This is an unusual case. The usual attempt at justification for organ retention is not applicable. It cannot have been to assist with research into infant mortal ity because Claire was almost 15 when she died. It cannot have been to assist research into congenital heart disease because her heart was strong.

There cannot be any justification for stockpiling organs awaiting final postmortem reports. Her parents have not been given any explanation as to why Claire's organs were retained and were not told why the postmortem examination was carried out.

Her father says he thinks everyone has a right to lay the dead to rest. It is a critical right because it is part of the grieving process. It is doubly important with the loss of a child because that in itself is an obscenity of nature. The long and difficult grieving process cost him his marriage, his career prospects and a heart attack.

webTitle: Uncanny resemblance costs TV comedy dear

fields.headline: Uncanny resemblance costs TV comedy dear
fields.trailText: Channel 4 television has paid thousands to a fire safety officer who complained that a comic character was based on him, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Channel 4 television has paid thousands to a fire safety officer who complained that a comic character was based on him, it emerged yesterday.

Keith Laird, who works for Bolton council, complained after a character called Keith Lard appeared on screen bearing an uncanny resemblance.

Lard appears on comic Peter Kay's show Phoenix Nights with a bushy moustache, wears a luminous yellow jacket and has an overzealous approach to fire safety. Mr Laird was shocked when the television fire chief was portrayed as enjoying bestiality, and workmates started to tease him.

Mr Kay, also from Bolton, who created the persona, stressed that the character was fictional.

But it is reported that a figure of £10,000 was split between Mr Laird and other organisations.

A spokesman for Channel 4 said yesterday that a payment and an apology had been made to Mr Laird.

After the show was broadcast on Sunday, Channel 4 stated that the character was not based on Mr Laird.

The controversial episode is expected to be repeated on Thursday night.

Press Association

webTitle: Prank backfires on Trigger Happy fan

fields.headline: Prank backfires on Trigger Happy fan
fields.trailText: Staging a spoof robbery might have seemed like a hilarious prank but Trigger Happy TV devotee Paul Booth found even he was struggling to see the funny side after an attempt to emulate the cult show went spectacularly wrong.
fields.body:
Staging a spoof robbery might have seemed like a hilarious prank but Trigger Happy TV devotee Paul Booth found even he was struggling to see the funny side after an attempt to emulate the cult show went spectacularly wrong.

Customers and staff looked on in horror as Booth, who was dressed as a postman, was suddenly attacked by two teenagers in the high street post office in Southend, Essex, on December 21.

But the stunt backfired and landed the would-be joker and friends in court after post office staff gave chase to all three. Booth was captured in a nearby store with the help of members of the public and held until police arrived.

His friends, who cannot be named for legal reasons, were also arrested.

The Trigger Happy TV fan later told police they had been filming the incident on a camcorder after being inspired by Dom Joly's stunts on the cult Channel 4 programme. Yesterday, in Southend magistrates court, Booth admitted using threatening behaviour and was fined £100 and ordered to pay £55 costs.

The case against the two teenagers was adjourned.

After the hearing Booth, who is unemployed, said he was sorry for any upset caused.

He added: "Dom Joly is my God."

webTitle: BBC set to win Lennox Lewis deal

fields.headline: BBC set to win Lennox Lewis deal
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The BBC is close to signing a deal with the heavyweight boxing champion Lennox Lewis, writes David Teather.
fields.body:
The BBC is close to signing a deal with the heavyweight boxing champion Lennox Lewis, bolstering the corporation's plan to restore its reputation as a serious challenger for the rights over leading sports.

The agreement, which could mean the boxer being paid up to £1m a fight, signals the return of top-flight boxing to the BBC. The corporation will screen its first heavyweight title clash for more than a decade when Lewis meets the little known US fighter, Hasim Rahman, in April.

But the real prize will be the expected contest against Mike Tyson, likely to take place later this year.

The deal lures Lewis from Rupert Murdoch's Sky, which has held the rights to screen the fighter's matches for the past seven years.

In recent weeks the BBC has demonstrated its ability to go a few rounds with Mr Murdoch. Ten days ago it announced a 10-fight package to screen bouts featuring the Olympic gold medallist Audley Harrison, who makes his professional debut in the next few months.

BBC chiefs have also held "exploratory talks" with the featherweight title-holder, Naseem Hamed, who has only two fights left before his Sky deal ends.

Yesterday, a Sky spokesman confirmed Lewis's next bout would be on the BBC. "We've enjoyed some memorable times with Lennox, particularly the two Evander Holyfield fights, and wish him continued success," he said.

The aim of the BBC's director general, Greg Dyke, is to rebuild a presence in sport after competition from rival broadcasters over a decade with bigger budgets. The BBC's position was gradually eroded. It lost rights to England's home test matches in cricket, England home rugby union matches, and Grand Prix motor racing. The worst humiliation was the loss of Match of the Day to ITV after 36 years.

Mr Dyke now appears to be building a bridgehead in boxing, which regularly drew audiences of 15m to 18m in the 1980s. The last world heavy weight fight screened by the corporation was Frank Bruno losing to Mike Tyson in 1989. Mr Dyke, a former boxing journalist, is close to the promoter Frank Warren from his days at ITV and could tempt him back to the corporation as well.

The BBC also signed a deal to broadcast the World Amateur Boxing Championships in Belfast in June, and the Four Nations ABA tournament in Liverpool in April.

The choice for Lewis was not straightforward maths. The BBC may be offering less cash upfront but higher audience figures can mean better sponsorship deals. Like Harrison, Lennox is also keen for the higher profile of the BBC which has built longevity into the careers of Frank Bruno and Chris Eubank.

At 35, Lennox is nearing the end of his career and will be eager to increase his job prospects. Sky, which shows big fights on a pay-per-view basis, generally musters between only 200,000 and 300,000 viewers.

Sporting events are at the forefront of attempts to win in the ratings war and their value has escalated almost exponentially in recent years. Last summer, the live rights to football's Premiership went to Sky for £1.11bn, for a three-year package starting this autumn. In 1986, the last year of the BBC and ITV cartel, the rights to the then First Division were sold for just £3.1m a year.

The BBC has been fighting back on several fronts. It has won the FA Cup and England's home internationals in football, as well as agreed a £42m deal to keep the Premiership on Radio 5 Live for the next three years. It is planning a standalone sports channel, thought to be in partnership with cable firm NTL.

 Paul Ingle, who suffered a brain blood clot during his featherweight title bout against South Africa's Mbulelo Botile last month, is recovering in a rehabilitation centre near his home, it was disclosed yesterday. A spokesman for the Royal Hallamshire hospital in Sheffield said Ingle, 28, had made good progress.

webTitle: The lack of clarity in performance assessments of social services

fields.headline: A clear mix-up
fields.standfirst: One says you're fine, the next says you're not. Why are performance assessments of social services so confusing, and which should we believe?  Steve Brown  reports
fields.trailText: One says you're fine, the next says you're not. Why are performance assessments of social services so confusing, and which should we believe? Steve Brown reports
fields.body:
When the health department published its second set of social care performance indicators in October last year, the key word was clarity. Explaining the introduction of its new banding system in a letter to council managers, social care minister John Hutton said the bands in the performance assessment framework answered "concerns raised last year about the ease of interpretation for those not expert in handling data". Councillors, users, carers, managers and the public, he says, would all be able to "better understand and question the performance of their local social services".

And what is clear, according to the indicators for 1999-2000, is that things are getting better. More than 120 of the 150 councils with responsibilities for social services showed improvements against 50% or more of the indicators.

So far so good. But the message becomes somewhat confused when you look at other official sources of information on the care provided by social services departments. Hutton says the in-depth joint review reports on individual departments, undertaken by the social services inspectorate and the audit commission, back up the view that social services are getting better overall, but the reports' findings on some councils seem to be at odds with their performance as measured by the indicators.

Take Derbyshire county council, for instance. The performance assessment framework rated it one of the three best social services departments in England, along with Redbridge, in east London, and Derby. It was found to provide services of an "acceptable", "good" or "very good" quality on 30 of the 37 performance measures. Yet the assessment of the joint review team found that its services were patchy, with only some people being served well.

"Despite Derbyshire's sound reputation for innovation," the assessment concluded, "it has failed to provide a level of consistency which benefits all local residents."

Or look at Redbridge. The joint review's conclusion? "Redbridge council is having some difficulty in providing adequate social services to all its residents." So much for clarity.

The mixed messages continue at the other end of the table. West Berkshire was one of six councils named by the health department as causing concern, as they earned ratings of "investigate urgently" or "ask questions about performance" in more than half the 37 indicators. Yet the headline message from its joint review was far from damning, concluding that the council provides good social services to some people and has excellent prospects for improvement.

What is going on? From an administration that has made joined-up government its holy grail, this seems a poor start to the crusade.

Birmingham city council was the subject of a highly critical joint review last summer. The findings were not disputed by the authority, and its director of social services, Sandra Taylor, who arrived at Birmingham just prior to the review team's visit at the end of 1999, has set in motion a series of changes aimed at addressing many of the problems. But looking at the performance assessment framework, you'd hardly get the idea that this was a department struggling with major difficulties in performance.

"While there is a spread in our performance assessment framework indicators, you'd think that we are a relatively OK department," says Taylor, although she accepts that the framework does raise questions about unit costs and child protection registrations. "The performance assessment framework is meant to help the public understand a service," she says. "But, on the face of it, in Birmingham the framework and the joint review tell different stories."

Derbyshire's social services director, Bruce Buckley, admits that there were mixed messages coming out of the county's joint review and its performance assessment ratings. And although he says this hasn't led to local confusion among the public, it did lead to staff being told one week that they are good at keeping people at home, for instance, only to be told the next week that they lack consistency in performance. "The intention is that the two systems should be complementary," he said. "But they haven't got to that stage yet."

It may just be at headline level that confusion arises. Redbridge, for instance, says there is a lot of consistency in the detail of both assessment systems. For instance, its joint review highlighted the performance of its registration and inspection unit as demonstrating good practice, which fits with its 100% top band score in the relevant performance indicator.

Given the health department's insistence that indicators "only indicate" and should not be used by themselves to judge performance, it was perhaps a poor decision to go public on the so-called best and worst performers under the performance frame- work. For a start, high scores in some indicators, earning the top banding of "very good", are not necessarily an indication of good performance.

"The performance assessment framework is not a test, and getting top marks doesn't mean you are a good authority," says Moira Gibb, president of the Association of Directors of Social Services (ADSS). "It is about telling you where questions need to be asked." Although she believes the assessment framework is helpful, she says the pursuit of a high score on a particular indicator could be counter productive.

For instance, one indicator measures the number of re-registrations on the child protection register. In general, to do well on this indicator a council needs to keep the number of re-registrations down. "To score well on this indicator might indicate good performance in ensuring children are well supported and safe, or it could mean children are left on the register when they could come off," says Gibb.

On the other hand, a good authority can be characterised by active management of the register, which may increase the number of re-registrations. But this good practice could earn a low score. "Other indicators of performance are needed to get a true picture of an authority," Gibb says.

"With the performance assessment framework and other performance tools, the overall mechanisms are evolving," says Tony Hunter, social services director of East Riding of Yorkshire unitary council and chair of the ADSS standards and performance committee. "The assessment framework is not without its problems and the Department of Health knows that." But he admits that the current system can be confusing. "Sometimes there are risks that different messages are given out," he says. To counter this, he believes councils need to work with the local media to ensure the public get an honest view of how a department is performing.

John Bolton, director of joint reviews, is clearly uncomfortable with the idea of turning the indicators into league tables of overall performance. For a start, choosing a different set of indicators - and there is a bewildering amount of data collected on social care that could produce countless different indicators - could reveal a different overall picture of an authority.

He also says that the reliability of the data being used has to be recognised. Derbyshire's joint review report pointed to the absence of a "robust and reliable management information system". Yet it is this flawed system that will have provided the data for the performance indicators which show Derbyshire as one of the top three councils for social care. While he believes the indicators are an important step forward, he feels they need to be looked at in context.

Bolton accepts that the public could be confused by the seeming contradiction between some councils' performance under the assessment framework and the findings of their joint reviews at least in the headlines that they generate. But he believes help may be at hand. The health department has this month kicked off a series of performance assessment meetings with individual social services departments.

"The Department of Health draws all the sources of information about an authority together - including its joint review, any inspections of services, general inquiries dealt with by the regional office and the management information - and then shares with the authority what it believes are the key messages," says Bolton.

This could lead to a single judgment about an authority. If that can be done and an unambiguous assessment of a council's performance in social care can be derived and, importantly, made public, the clarity and better understanding promised by the health minister may indeed be delivered.

When praise rings hollow

Criticism of Haringey social services in the tragic case of Anna Climbie, the eight-year-old tortured and killed by her carers, stands in sharp contrast to the very positive findings of the joint review of the north London authority.

According to the review report, published in November 1999, the people of Haringey are generally well served by social services and the department is well managed and modernising impressively. Child protection is singled out for praise, particularly the local guidelines on each agency's role and responsibilities and on the "signals" of abuse to watch for.

Although staff involved in the Climbie case have since been defended on grounds of overwork, the joint review team found impressive systems to deal with a pressured workload. The report quotes one team manager as saying: "It certainly allows us to sleep at nights."

And although he says this hasn't led to local confusion among the public, it did lead to staff being told one week that they are good at keeping people at home, for instance, only to be told the next week that they lack consistency in performance. "The intention is that the two systems should be complementary," he said. "But they haven't got to that stage yet." It may just be at headline level that confusion arises. Redbridge, for instance, says there is a lot of consistency in the detail of both assessment systems. For instance, its joint review highlighted the performance of its registration and inspection unit as demonstrating good practice, which fits with its 100% top band score in the relevant performance indicator. Given the health department's insistence that indicators "only indicate" and should not be used by themselves to judge performance, it was perhaps a poor decision to go public on the so-called best and worst performers under the performance frame- work. For a start, high scores in some indicators, earning the top banding of "very good", are not necessarily an indication of good performance. "The performance assessment framework is not a test, and getting top marks doesn't mean you are a good authority," says Moira Gibb, president of the Association of Directors of Social Services (ADSS). "It is about telling you where questions need to be asked." Although she believes the assessment framework is helpful, she says the pursuit of a high score on a particular indicator could be counter productive. For instance, one indicator measures the number of re-registrations on the child protection register. In general, to do well on this indicator a council needs to keep the number of re-registrations down. "To score well on this indicator might indicate good performance in ensuring children are well supported and safe, or it could mean children are left on the register when they could come off," says Gibb. On the other hand, a good authority can be characterised by active management of the register, which may increase the number of re-registrations. But this good practice could earn a low score. "Other indicators of performance are needed to get a true picture of an authority," Gibb says. "With the performance assessment framework and other performance tools, the overall mechanisms are evolving," says Tony Hunter, social services director of East Riding of Yorkshire unitary council and chair of the ADSS standards and performance committee. "The assessment framework is not without its problems and the Department of Health knows that." But he admits that the current system can be confusing. "Sometimes there are risks that different messages are given out," he says. To counter this, he believes councils need to work with the local media to ensure the public get an honest view of how a department is performing. John Bolton, director of joint reviews, is clearly uncomfortable with the idea of turning the indicators into league tables of overall performance. For a start, choosing a different set of indicators - and there is a bewildering amount of data collected on social care that could produce countless different indicators - could reveal a different overall picture of an authority. He also says that the reliability of the data being used has to be recognised. Derbyshire's joint review report pointed to the absence of a "robust and reliable management information system". Yet it is this flawed system that will have provided the data for the performance indicators which show Derbyshire as one of the top three councils for social care. While he believes the indicators are an important step forward, he feels they need to be looked at in context. Bolton accepts that the public could be confused by the seeming contradiction between some councils' performance under the assessment framework and the findings of their joint reviews at least in the headlines that they generate. But he believes help may be at hand. The health department has this month kicked off a series of performance assessment meetings with individual social services departments. "The Department of Health draws all the sources of information about an authority together - including its joint review, any inspections of services, general inquiries dealt with by the regional office and the management information - and then shares with the authority what it believes are the key messages," says Bolton. This could lead to a single judgment about an authority. If that can be done and an unambiguous assessment of a council's performance in social care can be derived and, importantly, made public, the clarity and better understanding promised by the health minister may indeed be delivered. When praise rings hollow Criticism of Haringey social services in the tragic case of Anna Climbie, the eight-year-old tortured and killed by her carers, stands in sharp contrast to the very positive findings of the joint review of the north London authority. According to the review report, published in November 1999, the people of Haringey are generally well served by social services and the department is well managed and modernising impressively. Child protection is singled out for praise, particularly the local guidelines on each agency's role and responsibilities and on the "signals" of abuse to watch for. Although staff involved in the Climbie case have since been defended on grounds of overwork, the joint review team found impressive systems to deal with a pressured workload. The report quotes one team manager as saying: "It certainly allows us to sleep at nights." David Brindle

webTitle: Telegraph drops T2

fields.headline: Telegraph drops T2 print supplement
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The Telegraph is closing its printed teen supplement in favour of producing it online, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
The Telegraph has moved against the tide, taking the unusual step of closing down a print supplement in favour of producing it online.

T2, the 16-page Saturday magazine supplement aimed at teenagers, will publish its last edition on February 24.

The Telegraph T2 brand will then only exist on the internet at T2Online.com.

In contrast, other media companies are pulling money out of the internet and back into their print products.

The Telegraph said the move was a more appropriate use of resources given the wider distribution of the internet.

It also cited opportunities to develop T2Online.com into a news and reviews portal for schoolchildren.

Hugo Drayton, managing director of Hollinger Telegraph New Media, the internet arm of the Telegraph, insisted there would be no redundancies.

The 10 staff from T2 Magazine will be redeployed on T2Online.com.

"This is great news for telegraph.co.uk," said Mr Drayton.

"There will be much more on/offline cross-promotion and the daily product will be much more interactive and interesting."

webTitle: Hollick backs staff in Express websites row

fields.headline: Hollick backs staff in Express websites row
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Lord Hollick, chairman of United Business Media, has intervened in the plight of the 46 former employees of the Express websites who lost their jobs at the start of the month.
fields.body:
Lord Hollick, chairman of United Business Media, has intervened in the plight of the 46 former employees of the Express websites who lost their jobs at the start of the month.

The Labour peer has written to the National Union of Journalists expressing concern at the treatment of the staff who were left without compensation and January pay.

United sold the sites to Richard Desmond's Northern & Shell last November. They were sold on to SP Investments, a subsidiary of Mr Desmond's financial adviser.

In his letter, Lord Hollick said: "We have made it clear to Northern & Shell that we believe there is an obligation for Express Newspapers to pay redundancy and contractual pay to the website employees." United had insisted on an undertaking that all employees' rights would be protected.

Michael Streeter, former editor of Express.co.uk, said: "It is quite unbelievable. He wants to look like a cuddly new Labour man who cares about employee rights, but words are cheap."

It is understood SP and Northern & Shell have agreed in principle to make payments without admitting liability.

webTitle: Boxing back in the big picture with heavyweight deal

fields.headline: Boxing back in the big picture with heavyweight deal
fields.trailText: While BBC executives sweated throughout yesterday, working on the details of a contract designed to bring Lennox Lewis's next world heavyweight title defence to a terrestrial television audience, British boxing was already beginning to celebrate the fact that the sport will once more be given a profile commensurate with its popularity.
fields.body:
While BBC executives sweated throughout yesterday, working on the details of a contract designed to bring Lennox Lewis's next world heavyweight title defence to a terrestrial television audience, British boxing was already beginning to celebrate the fact that the sport will once more be given a profile commensurate with its popularity.

At last there is no need for a dish, a decoder or the dreaded pay-per-view subscription. Once the signatures are in place in the deal, all you will need to see Lewis versus Hasim Rahman on April 21 is a good, old-fashioned TV aerial.

"What?" I hear you say. "He would say that, wouldn't he, because he's been commentating on world championship fights for BBC radio since Adam was a boy," and I confess that the corporation's continued support for boxing as a great radio sport goes a significant way towards paying the mortgage.

But I also admit to genuine excitement that boxing is going back on the national broadcaster's television network, and seriously.

Sky, who have dominated TV boxing coverage since Frank Warren signed a long-term contract in 1995, have done a fine job in following the sport week in, week out. Their commentary team of Ian Darke (an old radio colleague) and Glenn McCrory is outstanding and they are obviously here to stay.

If Lewis fights Mike Tyson later in the year, it is almost inconceivable that a fight of that stature would not be on Sky Box Office, with the public invited to cough up another £15 or so to watch. But the sport is big enough for Sky and the BBC.

As a boxing broadcaster and writer I find it more than a tad tedious answering suggestions, more often than not based on utter ignorance, that the sport is dying. Certainly it has its problems. No sane person would argue in favour of the proliferation of titles under the auspices of various governing bodies. There is corruption in its administration and it will always be dangerous for its practitioners. But that has always been the case. Boxing is alive and well.

Britain has the man in Lewis who is recognised by just about everybody outside the Don King household and the close family and friends of Evander Holyfield as being the world heavyweight champion, who has proved himself a worthy heir to the great names of the past.

Add to him Naseem Hamed, the most charismatic figure in the featherweight division, Joe Calzaghe and Johnny Nelson, not to mention the Olympic superheavyweight champion Audley Harrison, whose fights are also to be shown by the BBC, and even the casual follower should begin to recognise this is a sport at which Britain is actually pretty good.

And there are exciting prospects. The Manchester boys Ricky Hatton, Michael Gomez and Anthony Farnell are typical - all talented and, most likely in the case of Hatton, potential world champions.

But, for all the excellence of Sky's coverage, they are denied the oxygen of publicity for their endeavours. Exposure to a terrestrial television audience could bring national fame.

Fights on ITV involving Chris Eubank, Nigel Benn and Hamed attracted audiences of up to 13m as recently as 1995 and, going further back, the BBC could boast even more spectacular figures for fights involving sporting icons such as Barry McGuigan, Frank Bruno and Henry Cooper.

The new director general of the BBC, Greg Dyke, is a man who cut his teeth in a harsher commercial world and does not need me to bang on about boxing's popularity. As a former ITV bigwig, he knows only too well that boxing not only has the potential to replace Match of the Day in popular sporting culture but is likely to attract a bigger audience.

But what the sport needs is television's support at all levels. Sky has done a great job in showcasing emerging talent and it is to be hoped that that will continue. But fighters and promoters need the crowds, and the sport needs its stars, which is where the BBC - or ITV for that matter - should play its part.

In the final hours of negotiations a counter bid from Sky for Lewis-Rahman prompted some anxious phone calls and furrowed brows at BBC Television Centre but by teatime even Sky's mandarins at Isleworth were accepting that the BBC had won. Once more television boxing in Britain had moved into a healthy world of genuine competition.

Now my greatest hope is that logic prevails and the two competing networks make recorded highlights available to each other. Perhaps that is too much to hope for yet but the BBC and Sky would surely benefit from such forward thinking. And boxing would be the biggest winner of all.

webTitle: Mr Kipling revamps

fields.headline: Mr Kipling updates its image
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Cakes brand Mr Kipling is being relaunched for the first time in its 34-year history, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
Mr Kipling, the Manor Bakeries brand famous for its "exceedingly good" slogan, is being relaunched for the first time in its 34-year history.

The brand, which first appeared in 1967, has been given a wholesale makeover.

Its new logo and packaging are being supported by promotional and advertising campaigns.

The revamp is intended to modernise the Mr Kipling brand, giving it a more consumer-friendly feel.

Saatchi & Saatchi, the agency that handles Manor Bakeries's £6m advertising account, is working on the relaunch campaign.

The activity also includes the launch of a website on February 6.

This is Manor Bakeries's first foray onto the internet.

The site, created by digital agency Zinc, has been designed to appeal to children and mothers.

It provides information on the Mr Kipling product range, activities, games and consumer feedback.

It will also have an area dedicated to the brand's sponsorship of this year's Comic Relief fundraising effort.

The website address will appear on all packaging, promotions and ads.

"We want to give consumers the greatest access to the brand," said Mr Kipling brand manager Hazel Cawthorne.

"The Mr Kipling website has been established to give the brand a modern, confident face.

"We want to make Mr Kipling more accessible and responsive to consumers."

webTitle: ASA ruling on BT ad

fields.headline: ASA defends controversial BT ad
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Advertising watchdogs have rejected complaints about a BT ad that featured a picture of pubic hair, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The Advertising Standards Authority has rejected complaints about a BT ad that used a cartoon image of a woman's pubic hair to sell mobile phones to teenage girls.

The ad, for BT Cellnet, showed a cartoon drawing of a woman's pubic hair escaping from the edge of her bikini bottoms.

It used the line, "Life contains enough embarrassments without your mobile being one."

The ad attracted 17 complaints from members of the public, who slammed it as "distasteful, graphic, lewd and offensive".

The ASA ruled that the ad, which appeared in Sugar, Heat and Hot Tickets magazines, was unlikely to cause widespread or serious offence or to make teenage girls embarrassed about something that was normal.

The use of pubic hair in ads is always highly controversial.

A recent poster campaign for Organics shampoo showed a woman peering into her bikini bottoms to check her natural hair colour.

The ad attracted more than 30 complaints even though it did not actually show pubic hair.

A poster for the fashion retailer Kookai, which showed a man trimming a woman's bikini line with a lawnmower, was banned after it attracted a flood of complaints.
