webTitle: Comment: The Hindujas and the Home Office

fields.headline: The hidden role of the Home Office
fields.standfirst:
Will the Hammond inquiry into the passport affair be a cover-up?

Special report: Mandelson resigns
fields.trailText: Who better - from the government's point of view - to conduct the inquiry into the Hinduja passport affair than Sir Anthony "Wally" Hammond, a man who has spent most of his career protecting Whitehall from embarrassment?
fields.body:
Who better - from the government's point of view - to conduct the inquiry into the Hinduja passport affair than Sir Anthony "Wally" Hammond, a man who has spent most of his career protecting Whitehall from embarrassment?

Moreover, the recently retired Treasury solicitor, chief defender of state secrets, was legal adviser to the Home Office itself at a critical stage of his Whitehall passage.

Whatever the pressures placed on them, the decision to grant two Hinduja brothers (Gopichand and Srichand) British passports was the responsibility of Home Office ministers. Yet it was the home secretary who sealed Mandelson's fate last week when he told Blair that the former Northern Ireland secretary had misled the prime minister.

Straw told Blair there were "problems" with Mandelson's statements that he had no "recollection" of a phone call to Mike O'Brien, the home office minister, in June 1998.

For Hammond's inquiry to be at all meaningful it must answer rather more serious questions about why Mr Straw or his fellow ministers granted the passports than Mandelson's careless response to a call from the Observer newspaper about a call he made to O'Brien two and half years earlier.

The allegation of corruption over the sale of Bofors guns to India had been hanging over the Hinduja brothers for 13 years. It was a huge scandal in India involving claims they used their influence with the late Indian prime minister, Rajiv Gandhi, to secure the Bofors contract allegedly in return for bribes worth $10m placed in secret Swiss bank accounts codenamed Lotus, Tulip, and Mont Blanc.

Ann Widdecombe, Straw's shadow, has stirred the pot by asking Hammond to inquire what the British high commission in Delhi told London about the Indian criminal investigation into the Hindujas, and more pertinently, whether ministers had ignored warnings from MI6 about the dangers, and implications, of giving them British passports.

It would be very odd indeed if the high commission, and other Whitehall departments for that matter, had not given the Home Office warning signals. As for MI6, security sources insist it is not that agency's job to make policy decisions. Maybe not, but MI6 reports are supposed to inform ministers to enable them to make proper decision in the national interest.

Indian prosecutors link the Hinduja brothers' request for British passports to the bribery charges. Their charge sheet issued in New Delhi this week states that "the change of nationality of both these Hinduja brothers is directly linked to the stages in execution of the Letters Rogatory [requests for information by the Indian investigators] in Switzerland".

The chronology of events, as the Indian prosecutors point out, is not entirely coincidental. The brothers' application for British passports were rejected by Kenneth (now Lord) Baker, then home secretary, in 1991, (and the time when Hammond was the Home Office chief legal adviser).

In March 1997 Gopichand reapplies, and four months later offers financial support for the dome. In November that year he gets his passport. In June 1998, a Swiss court agrees to disclose details of bank accounts to Indian investigators, the Hindujas confirm their offer to contribute £3m to the dome's "faith zone", and Mandelson makes his fateful phone call. In October 1998, Srichand reapplies for a British passport and gets it in six months, compared to the average delay of 18 months. In August 1999 a Swiss court dismisses their appeal against the disclosure of the bank details.

There is no doubt that Hammond knows his way around Whitehall. He was legal adviser to the Northern Ireland Office as well as the Home Office, and later legal adviser to the Department of Trade and Industry. But he is not a judge, and was appointed an "honorary" QC only in 1997. The question is whether he will ask the awkward questions and look behind the papers officials in the Home Office, his former department, prepare for him.

Going by his past record, he will not. Evidence to the Scott arms-to-Iraq inquiry revealed how Hammond urged Baker to sign public interest immunity certificates - gagging requests - designed to suppress information, notably about the intelligence agencies, that was to prove vital to the defence in two criminal trials. Lord Scott chided Baker for not questioning the PII claims drawn up by Hammond. More to the point, he criticised Hammond for failing to take into account the impact of his gagging request on the defence.

The episode, and Hammond's history, raise the question whether we should have any confidence in his inquiry. It needs an independent minded judge of Scott's calibre to investigate the murky world of a Whitehall so adept at sophisticated cover-ups.

webTitle: Hard-hitting campaign targets gun crime

fields.headline: Hard-hitting campaign targets gun crime
fields.standfirst: Special report: gun violence in Britain
fields.trailText: Posters showing a man lying in a pool of blood under the words "Young, gifted and dead" went up in north-west London today as part of a campaign to stop gun crime.
fields.body:
Posters showing a man lying in a pool of blood under the words "Young, gifted and dead" went up in north-west London today as part of a campaign to stop gun crime.

The hard-hitting image is being displayed at about 60 sites in Brent, where eight people have been killed and 12 injured in shootings in the last two years.

They spearhead the government-backed Not Another Drop campaign being run by the Metropolitan police and Brent council.

The campaign was launched in Harlesden, which has one of the highest rates of shootings in Britain. In 1999 and 2000 in an area of just a few square miles there were 10 shootings.

The police have taken the radical step of advertising the campaign on pirate radio in an attempt to reach their target audience.

"Harlesden is the epicentre," he said. "Even some of the shootings which take place at raves and other venues outside Harlesden have a Harlesden connection.

"Harlesden is a really nice place with a village atmosphere but this small minority of lunatics, who appear to be detached from reality and often have little concern for their own lives, are ruining things for everyone else."

He said the gangsters used guns smuggled in through the traditional routes for smuggling people, drugs and weapons, either through eastern Europe or the US.

"We have recovered Uzi machine guns which are highly prized by the gangsters and other sorts of guns, too," Mr Farrell said.

The shootings were not always about disputes over drugs or even territory, he said.

"Respect is the cultural issue here. There is a feudal concept of honour and if one person disrespects another they can end up dead. This war is entirely within the black community."

The campaign aims to tackle the violence by improving surveillance. Police plan to use automatic number plate recognition, which has been employed to trap terrorists. The equipment can extract the number plate number from photographs and video footage.

It also has two projects to target young black men - Bears Youth Challenge and the Young Black Male Project. Their aim is to challenge young black men's assumption that their only option is to join the "glamorous" local gangster fraternity.

While some members of the community provide information about shootings, most are reluctant to come forward and testify in court, partly because of fear and partly because of mistrust of the police.

The campaign is establishing a community problem-solving panel to remedy this lack of trust.

Paul Daisley, deputy leader of Brent council, who has represented Harlesden for 10 years and plans to contest Ken Livingstone's Brent East seat for Labour at the next election, said: "Thanks to the evil activities of a handful of people Harlesden has a reputation as a bad and fearful place.

"The time has come for us to take a stand against the gangsters who are a menace on our streets."

North London rapper Semtex acknowledges that some of the more violent rap, particularly some of the US hip-hop output has contributed to the culture of violence among young black men. He is backing the campaign with a specially penned rap song to encourage this group to turn away from violence.

But not everyone supports the campaign's approach. Ferris Lindsay, of Friends of the Family, a Christian evangelical group, said: "This campaign uses a scattergun approach. This will cause distress to children and some adults, too, and it is unlikely to change the minds of those bent on violence."

Commander Mike Fuller, who heads the Met's Operation Trident to tackle gun violence in London, also expressed reservations.

He said he supported the campaign but added: "The methods here are novel. Because this is a hard-hitting campaign using a graphic image there is always a risk that it could heighten the fear of crime in the community." Operation Trident, which was set up last July, has made 116 arrests and recovered 51 guns. Its own advertising material is more conservative, using a target logo.

In November 1999 Mr Fuller made a complaint to the Advertising Standards Authority about a poster for Penguin Books which showed two boys, one who had taken a gun out of his jacket with the words "Be here".

Mr Fuller complained that the image was offensive and irresponsible, especially in areas prone to street crime, and that it promoted the possession of guns by children. His complaint was upheld.

The ASA said it would look at the new poster if it received any complaints but said that just because a poster was shocking did not mean that it was a breach of the ASA code.

An ASA spokesman said: "The issue is whether or not it is likely to cause serious or widespread offence. That is always a judgment call."

webTitle: Obituary: John Paddison

fields.headline: John Paddison
fields.trailText: Leading exponent of the stone-carving tradition of Barlach, Epstein and Gill.
fields.body:
John "Paddy" Paddison, who has died of cancer aged 71, was the leading, if largely unknown, exponent of the stone-carving tradition of Ernst Barlach, Jacob Epstein and Eric Gill. His output and range were astonishing.

One series of sculptures consists of wonderful, large stone-carvings based on the subjects of classical paintings, such as The Flaying of Marsyus and The Deposition. Another is of timeless, everyday events, such as a cat on the back of a sofa, or an evening meal with friends in Carrara - the sort of events one might see preserved forever in the lava of Pompeii.

Paddy's sculptures always transcended their source. This was particularly true of his extraordinary carvings of late 20th-century icons - including, for example, a stone motorcycle, a stone 35mm camera, and a stone traffic-jam in the centre of Wolverhampton. The most eloquent expression of his work was probably his semi-abstracts, in Welsh slate, of the rolling hills, clouds and rain of his beloved central Wales. Today, his work is to be found in several private collections.

Born in Wolverhampton, Paddy studied at Wolverhampton College of Art and, from 1952-56, at the Royal College of Art, under John Skeaping. He was a large man in all senses of the word, and perhaps his taciturn, if charming, personality, together with his then unfashionable work, did not serve him well, particularly in the image-conscious 1960s, when he should have been making his mark on the London gallery scene.

He taught stone-carving sculpture at Wolverhampton for many years, and many former students have distinguished themselves as sculp tors, including Glynn Williams, now professor of sculpture at the RCA.

Paddy moved to central Wales in the mid 1970s to be with his partner, Susan, and had a superb studio in Llandidloes. She committed suicide in the late 1980s, leaving Paddy heart-broken. Those of us privileged to have been among his students know that, like his remarkable work, his simple, direct and unpretentious teaching is never forgotten.

 John Paddison, sculptor and teacher, born June 2 1929; died December 28 2000

webTitle: Obituary: Michael Henderson

fields.headline: Michael Henderson
fields.trailText: Television pioneer and founder of the Alexandra Palace Television Society.
fields.body:
It is the voice of the television pioneer Michael Henderson, who has died aged 80, that is to be heard in the oft-replayed clip of the 1951 Oxford boat-race team sinking in bad weather. It is Henderson, too, who founded the Alexandra Palace Television Society, set up to commemorate the world's first public television service - that of the BBC - and preserve the north London studios from which it began to broadcast in 1936. Sadly, his life was ending just as the latter aim came under threat from a redevelopment scheme which would replace the studios with a nightclub.

Henderson was born in Scotland, but raised in Surrey. He abandoned his study of mathematics at Trinity College, Oxford, at the end of his first year with the onset of the second world war, and served in the Royal Horse Artillery, by then mechanised and assigned to armoured formations.

On demobilisation, he decided not to resume an academic career and joined what became the BBC World Service as a studio manager and announcer. He then contrived a transfer to television - and was sent to Alexandra Palace.

During the second world war, television was shut down. On its relaunch in 1946, it was, at first, wholly dependent on "Ally Pally", as it was affectionately known. By the early 1950s, the more demanding production departments - such as drama and light entertainment - had moved to the old Gaumont-British film studios in Lime Grove, in west London, but news lingered on at Alexandra Palace, and outside broadcasts were based there.

It was these departments that Henderson joined. According to legend, he turned up at a televised rugby match at Twickenham - he had been a rugger blue at Oxford - telling the producer that he could furnish a better commentary than the one going out.

Henderson supplied voice-over commentaries for television newsreel, still kept separate from news bulletins; helped cover special outside broadcast occasions, such as remembrance services at the Cenotaph and the 1953 coronation; and handled all kinds of sports commentaries, including Wimbledon and the boat race. With his friend and fellow commentator Wynford Vaughan Thomas, he also supervised the first television programmes to be produced from Wales.

In 1960, he married Mira Howe Matthews, formerly wife of the concert pianist Denis Matthews, with whom she had had four children. Henderson proved to be a splendid stepfather to them, and, to the surprise of his friends, left fulltime broadcasting to become a childcare officer in Oxford.

When the BBC embarked upon its programme of local radio stations, he was a natural choice to set up Radio Oxford in 1970, where he remained for six years. He then went on to manage the sport and arts centre at Abingdon, where Mira ran a community music centre. On retirement, they spent some time in Australia, to where Mira's eldest daughter and her family had migrated, before settling down with another daughter and her family on a sheep farm in Wales.

Henderson's last and most absorbing cause came after he had heard Judith Chalmers appealing on Radio 2 for members of a wartime anti-aircraft battery to contact an old comrade who wanted to organise a reunion. Why not, Henderson thought, have a reunion of that band of brothers who, from tiny studios, with primitive equipment, had invented the art of television as they went along?

Although BBC2 put out a nostalgic compilation, Magic Rays Of Light (1981), and, in 1986, the 50th anniversary of the service was marked with Jack Rosenthal's specially-written TV play, The Fools On The Hill, there never seemed to have been a reunion as such, nor any attempt to collect reminiscences and memorabilia of the early days.

With the help of the BBC's written archives, Henderson tracked down the survivors. In 1992, he organised a grand reunion. The Alexandra Palace Television Society was formed, and today has more than 300 members. Simon Vaughan, a media academic, took on the collection of material, and the society archive now boasts 5,000 items, including records of early programmes whose preservation had not been suspected.

Sadly, Henderson's health began to decline, and after only two years he had to drop out of an active role in the society. The BBC had continued to use the Ally Pally studios, latterly for Open University programmes, and did not finally vacate them until 1981. They have remained much as they were left, a historic site.

Last December, the society learned that the trustees of the charity which administers Alexandra Park and Palace were seeking to lease a large area of the building to a developer, who will be free to remodel much of the interior, including the Victorian theatre, the great hall and the promenade.

Henderson died on the eve of the last day for lodging objections to the plan with the Charity Commissioners. He is survived by Mira, his three stepdaughters, one stepson, and their children.

 Michael Henderson, television pioneer, born August 23 1920; died January 5 2001

webTitle: Civilians to interview police suspects

fields.headline: Civilians to interview police suspects
fields.standfirst: Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: Civilians are set to interview crime suspects in a controversial new scheme to free more officers on to the beat.
fields.body:
Civilians are set to interview crime suspects in a controversial new scheme to free more officers on to the beat.

The Wiltshire police project is thought to be the first of its kind in western Europe, but has been criticised by the Police Federation which said it raised serious concerns about using civilians in such a specialised role.

Under the system the new prisoner handling team investigators will mainly deal with "bulk" offences such as criminal damage and theft although police chiefs have not ruled out the possibility that they could handle more delicate interviews for rape and murder cases.

As well as interviewing suspects, their duties will include taking fingerprints, processing description forms and preparing a file on the offender for the crown prosecution service.

But civil rights lawyer Mark Stephens, of Finers Stephens Innocent, branded the scheme "policing on the cheap" saying it sacrificed quality for price.

"Trained police officers are uniquely placed to conduct a proper forensic examination to comply with the law when they do it," said Mr Stephens. "Civilians, however well intentioned, are going to be nothing more than interfering do-gooders. While there's nothing in the Human Rights Act to stop this happening, I have grave reservations that effectively untrained people are going to be involved in the collection of evidence, which will result in more errors than are presently made, and more guilty people walking free."

Superintendent Martin Abbott, divisional commander for north and west Wiltshire, said that far from making the system error-ridden it would prevent time wasting.

He said: "It has never been done before in this way and we hope it will make the system slicker and more efficient. The scheme will give the visible representations of the police that people require so much.

"It will release them to operational duties outside. It is quite a challenge for us in an area where police officers are traditionally seen as the only ones who can do the work.

"I have every confidence it will be successful and will be extended elsewhere. If it is not effective we will not continue with it."

The two-year pilot scheme is being run in a division, which takes in Ashton Keynes and Codford, near Warminster. Three police officers will be backed by five civilians, based at the divisional headquarters in Chippenham.

After an arrest, officers will book suspects in as usual but will then hand them over to the prisoner handling scheme.

It is hoped that the scheme will reduce the time officers spend preparing paperwork and waiting for solicitors.

The job advertisement in local newspapers reads: "This is a new initiative and an exciting opportunity for civilian members to join the Constabulary in a supportive role.

"Interviewing skills as well as an enquiring mind, a methodical approach to work and the ability to work to deadlines are essential."

The force already employs civilians as investigation assistants - who take witness statements - and the scheme is seen as an extension of that.

However, PC Philip Davenport, spokesman for the Wiltshire branch of the Police Federation, said: "My first concern is this is the first time it has happened anywhere in the country.

"There may be issues which have not been researched. I would hope the people who the police employ do have the appropriate skills.

"Those officers going on to CID, who investigate serious crimes, hone their skills through interviewing suspects throughout their service."

The Home Office said: "How any individual chief constable deploys officers is entirely a matter for the chief constable and is an operational decision for the police force."

webTitle: Editor of Zimbabwe's newspaper won't give up under fire

fields.headline: We're not giving up
fields.standfirst:
The deputy editor of Zimbabwe's Daily News says bombs won't stop them from getting the paper out

Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: The deputy editor of Zimbabwe's Daily News says bombs won't stop them from getting the paper out.
fields.body:
On Sunday morning, as I prepared for work, Anne Musonza the editor-in-chief's secretary, called me on my mobile and told me the news that "they" had bombed our printing press a few hours earlier. "We can't print anything." "They", if you ask me in the heat of that moment, were the war veterans, a rag-tag group of won't-works who claim to have fought in the liberation war in the 70s. Most are too young to have fought in the war, which ended 20 years ago.

They are led by a doctor trained in Poland, Chenjerai Hunzvi, who never held a rifle during the war itself. He had twice led noisy demonstrations at the our editorial offices in downtown Harare the previous week.

Then, at a press conference, he had announced that the war veterans were "banning" the newspaper - by which we thought he meant they would not allow the paper to be circulated in areas which they controlled.

They had already burnt copies of the paper after we had carried the results of a survey in which the majority of the people interviewed in Harare had said they hoped Laurent Kabila's death would result in the withdrawal of the 12,000 Zimbabwean soldiers from Congo. The war veterans, led by Hunzvi, managed to impute that the Daily News had cooked up the survey - as the government had done when we carried out a survey before the election in June last year which showed that President Mugabe's Zanu PF had lost popularity and would not win all the 120 seats being contested. In the event, they won only 62 and most of those in the rural areas.

But on the Monday after the explosion which ripped through the small refurbished Goss printing press, I was walking from my house in Chitungwiza, 40km from Harare, when I met a 10-year-old boy with two loaves of bread. The price of bread had recently gone up again. For a while I saw very few people with bread on my daily walk to the bus stop. At times I would see someone with just half a loaf.

The prices hit families hard but they adjusted to it, and the boy's parents must have made savings here and there to be able to buy two loaves a day. Perhaps the pater familias was no longer using the bus to go to Harare. Perhaps he had repaired his old bicycle and was now cycling to work - a saving of 60 Zimbabwe dollars a day.

"So you are leaving the country then?" he said to me without greeting. He looked down in the dumps. I said I was not sure what he meant. "I know they have bombed your printing press. You must leave the country. Last year, they bombed your offices. This year they've bombed your printing press. Next year they'll bomb you. Go, like everybody else - either to America, the UK, anywhere. As I will, when I grow up." Yes, there is an exodus. Ever since Robert Mugabe unleashed the war veterans on the Movement for Democratic Change and the white commercial farmers, there has been so much violence against any group opposing the government that many people feel trapped.

The Daily News editorial offices are located on the fifth floor of Trustee House. Last year a bomb exploded in a art gallery on the ground floor, directly below the office of the editor-in-chief, Geoff Nyarota. To this day there have been no arrests.

A swarm of police and army bomb disposal experts were at the bombed-out site of the printing press on Sunday. They were poking at this, peering at that, with a diligence that Chief Inspector Morse would have admired. Many of us were not impressed.

This was a political crime and the police had recently become so political we suspect they take their orders only from the politicians never mind the evidence. Augustin Shihuri, the police commissioner, himself a war veteran, had declared pub licly that he was a Zanu PF member and wanted every officer to be a party member. Others could wait until their party came to power, he said. The previous week the Daily News had been bombarded by both the war veterans, hired to frighten the daylights out of the voters during an election, and Jonathan Moyo, minister of state for information and publicity in Mugabe's office, whose assignment seems to be to put the fear of God into every journalist in the country.

He as much as said our days were numbered - we had become a national security risk he said, among other amazing accusations. We were linked to the MDC, to the commercial farmers and to the British and the Americans. We had to go.

The Daily News managed to publish a 12-page issue on Monday, instead of its usual 82 pages - and has published more pages since then, with the generous help of another independent publishing house in Harare.

Of the bombing, the government said it was to be regretted. The war veterans said they had played no part in it at all. Meanwhile, there were many sympathetic telephone calls to our offices. fields.bodyText: On Sunday morning, as I prepared for work, Anne Musonza the editor-in-chief's secretary, called me on my mobile and told me the news that "they" had bombed our printing press a few hours earlier. "We can't print anything." "They", if you ask me in the heat of that moment, were the war veterans, a rag-tag group of won't-works who claim to have fought in the liberation war in the 70s. Most are too young to have fought in the war, which ended 20 years ago. They are led by a doctor trained in Poland, Chenjerai Hunzvi, who never held a rifle during the war itself. He had twice led noisy demonstrations at the our editorial offices in downtown Harare the previous week. Then, at a press conference, he had announced that the war veterans were "banning" the newspaper - by which we thought he meant they would not allow the paper to be circulated in areas which they controlled. They had already burnt copies of the paper after we had carried the results of a survey in which the majority of the people interviewed in Harare had said they hoped Laurent Kabila's death would result in the withdrawal of the 12,000 Zimbabwean soldiers from Congo. The war veterans, led by Hunzvi, managed to impute that the Daily News had cooked up the survey - as the government had done when we carried out a survey before the election in June last year which showed that President Mugabe's Zanu PF had lost popularity and would not win all the 120 seats being contested. In the event, they won only 62 and most of those in the rural areas. But on the Monday after the explosion which ripped through the small refurbished Goss printing press, I was walking from my house in Chitungwiza, 40km from Harare, when I met a 10-year-old boy with two loaves of bread. The price of bread had recently gone up again. For a while I saw very few people with bread on my daily walk to the bus stop. At times I would see someone with just half a loaf. The prices hit families hard but they adjusted to it, and the boy's parents must have made savings here and there to be able to buy two loaves a day. Perhaps the pater familias was no longer using the bus to go to Harare. Perhaps he had repaired his old bicycle and was now cycling to work - a saving of 60 Zimbabwe dollars a day. "So you are leaving the country then?" he said to me without greeting. He looked down in the dumps. I said I was not sure what he meant. "I know they have bombed your printing press. You must leave the country. Last year, they bombed your offices. This year they've bombed your printing press. Next year they'll bomb you. This was a political crime and the police had recently become so political we suspect they take their orders only from the politicians never mind the evidence. Others could wait until their party came to power, he said. fields.headline: A walk on the wild side
fields.trailText: Congo | Jungle Janes
fields.body:
'This is a place that the 20th century forgot" (Congo, BBC2). Well, yes and no. There was The African Queen, of course. Katharine Hepburn called her diary of the production How I Went To Africa With Bogart, Bacall And Huston And Almost Lost My Mind. (The snap of Sam Spiegel in shorts is alone worth the price of admission.) John Huston shot The African Queen in the Congo chiefly, one fears, because he also wanted to shoot an elephant.

In 1920, Colonel Gore Browne built himself a country estate deep in the Congo jungle. The natives called him The Angry Rhino and it must have amused him because there is a rhino statue over the door. The TV crew came on the house in all its sleeping beauty. This was the most evocative moment of Congo.

Dust had sifted on the colonel's cricket bat and filled his briar pipe. His solar topee was slung on those extending tongs, which used to be called lazy tongs. His photograph albums were scattered. His desk had been rifled. A shapeless grey mass moved like a solid ghost in the mid-distance, crossing a path. A rhino.

Gore Browne had hoped to market exotic oils, and Brian Leith, the producer of Congo, said you could still smell the perfume in the bedrooms. In 1996, the colonel's daughter and son-in-law were murdered here. In spite of Leith's ticking-off tone ("Whatever horror we found here, we brought it with us"), the Congo has regularly lived up to its reputation. Like a notice saying Trespassers Will Be Shot, this has tended to protect the wildlife.

The first episode was largely an aerial sweep of the Congo from source to sea. In the course of which I saw enough cichlids (rock grazers, snail crushers, sand filterers, mud scoopers, nest spawners, mouth brooders and cross-dressers) to choke a pelican.

The first glimpse of a forest elephant was a sudden shock of joy that, as Katharine Hepburn put it, "seized you by the seat of the pants and raised you up and shook you". My taste for warm blood - perhaps a few Pygmies or a good, solid gorilla - will, I hope, be slaked in the next two episodes.

There was no shortage of human interest in the last Jungle Janes (Channel 4), which clashed with Congo. A dozen middle-aged, middle-class women with no gift for map reading (as their husbands did not hesitate to mention) endured a month's survival training in the Brunei jungle. Personally, I would have hesitated to take an opera singer and an actress, and I would have been wrong.

Life boiled down to the big simplicities of food, fire and friendship with precious, relished, dormitory treats. A bit of peanut brittle shared; a packet of honey roasted almonds passed around. Not one dropped out. Dicky, hard boiled in the egg by being sent to boarding school at three years old, became their natural chronicler, showing an unexpected gift for metaphor. The forced marches, carrying 65lb packs, reminded her of going to the seaside as a child. "You keep saying 'Daddy, when are we there? When are we there?' and he keeps saying 'Nearly there. Nearly there', and suddenly, over the top of a hill, you see the sea." All soldiers must feel like that. Xenophon's troops cried "The sea! The sea!" at the end of their 1,000 mile march and so, I dare say, did the British at Dunkirk.

Water ran low. Doctor and team leader clashed in viperish whispers ("I know what I'm doing, OK, and I don't need you to tell me." "I think you have a problem with your temper." "I haven't got a problem with my temper.") Alex, the actress, deaf to this snake dance, mused "How am I going to cope without the marvellous peace we've had?" When they were finally airlifted out, it seemed to Dicky like a Caesarean, exchanging the deep peace of the womb for the hurly-burly of the world.

As they rafted back on hand-felled, vine-lashed logs, she yelled to Alex, "Log ahoy, or crocodile! Poke it off!" Even Bogart would have whistled.

This Soap Believes That Children Are A Great Mistake. Discuss with animus or animation. Rita: "Children are the greatest blessing you can have. Even if they do break your heart." Edna: "Kids! I'd have 'em tarred and feathered if it was me." Phil: "Take it from me, they ain't worf the grief." Duggie: "I vote they're banned. Motion carried."

webTitle: TV and Radio: Pick of the day

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: The Third Man | Lust for Life | Snake Eyes
fields.body:
Films

The Third Man
(Carol Reed, 1949)
8pm, FilmFour

Reed's classic thriller, born out of an elite collaboration with Graham Greene and Orson Welles. The scene is postwar Vienna, shadowy and bare in Robert Krasner's Oscar-winning black-and-white photography, Anton Karas's zither a melancholy accompaniment. Welles's Harry Lime is a marvellously cynical flourish, presumed dead but found alive and thriving as a black marketeer by loyal old pal Joseph Cotten. The wonderful cast includes Trevor Howard, Bernard Lee and Wilfrid Hyde-White, all stamping redundant British values on central Europe.

Lust For Life
(Vincente Minnelli, 1956)
9pm, TCM

An intense and dedicated performance from Kirk Douglas drives this unusually astute biopic about Vincent Van Gogh. Douglas learned to paint for the role, but the real energy is in his anguished depiction of the artist's tormented psyche, a man constantly on the edge of breakdown. Minnelli fashions a complex if overheated picture of both man and artist.

Snake Eyes
(Brian De Palma, 1998)
10pm, Sky Premier

The bravura opening - a single apparent 12-minute take in which we follow Nicolas Cage's hustler-cum-cop Santoro going about his dodgy business in an Atlantic City sports stadium before a big fight - is a homage to De Palma's beloved Hitchcock, and enticingly sets the scene for a gripping thriller. The champ takes a dive; and despite the attentions of Santoro's security-chief chum Dunne (Gary Sinise), a political bigwig is shot. Are the two events linked?

Walkabout
(Nicolas Roeg, 1970)
3.55am, FilmFour

A brother and sister are abandoned in the outback when their father commits suicide; on the long hot walk back to civilisation they encounter the mystic aboriginal world, in Roeg's eerie rites-of-passage story. Jenny Agutter is the very English rose who takes the Aussie sun in her stride, Lucien John her brother. It lacks the ley-lined menace of Peter Weir's Picnic At Hanging Rock, but is vividly photographed.

Monkey Business
(Howard Hawks, 1952)
9.15am, Sky

Cinema Joyful comedy about a scientist with a crazy idea that doesn't quite work, creating instead a serum that dumps him and his girl back into childhood. With a Ben Hecht script, a witty, silly lead pair in Cary Grant and Ginger Rogers, and Hawks in charge, how can you lose? Fine support too from company boss Charles Coburn and Marilyn Monroe, as the secretary who can't type. So who needs a typist?

Sports

Tennis: Milan Indoors
2pm, British Eurosport

Half a world away from the Australian Open but still a triumph of sorts. The prospect of a brand new ATP tour event in Milan has attracted Marat Safin and Yevgeny Kafelnikov as well as Marc Rosset, who qualifies as defending champion because he won the tournament which this has replaced. The Swiss is due to play Greg Rusedski today for the right to take Safin.
Simon Burnton

webTitle: G2: Country diary

fields.headline: The old railway line
fields.standfirst: Dartmoor
fields.trailText: Dartmoor
fields.body:
On a cold Sunday morning, scores of cars park by the dam of Burrator reservoir - navy blue water surrounded by mature plantations below Sheeps Tor's sunlit rocks. People stroll and jog and an ice-cream van has already set up pitch.

Nearby, the dismantled Yelverton-Princetown railway winds through the wood beside Devonport leat, towards exposed pastures on the wet Dartmoor fringe, where shaggy ponies huddle in an old droveway from Walkhampton.

Beyond the Tavy, across the Tamar's sheltered domain, landmarks such as Kit Hill, Sentry Hill wood and St Dominic's alstroemeria glass houses are discernible and, on the skyline, Bodmin Moor lies under a cold haze. The former railway meanders upwards through deserted moorland above lichened woods in Walkham valley.

Black-faced sheep graze among granite boulders, orange bracken, dark gorse bushes, stunted hawthorns and ancient boundaries, all vivid and clear-cut beneath blue sky. As the track gains height, doubling back around Ingrator and its derelict quarry, views become ever more expansive northwards to Cox tor, Great Staple and Great Mistor.

In the bitterly cold east wind, ground is frozen hard, with ice-crazed puddles in Eggworthy cutting. One can imagine the engine and single coach with eight passengers stranded, buried up to its roof in snow, during the great blizzard of March 1891. Another tortuous loop around King's tor must have added to the sense of desolation experienced by convicts en route to the prison, remote and hidden behind the blasted tussocky slopes of Hessary tor (517m).

webTitle: Navy frigate may be sunk to become wildlife haven

fields.headline: Navy frigate may be sunk to become wildlife haven
fields.trailText: Plans to sink a navy frigate off Cornwall to create an artificial reef for divers and a haven for wildlife have been approved by the government.
fields.body:
Plans to sink a navy frigate off Cornwall to create an artificial reef for divers and a haven for wildlife have been approved by the government.

Divers will have to carry out a full environmental assessment before being granted a licence by the Ministry of Agriculture but the ship should be sunk in Whitsand Bay, off Plymouth, by the end of the year.

The Artificial Reef Consortium needs to raise £35,000 to buy their preferred ship, HMS Scylla, a Leander class frigate tied up at Portsmouth and due to be sold for scrap in a few weeks.

John Busby, one of the divers involved in the project, said they were supported by such organisations as the National Marine Aquarium, and Mountbatten Water Sports Centre, both at Plymouth.

"We have been diving for years on a US ship, the James Eagan Layne, in Whitsand Bay, but it is breaking up and we wanted to replace it. One of the good things about buying this ship is that we can clean it up and make it safe for divers before we sink it. The Mountbatten centre is starting courses for disabled divers and this would make the perfect venue."

He said the wreck would be open for anyone to dive on. "This is not a money-making venture but to provide a facility for divers, something which has given me a lot of fun."

Mr Busby said the wreck site was away from shipping lanes and fishing grounds. In any case it was impossible for fishing boats to trawl near the area because the existing wreck would snag nets.

A spokesman for the Ministry of Agriculture said yesterday that there were no objections from the government in principle. The Artificial Reef Consortium plans to take the ship to Plymouth for environmental cleaning for a possible 10 months.

webTitle: Divided leaders look for unity

fields.headline: Divided leaders look for unity
fields.standfirst:
The future Paris needs a new relationship with Berlin

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: French and German leaders meet today in the knowledge that the future shape of Europe will to a large extent depend on their ability to salvage a relationship probably in its worst shape for 40 years.
fields.body:
French and German leaders meet today in the knowledge that the future shape of Europe will to a large extent depend on their ability to salvage a relationship probably in its worst shape for 40 years.

The informal talks between the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, France's president, Jacques Chirac and his prime minister, Lionel Jospin, and foreign ministry officials were called as a matter of urgency after last month's divisive EU summit in Nice.

Over dinner in Strasbourg, the leaders will attempt to patch up an alliance that has been seen as the engine of European integration, and one which both sides recognise as badly in need of repair.

"We need a frank and friendly discussion that leads to a redefinition of our cooperation; a real relaunch, so that we are again able to progress together for a Europe that is enlarging and faces unprecedented challenges," the French European affairs minister, Pierre Moscovici, said.

"We should be able to say things openly, take stock of what works and what doesn't, and decide together how to redefine cooperation between France and Germany which is absolutely indispensable for Europe, because there is no alternative to this Franco-German motor."

France was confronted at Nice with a political reality it would have preferred to ignore during its EU presidency: the united Germany of 2000 is no longer the divided Germany of the cold war years; nor is it prepared to be treated as such.

The bitter row about the allocation of votes in the EU's council of ministers, sparked by France's refusal to grant Germany's request that its greater population - 82m compared with 60m French - be reflected in voting procedures in Brussels, ended in a superficial victory for Paris.

Mr Schröder, however, only acquiesced to France after getting everything else he wanted from the summit.

French analysts and diplomats privately acknowledge that Nice marked a watershed in Franco-German relations.

"Nice showed that France is still acting within a framework dating from the 1960s, on the basis of a Franco-West German relationship in fact," said Stephan Martens, a researcher at the Paris-based Institute for International and Strategic Relations.

"That mental picture has not changed. Whereas Germany is headed by a new generation of young leaders with no hang-ups about the past, the French political elite still sees things according to the old model. It thinks in terms of a balance of power. That is one reason why the Franco-German motor is no longer working."

The new Germany, Paris is beginning to realise, has no intention of showing France the deference of old. It wants a bigger place in Europe, is seeking new relationships - including with Britain - to achieve that, and will have no further truck with privileged alliances fuelled by mutual national self interest.

France, severely hampered in any effort to construct a coherent policy on Europe by the uncomfortable cohabitation of a rightwing president with a Socialist prime minister who wants to succeed him, does not know how to deal with this new reality.

While France's multinational businesses can compete on the global stage with Germany's, and its economic performance more than rivals Berlin's, on the diplomatic front, Paris is losing confidence. It senses the danger of increasing isolation as the centre of gravity of an expanded EU shifts towards the German capital.

"Until now we've basically turned a blind eye to this whole issue," a senior French diplomat said, "perhaps because we don't ourselves know what kind of Europe we want, and we cannot get used to the idea of a new, complex-free Germany. We remain deeply influenced by our republican, centralising traditions, and we really don't know what to think of this 27-strong European Union that's on the way."

Innately opposed to the vision of a federal Europe, France's leaders are unlikely to put their heads on a domestic chopping block by backing radical EU institutional reform in the run-up to 2002 presidential elections.

"There needs to be a real upheaval at the heart of the French political elite," Mr Martens said. "I think the Franco-German relationship will probably stabilise, the problems will be resolved, but the ball is very much in the French camp."

If France wants to stay at the EU's highest table, it will need to do more than smooth ruffled German feathers over dinner.

France was confronted at Nice with a political reality it would have preferred to ignore during its EU presidency: the united Germany of 2000 is no longer the divided Germany of the cold war years; nor is it prepared to be treated as such. The bitter row about the allocation of votes in the EU's council of ministers, sparked by France's refusal to grant Germany's request that its greater population - 82m compared with 60m French - be reflected in voting procedures in Brussels, ended in a superficial victory for Paris. Mr Schröder, however, only acquiesced to France after getting everything else he wanted from the summit. French analysts and diplomats privately acknowledge that Nice marked a watershed in Franco-German relations. "Nice showed that France is still acting within a framework dating from the 1960s, on the basis of a Franco-West German relationship in fact," said Stephan Martens, a researcher at the Paris-based Institute for International and Strategic Relations. "That mental picture has not changed. Whereas Germany is headed by a new generation of young leaders with no hang-ups about the past, the French political elite still sees things according to the old model. It thinks in terms of a balance of power. That is one reason why the Franco-German motor is no longer working." The new Germany, Paris is beginning to realise, has no intention of showing France the deference of old. It wants a bigger place in Europe, is seeking new relationships - including with Britain - to achieve that, and will have no further truck with privileged alliances fuelled by mutual national self interest. France, severely hampered in any effort to construct a coherent policy on Europe by the uncomfortable cohabitation of a rightwing president with a Socialist prime minister who wants to succeed him, does not know how to deal with this new reality. While France's multinational businesses can compete on the global stage with Germany's, and its economic performance more than rivals Berlin's, on the diplomatic front, Paris is losing confidence. It senses the danger of increasing isolation as the centre of gravity of an expanded EU shifts towards the German capital. "Until now we've basically turned a blind eye to this whole issue," a senior French diplomat said, "perhaps because we don't ourselves know what kind of Europe we want, and we cannot get used to the idea of a new, complex-free Germany. We remain deeply influenced by our republican, centralising traditions, and we really don't know what to think of this 27-strong European Union that's on the way." Innately opposed to the vision of a federal Europe, France's leaders are unlikely to put their heads on a domestic chopping block by backing radical EU institutional reform in the run-up to 2002 presidential elections. "There needs to be a real upheaval at the heart of the French political elite," Mr Martens said. "I think the Franco-German relationship will probably stabilise, the problems will be resolved, but the ball is very much in the French camp." If France wants to stay at the EU's highest table, it will need to do more than smooth ruffled German feathers over dinner.

webTitle: Pub cricket team hope to sign Brian Lara

fields.headline: Pub cricket team hope to sign Brian Lara
fields.trailText: Brian Lara is more familiar with the hallowed grounds of Lord's and Edgbaston. But the highest scoring Test batsman might be persuaded to take the crease for a pub team in Kent.
fields.body:
Brian Lara is more familiar with the hallowed grounds of Lord's and Edgbaston. But the highest scoring Test batsman might be persuaded to take the crease for a pub team in Kent.

Simon Noble, 30, millionaire managing director of a Caribbean-based internet gambling empire, has approached Lara to persuade him to turn out for Lashings, a team he sponsors that began life in a Tex-Mex bar.

The club already have the services of former West Indies Test players Richie Richardson, Stuart Williams and Junior Murray, and a peg in the dressing room at their ground at Sutton Valence school in Maidstone is reserved for BC Lara.

The club has registered him as a player for the 2001 season with stunned East Kent League officials, and insist that the prospective signing is not a publicity stunt. In the past Muttiah Muralitharan (Sri Lanka) Gary Kirsten (South Africa) and Eldine Baptiste (West Indies and Kent) have played for Lashings.

Lara, 31, the former West Indies captain, holds the record for the highest Test and first class scores, but recently has been experiencing problems with his form.

A money-no-object offer from Mr Noble has been passed to the player and backed up with faxes to the West Indies tour hotels in Australia, where the side are coming to terms with a 5-0 Test series defeat.

Lara is said to be considering the offer seriously. Mr Noble's previous generous sponsorship led to the signings last season of Stuart Williams and Junior Murray.

Speaking from his headquarters in Antigua, Mr Noble said: "I support Lashings because they have given several young West Indian players the chance to develop their game in England.

"For them to have a chance to play cricket with Brian Lara would be an unforgettable experience."

David Folb, who founded Lashings, said last night: "We're used to the big names. Richie came to us straight after the World Cup five years ago, and he was in pretty good form."

Lara may find the promise of success at Lashings attractive. The side won the league and cup last year.

However, Mr Folb admitted that the player had yet to come back with a response to the offer. But if Lara accepted he could be striding from the school pavilion by late June.

webTitle: Confident Berlin ready to shed burden of history

fields.headline: Confident Berlin ready to shed burden of history
fields.standfirst:
Has axis had its day?

Special report: European integration
fields.trailText: There was a point at the Nice summit last month that historians may well look back on as the moment when Germany finally shrugged off its postwar guilt and signalled it was ready for leadership in Europe.
fields.byline: John Hooper and Kate Connolly in Berlin
fields.body:
There was a point at the Nice summit last month that historians may well look back on as the moment when Germany finally shrugged off its postwar guilt and signalled it was ready for leadership in Europe.

Jacques Chirac was having an open spat with the German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, and, according to one witness, remarked that France and Germany had always run Europe between them.

Mr Schröder fixed him with a steady gaze and replied: "Things can always move on, you know, Mr President."

When the chancellor, his foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, and their French counterparts meet today in Strasbourg, their most important task will be to decide whether things have already moved on.

Mr Fischer tried yesterday to repair the splits which appeared in Nice, stressing the importance of Berlin's relationship with Paris for Europe's integration process.

"Without a close European and transatlantic partnership, Germany gives rise all too quickly to reservedness and scepticism. As far as we're concerned, for the completion of European integration this partnership can only be with France," Mr Fischer said in a speech at Freiburg university.

"This partnership has always included the other Europeans. But our history connects us like no two other countries in Europe in a common responsibility for the future."

However, the Nice summit, in which the two countries' leaders clashed bitterly over the future distribution of power in the EU, left the Paris-Berlin axis undeniably corroded. Some fear that it could be damaged beyond repair and that the consequences could be momentous in terms of a return to the old, nationalistic way of doing politics in Europe.

"Either France and Germany succeed in keeping the continent together or else the continent just won't stay together," says Ulrike Guerot, the head of European studies at the German council for foreign relations.

Many fear the process of integration could grind to a halt for lack of an impetus from what has traditionally been the centre. When the first splutterings were heard from the Franco-German "engine", they were explained away in terms of circumstantial factors. In particular, it was argued, Mr Schröder did not have the same rapport with Mr Chirac as previous chancellors and presidents had enjoyed.

German reunification has made the French deeply fearful of German hegemony while the Germans, who are led by a generation of politicians with impeccable anti-fascist credentials, no longer feel obliged by a sense of historic guilt to give in routinely to the French.

The two countries, moreover, are on opposite sides in the fundamental debate over Europe's future.

The French have been increasingly aligning themselves with the British in seeking a so-called inter-governmental procedure whereby the Brussels institutions are bypassed on key decisions. The Germans remain faithful to a more traditional community method. The difference reflects growing French reticence over German dreams of a federal Europe.

Mr Schröder's government is increasingly under pressure from pro-integrationist countries such as Italy to take the lead. But the more it does so, the more it stokes French fears of German domination. And the more those fears grow, the more the French dig in their heels on the issue of sovereignty.

The problem the Germans face is not so much whether to show leadership in Europe as how to do so when most other leading nations are pulling in the opposite direction. Madrid is as keen on preserving national prerogatives as London and Paris.

Germany may have taken up the drill sergeant's pace stick, but half the platoon is intent on marching to its own step.

webTitle: High court rules against Trimble's ban on Sinn Fein

fields.headline: Trimble loses bid to appease hardliners
fields.standfirst:
High court rules against meeting ban on Sinn Fein

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The paramilitary disarmament row stalling the Northern Ireland peace process rumbled on as the first minister, David Trimble, vowed to appeal yesterday's legal decision against his ban on Sinn Fein attending north/south meetings.
fields.body:
The paramilitary disarmament row stalling the Northern Ireland peace process rumbled on as the first minister, David Trimble, vowed to appeal yesterday's legal decision against his ban on Sinn Fein attending north/south meetings.

Irish premier Bertie Ahern will meet Tony Blair at Downing Street tonight to assess all sides' responses to a possible formula to overcome the deadlock on decommissioning, demilitarisation and policing.

But the battle regarding the complex Belfast high court ruling, which stated while Mr Trimble's veto was unlawful, he still had discretion over nominations to the cross-border summits, proved an unwelcome distraction.

The Ulster Unionist leader imposed the bar on Stormont education minister, Martin McGuinness, and health minister, Bairbre de Brun, last October, in an attempt to get the IRA to make progress toward getting rid of its weapons.

It was part of a package of measures that helped Mr Trimble fend off hardliners inside his own party, who wanted him to pull out of power-sharing with republicans because the Provisionals had not started to give up their guns.

However, Sinn Fein insisted the sanction was contrary to the Good Friday agreement. The party views the peace accord's cross-border dimension, with its ministerial council and six cooperative bodies, as a hugely important step toward an embryonic united Ireland.

Mr McGuinness was pleased with yesterday's ruling by Mr Justice Brian Kerr, who said Mr Trimble could not use his powers in this way to exert pressure on Sinn Fein and nominations must rest on suitability rather than political objectives.

The deputy first minister, the nationalist SDLP's Seamus Mallon, who has responsibility with Mr Trimble for nominating attendees to north/south meetings, also welcomed the high court decision.

But the judge added: "It does not follow that he [Trimble] must nominate the applicants. He may exercise his discretion. It would be open to the first minister to conclude that a potential nominee was unsuitable for nomination because he had not made appropriate efforts to implement the [Good Friday] agreement."

Hardline anti-agreement unionists were quick to use it to increase pressure on Mr Trimble. DUP deputy leader Peter Robinson described it as "humiliating defeat" for the first minister, whom he claimed had "neither the wit nor wisdom to understand the agreement he signed up to in 1998."

The Ulster Unionist Lagan Valley MP, Jeffrey Donaldson, Mr Trimble's arch internal rival, said the leader was right to appeal but the sanctions should be increased and Sinn Fein's expulsion from the Stormont executive considered.

 Sinn Fein's John Kelly, a member of the Northern Ireland assembly last night told a debate at Stormont that he made no apologies for having once been a member of the IRA.

The admission sparked immediate calls by unionists for him to be arrested. The member for Mid Ulster said: "I was a member of the Provisional IRA and I'm still a socialist."

webTitle: Yesterday in Parliament

fields.headline: Yesterday in Parliament
fields.standfirst: Special report: Parliament
fields.trailText: Yesterday
fields.body:
Yesterday

Good day

Pensioners. Social security secretary Alistair Darling unveiled a new form designed to make it easier to claim the minimum income guarantee benefit top-up. Instead of 40 complex pages - with questions such as 'Are you pregnant?' - the new form will be just 10 pages.

Bad day

Labour supporter John Byrne in Brighton was excited when he received two mystery parcels. Expecting them to be gifts from his sister in Chicago he ripped them open - to discover 68 copies of Ann Widdecombe's novel, The Clematis Tree. A spokeswoman from the nearby Conservative association said: "I wondered where they were. We will collect them from Mr Byrne."

Contest of the day

Parliamentary secretary Paddy Tipping revealed that 3,141 people had been nominated for eight to 10 people peer seats in the Lords. The appointments commission will whittle the list down with ermine due in eight weeks.

Today

Commons: Welsh questions. PM's questions. Lords: Parliamentary referendum bill, second reading.

webTitle: Flood victims protest at No 10

fields.headline: Flood victims protest at No 10
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: The land of sodden furniture and of families crammed into caravans and bedsits came to Downing Street yesterday to remind ministers that the autumn flood disaster is still part of hundreds of people's lives.
fields.body:
The land of sodden furniture and of families crammed into caravans and bedsits came to Downing Street yesterday to remind ministers that the autumn flood disaster is still part of hundreds of people's lives.

Four symbolic sandbags were left by a delegation from Ryedale, North Yorkshire, where nearly 200 homes are still uninhabitable after standing for up to a fortnight in sewage polluted river water.

The protesters, who also left an album of flood pictures for the prime minister, were backed by an all-party report from the Commons agriculture committee, published yesterday. The MPs called for extra government funds to avoid huge council tax rises in areas worst affected.

The report said a survey found 120 local authorities unable or unwilling to carry out their share of a national analysis of flood defences requested by the environment agency, be cause the money simply was not there. More than 10 authorities face 60% increases in the agency's annual national levy, with North Yorkshire alone facing an extra precept of £1.4m.

No provision has been made for the rises in the standard spending assessment formula for council budgets, leaving councils threatened by what the MPs called "a substantial hit on their cash flow".

"The government should explore ways of taking account of these additional costs, as well as developing a clear, long-term strategy for dealing with flood damage and defences," the report said.

The protesters said permanent defences were essential along the river Derwent in Ryedale, where repeated flooding has led to millions of pounds in insurance claims.

The delegation's leader, Di Kean, said: "When floods came in March 1999 we were told it was a one in 50 occurrence. Clearing up, claiming and rebuilding is a tortuous process ... to have to do it twice in two years is an unreasonable way to live in the 21st century."

webTitle: 'CJD in blood' sparks haemophiliac therapy boycott

fields.headline: 'CJD in blood' sparks therapy boycott
fields.standfirst: Special report: the BSE crisis
fields.trailText: The government was last night facing the embarrassing prospect of a "treatment strike" by growing numbers of haemophiliacs seeking to shame ministers into paying for safer blood clotting agents.
fields.body:
The government was last night facing the embarrassing prospect of a "treatment strike" by growing numbers of haemophiliacs seeking to shame ministers into paying for safer blood clotting agents.

As the government sought to calm protests over the way haemophiliacs, as late as 1997, had been exposed to potential infection from the human form of BSE, the Department of Health said patients should first consult their GPs.

People with haemophilia are furious that for the third time in just over three years patients are being told that they have used products that have been found to include material from a variant CJD victim.

The news, first reported in the Guardian this month, has forced ministers to consider whether to give adult haemophiliacs in England access to laboratory-made alternatives, as happened for children in Britain, and for adults in both Scotland and Wales.

The Haemophilia Society said it had heard more patients were refusing treatment with clotting factor from human sources and joining networks that allow patients who do get the synthetic type, called recombinant, to send part of their dose to others without it.

This is almost certainly illegal. But one patient who did this in the autumn forced his local health authority to pay for the more expensive recombinant factor.

Karin Pappenheim, director of the Haemophilia Society, said it was not clear how many people might be affected by the postcode lottery over access to clotting treatment, but it could be as high as 2000.

The government ordered the import of most blood plasma products two years ago because of the theoretical risk of infection by donors who had vCJD. Thirteen of the 88 known vCJD victims had been blood donors. A spokeswoman for the Department of Health said that the risk of vCJD from existing clotting factors was "unsubstantiated".

webTitle: DNA traps scientist's killer 15 years on

fields.headline: DNA traps scientist's killer 15 years on
fields.standfirst: Man killed researcher to stop her testifying against him over sex attack and was caught by techniques she helped perfect
fields.trailText: A man who killed a young British scientist to stop her from testifying against him on a sexual assault charge more than 15 years ago has been convicted of her murder.
fields.body:
A man who killed a young British scientist to stop her from testifying against him on a sexual assault charge more than 15 years ago has been convicted of her murder.

In an extraordinary twist of fate, the key DNA evidence that helped to convict David Frediani came from the very body of work on which the scientist had been engaged at the time of her death.

A jury in Vista, California, decided that Frediani, 46, a financial analyst from San Francisco, murdered Helena Greenwood, who was 34, in the garden of her home in southern California in 1985. He will be sentenced on March 9 and will probably be jailed for life without parole.

Ms Greenwood had moved to the United States in 1977 with her husband, Roger Franklin, having graduated from Sheffield University and completed her doctorate in biochemistry at the University of London.

The couple spent a year travelling across the country in a camper van and then settled in Atherton in Silicon Valley - the area where she worked as a research analyst specialising in DNA.

In 1984, Frediani, then aged 30, broke into their home. Although Frediani, from nearby San Mateo, was an intelligent man who had held down a number of jobs in the financial sector, he also carried out burglaries in wealthy areas.

He held Ms Greenwood, who was alone, at gunpoint for a number of hours and sexually assaulted her. During long conversations, she persuaded him not to kill her and convinced him the she would not contact the police.

Frediani was not masked and Greenwood was able to provide police with enough information from what he had told her for them to find him and charge him with burglary and sexual assault.

At an initial court hearing, Frediani, who faced a 20-year sentence for the assault and death threats, was granted bail. His trial was scheduled for the summer of 1985.

In the meantime, Ms Greenwood was approached by the research company Gen-Probe of San Diego and offered a post of vice-president and a chance to continue her DNA research, working on the reading of gene sequences.

The couple moved south and found a house outside the city in Del Mar and continued to take safety precautions as Frediani was still at large.

Then in August 1985, three week's before Frediani's trial was due to start, Ms Greenwood did not arrive for work and her colleagues contacted her husband. He rushed home to find her strangled and beaten body in their garden. Within hours, police tracked down Frediani who was immediately the prime suspect. Credit card transactions placed him in the San Diego area just before the murder but he claimed to have had other reasons for being there and said that he had been 500 miles away in San Francisco at the time of the killing.

Police had no evidence that linked Frediani to the body. He stood trial for the sexual assault, was convicted on the basis of the statements that Ms Greenwood had made earlier. He was jailed for six years.

But although detectives were certain that Frediani was the killer, they were unable to get sufficient evidence to bring the case to court. Frediani was released after serving only three years.

In 1999, San Diego police reopened around 300 unsolved murders to see whether new scientific techniques would help them to find the perpetrators.

There had been skin particles found under Ms Greenwood's fingernails which were re-examined. Experts tried to see whether the advances in the DNA techniques on which Ms Greenwood herself had been working were sufficient to create a match with Frediani. They were.

webTitle: Tales of hope in Indian town that turned to dust

fields.headline: Tales of hope in Indian town that turned to dust
fields.standfirst:
Special report: natural disasters
US government earthquake centre, current quakes in Asia map
Details of UK government emergency aid package
Gujurat state's official earthquake information site
fields.trailText: At 104 Rajdeep Apartments it was a normal morning. Chitra was making breakfast. Her husband, Chellappan, was having tea. Their two-year-old daughter, Gita, was drinking a cup of milk. And then the walls started to tremble.
fields.body:
At 104 Rajdeep Apartments it was a normal morning. Chitra was making breakfast. Her husband, Chellappan, was having tea. Their two-year-old daughter, Gita, was drinking a cup of milk. And then the walls started to tremble.

In a panic, Chellappan tried to save the TV set. Chitra, meanwhile, cowered on the sofa with her daughter as the masonry came raining down. The earthquake which ripped through their first-floor home in the town of Gandhidham last Friday left the family alive. But it also left them trapped.

"The flat totally collapsed. It was completely dark. A friend of mine who had managed to jump out called for me three times. I cried but he couldn't hear me," Chitra, 28, said. "I didn't know whether it was day or night. I was praying to God. My daughter kept on asking: 'Give me water, give me biscuits or milk.' I kept saying: 'I will give them to you. I will give them to you'."

For four-and-a-half days the family sat in a subterranean tomb, imprisoned by slabs of masonry. Chitra managed to get the fridge door half open and rescued a bottle of water and five tomatoes. "There was also a coke bottle in the fridge. It was very big. I tried so many times to pull it out but it would not budge," she said.

And then at lunchtime yesterday, with her daughter close to death, Chitra heard the sound of a digger. The family was rescued after more than 100 hours under the rubble.

Gandhidham was a prosperous place. But last Friday the town's blocks of flats proved as perishable as those elsewhere in Gujarat. Some 51 buildings disintegrated. The death toll has reached 600 with at least 200 more bodies to be dug up. Across the state, officials and aid workers estimate the total number of dead at between 15,000 and 100,000.

Incredibly Chitra and her family were not the only people rescued yesterday from the debris of Gandhidham.

In the early afternoon, rescuers in a neighbouring block heard a voice. "My name is Ramesh Soni. I am alive," the voice said. At 3:30pm - after 103 hours - Mr Soni was carried out to wild applause.

Recovering in the town's temporary hospital, Mr Soni described what happened. "I was drinking tea in my house when the walls started breaking," he said. "I stood with my feet to the wall. That is why I lived. It was completely dark. I had five days like that. My leg was trapped under the sofa. I prayed to my God all that time and finally my shouts were heard."

But Mr Soni's escape is far from typical, not just in Gandhidham but across Kutch, the barren desert district almost obliterated by the disaster. Last night Nishi Argarwal's relatives were still searching for her body from under a 20 metre pile of masonry.

"She was either in the bathroom or in the kitchen, we can't find her," family member Lalait Modi said. "We found her son on his bed. He must have been asleep at the time. He was dead but did not have a single scratch on him."

At the hospital, patients were recovering in the courtyard. It has treated 1,700 patients in five days, surgeon Dr HC Hotchanbani said. "In extreme conditions people can survive for 10-12 days without food or water. Today we were not expecting any more survivors. We had five."

The focus would now shift from trauma treatment to managing the epidemics that were expected to break out in the next day or two, he added.

While homeless families beg by the roadside in Kutch's devastated interior, Bhuj - the town nearest the centre of Friday's quake - has been turned into a multinational circus.

The road to Bhuj is one giant traffic jam, clogged with mainly Indian relief vehicles. But meaningful aid is finally getting through in the form of water and fuel, as well as mattresses, bamboo poles and sheeting, destined for the 500,000 people left homeless by the earthquake.

The task of digging up the dead continues but the relief operation has emphatically tilted towards helping Ramesh and Chitra: the survivors.

webTitle: G2: The Crossness pumping station

fields.headline: Royal flush
fields.standfirst: Think there's nothing beautiful about sewage? Think again.  Peter Bazalgette on the restoration of a source of family pride
fields.trailText: Think there's nothing beautiful about sewage? Think again. Peter Bazalgette on the restoration of a source of family pride.
fields.body:
So this is the year we are celebrating Queen Victoria and all her works. But amid all the newspaper features and documentaries, spare a thought for the long-suffering members of her family: Albert the Prince Consort, Albert Edward the Prince of Wales and Alexandra. I refer not to her husband, son and daughter but to the Crossness Engines. Beyond Woolwich, on the southern bank of the Thames, are the four largest rotative steam beam engines in the world. They were installed by my great-great-grandfather in 1865 as part of his sewerage system for London. Their job was to discharge London's waste into the Thames at high tide so it could be swept out to sea. The Victorians' pride in grand public works far outweighed their prudery. Thus the engines were named after Victoria, Albert and two of their children.

After the second world war, the plant was superseded and the engines fell into disrepair. But now a team of steam enthusiasts is coaxing these sleeping giants back to life. In 1990, one saw my name on the credits of a television programme and called me up. Could I help them regain access to their beloved engines? There had been a misunderstanding with Thames Water, the site owners, and they had been locked out. Peace was eventually declared.

Now, with magnificent wrought-ironwork restored and one rebuilt engine due to be steamed this autumn, we have to turn our attention to the ornate, Romanesque building - a veritable cathedral to sewage. It is listed as Grade 1 Industrial and needs at least £3m spent on it. We are giving ourselves five years to raise the money and get the job done. The result will be a magnificent educational resource - not only a massive, gleaming, puffing museum of steam but also a place to learn how 19th-century London was saved from the curse of cholera and typhoid.

When I was growing up, I was told I had a distinguished ancestor, Sir Joseph Bazalgette, who had been responsible for shaping much of modern London while chief engineer of the Metropolitan Board of Works. My excitement was soon dulled by the evident fact that few had heard of him or were interested in his sewers, embankments and bridges. I remember being astonished when I met Enoch Powell as a teenager and he lectured me at length about my great-great-grandfather's achievements. Someone had actually heard of him!

On April 4 1865, a barge set out from the centre of London with the Prince of Wales (Albert Edward, later Edward VII), the Archbishops of York and Canterbury, the Lord Mayor and a host of dignitaries. They all dined in the Crossness site (a brave idea) and there was much celebration as the Prince of Wales turned on the engines. Mr Bazalgette was called upon to explain his sewerage scheme to the throng and received three cheers in return.

To see the engines rusted through, accompanied only by the odd dead pigeon, as I first did 10 years ago, was dispiriting. Fortunately Thames Water had repaired the roof so restoration work could begin. And by chance we came across an added incentive. Arthur Green, now 96, had worked as a chemist at the Cross ness site just after the war. In 1953 there were terrible storms and the redundant engines were started up for the last time to deal with the dangerous volume of storm water. Arthur filmed them on his black and white cine camera, so we now have a mute record, carefully preserved, of how magnificent these beasts are in operation. Their huge beams plunge to and fro as though part of an indoor oilfield.

When it is finished, we will be able to tell visitors the whole story of how London was plagued by cholera and typhoid, then cured of it. The villain was the water closet which became popular in the 1830s and 1840s, and flushed waste material into sewers designed for storm water, not household effluent. The sewers flowed into local rivers, all tributaries of the Thames.

In the centre of London it became a rank channel from which the putrefaction could not escape. The so-called "Great Stink" of the late 1850s finally persuaded parliamentarians to sort the problem out. At the time, most people thought bacterial diseases were spread through the air via a "miasma". Dr John Snow's famous Soho experiment in 1854, when he disabled a water pump and saw the infections cease, was by no means accepted, but Bazalgette's successful system provided further proof.

In his book on London, Sir Hugh Casson says Sir Joe should, in justice, be as well known as Wren or Nash: "He invested everything he touched, however mundane, with an engaging swagger. A great man." Now the volunteers are putting the swagger back into Crossness.

The Crossness pumping station
