webTitle: Isabel Hilton: Pinochet trial may restore faith in judicial system

fields.headline: The cowardly lie and a general with a tortured conscience
fields.standfirst:
Pinochet's trial can restore Chile's faith in the judicial system

Special report: Pinochet on trial
fields.trailText: Pinochet's trial can restore Chile's faith in the judicial system.
fields.body:
I found it hard to believe Judge Juan Guzman in November 1998, when he told me he was going to put Augusto Pinochet on trial. Given how diligently he went on to pursue the case, I felt bad about my initial scepticism and confessed it to him a few weeks ago. In 1998, though, it had not seemed likely, with Pinochet under arrest in Britain, that Guzman's bluff would ever be called.

At the time, Norman Lamont, the president of Chile and General Pinochet himself, were all arguing that he should be permitted to go home precisely because there was a fine judicial system in Chile, more than capable of doing any business that had to be done. But you didn't have to be terribly smart to know that Pinochet had his fingers crossed. After all, he has done more to damage the Chilean judicial system than most.

Juan Guzman knew that too. He had been a judge throughout the dictatorship and knew perfectly well that Chile's judges had washed their hands of their responsibilities to the victims' families. With a few honourable exceptions, they had caved in to the fiction that every crime committed by a man in uniform is a military crime and should receive the sympathetic judgment of a military court. As Guzman now says, a military crime is when a soldier deserts, or falls asleep on duty. Torture, murder and aggravated kidnapping are criminal acts and it is the responsibility of the criminal courts to judge them.

A few months ago, Guzman confessed that it hadn't seemed likely to him either, back in 1998, that he could or would get this far. He, too, had had his fingers crossed when he argued for Pinochet's return. All the more credit, then, to this modest and serious man for having risen to the occasion, despite the arguments of convenience, personal threats and social ostracism which have come with doing his judicial duty.

The general, in these troubled days, has produced yet another version of history. Under the dictatorship, Pinochet's men used to say that tales of human rights abuse were mere communist propaganda and that the disappeared were all living it up in Sweden or Mexico. After the return to democracy the Rettig truth and reconciliation commission detailed a long list of torture cases, disappearance and death, and the general's men had to admit that there were a few such cases, but claimed that it was only to be expected in a "war" against subversion.

General Guillermo Garin, Pinochet's right hand man, repeated this line to me recently. "As you well know," he said, "you have examples close to home." So for the record, there was no war in Chile. In the case of the "Caravan of Death", the 76 murders that took place mainly in the north of Chile in the space of a few days in October 1973, all the victims were already in the custody of the local military commanders. When Pinochet's "special commission", led by his friend General Arellano Starck arrived, the prisoners were taken out and murdered. Perhaps that happened, Pinochet has now admitted in his latest version, but if it did, it was the local military commanders who were to blame, not the innocent commander in chief.

He really should not have ventured this final, cowardly lie. His remarks provoked a furious response from General Joaquin Lagos who was in command of Calama, a mining town in the Atacama desert, when Arellano Starck arrived in his helicopter on October 19 1973. General Lagos is in a good position to know what happened and has lived with a tortured conscience ever since because he could not prevent it.

It was the duty, of course, of the local commanders to protect their prisoners. But when Arellano arrived with special orders from Pinochet, he outranked all of them and, under the military code, he assumed command for the duration of his visit. Had his orders not been obeyed, Arellano was entitled to have men like Lagos shot.

When Arellano ordered the murder of 26 of his prisoners, Lagos protested. On whose authority, he demanded, was such a barbarous act to be committed? Arellano, in response, showed him the orders from Pinochet. Outraged, Lagos told Pinochet what had happened on October 20 1973, as Pinochet and his sinister wife, Dona Lucia were passing through Antofagasta airport. Pinochet asked for a written report, which Lagos duly sent to him. Pinochet ordered him to rewrite it to remove all mention of Arellano. Eight months later, Lagos left the army. Last week, he publicly produced both versions of the documents.

The murders, of course, were crimes under the law. Had there been a war, the dead might have been passed off, if you did not look too closely, as casualties of conflict. But there was, I repeat, no war.

Had Arellano acted without an order from Pinochet, it was Pinochet's clear duty under military law to court martial him. Instead, he promoted Arellano in December 1973, along with the officers who had accompanied him. Compare that with the fate of Major Fernando Reveco, also from Calama, who was tortured and imprisoned by the army that he loved, on charges of "excessive leniency" with the civilian population. Reveco confirms that the entire area was peaceful at the time.

Why then, the caravan of death? Its purpose, Reveco says, was to instil terror not so much in the civilian population as in the army itself, to put on notice those officers who had a respect for the oath they had taken to defend both the constitution and the civilian population, that the time of constitutions, civil rights and the rule of law was over. As such, it was a key moment in the installation of the terrorist state that Pinochet set up after the 1973 coup.

In order to restore the rule of law to Chile, that fine judicial system that he claims exists, Pinochet has to answer for those crimes. That is why Juan Guzman has again charged him with murder and aggravated kidnapping.

There is a broad avenue in the centre of Santiago that begins at the back of the presidential palace. In it are several statues of heroic, patriotic figures and one empty space. It is that spot that Pinochet had picked out for a statue of himself - to commemorate the man who saved the nation from communism. Pinochet may never go to jail, but at least now, thanks to Juan Guzman, he won't get his statue and Chileans no longer have to pretend to believe him.

A few months ago, Guzman confessed that it hadn't seemed likely to him either, back in 1998, that he could or would get this far. He, too, had had his fingers crossed when he argued for Pinochet's return. All the more credit, then, to this modest and serious man for having risen to the occasion, despite the arguments of convenience, personal threats and social ostracism which have come with doing his judicial duty. The general, in these troubled days, has produced yet another version of history. Under the dictatorship, Pinochet's men used to say that tales of human rights abuse were mere communist propaganda and that the disappeared were all living it up in Sweden or Mexico. After the return to democracy the Rettig truth and reconciliation commission detailed a long list of torture cases, disappearance and death, and the general's men had to admit that there were a few such cases, but claimed that it was only to be expected in a "war" against subversion. General Guillermo Garin, Pinochet's right hand man, repeated this line to me recently. "As you well know," he said, "you have examples close to home." So for the record, there was no war in Chile. In the case of the "Caravan of Death", the 76 murders that took place mainly in the north of Chile in the space of a few days in October 1973, all the victims were already in the custody of the local military commanders. When Pinochet's "special commission", led by his friend General Arellano Starck arrived, the prisoners were taken out and murdered. Perhaps that happened, Pinochet has now admitted in his latest version, but if it did, it was the local military commanders who were to blame, not the innocent commander in chief. He really should not have ventured this final, cowardly lie. His remarks provoked a furious response from General Joaquin Lagos who was in command of Calama, a mining town in the Atacama desert, when Arellano Starck arrived in his helicopter on October 19 1973. General Lagos is in a good position to know what happened and has lived with a tortured conscience ever since because he could not prevent it. It was the duty, of course, of the local commanders to protect their prisoners. But when Arellano arrived with special orders from Pinochet, he outranked all of them and, under the military code, he assumed command for the duration of his visit. Had his orders not been obeyed, Arellano was entitled to have men like Lagos shot. When Arellano ordered the murder of 26 of his prisoners, Lagos protested. On whose authority, he demanded, was such a barbarous act to be committed? Arellano, in response, showed him the orders from Pinochet. Outraged, Lagos told Pinochet what had happened on October 20 1973, as Pinochet and his sinister wife, Dona Lucia were passing through Antofagasta airport. Pinochet asked for a written report, which Lagos duly sent to him. Pinochet ordered him to rewrite it to remove all mention of Arellano. Eight months later, Lagos left the army. Last week, he publicly produced both versions of the documents. The murders, of course, were crimes under the law. Had there been a war, the dead might have been passed off, if you did not look too closely, as casualties of conflict. But there was, I repeat, no war. Had Arellano acted without an order from Pinochet, it was Pinochet's clear duty under military law to court martial him. Instead, he promoted Arellano in December 1973, along with the officers who had accompanied him. Compare that with the fate of Major Fernando Reveco, also from Calama, who was tortured and imprisoned by the army that he loved, on charges of "excessive leniency" with the civilian population. Reveco confirms that the entire area was peaceful at the time. Why then, the caravan of death? Its purpose, Reveco says, was to instil terror not so much in the civilian population as in the army itself, to put on notice those officers who had a respect for the oath they had taken to defend both the constitution and the civilian population, that the time of constitutions, civil rights and the rule of law was over. As such, it was a key moment in the installation of the terrorist state that Pinochet set up after the 1973 coup. In order to restore the rule of law to Chile, that fine judicial system that he claims exists, Pinochet has to answer for those crimes. That is why Juan Guzman has again charged him with murder and aggravated kidnapping. There is a broad avenue in the centre of Santiago that begins at the back of the presidential palace. In it are several statues of heroic, patriotic figures and one empty space. It is that spot that Pinochet had picked out for a statue of himself - to commemorate the man who saved the nation from communism. Pinochet may never go to jail, but at least now, thanks to Juan Guzman, he won't get his statue and Chileans no longer have to pretend to believe him. isabel.hilton@theguardian.com

webTitle: Taiwanese government in crisis over nuclear plant

fields.headline: Taiwanese government in crisis over nuclear plant
fields.standfirst: Special report: Taiwan and China
fields.trailText: Taiwan's minority government faces a political crisis today after refusing to abandon an election pledge to scrap a controversial nuclear power station project.
fields.body:
Taiwan's minority government faces a political crisis today after refusing to abandon an election pledge to scrap a controversial nuclear power station project.

Parliament is expected to approve the project today, but the premier, Chang Chun-hsiung, told legislators yesterday he would not be bound by such a vote.

"Construction of nuclear power plants in Taiwan is neither an economic nor an ideological issue, but an issue of life and survival of the 23m people, and an issue concerning the future welfare of all," he said defiantly.

The island lacked the capacity to handle nuclear waste or possible disasters, he added.

President Chen Shui-bian repeated the pledge to stop the construction of Taiwan's fourth nuclear power station when he won last year's election as head of the opposition Democratic Progressive party (DPP).

But the former ruling party, the Kuomintang (KMT), has seized on the issue, which has been badly mishandled by Mr Chen's cabinet. The opposition coalition, led by the KMT, is likely to call for Mr Chang's resignation and refuse to cooperate with the government.

The row, which has been raging since autumn, also weakens Mr Chen's ability to work out a new relationship with Beijing, which is deeply suspicious of his nation-making intentions.

The nuclear plant was originally pushed through by the previous KMT administration despite violent street protests, and is already one third complete. If cancelled, the government will have to pay almost £2bn in compensation.

Mr Chang gave the opposition-dominated legislature its political opening in October when he announced that work on the plant would halt immediately without reporting to them first.

The KMT and two other main opposition parties hold 141 of the legislature's 221 seats: the DPP has 68 with the rest held by independents.

China's highest legal body, the council of grand justices, has ruled that Mr Chang followed "flawed procedures" in halting work on the site, but it was unclear to whether he had violated the constitution.

Observers say that Mr Chen has shown political inexperience in allowing what should have been a popular decision to be turned against him.

Polls show that 30% to 40% of the public accept the anti-nuclear argument. But the opposition, backed by the markets, has convinced many others that an anti-nuclear decision will undermine financial confidence.

KMT stalwarts, who ruled Taiwan dictatorially for more than 30 years, are now happily presenting themselves as champions of democracy against Mr Chen, whom they say has acted with wanton disregard for political process.

Legislators yesterday accused him and the premier of lacking political wisdom and of risking his future in the same manner as the recently deposed president of the Philippines, Joseph Estrada.

The independent Taipei Times yesterday urged both sides to seek a compromise.

The DPP, it argued, should understand that "a policy needs majority public support no matter what moral high-ground [it] may command". It also urged the KMT to "leave behind its ruling-party mentality" and to stop opposing Mr Chen for the sake of opposition.

The issue has definitely touch a raw nerve with the public; two Taiwanese men set themselves on fire in the run-up to the debate in the legislative council in protest against the project. Yesterday, however, some 50 protesters demonstrated peacefully outside the legislature holding pictures of the nuclear disasters at Three Mile Island and Chernobyl.

webTitle: Former Whitbread chairman berates handling of real estate sale

fields.headline: Former Whitbread chairman sides with publicans
fields.trailText: A former chairman of Whitbread yesterday joined angry pub licensees in berating the company's directors over their handling of the £1.5bn sale of the group's retail estate.
fields.body:
A former chairman of Whitbread yesterday joined angry pub licensees in berating the company's directors over their handling of the £1.5bn sale of the group's retail estate.

Tenants claimed they have been treated "like lepers" by Whitbread, which is refusing to allow them first refusal in the sale of the pubs.

At a shareholders' meeting Sir Charles Tidbury, who chaired Whitbread from 1979 to 1984, urged directors to listen to the publicans. He said: "I would ask the board to consider very carefully what they are doing to these people, in a moral sense."

Sir Charles, a friend of the royal family, who once survived an assassination attempt by the IRA, asked the board to consider "the principles of fair play imbued by the founders of the business". He said: "I'd rather forgo a little bit of money and time and see these chaps dealt with in what I'd consider an honest, fair way."

Whitbread wants to sell all 3,000 pubs in one block, on the grounds that this would be quicker, simpler and potentially more lucrative. Tenants are concerned that a financial buyer, such as Nomura or Candover, would attempt to change their supply contracts, making them purchase different beers at higher prices.

Carol Frewing, who runs two pubs in Portsmouth, said: "They call our businesses pub partnerships. But if one partner wants to withdraw, surely you've got to let the other proceed on decent terms."

Gary McClure of the Old King's Head, Barrow-in-Furness, said: "They think we're just stupid landlords, but we work 14 or 16 hours a day."

Addressing Whitbread's current chairman Sir John Banham, Mr McClure said: "You've treated your partners like second-class citizens - like lepers."

Sir John replied: "We are selling a business, not a series of properties. It's very much in the interests of shareholders to sell it as one business."

Whitbread's directors were also attacked for a pay-off to departing director Alan Perelman. He is to receive compensation of £375,000, plus a £1.7m addition to his pension fund. Sir John said that the payments were a contractual obligation.

Proposals for a tax-efficient financial restructuring to enable the sale of the pubs were overwhelmingly carried. Whitbread is to focus on hotels and restaurants.

webTitle: Iceland's founder to quit

fields.headline: Iceland's founder to quit
fields.standfirst: Share sale row intensifies
fields.trailText: Iceland supermarkets' chairman, Malcolm Walker, will quit the company today amid mounting criticism over the timing of a £13m share sale.
fields.body:
Iceland supermarkets' chairman, Malcolm Walker, will quit the company today amid mounting criticism over the timing of a £13m share sale.

Mr Walker, who founded the Iceland chain more than 30 years ago, is expected to resign this morning. He is understood to have told Iceland's directors of his decision to go at a crisis board meeting held in London yesterday.

Pressure had been mounting on Mr Walker since Iceland issued a shock profit warning last week. The warning revealed that Christmas sales had fallen well short of expectations.

Only a few weeks earlier - on December 20 - Mr Walker had sold 4m shares in the company at some 339p - just short of the group's five-year high. The sell-off, which represented the bulk of Mr Walker's stake in the company, netted the chairman £13.5m.

Since the profit warning the shares have continued to drop and last night they closed down 5p at 187.5p - their lowest in two years. If the tranche of shares had been sold yesterday Mr Walker would have been £6m worse off.

Analysts have been particularly incensed about the timing of the share sale because they had been invited on an Iceland company visit just before Mr Walker's controver sial dealings and claim they had received a positive impression about progress.

Defending the timing of his sale, the Iceland chairman has insisted that he did not know that Christmas sales would be so poor. They collapsed by 5.5% on last year's levels in the four Christmas trading weeks.

It is now clear that the integration of cash and carry group Booker, with which Iceland merged last year, is also falling short of targets. An update on the merger, to be provided today, is expected to confirm that the £20m savings expected from the merger have not yetbegan to appear.

Stuart Rose, the Booker chief who co-engineered the merger and became Mr Walker's chief executive, has since left the company to head the fashion chain Arcadia and another new chief executive has been hired. Former Wickes boss Bill Grimsey has already ditched Iceland's commitment to organic produce, which has been blamed for the downturn in sales, and will outline his strategy for Booker today.

A financial services authority investigation into the timing of Mr Walker's share sale is under way.

It is understood that the Iceland board did not ask Mr Walker to sever his ties with the company. A source close to Mr Walker, 54, said the meeting was amicable and the Iceland boss had chosen retirement.

Cheshire set's Mr Green

One minute Malcolm Walker is the multi-millionaire epitome of the Cheshire set - a shooting, deer-stalking Margaret Thatcher fan - the next Mr Green, the only chairman of a listed company who keeps chickens, grows his own vegetables and is a member of Greenpeace.

The son of a colliery electrician from Huddersfield, Mr Walker left school at 17 train as a Woolworths manager.

While there he set up a frozen food shop, selling loose peas and fish fingers by the scoop. The idea took off and his £60 start-up capital was transformed into a 700-store chain and a personal fortune estimated at £25m.

Mr Walker introduced home delivery and pioneered internet sales - even rebranding the company as Iceland.co.uk. Then he attempted to make Iceland a cool place to shop, trying to turn it from a shop associated with cheap burgers to the home of mass-market organic produce.

Last year he agreed a merger with cash & carry group Booker, and installed its boss Stuart Rose as chief executive - only to see him poached by fashion group Arcadia.

After Iceland's sales slumped, the shares tumbled and Mr Walker walked.

webTitle: Judge says Nadir must face charges

fields.headline: Judge says Nadir must face charges
fields.trailText: Fugitive tycoon Asil Nadir was last night "considering his options" after failing in his high court attempt to have the multi-million pound fraud charges against him dropped.
fields.body:
Fugitive tycoon Asil Nadir was last night "considering his options" after failing in his high court attempt to have the multi-million pound fraud charges against him dropped.

The former Polly Peck boss, who is in self-imposed exile in northern Cyprus after fleeing Britain seven years ago, had applied for the case to be dismissed by arguing he would be unable to receive a fair trial.

But lawyers acting for the serious fraud office put in a counter-application saying this would be an abuse of process because he was refusing to return to face charges in the UK.

Yesterday afternoon, in a landmark judgment, Mr Justice Potts ruled in favour of the SFO, saying that to allow the dismissal would be an "affront to the public conscience".

After partly lifting stringent reporting restrictions which had been in place during the two-week hearing, the judge said medical reports suggesting Mr Nadir was clinically depressed had failed to convince him the tycoon was not able to stand trial in Britain.

Mr Justice Potts said Mr Nadir could not rely on applications to British courts while at the same time denying their jurisdiction, but could make the application if and when he returned. "I am satisfied the crown, in seeking an order to stay, is seeking to maintain the integrity of the legal system and the trial process in this case," he said.

webTitle: BMW's unofficial input into new MGs

fields.headline: Quick off the marque BMW's unofficial input into new MGs
fields.trailText: MG Rover yesterday admitted it had developed three MG models in record time partly as a result of unofficial work carried out when BMW owned the company.
fields.body:
MG Rover yesterday admitted it had developed three MG models in record time partly as a result of unofficial work carried out when BMW owned the company.

The cars, codenamed X10, X20 and X30 sports saloons, derivatives of the existing R25, R45 and R75 models, will cost between £10,000 and £30,000 when they go on sale at the end of August.

Rod Oldaker, MG Rover's director of product development, said the group had invested about £100m since it came into being in May, to develop the models in time. Some preparatory work was carried out when Munich-based BMW owned the company. "Some of it was official and some of it was a bit below Munich's radar screen."

Kevin Howe, group chief executive, said engineers had started work on sporty versions of existing Rover models off their own bat once they became aware that BMW wanted to sell the company. "Engineers like playing about to see what a car will do," he said.

The group wants Rover as its luxury marque and MG as the performance car. Mr Howe said he expected MGs to account for 25% of the group's 210,000 sales next year. It is aiming to produce an average of 200,000 cars a year.

webTitle: Analysis: EU reluctant to take-on US 'powerhouse' status

fields.headline: Europe finds US mantle is no snug fit
fields.standfirst: EU is reluctant to take over from recession-stricken America as global powerhouse
fields.trailText: EU is reluctant to take over from recession-stricken America as global powerhouse.
fields.body:
Europe's policymakers have had to grin and bear it as the US has provided the template for the way the global economy should be run. The past 10 years have been an Alan Greenspan master-class in the theory and practice of modern capitalism, with the Europeans forced to listen to lectures about how they should scrap their social-market model and learn to be more dynamic.

But today the boot may be on the other foot. Mr Greenspan is widely expected to have to cut US interest rates tonight by half a percentage point, but as the new treasury secretary, Paul O'Neill, is aware, this is not because the American economy is booming but because it is teetering on the brink of recession. Yesterday came figures showing US consumer confidence in January had fallen to its lowest level in four years, driven down by growing fears of a hard landing for the economy.

By contrast, growth in Europe is likely to be between 2.5 and 3% - modest by the standards of the US since the mid-1990s but still markedly better than Bush's America is likely to achieve in 2001.

Outperforming the Americans will be heartily welcome for countries such as France, which has always insisted that there is an alternative to the Anglo-Saxon model. The crucial question, however, is whether Europe is capable of taking on the role of locomotive of the global economy, taking up the slack left by America's faltering miracle.

Looking around euroland, there are economies that are performing strongly. Ireland is one of the world's fastest growing economies, while Sweden and Finland have surfed the hi-tech wave, and proved that dynamism and social welfare are not mutually exclusive. But for Europe to become the US of the first decade of the new millennium would require growth rates well in excess of 2.5-3%. While economists have no doubt that Europe has sufficient resilience to weather the storm brewing on the other side of the Atlantic, there is considerable scepticism that it can provide an umbrella for the rest of the world.

This is precisely what the US did when the knock-on effects from the Asian financial crisis rippled around the globe in 1997 and 1998. Prompted by the cheap-money policy engineered by Mr Greenspan, consumers went on a spending spree. The result was fast growth, but the twin legacy of heavy indebtedness and an ever-larger trade deficit.

Leo Doyle, analyst at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, said: "Europe is in good shape but I'm not sure whether culturally it is willing to take on that role of debtor. It has healthy balance sheets, asset prices have risen and taxes have been cut. Consumers should be willing to go on a bit of a spree but they have never shown much of a willingness to do so.

"What you would need is a quite aggressive central bank which would lower rates in advance of possible negative effects arriving from the US, and dramatically so. But I can't see it happening. The European Central Bank is still fighting inflation and will keep rates somewhat higher than they need to be."

Gerard Lyons, chief economist at Standard Chartered bank, said the rise in the value of the euro over recent months was chipping away at one of the main components of European growth - the boom in exports.

As a result, much faster European growth would depend on a substantial relaxation of fiscal policy or the conversion of the ECB to a growth-oriented monetary policy. "I have no confidence in the ECB being growth-oriented."

Although the US and Europe's single market are of similar size in economic terms the latter is unlikely to be able to deliver growth on the scale demonstrated by the US as it took the global strain through a succession of crises - the meltdown in south-east Asia and the Russian debt default. According to Ralph Solveen, senior economist at Commerzbank in Frankfurt, the US was able to act as an engine for the global economy on the back of growth rate of 5% a year. "The dynamism of growth in euroland will not be so high - and imports will not be so strong as they were in the US."

Dr Lyons said Europe's supply-side problems were one reason it would not emulate the US. "It still has its unemployment black spots, and while the US is a large market that imports a lot, Europe is a lot more insular."

That is not to say that if the US sneezes Europe will necessarily succumb to a heavy cold. Alison Cottrell at UBS Warburg argues that Europe has a number of internal factors helping to sustain domestic growth during a short, sharp US shock: high confidence, tax cuts and falling unemployment.

"If the US trips, Europe may be able to avoid stumbling too, but it is not going to be able to pull the US back up again."

For Europe, the immediate future will provide a real test. Does it play safe and accept it will for ever play second fiddle to the US, or does it accept the challenge of at least a share in global economic leadership, despite the risk that more rapid expansion may prove unsustainable?

Almost two centuries ago, the British statesman George Canning said: "I called the New World into existence, to redress the balance of the Old." It may be a while before an economic policymaker can boast about having done the reverse.
fields.bodyText: Europe's policymakers have had to grin and bear it as the US has provided the template for the way the global economy should be run. The past 10 years have been an Alan Greenspan master-class in the theory and practice of modern capitalism, with the Europeans forced to listen to lectures about how they should scrap their social-market model and learn to be more dynamic. But today the boot may be on the other foot. Mr Greenspan is widely expected to have to cut US interest rates tonight by half a percentage point, but as the new treasury secretary, Paul O'Neill, is aware, this is not because the American economy is booming but because it is teetering on the brink of recession. Yesterday came figures showing US consumer confidence in January had fallen to its lowest level in four years, driven down by growing fears of a hard landing for the economy. By contrast, growth in Europe is likely to be between 2.5 and 3% - modest by the standards of the US since the mid-1990s but still markedly better than Bush's America is likely to achieve in 2001. Outperforming the Americans will be heartily welcome for countries such as France, which has always insisted that there is an alternative to the Anglo-Saxon model. The crucial question, however, is whether Europe is capable of taking on the role of locomotive of the global economy, taking up the slack left by America's faltering miracle. Looking around euroland, there are economies that are performing strongly. Ireland is one of the world's fastest growing economies, while Sweden and Finland have surfed the hi-tech wave, and proved that dynamism and social welfare are not mutually exclusive. But for Europe to become the US of the first decade of the new millennium would require growth rates well in excess of 2.5-3%. While economists have no doubt that Europe has sufficient resilience to weather the storm brewing on the other side of the Atlantic, there is considerable scepticism that it can provide an umbrella for the rest of the world. This is precisely what the US did when the knock-on effects from the Asian financial crisis rippled around the globe in 1997 and 1998. Prompted by the cheap-money policy engineered by Mr Greenspan, consumers went on a spending spree. The result was fast growth, but the twin legacy of heavy indebtedness and an ever-larger trade deficit. Leo Doyle, analyst at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, said: "Europe is in good shape but I'm not sure whether culturally it is willing to take on that role of debtor. It has healthy balance sheets, asset prices have risen and taxes have been cut. Consumers should be willing to go on a bit of a spree but they have never shown much of a willingness to do so. "What you would need is a quite aggressive central bank which would lower rates in advance of possible negative effects arriving from the US, and dramatically so. But I can't see it happening. The European Central Bank is still fighting inflation and will keep rates somewhat higher than they need to be." Gerard Lyons, chief economist at Standard Chartered bank, said the rise in the value of the euro over recent months was chipping away at one of the main components of European growth - the boom in exports. As a result, much faster European growth would depend on a substantial relaxation of fiscal policy or the conversion of the ECB to a growth-oriented monetary policy. "I have no confidence in the ECB being growth-oriented." Although the US and Europe's single market are of similar size in economic terms the latter is unlikely to be able to deliver growth on the scale demonstrated by the US as it took the global strain through a succession of crises - the meltdown in south-east Asia and the Russian debt default. According to Ralph Solveen, senior economist at Commerzbank in Frankfurt, the US was able to act as an engine for the global economy on the back of growth rate of 5% a year. "The dynamism of growth in euroland will not be so high - and imports will not be so strong as they were in the US." Dr Lyons said Europe's supply-side problems were one reason it would not emulate the US. "It still has its unemployment black spots, and while the US is a large market that imports a lot, Europe is a lot more insular." That is not to say that if the US sneezes Europe will necessarily succumb to a heavy cold. Alison Cottrell at UBS Warburg argues that Europe has a number of internal factors helping to sustain domestic growth during a short, sharp US shock: high confidence, tax cuts and falling unemployment. "If the US trips, Europe may be able to avoid stumbling too, but it is not going to be able to pull the US back up again." For Europe, the immediate future will provide a real test. webTitle: Whitbread: Sir Charles fires a shots for the tenants

fields.headline: Sir Charles fires a shot for the tenants
fields.standfirst: Board in Old Etonian's sights
fields.trailText: Hell hath no fury like an old Etonian scorned, so the board of Whitbread had better watch out. Former chairman and general City grandee Sir Charles Tidbury, who evaded murder by the IRA in the 1980s and lists "rough shooting" among his hobbies, is not happy.
fields.body:
Hell hath no fury like an old Etonian scorned, so the board of Whitbread had better watch out. Former chairman and general City grandee Sir Charles Tidbury, who evaded murder by the IRA in the 1980s and lists "rough shooting" among his hobbies, is not happy.

Sir Charles wants Whitbread to let its licensees buy their own pubs rather than selling their homes and businesses en masse to whichever Japanese bank comes up with the fattest cheque.

The company is not keen - it is worried that negotiations with individual landlords would be lengthy and complicated.

Whitbread's attitude is an example of the City at its worst. The firm held a meeting yesterday to approve a highly complex "scheme of arrangement" requiring investors to swap their Whitbread shares for equity in something called Whitbread Holdings. This is in order to save a few million in tax.

Yet when it comes to looking after long-serving tenants, laughably called "partners", the company insists that simplicity is of the essence.

In reality, only a few hundred landlords would be able to mount a credible bid for their properties. This would represent a tiny slice of the estate as a whole. Whitbread should indulge these long-term stakeholders, even if it means investors have to wait a bit longer to trouser a £1bn cash handout following the sale's completion.

Nasdaq moves

Having spent the past four years trying to distance itself from the diminutive European Easdaq stock exchange, Nasdaq of the US - on which the Brussels-based market was based - is now in talks to take it over.

The Americans, of course, do not want anyone to confuse these long-standing discussions with Nasdaq's much grander plans to take over either the London Stock Exchange or the Deutsche Börse (or both) and establish itself as the prime European equity market.

The move is being billed as a tidying-up exercise - sorting out a financially challenged bastard offspring which boasts just 62 listed companies of its own.

But this cannot avoid drawing attention to the fact that Nasdaq really is struggling to woo any of the major European bourses. Its self-imposed mid-January deadline to chisel out some sort of deal with the LSE has come and gone. In Frankfurt, the Deutsche Börse float has happened - without any indication that something strategic with the Americans might be in the offing.

The best, it seems, Nasdaq can hope for is some sort of strategic stake in one or other institution. Operational control of pan-European equity platform with real clout will continue to elude it.

Meanwhile, in New York, Nasdaq is left as the last major exchange still using fractions for prices after the New York Stock Exchange moved to decimalisation this week. Nasdaq promises to follow within a few months.

And we must assume, in the meantime, that the delay has nothing to do with technical problems at the market which brought us electronic trading in the first place.

Bad custom

Fred Goodwin, the chief executive of Royal Bank of Scotland, which owns NatWest, boasted yesterday that 30% of its customers "elect" to pay a set monthly fee for their current accounts.

This suggests two things. Either Royal Bank has found a very clever way to boost its profitability by charging its customers for their everyday banking facilities, or, its customers are slightly stupid.

In bankers' speak, the customers pay because they "prefer the proposition". If the customers spoke, it would probably be to say that they "can't be bothered" to move their account elsewhere. This probably explains why some 70% of the country's current accounts are run by the "big four" - Lloyds TSB, NatWest, HSBC and Barclays - and have been for as long as any one can remember.

Yesterday, it was the MPs on the influential Treasury committee that were trying to get to the bottom of why it is so few people move their accounts. It is also a situation that the government is trying address. Why is it that millions of Britons surf the net and plough through best-buy tables to look for the cheapest mortgages and loans and highest savings rates but very rarely move their current accounts?

In part it is because there is a lot of hassle involved in moving a current account. Salary details need to be changed, direct debits and standing orders moved over. The banks claim to be tackling this and taking the hassle out of moving by swapping the information about debits and credits between themselves.

But it could be at least a year or so before it is clear whether this will make any difference at all to lazy bank customers.

webTitle: At this price?  Crest Nicholson

fields.headline: At this price?  Crest Nicholson
fields.trailText: John Callcutt, chief executive of housebuilder Crest Nicholson, holds a romantic vision of the future where faceless buildings and "soulless" industrial parks have given way to individualism and the return of close communities.
fields.body:
John Callcutt, chief executive of housebuilder Crest Nicholson, holds a romantic vision of the future where faceless buildings and "soulless" industrial parks have given way to individualism and the return of close communities.

In his world housing developments are places which have "some life and character" and people do not have to travel out of town to do their shopping. This idealism may seem somewhat airy-fairy, but developing such neighbourhood sites is producing concrete returns for Mr Callcutt's company.

Yesterday it announced a 20% rise in full-year, pre-tax profits to £48.1m, with earnings up 26% to 30p per share.

Recent years have seen the company concentrate on building up its land bank, now a problem area full of unpredictable dealings with local councils, as well as focusing on larger mixed-use sites rather than standard houses on small plots.

Crest is upbeat on its future prospects, saying: "The outlook for the housing market is sound. We are ideally positioned to have a good year."

This was enough to lift the shares more than 10%, or 18p, taking the stock to a year's high of 193.5p.

As one of the army of smaller construction compa nies in a rapidly consolidating industry, Crest Nicholson rarely has the chance to fight its way into the headlines.

Its market size significantly lags behind rivals and the recent waves of consolidation in the sector can only increase this divide.

But the company's recent success, coupled with what is undoubtedly a cheap share price, could make Crest a very attractive takeover target in coming months.

Observers would like to see the company improve its margins on the housing side and have questioned the value of maintaining its construction arm, but these are relatively minor points.

Crest seems soundly based and continuing talk about possible takeoveris likely to give the shares a speculative edge. Worth considering.

webTitle: ING to drop Barings name as 500 City jobs go

fields.headline: ING to drop Barings name as 500 City jobs go
fields.trailText: At least 500 City jobs are being cut by Dutch bank ING after a decision to curtail its global ambitions.
fields.body:
At least 500 City jobs are being cut by Dutch bank ING after a decision to curtail its global ambitions.

As part of the move it is scaling back the investment banking business it had been building since rescuing Barings from collapse in 1995. In total 2,300 jobs worldwide will be affected by the restructuring.

It is now only a matter of time before the Barings name is dropped by the Amsterdam-based bank which presently describes its investment banking division as ING Barings.

Deterred by the cost of recruiting and paying bankers in the United States, ING also sold its US domestic operation to its Dutch rival ABN Amro yesterday. Over 1,300 staff will transfer to ABN Amro, which is preparing to pay lock-in bonuses of up to £70m to retain top staff.

The move is a reversal of the strategy previously adopted by ING, which only two years ago bought US broking firm Furman Selz as it embarked on a strategy to be become a leading investment bank.

Yesterday, though, Michel Tilmant, vice chairman of ING's executive board, made it clear that ING no longer harboured ambitions to become a global investment bank. He said: "In the US, the cost of doing business - hiring and paying - is very high."

ING insisted, however, that it remained committed to investment banking in Europe, Asia and Latin America although will cut 1,000 staff as its restructures the operation along two main business lines - wholesale and financial markets - and shuts ING Barings' head office operations in the City. Control will move to Europe, where ING owns BBL and BHF.

The 500 jobs being eliminated in London incorporates the 160 or so bankers who have already left, including the former chief executive David Robins. Another 160 will leave by the end of the week with the large majority of the remainder being agency staff. It will cost ING over £300m to pay for the restructuring but the company aims to reduce operating expenses as a result.

ING will book a profit of around £25m on the sale of the US domestic business to ABN Amro.

webTitle: Market forces: Telecoms sector picks up

fields.headline: Telecoms sector picks up
fields.trailText: Stock market traders were topping up on telecoms stocks yesterday, but there was caution elsewhere ahead of this evening's decision from the US federal market open committee. Fed boss Alan Greenspan is widely expected to cut US interest rates by 0.5% - any other development is likely to upset markets on both sides of the Atlantic.
fields.body:
Stock market traders were topping up on telecoms stocks yesterday, but there was caution elsewhere ahead of this evening's decision from the US federal market open committee. Fed boss Alan Greenspan is widely expected to cut US interest rates by 0.5% - any other development is likely to upset markets on both sides of the Atlantic.

All of the big telecoms companies moved ahead sharply, but analysts said there was no one reason to explain the sudden interest. The sector even shrugged off a bleak outlook for the year from Nokia, the world's largest phone maker.

The effect, however, was to add 27 points to the FTSE 100 and keep it in positive territory. By the end of the day it was 17.5 points up at 6,334.5.

Gainers outnumbered losers by almost three to two, with volume a moderate 1.7bn shares traded. British Telecom put on 5% at 726p, helped by what was said to be a positive meeting with some of its key institutional shareholders on Monday night.

The company plans to demerge its directories business Yell rather than opting for a flotation of 25% of the business. Cable & Wireless was also on the up, helped by talk that it was the one cash-rich telecoms company in a field of debt. It gained 3% at 932p, while Vodafone increased by 2% to 246.5p.

But the majors were not alone as the mid-cap telecom stocks moved ahead, with Thus the pick of the bunch, showing a 20% surge to 74.5p on the back of better-than-expected third-quarter results.

Hull-based Kingston Communications enjoyed a 5% increase to 12.75p, ahead of its third-quarter figures due out today.

Carphone Warehouse, however, was a visible victim of Nokia's warning with its shares sinking 6.5%, or 12p, to 171.5p, which is well off its 230p year high but not too far off its 142.5p low.

Elsewhere, bold moves were few and far between with strategists insisting it was fool ish to make major decisions before the outcome of the Fed's two-day meeting was known.

Supermarket chain J Sainsbury was the only one in its sector to see gains, edging up 8p to 364p on the back of a positive note from co-house broker ABN Amro which gushed that the company's recovery was in "excellent hands".

Another prominent food retail analyst said there was "no new news".

Iceland, which recently issued a profits warning, dropped 2.6% ahead of today's statement relating to progress on its merger with cash-and-carry business Booker, while Safeway was down 2.75p at 298.5p.

The general retailers were having a better time with Matalan, the discount store, climbing 8.8%, Mothercare putting on 4.5% at 204.5p and Boots, the chemist chain, rising 8p to 593p.

But it was a bad day for the oil and gas stocks which, when combined, had wiped 22 points off the benchmark index by close of business.

Analysts blamed the drop in crude oil prices sparked by forecasts of mild weather in the US for BP Amoco slipping almost 2% to 578.5p and Shell dropping 5p to 558p.

EMI Group struck a wrong chord with concerns raised over its proposed merger with BMG, the music arm of Bertelsmann. The stock slipped 15p to 508p, a long way off its year high of 810p.

British American Tobacco, the world's second largest tobacco manufacturer, launched an A$1.1bn bid for the 40.5% stake in BAT Australasia it didn't already own. Shares rose 17p, or 3.5%, to 499p.

Advanced Technology, which provides power communication systems, jumped 17.4% after announcing it was in detailed discussions for a large supply contract.

Away from the lead index, the FTSE 250 rose 25.9 points to 6,751.1 and the Techmark index of technology shares crept up 1.48 points to close at 2,784.41.

webTitle: Thus pulls out of the loop on net access

fields.headline: Thus pulls out of the loop on net access
fields.trailText: The government's promise of "widespread availability" of high-speed internet access by the summer looked increasingly hollow last night after another telecoms company shelved its plans to compete in BT's local exchanges.
fields.body:
The government's promise of "widespread availability" of high-speed internet access by the summer looked increasingly hollow last night after another telecoms company shelved its plans to compete in BT's local exchanges.

Thus, the former Scottish Telecom, yesterday decided to pull out of plans to participate in the"unbundling of the local loop", saying it could not justify the cost.

The break-up of BT's local monopoly is seen as the key for the adoption of broadband services. It allows rival operators to install DSL equipment which upgrades the old copper wire network for higher bandwidth use. Thus has joined a growing band of companies abandoning their plans in the face of what they see as intransigence on the part of BT and an increasingly protracted process.

Last year US telecoms group WorldCom pulled out of the broadband market - after reports that it was "frustrated" with Oftel's handling of the process of opening up BT's monopoly to competition.

Another player, RSL Communications, pulled out of the first stage of bidding and accused the industry's regulator of failing to ensure fair play for rivals to BT. The latest to scale back was Redstone Telecom, which two weeks ago sharply reduced its investment.

The announcement from Thus will be a further blow to Oftel director general David Edmunds who called a meeting with BT and its rivals two weeks ago to calm the growing sense of crisis surrounding the break-up of the local monopoly. During the meeting BT agreed to bring forward the timetable for opening up local exchanges.

Thus had earmarked £40m for investment in DSL and had applied for access to 300 BT exchanges. It hoped to provide users of its Demon Internet service with unlimited broadband access.

The City delivered its own verdict on the unbundling of the local loop by marking Thus shares up 20% to 74.5p.

Thus said it would offer DSL services by buying minutes from BT wholesale but added a note of caution. BT has already set up its own DSL equipment at 619 exchanges, reaching more than 40% of the households in Britain.

"If [the service] is provided to us as second-class citizens, and favours BT's in-house ISP, then we are being disadvantaged in the market," said Keith Monserrat, director of legal and regulatory affairs at Thus.

Another player, RSL Communications, pulled out of the first stage of bidding and accused the industry's regulator of failing to ensure fair play for rivals to BT. The latest to scale back was Redstone Telecom, which two weeks ago sharply reduced its investment. The announcement from Thus will be a further blow to Oftel director general David Edmunds who called a meeting with BT and its rivals two weeks ago to calm the growing sense of crisis surrounding the break-up of the local monopoly. During the meeting BT agreed to bring forward the timetable for opening up local exchanges. Thus had earmarked £40m for investment in DSL and had applied for access to 300 BT exchanges. It hoped to provide users of its Demon Internet service with unlimited broadband access. The City delivered its own verdict on the unbundling of the local loop by marking Thus shares up 20% to 74.5p. Thus said it would offer DSL services by buying minutes from BT wholesale but added a note of caution. BT has already set up its own DSL equipment at 619 exchanges, reaching more than 40% of the households in Britain. "If [the service] is provided to us as second-class citizens, and favours BT's in-house ISP, then we are being disadvantaged in the market," said Keith Monserrat, director of legal and regulatory affairs at Thus.

webTitle: Sachs begins new rating

fields.headline: Sachs begins new rating
fields.trailText: Goldman Sachs, the City investment bank, yesterday announced it had started coverage of the European technology services and listed five stocks which it classed as "core holdings".
fields.body:
Goldman Sachs, the City investment bank, yesterday announced it had started coverage of the European technology services and listed five stocks which it classed as "core holdings".

In the first research note it has produced on the sector, analysts said they were giving Dimension Data and Cap Gemini "market outperformer" ratings.

The other three to receive praised were CMG, Logica and Pixelpark which were all rated as "market performers".

The report said the five stocks had been selected on the basis of "key sector themes" during 2000.

These are said to include a Europe-wide move towards large-scale e-business, opportunities in creating software to leverage mobile communications, servicing of networks and the outsourcing of managed services.

webTitle: City briefing

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Sara Lee in Bestfoods race
fields.body:
Sara Lee in Bestfoods race

Anglo-Dutch consumer products group Unilever has shortlisted Sara Lee and Mexico's Grupo Bimbo to buy its Bestfoods Baking business, industry sources said yesterday.

The sources said Unilever was expecting to get around $1.3bn (£890m) for the business and a deal could be announced early next week.

Sources said Sara Lee has offered cash for the business. Grupo Bimbo is being backed by a financial partner. The news comes just a day after Unilever sold its dry soup brands to Campbell Soup for $925m to meet conditions set by competition regulators for approving its takeover of the Bestfoods group.

House market shows strength

Housing market figures are expected to show a boost in the coming months, following strong mortgage data released yesterday.

The Bank of England said the value of loans approved for house purchase, including other housing-related loans, in December was £10.7bn - about £300m higher than the average in the three months to November.

The number of loans approved for house purchase increased to 101,000, compared with an average of 99,000 in the three months to November.

BPB snaps up Rawlplug

BPB, the plasterboard maker, yesterday announced it was buying Rawlplug, the producer of fixing systems, from the Baxi Group for £27m.

The all-cash deal includes the Glasgow-based firm, which has annual sales of £35m, as well as associated distribution businesses in Ireland and France.

As the London markets closed for business last night shares in BPB had edged up 5.25p to 280.75p.

Beazer bows to Persimmon bid

Beazer bowed to the inevitable yesterday by accepting a £559m takeover bid from rival Persimmon to create Britain's largest housebuilder.

Persimmon last week offered a combination of cash and shares worth 195p for each Beazer share to take control of the target and its prized subsidiary Charles Church.

Beazer had been holding out for rescue from a white knight and its reluctance to immediately endorse the Persimmon deal suggests there will be few top jobs on offer in the new merged entity.

Beazer share ended the day up 3.5p at 194.5p while Persimmon was up 3p at 282.5p.

US judge clears autioneers

A US judge yesterday dismissed three anti-trust lawsuits brought against auctioneers Christie's International and Sotheby's, alleging they had fixed commission fees charged to customers in overseas auctions.

US district court Judge Lewis Kaplan ruled that US anti-trust laws did not apply to activities abroad unless it could be shown the conduct intended to have or had significant effects within the US.

The three lawsuits were brought by eight parties who bought or sold items through auctions outside the United States, principally in London.

webTitle: Open revolt in the court of 'King' Wolfensohn

fields.headline: Open revolt in the court of 'King' Wolfensohn
fields.standfirst:
Managers live in fear at World Bank

The World Bank
Anti-World Bank site
fields.trailText: Senior staff of the World Bank are in open revolt at attempts by its president, James Wolfensohn, to impose Wall Street culture on the Washington-based bureacracy, according to a leaked document seen by the Guardian.
fields.body:
Senior staff of the World Bank are in open revolt at attempts by its president, James Wolfensohn, to impose Wall Street culture on the Washington-based bureacracy, according to a leaked document seen by the Guardian.

The internal memorandum reflects the civil war inside the world's biggest development institution, with Mr Wolfensohn's management style attracting outrage from senior staff. He is accused of humiliating senior staff in front of colleagues and expressing his low opinion of workers to outside audiences.

The memo was prepared by senior staff and managers after a pre-Christmas request from Mr Wolfensohn for feedback on why staff were so demoralised. It says the Bank is in "deep trouble," with a "growing cynicism and to some extent even a sense of resignation among staff".

Mr Wolfensohn, a former Wall Street banker, has spent six years trying to rid the Bank of its reputation for being arrogant and out of touch with its developing country clients. In particular, he has forced the Bank to engage with its critics in the development community.

While he has improved the Bank's external reputation, the memo highlights weaknesses within the institution. These are: the president's management and leadership style, a lack of clear direction, problems with senior management, inadequate resources and the high degree of negativity among staff.

"Of these five issues we believe the first one is the most important which the president must deal with personally," the memo says.

"We do not think the president receives honest feedback from his senior managers. He does not welcome criticism or tolerate dissent. Managers at all levels live under fear. Many have learnt that it serves them to agree with him. He is thus isolated from reality."

A World Bank spokeswoman said the memo reflected the views of a small group of staff from one region whose jobs were under threat. "Some of the staff in that section have dissociated themselves from the memo," she added. A meeting last week with senior staff agreed that the management problems at the Bank predated Mr Wolfensohn's arrival.

The memo accuses Mr Wolfensohn of constantly discovering new projects and adding them to the Bank's overburdened mandate when the rich countries which foot its bills are calling for belt tightening. "The president puts forward many ideas, some with great zeal and vigour. These ideas, while perhaps individually worthwhile, have tended to diffuse the Bank's focus. The ideas have not been accompanied by adequate resources for implementation."

Development organisations say the Bank under Mr Wolfensohn has suffered from "mission creep" - a tendency to take over areas covered by other international institutions. Staff, according to the memo, are too afraid of the president to challenge his pet projects.

"Coming from the president these [projects] are treated as mandates. These have contributed to the Bank losing its focus," the memo says.

"People run scared and won't challenge him," said Alex Wilks of the Bretton Woods Project, a pressure group which monitors the Bank. "He's like a medieval king surrounded by fawning courtiers who won't tell him the ship is about to hit the rocks."

Contributing to the low morale among staff is the threat of redundancies. Mr Wolfensohn promised the Bank's shareholders - the industrialised countries - that he would overhaul management systems in return for a three-year funding boost. With funding set to return to 1997 levels this year, few of the reforms have been delivered, according to the memo, while Mr Wolfensohn's initiatives have added to the Bank's costs, forcing managers to consider cutting staff.

"It is difficult to have motivated staff when they live constantly under the threat of being declared redundant," says the memo. "It is even more difficult when the managers themselves feel that the redundancies are not justified on work programme grounds."

&#149 James Wolfensohn came to the World Bank from blue chip Wall Street bankers, Salomon Brothers, in 1995. Trained as a lawyer, the 67-year-old Australian had spent most of his career at high-powered private sector banks in Sydney, London and New York.

The choice of World Bank president is traditionally made by the US government and Mr Wolfensohn's familiarity with global capitalism was seen as a plus in Washington but he proved to be a closet radical.

From the start, Mr Wolfensohn was determined to shake up the Bank, whose reputation in the development community was low. He championed debt relief and declared that the Bank had to work in partnership with the development organisations and charities which were among its harshest critics.

Most importantly, he declared the Bank's work should focus on poverty reduction - a goal which the Bank seemed to have forgotten in the years when it appeared to be preoccupied with forcing developing countries to sort out their public finances.

Even Mr Wolfensohn's friends acknowledge he has a reputation for not suffering fools gladly. But yesterday some of his critics sprang to his defence, attributing the critical memo to disgruntlement among staff that the Bank might have to swallow some of the belt-tightening prescriptions it hands out.

"What Wolfensohn has done is important. He has tried to focus on poverty reduction and greater equity," said Kevin Watkins, of Oxfam. "That has involved structural change at the Bank and he has clearly not taken the mass of staff with him."

webTitle: Simon Hoggart's diary of parliamentary debates

fields.headline: A disgrace beyond imagining unites the house
fields.standfirst: Special report: Alder Hey hospital
fields.trailText: For once, even Liam Fox did not try to blame the horrors of Alder Hey on the government, although he might have been tempted to try. Instead the house was suffused by a sombre, non-combative mood. On these rare occasions when the whole Commons is anguished, appalled and united, it is almost always wrong.
fields.body:
For once, even Liam Fox did not try to blame the horrors of Alder Hey on the government, although he might have been tempted to try. Instead the house was suffused by a sombre, non-combative mood. On these rare occasions when the whole Commons is anguished, appalled and united, it is almost always wrong.

This time there was nothing to be wrong about. What had happened was a disgrace beyond imagining. All a minister can do is to announce inquiries, reviews, new laws and special commissions. Alan Milburn, the health secretary, duly did those things.

His statement - and this is a measure of the pity and the horror - even sounded as if he had written it himself, rather than, in the normal way, tossed it over for civil servants to run through their word processors. It was written in real words, with real emotion, in sentences which had not been surgically detached from their meaning.

"According to the report, in addition to over 2,000 children's hearts, there are large numbers of brain parts, eyes taken from foetuses, over 1,500 still births, and perhaps most disturbingly of all, a number of children's heads and bodies."

Later, "their child's body had been stripped of their entire internal organs, leaving the body as a shell." People had got their infants back on an odious installment plan: "Some parents faced up to four funerals as different organs were returned to them at different times. The pain caused is unforgiveable."

We do not often hear demotic English in parliament, so the words made the goose pimples almost painful, and the chill in the pit of the stomach even worse.

In a horrible way, such a statement must be a relief to Mr Milburn. For just a day he could concentrate on the unspeakable Professor van Velzen. (Frankenstein was building a monster; Burke and Hare wanted the money - providing, if not an excuse, at least an explanation.)

So Mr Milburn could for 24 hours forget the more intractable problems elsewhere: the shortage of nurses and doctors, the disastrous administration, the burning anger of people forced to wait for vital operations for which they have already paid through a lifetime's taxes.

In need of relief I went off to hear the committee of privileges consider the election of the Speaker. This, you may remember, was held in autumn and lasted forever. In the view of some of us, it did something even worse - it produced the wrong result.

The man blamed at the time was Sir Edward Heath who, as father of the house, chaired the session.

But Sir Edward is never wrong, as he so often takes the chance to point out to us. He is marvellous. Eighty-four years old, and as self-satisfied as ever!

He had been right at the time, he said. Even Tony Benn realised he was right. The only people who were wrong were the members of the Conservative party.

Sir Edward does not like the Conservative Party. He never cared for them much. But when they dismissed him as leader his disaffection turned to outright hatred.

"I'm afraid that, on our side - well, my party's side - they thought it was their turn.

"But it is really not rational for a party which has been out of power for 18 years, and has had a speaker for five years, to then replace her from a party which has only a handful of seats!" The last said with scowling and satisfying contempt for the Tories.

Later the former speaker Lord Weatherill said that the new man's press coverage had been "disgraceful". We sketchwriters, who had given Michael Martin the disgraceful coverage complained of, tried to look shifty and evasive. But inside we felt a fierce and glowing pride.

webTitle: Extent of organ stockpile at Alder Hey

fields.headline: The growth of a gruesome stockpile
fields.standfirst:
QC recommends that pathologist who stored body parts should never be allowed to practise again

Special report: Alder Hey hospital
fields.trailText: QC recommends that pathologist who stored body parts should never be allowed to practise again.
fields.body:
Two thousand dirty and dust-covered containers in a laboratory in Liverpool contained the gruesome secrets of Professor Dick van Velzen's seven-year stockpile of body parts. Most of the containers, discovered in a basement, contained multiple organs and pieces of tissue collected from approximately 850 postmortem examinations. Some of the organs were poorly preserved as adequate levels of formalin had not been maintained.

There was also a collection of 445 foetuses retained by Prof van Velzen between 1989-1991 and a total of 1,564 foetuses dating back to the 1950s. Nearly half of a stockpile of 188 eyes which had been kept from foetuses had not been used for research.

"There can be no doubt that Prof van Velzen failed parents and doctors at every level. Organs were retained so that parents unwittingly buried 'shells' of their children, causing immense distress when discovered," concluded the independent inquiry by Michael Redfern QC.

"The failure to perform histology [the study of organic tissue] means that the research undertaken by Prof van Velzen's unit is fundamentally flawed. His failure to report promptly, comprehensively and honestly means that parents were given inaccurate and incomplete information about the deaths of their loved ones.

"We have no hestitation whatsoever in recommending that Prof van Velzen's activities be investigated by the General Medical Council as a matter of urgency. In our opinion, he should not be allowed to practice again in the United Kingdom or anywhere else."

The inquiry found that as well as thousands of organs, there were a number of children's heads and whole bodies stored at the hospital, dating back to the 1960s and early 1970s. There were 13 heads or parts of heads from children aged between a few days old and 11 years old, dating back to the 1960s, and 22 heads from premature or full-term foetuses.

Two containers were found with the full body of a child in one and the head of an 11-year-old boy in another. The collection dates back to dental cleft palate research, before Prof van Velzen's time.

The Redfern inquiry discovered that Professor van Velzen had lied to the interview committee and within a week of taking up his post in 1988 he ordered that there would be no more disposal of human material at Alder Hey.

Hospital technical staff realised that his clinical practice in the removal and retention of organs was unlike anything they had seen before. Until then, pathologists had retained sections only of the relevant organs and returned everything to the body, except heart/lungs and possibly brain.

In September 1988, the professor stopped histological analysis of organs as part of his routine clinical analysis. Instead, he prepared a lengthy and detailed report based upon the macroscopical (naked eye) findings.

His appointment to the new Liverpool health authority chair of foetal and infant pathology, a joint position which involved working at Liverpool University, was against a background of near unanimous concern for the resources available. The premises and equipment were inadequate, the university authorities ignored convincing advice and informed warnings.

Prof van Velzen was guilty of falsifying postmortem examinations and causing an unnecessary excessive, illegal and unethical build-up of organs following postmortem examination, ostensibly for research, but with no likelihood that the bulk of organs stored in containers would never be used for research.

He delayed reporting on postmortem examination and histology to such an extent that in at least one case a second child was born to a family with the same genetic condition as an earlier child.

In several cases, he ignored parents' wishes and did not carry out limited postmortem examinations as had been specified on consent forms. "There can be no justification for Prof van Velzen's actions in these cases. His behaviour exemplified his lack of respect for the parents and their children."

Research became the main activity of the professor, with his main work into the consequences of intra-uterine growth retardation. He used the research tool of stereology, which required whole organs.

By spring 1991 at the latest, the executive board at Alder Hey knew that postmortem histology was not being carried out by Prof van Velzen. By autumn 1992 at the latest, the university knew that he was not fulfilling his contract for clinical sessions.

The report found that Hilary Rowland, the former chief executive at Alder Hey, knew of his unreliable behaviour; his reputation as a maverick was well-established, according to the report.

By 1994, Prof van Velzen was doing little or no clinical work. When he left Alder Hey the following year, there was a £68,000 deficit.

Alder Hey hospital was criticised for ignoring the warnings and failing to supervise him. Both the hospital and the university failed to properly resource the chair of foetal and infant pathology from the outset. They failed to monitor and follow up complaints about delays in providing postmortem and histology reports and they permitted Prof van Velzen to abdicate his clinical duties and responsibilities.

"Alder Hey and the university missed numerous opportunities to discipline Professor van Velzen for justifiable reasons from 1989 onwards," said the report.

Liverpool University was singled out for criticism for never accepting its responsibility and leaving Alder Hey to make a series of mistakes.

The university was aware of the existence of a collection of 146 cerebella in late 1999, gathered from brains retained by Prof van Velzen.

But it was not until August 2000, that the hospital released the news of the cerebella collection. A group of 58 parents, who had already held second funerals, were told that there were cerebella yet to be buried. Yet again the parents were "dismayed, disillusioned and distressed."

"The university has never accepted its responsibility in the matter and has left Alder Hey to make a sequence of mistakes," it said. "Alder Hey have made four or five separate attempts to provide parents with accurate information relating to organ retention, not learning from and compounding mistakes made in each previous attempt."

The inadequate handling strategy adopted by Alder Hey "merely served to aggravate the situation to the extent that some families have faced numerous funerals as a result of organs being returned to them on a piecemeal basis. There are still organs awaiting repatriation."

Wrongly delegated

The former Liverpool coroner, Roy Barter, was criticised for wrongly considering that the decision to carry out a coroner's postmortem was a simple administrative decision, which he wrongly delegated to the coroner's officer. The inquiry found that the decision is one to be taken personally by the coroner.

"Mr Barter had no proper system for specifying the cases in which histology was required or identifying the organs or tissue to be preserved for histological examination by the pathologists."

On several occasions, sudden infant death syndrome was accepted by him as the proper cause of death without histological examination being carried out, when he knew or should have known that the syndrome was a diagnosis of exclusion.

"He should have known that the reports he received from Prof van Velzen were preliminary reports without histology," the inquiry found.

The inquiry discovered that the widespread practice of organ retention without consent arose from a sense of paternalism on the part of the medical profession which served to conceal retention in the supposed best interest of the parents.

The report recommends that the Royal College of Pathologists instruct all practising histopathologists that they should not retain samples and organs beyond those needed to establish the cause of death, unless there is also written consent properly obtained under the Human Tissue Act 1961.

The act should be amended to impose a criminal penalty for breach of its provisions.

"Fully informed consent means that a person must have all the information required to make a final decision. It is not enough for clinicians to tell the next of kin that they would like to examine the body after death and this might involve taking some tissue. The next of kin need to understand what is involved in a postmortem examination, including a description of whole body systems, removal of the brain and the steps necessary to remove various organs, no matter how distasteful the giving of this information might be to the clinician concerned."

The new approach to consent should also involve a clinician, bereavement adviser and the next of kin.

It concludes: "The ultimate control should be a proper system of fully informed consent. The evidence indicates that many parents will readily consent to retention for these purposes, if sensitively approached with openness, honesty and transparency."
