fields.bodyText: Two thousand dirty and dust-covered containers in a laboratory in Liverpool contained the gruesome secrets of Professor Dick van Velzen's seven-year stockpile of body parts. Most of the containers, discovered in a basement, contained multiple organs and pieces of tissue collected from approximately 850 postmortem examinations. Some of the organs were poorly preserved as adequate levels of formalin had not been maintained. There was also a collection of 445 foetuses retained by Prof van Velzen between 1989-1991 and a total of 1,564 foetuses dating back to the 1950s. Nearly half of a stockpile of 188 eyes which had been kept from foetuses had not been used for research. "There can be no doubt that Prof van Velzen failed parents and doctors at every level. Organs were retained so that parents unwittingly buried 'shells' of their children, causing immense distress when discovered," concluded the independent inquiry by Michael Redfern QC. "The failure to perform histology [the study of organic tissue] means that the research undertaken by Prof van Velzen's unit is fundamentally flawed. His failure to report promptly, comprehensively and honestly means that parents were given inaccurate and incomplete information about the deaths of their loved ones. "We have no hestitation whatsoever in recommending that Prof van Velzen's activities be investigated by the General Medical Council as a matter of urgency. In our opinion, he should not be allowed to practice again in the United Kingdom or anywhere else." The inquiry found that as well as thousands of organs, there were a number of children's heads and whole bodies stored at the hospital, dating back to the 1960s and early 1970s. There were 13 heads or parts of heads from children aged between a few days old and 11 years old, dating back to the 1960s, and 22 heads from premature or full-term foetuses. Two containers were found with the full body of a child in one and the head of an 11-year-old boy in another. The collection dates back to dental cleft palate research, before Prof van Velzen's time. The Redfern inquiry discovered that Professor van Velzen had lied to the interview committee and within a week of taking up his post in 1988 he ordered that there would be no more disposal of human material at Alder Hey. Hospital technical staff realised that his clinical practice in the removal and retention of organs was unlike anything they had seen before. Until then, pathologists had retained sections only of the relevant organs and returned everything to the body, except heart/lungs and possibly brain. In September 1988, the professor stopped histological analysis of organs as part of his routine clinical analysis. Instead, he prepared a lengthy and detailed report based upon the macroscopical (naked eye) findings. His appointment to the new Liverpool health authority chair of foetal and infant pathology, a joint position which involved working at Liverpool University, was against a background of near unanimous concern for the resources available. The premises and equipment were inadequate, the university authorities ignored convincing advice and informed warnings. Prof van Velzen was guilty of falsifying postmortem examinations and causing an unnecessary excessive, illegal and unethical build-up of organs following postmortem examination, ostensibly for research, but with no likelihood that the bulk of organs stored in containers would never be used for research. He delayed reporting on postmortem examination and histology to such an extent that in at least one case a second child was born to a family with the same genetic condition as an earlier child. In several cases, he ignored parents' wishes and did not carry out limited postmortem examinations as had been specified on consent forms. "There can be no justification for Prof van Velzen's actions in these cases. His behaviour exemplified his lack of respect for the parents and their children." Research became the main activity of the professor, with his main work into the consequences of intra-uterine growth retardation. He used the research tool of stereology, which required whole organs. By spring 1991 at the latest, the executive board at Alder Hey knew that postmortem histology was not being carried out by Prof van Velzen. By autumn 1992 at the latest, the university knew that he was not fulfilling his contract for clinical sessions. The report found that Hilary Rowland, the former chief executive at Alder Hey, knew of his unreliable behaviour; his reputation as a maverick was well-established, according to the report. By 1994, Prof van Velzen was doing little or no clinical work. When he left Alder Hey the following year, there was a £68,000 deficit. Alder Hey hospital was criticised for ignoring the warnings and failing to supervise him. Both the hospital and the university failed to properly resource the chair of foetal and infant pathology from the outset. They failed to monitor and follow up complaints about delays in providing postmortem and histology reports and they permitted Prof van Velzen to abdicate his clinical duties and responsibilities. "Alder Hey and the university missed numerous opportunities to discipline Professor van Velzen for justifiable reasons from 1989 onwards," said the report. Liverpool University was singled out for criticism for never accepting its responsibility and leaving Alder Hey to make a series of mistakes. The university was aware of the existence of a collection of 146 cerebella in late 1999, gathered from brains retained by Prof van Velzen. But it was not until August 2000, that the hospital released the news of the cerebella collection. A group of 58 parents, who had already held second funerals, were told that there were cerebella yet to be buried. Yet again the parents were "dismayed, disillusioned and distressed." "The university has never accepted its responsibility in the matter and has left Alder Hey to make a sequence of mistakes," it said. "Alder Hey have made four or five separate attempts to provide parents with accurate information relating to organ retention, not learning from and compounding mistakes made in each previous attempt." The inadequate handling strategy adopted by Alder Hey "merely served to aggravate the situation to the extent that some families have faced numerous funerals as a result of organs being returned to them on a piecemeal basis. There are still organs awaiting repatriation." Wrongly delegated The former Liverpool coroner, Roy Barter, was criticised for wrongly considering that the decision to carry out a coroner's postmortem was a simple administrative decision, which he wrongly delegated to the coroner's officer. The inquiry found that the decision is one to be taken personally by the coroner. "Mr Barter had no proper system for specifying the cases in which histology was required or identifying the organs or tissue to be preserved for histological examination by the pathologists." On several occasions, sudden infant death syndrome was accepted by him as the proper cause of death without histological examination being carried out, when he knew or should have known that the syndrome was a diagnosis of exclusion. "He should have known that the reports he received from Prof van Velzen were preliminary reports without histology," the inquiry found. The inquiry discovered that the widespread practice of organ retention without consent arose from a sense of paternalism on the part of the medical profession which served to conceal retention in the supposed best interest of the parents. The report recommends that the Royal College of Pathologists instruct all practising histopathologists that they should not retain samples and organs beyond those needed to establish the cause of death, unless there is also written consent properly obtained under the Human Tissue Act 1961. The act should be amended to impose a criminal penalty for breach of its provisions. "Fully informed consent means that a person must have all the information required to make a final decision. It is not enough for clinicians to tell the next of kin that they would like to examine the body after death and this might involve taking some tissue. The next of kin need to understand what is involved in a postmortem examination, including a description of whole body systems, removal of the brain and the steps necessary to remove various organs, no matter how distasteful the giving of this information might be to the clinician concerned." The new approach to consent should also involve a clinician, bereavement adviser and the next of kin. It concludes: "The ultimate control should be a proper system of fully informed consent. The evidence indicates that many parents will readily consent to retention for these purposes, if sensitively approached with openness, honesty and transparency." webTitle: Mandelson calls in lawyers for passports row inquiry

fields.headline: Mandelson calls in lawyers for passports row inquiry
fields.standfirst: Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson yesterday raised the stakes in his increasingly tense relationship with Downing Street by calling in a firm of lawyers to represent him in the Hammond inquiry into the events that triggered his resignation last week.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson yesterday raised the stakes in his increasingly tense relationship with Downing Street by calling in a firm of lawyers to represent him in the Hammond inquiry into the events that triggered his resignation last week.

The ousted Northern Ireland secretary has asked a London West End firm of solicitors, Goldsmiths, to trawl through all paperwork relating to his role in the applications for British citizenship by the Indian-born Hinduja brothers and to ensure the inquiry is "fair and objective".

The move reflects the gulf of mistrust that has opened up between No 10 and the prime minister's former closest confidant, who has not ruled out publishing a book after the general election about his experiences at the heart of power.

Mr Mandelson, who is abroad, has already had five book contract offers - including one with a £500,000 advance - since he was forced out of government last week. But he would "not want to do anything which could harm the party before the election", an ally said last night.

The inquiry by Sir Anthony Hammond QC was set up by Mr Blair on the day of Mr Mandelson's resignation, to review whether the applications by SP and GP Hinduja were "properly dealt with in all respects".

Questions have been raised about Sir Anthony's links to the Home Office - he worked there for 24 years. The department is at the centre of the passports-for-cash controversy and the home secretary, Jack Straw, has already said he believes Mr Mandelson told an "untruth" about the affair.

The Hartlepool MP's decision to call on legal backup follows a press and broadcasting campaign in support of him by his friend the novelist Robert Harris, which focused on the part played in his departure by Mr Blair's official spokesman, Alastair Campbell.

The former minister is understood to be returning to Britain by the weekend and is expected to attempt a media counter-offensive of his own.

Both Mr Blair and Mr Campbell have made clear they want to close down the controversy as quickly as possible and they are likely to try to convince their longtime friend to wait for the outcome of the inquiry.

Mr Mandelson's lawyer, senior partner Lee Goldsmith - who was yesterday instructed to write to all newspaper editors warning them against accusing the former minister of lying - will be seeking access to all government papers relating to his client's involvement in the Hinduja brothers' passport applications.

webTitle: What organs and tissue are used for

fields.headline: What organs and tissue are used for
fields.standfirst: Special report: Alder Hey hospital
fields.trailText: Corneas, kidneys, hearts, lungs, livers and bone marrow can all be used for transplant when removed from the body with consent.
fields.body:
Corneas, kidneys, hearts, lungs, livers and bone marrow can all be used for transplant when removed from the body with consent. Donated skin is used in treatment of burns. In the US, a lively market has grown up for human skin for use in plastic surgery and for a wide range of products such as screws, dowels and spacers carved out of human bone and used in spinal surgery.

Brain

Much of our knowledge of the brain comes from studies of brains removed from the dead, since it is such an inaccessible organ in life. The existence of new variant CJD could not have been established without studying post mortem brain tissue.

Eye

Very rarely removed in postmortem examinations unless foul play suspected. Not generally used for research.

Tonsils

Source of anti-bodies used to test patients' immune system.

Bonemarrow

Used in study of immune system and leukaemia.

Lungs

Lungs removed from living patients prior to heart-lung transplants can be helpful in understanding of lung disease.

Thymus gland

Used to save transplant patients.

Heart

Used in research to minimise death rate in heart surgery, learn more about heart abnormalities, develop new surgical techniques, and in training. Study of heart collection at Alder Hey thought to have saved lives of 1,600 children by drastically cutting risk of surgery early in life.

Liver

Research into complex blood supply to liver has sharply lowered risk of liver damage in surgery against cancer. Liver cells removed from living patients now being used as potential alternative to animal testing of new drugs.

Kidney

Tissue being used to test new kidney cancer diagnosis technique.

Colon

Used in research into inflammatory bowel disease.

Pancreas

Cells removed from living patients being used in promising new anti-diabetes treatment.

Ovary

Used to study hormone production.

Foetus

Research into diseases of gut, treatment of neuroblastoma and general foetal development. Foetal tissue being used as treatment for Parkinson's disease.

Thigh muscle

Tissues from quadriceps used for research into reprogramming muscles.

webTitle: Parents demand belated apology

fields.headline: Parents demand belated apology
fields.standfirst:
Report still leaves too many unanswered questions

Special report: Alder Hey hospital
fields.trailText: The parents of children whose organs were removed without their knowledge or permission last night demanded an apology from Alder Hey hospital and Liverpool University, and called for further investigations into the actions of Professor Dick van Velzen.
fields.body:
The parents of children whose organs were removed without their knowledge or permission last night demanded an apology from Alder Hey hospital and Liverpool University, and called for further investigations into the actions of Professor Dick van Velzen.

Ed Bradley, chairman of the families' support group, Pity II, said: "The last 17 months have been harrowing and have had a devastating effect on all the families involved. Almost on a weekly basis, fresh revelations have been coming out not only from Alder Hey but also from the University of Liverpool.

"The fact is that the parents have had to deal not only with the removal and retention of their child's organs but the disgraceful manner in which they have been treated by the hospital and the university since the information came to light."

Mr Bradley, whose daughter Niamh's heart, lungs and brain were kept at Alder Hey, added: "To date, Alder Hey and the university have failed to apologise for the removal and retention of organs without consent, a point which has been highlighted in the Redfern report today. We are dismayed by the prevalence of paternalism, that doctor knows best. We want a full and humble apology from both hospital and university."

He said families needed more time to consider the report, which was delivered to five members of the support group at 9.30am yesterday. They were locked in a room in a Liverpool hotel to read it without access to telephones. A second group of about 30 parents was handed the report at noon.

At a press conference, parents welcomed the announcement that the conduct of Prof van Velzen had been referred to the director of public prosecutions.

But they called for further investigations into what happened at the hospital before and after his time there.

Mr Bradley said: "We as parents have been betrayed not only by the clinicians but also by the management past and present."

Paula O'Leary, whose son Andrew had organs removed after his death at the hospital in 1981, said. "My criticism is that it just doesn't go far enough, in terms of time and what happened.

"We need a public inquiry. This needs to be just the beginning. This report is a stepping stone. A lot of parents are not happy. "

Another member of the pressure group, John O'Hare, said the report had focused almost entirely on Prof van Velzen but he insisted others had been equally at fault.

"His practices were unacceptable and unusual but there were more people who were just as guilty," he said.

Another parent, Jan Robinson, called for action to be taken against the former Liverpool coroner Roy Barter, who was heavily criticised in the report. "He has brought disgrace on his office and some sort of action should be taken," she said. "He ought to have his pension taken away."

Mary Allen, whose daughter Kathleen died at Alder Hey in 1991, attacked the government for heaping blame on Prof van Velzen.

"The government has simply used van Velzen as a scapegoat, but that man was not a law unto himself," she said. "The government themselves are to blame for all of this, they let it go on.

"Van Velzen is evil, he went along with what was passed down to him, but he was not the only one to blame, this was going on 10, 20, 30 years before he was at Alder Hey.

"They took 47 of my daughter's body parts and I have still not got them all back and I want justice for that."

Cindy Bewes, whose stillborn twins were secretly stored in a jar at Alder Hey, broke down as she spoke about the report. "I am horrified, just horrified. I knew it was going to be hard but I never imagined this.

"I only recently found out that Alder Hey had my daughters in jars but now I have been told that their heads may not even be with their bodies. No-one today has answered my questions."

Geoff and Lisa Harris, from Glossop, Derbyshire, lost their day old son James in 1990. The couple criticised the Redfern report for failing to answer enough questions.

"We are very disappointed with the report, it did not look at all the evidence and it did not cover a wide enough timeframe. There is not enough information for people whose children died after van Velzen left.

"We have not had the answers we wanted here today and I think the majority of people will be very unhappy."

The regional director of public health, Professor John Ashton, said: "I am very shocked by today's report because of the extent of what went on.

"What the parents have been through is outrageous and totally despicable. Van Velzen behaved in an extremely criminal way, but what this report also reveals is that within medicine there is a culture of arrogance."

webTitle: Inquiry team deeply affected by evidence

fields.headline: Inquiry team deeply affected by evidence
fields.standfirst:
Management attitudes criticised

Special report: Alder Hey hospital
fields.trailText: The man who led the organ retention inquiry said last night that he and his colleagues had been deeply and personally affected by the evidence given to them by parents.
fields.body:
The man who led the organ retention inquiry said last night that he and his colleagues had been deeply and personally affected by the evidence given to them by parents.

Michael Redfern QC said the parents would have drawn "deep comfort" from the fact that the report had been accepted in its entirety by the health secretary, Alan Milburn, and that radical action had already been announced to implement all the recommendations.

He said the doctors involved had adopted a policy of paternalism, restricting the freedom and responsibility of parents to object or consent to organ retention in their supposed best interest.

Mr Redfern added: "A prevalent attitude has been that following death it is far better to carry out research for the common good than to bury or cremate organs, thereby wasting potential research material. This completely misses the point of our inquiry. It is no defence that the clinicians were following similar practices elsewhere. That would be an explanation but not an excuse. Since 1961, the law has required the equivalent of fully informed consent and nothing less."

Mr Redfern described the "inadequate management systems, record-keeping and research records" at Alder Hey and the University of Liverpool.

"Many opportunities were missed to control Professor [Dick] van Velzen's excesses and there was delay in addressing and dealing with the accumulation of organs," he said.

"Prof van Velzen wrongly diverted NHS resources to his university research work into sudden infant death syndrome. Nevertheless, the published research work was flawed because his diagnosis of the syndrome was unreliable.

"He had not first carried out microscopical examination to exclude other conditions. Throughout the van Velzen years, in particular, there is little evidence of the essential mutual trust which must exist between a hospital and a university."

Mr Redfern said a high rate of postmortem examinations should be encouraged. Research was vital in changing methods of investigation and treatment of infants and children.

He said the evidence showed that a majority of parents would have consented to some organ retention had they been approached with openness and transparency.

Mr Redfern said Prof van Velzen admitted wrongdoing to the inquiry board.

The QC said: "We took over three days of evidence from van Velzen. On the final day he came in - it was a long day - and when he left he left having made admissions as to those matters that we have found in the report.

"To that extent he was honourable. But his procedures were totally unacceptable and he accepted that."

Mr Redfern would not attribute blame to any other named persons, adding: "Prof van Velzen was the only person who explicitly admitted wrongdoing. To that extent we could say he was guilty."

webTitle: 5,000 jobs to go in steel closures

fields.headline: 5,000 jobs to go in steel closures
fields.standfirst: Wales braced for closure of plant as manufacturer rejects deals
fields.trailText: South Wales is bracing itself for a wave of steel plant closures within the next 48 hours which will rip the heart out of the country's manufacturing base and may lead to up to 5,000 job losses.
fields.body:
South Wales is bracing itself for a wave of steel plant closures within the next 48 hours which will rip the heart out of the country's manufacturing base and may lead to up to 5,000 job losses.

A last desperate round of meetings in Brussels and London yesterday failed to move Corus, the privatised steelmakers who claim that restructuring is necessary due to the pound's strength against the Euro and the loss of traditional British manufacturing markets.

The company employs 3,500 workers at Port Talbot, 3,000 at Llanwern in Newport and 3,500 elsewhere in Britain. The Newport steel rolling plant has been threatened with closure and there are likely to be job losses across the rest of the company.

Any closure would have a vast political and economic impact. Labour fears it could lead to a surge in support for Plaid Cymru which is making inroads in south Wales.

Labour MPs and ministers are furious at the company's attitude - and the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, has already given notice that Corus will be accused of short-termism if it cuts production in Britain just as the crippling gap between the euro and sterling is lessening.

Mr Byers' avenues of action are limited as strict European Union rules ban direct state aid to steelmaking firms.

Last night there were calls for the resignation of the Corus chairman, Sir Brian Moffat, who has met Labour MPs and the prime minister this week.

After the stormy meeting, the MP for Rotherham, Denis MacShane, who is chairman of the 70-strong group of steel MPs, said: "I think the scales may have dropped from the eyes of some of our political leaders as they see the extent to which Corus and Sir Brian Moffat have arrogantly refused to share information or consult with the nation's elected leaders and representatives on the fate of UK steel communities".

In Brussels, the European commission promised to fast track the provision of aid to south Wales as a delegation of Labour MEPs led by Eluned Morgan failed to persuade the Corus European management to reconsider their plans.

She claimed the Corus workforce in Holland had more information on the plight of UK steel plants than British workforce and said that the lack of consultation should force the government to rethink its refusal to back the EU directive on worker consultation.

Even the Department for Education and Employment, which wants to prepare retraining packages, has been frustrated by the company's refusal to give an age profile of the workforce.

In a last-ditch effort to persuade the company to reprieve the Llanwern plant, the Welsh first minister, Rhodri Morgan, had warned Corus that it would be made to pay for clearing up the site after closure, even though the act of parliament which gives this right is not yet in force in Wales.

Lord Sainsbury confirmed to peers yesterday that the company told the Welsh assembly that it was not interested in its rescue package.

Downing Street yesterday hinted that Brussels would allow state aid to the steel firm, in the form of research and development grants, which Labour is willing to provide.

"We believe there is a future for a viable steel industry in this country," a spokesman said. "The government's job is to talk to industry. We have made it clear that we stand ready to do whatever we can. But no one underestimates the difficulties."

webTitle: Survey reveals extent of storage of human tissue

fields.headline: Survey reveals extent of storage of human tissue
fields.standfirst:
Chief medical officer demands overhaul of autopsy procedure

Special report: Alder Hey hospital
fields.trailText: At least 105,000 organs and body parts, including stillborn babies and foetuses, were being held in hospitals and medical schools around Britain at the end of 1999, according to a census carried out by the chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, and published yesterday.
fields.body:
At least 105,000 organs and body parts, including stillborn babies and foetuses, were being held in hospitals and medical schools around Britain at the end of 1999, according to a census carried out by the chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, and published yesterday.

An independent commission was announced by the health secretary, Alan Milburn, in the Commons to trace and catalogue all the organs and to help families get them back, if they wanted them returned. But the initial focus will be on the return of organs, body parts and foetuses that were taken by pathologists and stored after 1970.

Scientists have argued that the material stored in museums and archives before that date is of great national and international medical value. The retained organs commission will advise the government on how to deal with these collections.

The CMO, Professor Donaldson says the census total is not an exact figure. It is probably higher. Hospitals have not kept accurate records of the material they hold - a practice that his report says must change. Some hospitals at first told him it was impossible to calculate what they had, but eventually provided an estimate.

As well as the organs, body parts and foetuses, there is a vast amount of human tissue; 480,600 samples which are held in museums and archives. At the moment, there are no plans for their return.

From the post-1970 period, there are about 54,300 organs, body parts, stillbirths and foetuses held by pathology services, but the biggest concentrations are in a relatively few places. Twenty-five institutions hold more than 500 organs each, which amount to 88% of the total.

Although the original outcry resulted from the retention of hearts, they made up only a sixth of the organs taken, while brains accounted for half. One reason for the widespread retention of brains may be that for a brain to be examined it has to be "fixed" with chemicals, which takes four to six weeks, by which time the funeral has taken place.

More organs were retained from postmortem examinations of adults (17,800) than of children or babies (9,800). There were 2,900 stillbirths or pre-viable foetuses.

The report reveals that the terms of the law were regularly breached. Organs were removed and kept for research during coroner's autopsies, even though the law says they may be removed only to estab lish the cause of death, and should then be returned to relatives.

The CMO says the coroner's rules will be overhauled. Mr Milburn announced in the Commons that the home secretary had set in train a review of the coroner's system, to see what lessons could be learned.

But even where consent forms were signed by parents or relatives for hospital autopsies - examinations requested by doctors so they can find out more about why patients died - the CMO's report makes it clear they had no idea what they were agreeing to.

While he says there are important gains to be made in medical science from autopsies and the study of organs and tissues removed, Prof Donaldson highlights a gulf between the pathologist and the bereaved relative. "There has been no adequate recognition or acknowledgement on the part of the majority of NHS staff or many doctors, of the feelings people have on the recent loss of a family member, particularly a child, and the extent to which they feel the need to protect a child even after that child's death," he writes.

There were fundamental problems with the consent forms, which followed a similar pattern in most hospitals, suggesting that they were once standardised within the NHS although nobody can remember when or how. The forms do not ask for permission, but ask relatives to sign to say they "do not object" to autopsies.

If they sign, they say they understand examination "may involve retention of tissue for laboratory study" and that tissue may also be removed "for the treatment of other patients and for medical education and research". None of this led parents to suspect that their children's hearts, brains or other organs might be removed and stored in jars.

The CMO recommends a standardised consent form to be used throughout the NHS, which will lay out clearly the different organs and tissues that might be wanted for research purposes and give relatives the option to agree to the removal of some, but not others. Many people, for instance, do not mind the use of internal organs but cannot countenance the removal of eyes.

Relatives will be able to limit the use to which the organs can be put and will be able to specify what they want to happen to organs or tissue that are no longer needed by doctors. Prof Donaldson says the public might find it particularly shocking that the majority of organs which are no longer needed are incinerated as clinical waste. He adds that cultural beliefs and religious practices also need to be respected.

The law will be changed to require doctors to obtain this full consent and to make it an offence to proceed with an autopsy without it, but the measures will be brought in first for consent involving children. Prof Donaldson says it is simple to work out who has the right to give consent for a child, but it is more complicated in the case of an adult.

In the interests of the feelings of relatives and the needs of medical science, he wants a fundamental change in the treatment of relatives who have just seen loved ones die. "People were descended on within minutes of the death. That is insensitive and it has to stop," he says.

All hospitals will have to employ bereavement counsellors who can help relatives through each stage, from being told of a death, to a full understanding of the consent form for an autopsy. The counsellor would also ensure they had time to think it over.

But the whole thinking about autopsies had to change, too. "At the moment the language in the law is all about taking, retention and making sure people don't object," Prof Donaldson says. "It isn't about asking people. It isn't about seeking permission. It isn't about donation.

"It should be more in the territory of a relationship based on a gift for which we feel and express gratitude."

The CMO also proposes that the parents of a child whose heart is taken for research should put together "a scrapbook or life book", which would be stored with the organ. It would be shown to medical students so that they "realise that this was a real person".

webTitle: Voters 'turned off' by Mandelson row

fields.headline: Voters 'turned off' by Mandelson row
fields.standfirst:
Blair tells cabinet Tories will exploit 'strategy of cynicism'

Peter Mandelson

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Education secretary David Blunkett acknowledged yesterday that Peter Mandelson's resignation had damaged Labour, by increasing cynicism and by potentially lowering voter turn-out, one of the biggest threats to a second Labour term.
fields.body:
Education secretary David Blunkett acknowledged yesterday that Peter Mandelson's resignation had damaged Labour, by increasing cynicism and by potentially lowering voter turn-out, one of the biggest threats to a second Labour term.

Mr Blunkett was speaking after a special two hour cabinet meeting at which Tony Blair urged his colleagues to harden the policy differences between Labour and the Conservatives.

The government is expected to announce initiatives on persistent criminals and secondary schools in the next few weeks.

The warning about voter cynicism was made on the PM programme after a poll emerged suggesting that voters regarded Labour as more sleazy than the Conservatives.

The NOP poll, commissioned by the Powerhouse programme, found that 49% of respondents thought Labour "give the impression of being very sleazy and disreputable", compared with only 19% responding to the same question before the last election. The Tories had improved their image. In 1997 63% of the public had thought they appeared sleazy, compared to 47% now.

Mr Blunkett said the poll was very worrying.

"I think that 'a plague on all your houses', or "all politicians are in it for themselves', is very dangerous for our democracy, and it plays into the hands of our opponents who would like to see a very low turn-out," said Mr Blunkett.

"If you take any opinion poll, few people believe politicians, and the more that corrosive feeling gets across, the less people switch into and take notice of the major events around them."

Mr Blunkett said he hoped voters would realise in time that the Mandelson controversy was not about a politi cian pocketing cash for himself. He admitted: "We have had almost almost a week of massive publicity, headlines, speculation oozing out of every media outlet about whether a conversation took place about someone's nationality application."

Labour strategists recognise that William Hague is trying to move closer to Labour in the areas where Labour is most popular, including public spending and a rejection of basic income tax cuts.

The chancellor, Gordon Brown, drawing in part on lessons from the US, told yesterday's meeting that Labour had to make sure that voters understood that the successful economy and falling mortages resulted directly from decisions taken by the government. Labour has tried to encapture the argument in the slogan: Choice, not chance.

Yesterday's cabinet heard that Labour was still ahead on every big issue, even Europe. It had also managed to recover ground lost with older voters, largely due to the pre-budget report promising big rises in the basic pension.

However, Lady Jay, the women's minister, told the meeting that younger women voters had deserted Labour more than any other single group since the election. Women voters had been especially alienated by the government's handling of the petrol crisis last autumn. Ministers briefly discussed extra help for child care and a package of family friendly policies.

Mr Blair told ministers during a lengthy speech that "the Tories will try to close down policy debate as much as possible, and hide behind a strategy of cynicism".

Cabinet members do not believe the Mandelson affair in itself will lose Labour votes in the long term, but they believe it may add to the impression of an arrogant government that is fundamentally little different from the Conservatives.

Labour officials hope to dispel the image of arrogance though a "thank you" poster campaign.

In an effort to galvanise a largely apathetic party, John Prescott will start a one month "get ready" tour of party workers, starting in Huddersfield on Wednesday.

The deputy prime minister will be accompanied by a jazz band, comedians and soap celebrities. He said yesterday: "There is no room for complacency. Our biggest enemy, apart from the Tories, is apathy; and in the election, whenever it comes, we must fight to stop the Conservatives getting in through the back door."

webTitle: Damning verdict on doctor who practised deception

fields.headline: Damning verdict on doctor who practised deception
fields.standfirst:
Van Velzen Ambitious pathologist whose maverick methods hid lies

Special report: Alder Hey hospital
fields.trailText: Dick van Velzen wants to be regarded by the world as a wronged and misunderstood genius. He has repeatedly said that he is a scapegoat. But the Alder Hey report paints him as a liar and fraudster who played with the emotions of trusting parents to further his ambitions.
fields.byline: Steven Morris, Helen Carter  and Andrew Osborn  in Oegstgeest, the Netherlands
fields.body:
Dick van Velzen wants to be regarded by the world as a wronged and misunderstood genius. He has repeatedly said that he is a scapegoat. But the Alder Hey report paints him as a liar and fraudster who played with the emotions of trusting parents to further his ambitions.

When Professor Van Velzen was appointed chairman of foetal and infant pathology at the University of Liverpool - the first post of its kind in Britain - in September 1988, colleagues were surprised. Aged 38, he had published relatively few papers and most of these were in Dutch, though English is the preferred language in the world of scientific publications.

But the interview panel was impressed when he told it that he had already run through some important clinical issues with the unit general manager at Alder Hey. In fact, this was the first of his lies - he had done no such thing.

When he arrived in Liverpool from the Netherlands, touted as the world's leading cot death expert, he declared that children were "much too precious to die without making use of every single scrap of available information which could help the next child" - disturbing words in the light of what is now known.

With funding from, among others, the Foundation for the Study of Infant Deaths and Liverpool health authority, his brief was to carry out postmortem examinations on children who had died there.

Prof Van Velzen spoke of his wish to see a postmortem carried out in every case. He was to be one of the leaders on a research project suggesting that more than half the cot deaths in Britain were linked to a respiratory virus.

But from the start his peculiar methods - the report labels him a "maverick", irregular working hours and odd attitude troubled staff. However, his cold, confident manner, coupled with a piercing glare typically delivered over his spectacles, did not encourage them to question him.

What the report rather chillingly dubs "the Van Velzen years" ended in 1995 when he left Alder Hey for the IWK Grace hospital in Nova Scotia. He was dismissed after six months amid allegations of incompetence. Last year it emerged that Canadian police wanted to question him about the storage of children's body parts in a warehouse.

He moved to Port of Spain hospital in Trinidad but by December 1999, when the organs retention scandal broke, was back in his homeland, working at the Westeinde hospital in the Hague. He took an indefinite leave of absence in October and set about defending himself.

He claimed that Alder Hey was aware of the stored organs because he had sent a detailed report to the hospital's management as far back as 1993.

Prof Van Velzen told the NOS television channel in the Netherlands: "I warned [Alder Hey] management from 1993 that from the ethical point of view it was a time-bomb. Now they are trying to describe me as a kind of Dr Frankenstein, just to get themselves off the hook."

For now, he is in hiding.

His family home, a modest semi in the village of Oegstgeest 10 miles from the Hague which he shares with his English wife, Lynn, who also used to work at Alder Hey, and nine-year-old daughter, Sarah, appeared deserted yesterday. A withered Christmas wreath hung from the front door and pumpkins lay decomposing on the doorstep.

He left home under police escort on Monday night, but not before an ugly altercation with a photographer from the Daily Telegraph.

Hans Reesink, 41, a neighbour and friend, said Prof Van Velzen was convinced he had done nothing wrong. "He is a nice guy and an honourable man. He was completely confident that it would all turn out well when I spoke to him. Because of different laws there have been a lot of misunderstandings."

But another neighbour, Betsy Blanken, said her three children had been asking her unsettling questions about Prof Van Velzen. "They were afraid. I told them not to worry."

webTitle: Vaz's wife wrote visa guidebook

fields.headline: Vaz's wife wrote visa guidebook
fields.standfirst: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText: Maria Fernandes - the wife of Keith Vaz, the minister embroiled in the Hinduja passport row - is the author of a guide to help Asians get a visitors' visa to Britain.
fields.body:
Maria Fernandes - the wife of Keith Vaz, the minister embroiled in the Hinduja passport row - is the author of a guide to help Asians get a visitors' visa to Britain.

The Europe minister's wife will be launching an up-to-date version of the book within three weeks - to take account of the government's new "fast track" appeal procedures for visa applicants .

The first edition of the book was published in 1995 by her private company, Mapesbury Communications, and includes a foreword by Jack Straw, then shadow home secretary.

She said yesterday: "We distribute it through the book club of the Asian Times and I have lost count of how many copies have been sold."

The book covers family, business, transit and medical visits to the UK designed to help Asians, many of whom run into long delays and problems when entering Britain.

It is dedicated "to my husband Keith for his inspiration and encouragement" and "to those who struggle every day to grapple with the complexities of our immigration system".

Her introduction says: "Those applying for visas are often left to find their own way through a maze of forms, documents and procedures. At the end of it they are asked to attend interviews with little idea of what is expected of them."

The guide warns applicants will be asked if they would work, marry or study if given the opportunity. "If you intend any of these you will be refused."

It reads: "Vague answers are likely to result in a refusal. Be clear and truthful. A lie, even about an unimportant matter, could damage the application."

The guide warns people not to change their minds when they are over here or try and stay in Britain while they are appealing for an extension. "Beware of the consequences of doing this. The application is treated as if it has been withdrawn. Visitors cannot change their minds and stay on."

webTitle: Diary: Matthew Norman

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: From a secret location overseas, Mandy Mandelson imperiously rejects media advances. Apart from several book offers (one for £500,000), Mandy has also said no to a researcher on ITV's Tonight With Trevor McDonald who invited him to be interviewed by - who else? - Martin Bashir.
fields.body:
 From a secret location overseas, Mandy Mandelson imperiously rejects media advances. Apart from several book offers (one for £500,000), Mandy has also said no to a researcher on ITV's Tonight With Trevor McDonald who invited him to be interviewed by - who else? - Martin Bashir. Who can say why Mandy resisted the temptation to sit there all doe-eyed, cooing: "The trouble was, there were three of us in this marriage"?

As for the pair of beauties left in the marriage, Mr T and Camilla Campbell have now put Downing Street, to continue yesterday's tedious analogy, at Defcon One. Following Robert Harris's Independent piece yesterday and today's news that Mandy has hired an aggressive West End law firm to represent him at the Hammond enquiry, the Mandy camp expects a strike to be launched against him imminently. If so, we believe Mandy will counterstrike at once, perhaps with a new slant on the Ecclestone affair, possibly with something less easily foreseen. It seems absurd, but in a world where everyone perpetually accuses everyone else of being mad, perhaps mutually assured destruction is the fairest way out.

 Speaking of accusations of lunacy, a flick through the Downing Street website reveals that Friday's afternoon briefing at which Ali said Mandy was doolally is missing. After an account of Friday morning's briefing, it jumps to Monday morning's, so my colleague Marina Hyde rings the press office at Number 10 for an explanation.

"The Sunday lobby is different," says Tania Joseph. "We never put it on the website." What luck. But why not? "It's just never been done for some reason. I don't know why - but there's no secret." Well then, given these special circumstances, why not just send over the transcript? A sigh ensues. "I think we've been through this." Have we? "Yes. There's no secret." You're very kind.

 A warm hats off to Mirror sports editor Des Kelly, who is revealed as Carol Vorderman's new chap. His office nickname is now "Two consonants and a vowel". Des is not the first tabloid sports hack with links to entertainment. Sun football writer Stephen Howard, you will recall, is either the son of Leslie Howard or Trevor Howard's nephew. Or both. Or possibly neither.

 Drama at the Times, where religion writer Ruth Gledhill has faced a crisis. It began with countryside editor Val Elliot so disliking the aroma of curries being heated up in the kitchen that she started removing fuses from the microwave plug.

When the curry-eaters responded by transferring fuses from the kettle to the microwave. Ruth intervened: she brought in a supply of fuses for colleagues to keep in their desks and slip into the plugs when required. When the entire stock vanished, Ruth was compelled to email staff, thanking them for "helpful messages on the problem" and recapping the history. "There has now been a new development," she concluded. "The plug has now been severed from the microwave. Maybe it's for the best." Maybe it is.

 Exciting news of Rizla Rosie Boycott, who after leaving the Express with £250,000 is thinking of television. She has been talking to the producer of Channel 5's The Wright Stuff, apparently an historically laughable show presented by a former Mirror showbiz hack. Details are sketchy, but one obvious precedent would be Open House With Gloria Hunniford, with celebrity pals casually popping in, as if they happened to be passing, to a studio mock-up of Rizla's own kitchen for a spliff and a chat. "Skunk With Rosie" is one title being considered.

 A red mousepad advertising the Spectator's new website (www.dementedravings.co.uk) arrives, and clipped to it is a card. "Stay lucky" it says.

webTitle: Police ask New Delhi court to keep Hindujas in India

fields.headline: Police ask New Delhi court to keep Hindujas in India
fields.standfirst: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText: The Indian police yesterday tried to prevent the Hindujas from returning to Britain after claiming that they acquired UK passports to help them to fight possible charges in the Bofors arms corruption case.
fields.body:
The Indian police yesterday tried to prevent the Hindujas from returning to Britain after claiming that they acquired UK passports to help them to fight possible charges in the Bofors arms corruption case.

Lawyers for India's central bureau of investigation asked a New Delhi court not to allow the billionaire brothers to go abroad after saying they had been evasive during interrogation.

If they were allowed to leave India, conditions should be attached to ensure they returned for any trial resulting from allegations that they banked illegal "commissions" when Bofors in Sweden sold howitzers to India in the 1980s, police said.

Judge Ajit Bharihoke will give his ruling tomorrow. The Hindujas' legal team requested bail and offered to accept any conditions imposed by the judge, promising the family's full cooperation.

If allowed to return, the two British based brothers at the centre of the passport row, Srichand (SP) and Gopichand (GP), face questioning by Sir Anthony Hammond QC over how they got their British nationality.

The controversy has already cost Peter Mandelson his political career after he was accused of lying about his role, and has threatened the future of the minister for Europe, Keith Vaz.

The charge sheet filed in India against SP, GP and Swiss-based Prakash, who also asked for Mr Mandelson's help to get a passport, ties the Bofors investigation to the passport applications of SP and GP.

According to the police, who have investigated the Bofors deal for 10 years, "the change of nationality of both these Hindujas brothers is directly linked" to legal action brought by police, and unsuccessfully opposed by the Hindujas, to gain access to Swiss bank accounts through which the kickbacks were allegedly channelled.

SP and GP, then Indian nationals, are alleged to have opened accounts called Tulip and Lotus with the Geneva branch of the Hanover Trust Company of New York in May 1986 to receive the illegal payments.

The investigation started in 1990, though police had to wait until 1998 before they could examine the Swiss accounts. The Swiss cantonal court dismissed an appeal by the brothers in 1999.

GP was granted British nationality in 1997 and SP in 1999 after earlier applications had been rejected.

Criminal charges in India alleging corruption would embarrass a series of ministers from Tony Blair down who have met SP and GP.

SP disclosed at the weekend that Mr Vaz was asked to advise the brothers on what protection British passports would provide if they were formally charged in India.

The Hindujas have admitted receiving money from Bofors but maintain it had nothing to do with the gun deal. They told the court they had gone to India voluntarily to be questioned, and their business was suffering while they were out of London.

Criticising the police, SP said: "They have not given a correct picture to the judge. We have answered all kinds of questions put to us by the CBI, and there is nothing more they have to know from us, yet they say we were being evasive. Nothing can be farther from the truth."

fields.bodyText: The Indian police yesterday tried to prevent the Hindujas from returning to Britain after claiming that they acquired UK passports to help them to fight possible charges in the Bofors arms corruption case. Lawyers for India's central bureau of investigation asked a New Delhi court not to allow the billionaire brothers to go abroad after saying they had been evasive during interrogation. If they were allowed to leave India, conditions should be attached to ensure they returned for any trial resulting from allegations that they banked illegal "commissions" when Bofors in Sweden sold howitzers to India in the 1980s, police said. Judge Ajit Bharihoke will give his ruling tomorrow. The Hindujas' legal team requested bail and offered to accept any conditions imposed by the judge, promising the family's full cooperation. If allowed to return, the two British based brothers at the centre of the passport row, Srichand (SP) and Gopichand (GP), face questioning by Sir Anthony Hammond QC over how they got their British nationality. The controversy has already cost Peter Mandelson his political career after he was accused of lying about his role, and has threatened the future of the minister for Europe, Keith Vaz. The charge sheet filed in India against SP, GP and Swiss-based Prakash, who also asked for Mr Mandelson's help to get a passport, ties the Bofors investigation to the passport applications of SP and GP. According to the police, who have investigated the Bofors deal for 10 years, "the change of nationality of both these Hindujas brothers is directly linked" to legal action brought by police, and unsuccessfully opposed by the Hindujas, to gain access to Swiss bank accounts through which the kickbacks were allegedly channelled. SP and GP, then Indian nationals, are alleged to have opened accounts called Tulip and Lotus with the Geneva branch of the Hanover Trust Company of New York in May 1986 to receive the illegal payments. The investigation started in 1990, though police had to wait until 1998 before they could examine the Swiss accounts. The Swiss cantonal court dismissed an appeal by the brothers in 1999. GP was granted British nationality in 1997 and SP in 1999 after earlier applications had been rejected. Criminal charges in India alleging corruption would embarrass a series of ministers from Tony Blair down who have met SP and GP. SP disclosed at the weekend that Mr Vaz was asked to advise the brothers on what protection British passports would provide if they were formally charged in India. The Hindujas have admitted receiving money from Bofors but maintain it had nothing to do with the gun deal. They told the court they had gone to India voluntarily to be questioned, and their business was suffering while they were out of London. Criticising the police, SP said: "They have not given a correct picture to the judge. We have answered all kinds of questions put to us by the CBI, and there is nothing more they have to know from us, yet they say we were being evasive. Nothing can be farther from the truth." webTitle: Arts: Profile of actress Lindsay Duncan

fields.headline: Experience not required
fields.standfirst: Lindsay Duncan insists that she's not a natural performer. Nor can she find inspiration in a traumatic past. So how has she ended up a star? She talks to  Phil Daoust
fields.trailText: Lindsay Duncan insists that she's not a natural performer. Nor can she find inspiration in a traumatic past. So how has she ended up a star? She talks to Phil Daoust.
fields.body:
Lunch with Lindsay Duncan is a daunting prospect. She's best known for cool, commanding, often predatory roles: the Marquise de Merteuil in the Royal Shakespeare Company's Les Liaisons Dangereuses, say, or basque-wearing Barbara in Alan Bleasdale's TV drama GBH. You half expect her to snap at the waitress, then send back her smoked haddock soup because it's too fishy or too wet. But she's nice as pie, all please and thank you and, "Are you sure you've got enough to eat?" When director Peter Brook drifts into the restaurant, she gasps with excitement.

Duncan is taking a brief break from rehearsing a new play for the Royal Court. When she goes back, she says, someone is sure to ask her: "So, did you talk a load of old bollocks?" And she'll reply: "Yes."

Perhaps it's work that keeps her mellow. For the past few weeks Duncan has been preparing Mouth to Mouth, by her old friend Kevin Elyot, creator of the hit play My Night With Reg. She plays Laura, a married woman whose nearest and dearest would drive anyone round the bend. The play has Aids, death, infidelity, the supernatural, humour and tragedy - yet done with a lightness of touch that might easily come across as flippancy.

But Duncan is sure it will be a success. "I was quite shaken when I read it for the first time," she says in her perfectly articulated Home Counties tones. "It's a devastating play, a passionate play. Kevin has a serious comic gift but he also has a depth of feeling. With every fibre of my being I consider this to be a remarkable play. But no matter how you try to say that, it sounds forced, false, because what else am I going to say? It's very hard to talk about a piece of writing that moves you."

And, God knows, there is some rubbish out there. She won't name names, but it sounds as if she means The Graduate. "There's a famous screenplay, from one of the most brilliant films ever made, that has just been stuck on the stage. I haven't seen it; why would I? It seems to be an entirely cynical exercise. What's the real motivation for doing that kind of theatre? The producer isn't going, 'My God, I really believe in this piece of writing.'

"I do feel almost violent when I'm watching things that I don't think are good enough. I get furious for the audience. I want to say them, 'This play is not supposed to be like this. They've got it completely wrong. You should be electrified by this.' "

Duncan, 50, was born in Scotland and spent the first six years of her life there. She can't remember precisely when or why she decided to be an actor, but there was a family tradition of performance. "My parents' generation was definitely pre-telly, and they knew how to entertain each other. Everybody knew something that they could do - a song or a poem, or a piece of music. At school I remember being a cat and then a budgie and then a bumble bee. I obviously thought all that was marvellous."

Was she - is she - one of those revolting people who are always performing to friends and family? "I'm not remotely like that. I don't perform well in private." She giggles. "Socially, I mean. And I didn't as a child. Actors aren't necessarily outgoing, are they?" Even now, the thought of parlour games sends a chill down her spine. "That awful thing of playing charades! People expect you to do something magnificently well-honed - act out the whole of Ben Hur - and then they're terribly disappointed when you're humming and hawing."

After three years at the Central School of Drama, Duncan got her first acting job in weekly rep in East Anglia. "It was terribly weird and old-fashioned and a bit mad," she recalls. "You go from being this London drama student to doing Agatha Christies and performing at the end of a pier. Swapping clothes, because you had to provide your own costumes. It was all rather camp, really - like being in a time warp. But I just loved it. It was so bonkers."

Rep was followed by more challenging work - the opening season at the Royal Exchange, Top Girls at the Royal Court - and finally, in the 1980s, the RSC, alongside Alan Rickman, Fiona Shaw and Juliet Stevenson.

What made Duncan's name was the RSC's production of Les Liaisons Dangereuses, which won her an Olivier in Britain, and took her to the States, where she was nominated for a Tony. "A lot of people left the theatre wanting to have sex, and most of them wanted to have it with Alan Rickman," she famously remarked. Duncan is now part of Harold Pinter's informal repertory company and an obvious choice whenever a TV drama needs a sexy, classy older woman, like The Rector's Wife or Shooting the Past.

But if Les Liaisons was her big break, it was also a missed opportunity. For Stephen Frears's film of the play, Duncan and Rickman were replaced by Glenn Close and John Malkovich. "I'm probably more annoyed about that now than I was at the time. We'd done it and done it and done it on stage over a period of two years. Alan and I particularly just looked like a couple of ghouls at the end of it - completely wasted. The thing is, we knew there had to be American actors. We even went out with dinner with the people who'd bought the film rights to talk about casting. And, you know, they didn't make a completely ridiculous film.

"But really," she continues, "the only time I think about it is when it comes up in interviews." It's all part of "the most familiar, boring, boring theme: why haven't I got a film career? Why didn't I go to Hollywood? Did I go to Hollywood and did I fail? People seem to think I'm feeling happy, fulfilled, challenged, so they'll just just chip away: 'You could have done more!'

"Of course, movies are the universal art form. They communicate to a vast amount of people. You earn a hell of a lot of money and have a fantastic lifestyle. But I don't see that it all happens there and that I'm at the wrong end of the spectrum. I reckon where I am is the sharp end."

Duncan is married to another actor, Hilton McRae. Would she be happy for their nine-year-old son, Cal, to go into the business? "Neither Hilton nor I came from acting families. But I do want him to do something creative that he enjoys. I want him to feel about work the way we feel about work. I want him to get really excited when he's more than halfway through his life about a job. That's got to be the best thing."

Is she one of those actors who have to ground every part in their own experience? In Mouth to Mouth, where she plays a mother of a teenage son, is she thinking of her own boy? "Ugh, no," she shudders. "There would be something faintly disgusting about using that relationship. I'd find it quite spooky."

Yet many actors do insist everything comes down to personal experience. "That's bollocks, isn't it? I've played so many parts where I simply haven't had that life experience. And what would be the point of being an actor? If it was all down to experience, you could get up there and do it. Obviously, every actor is the better for being engaged in the world, but beyond that ... You just get practised at exercising your imagination, and hopefully reading a play more accurately - literally and intellectually and emotionally. I've always been a material-based actor. That's what I've done, the choices I've made - like a heat-seeking missile." And off she goes, back to her script.

 Mouth to Mouth is in previews at the Royal Court, London SW1 (020-7565 5000), from tomorrow and runs until March 10.

webTitle: Arts: Arthur Smith's column

fields.headline: Arthur Smith
fields.trailText: Richard Briers is our premier fast-talking actor but, compared with the characters in The West Wing and Sex and the City, he speaks at the speed of Leonard Cohen with a headache.
fields.body:
Hamlet is the longest of Shakespeare's plays, and the Prince of Denmark is the longest part in English classical theatre. Nevertheless, when Richard Briers did it, I am told, it came in at just over an hour and a half. Briers is our premier fast-talking actor but, compared with the characters in The West Wing and Sex and the City, he speaks at the speed of Leonard Cohen with a headache.

Do they really speak that fast in Washington and New York? In these two programmes they gabble away at such a lick that I feel sorry for the writers, who must have to deliver several extra kilos of script per hour of TV. If we really talked so quickly, we'd have used up a normal day's speech by 10am. Drama should often be played at pace, but the spirit of these American shows gives them an unearned urgency and kids you the dialogue is more scintillating than it really is. Or maybe I'm old and slow.

I'm interviewing Candace Bushnell, who wrote the original Sex and the City, on Loose Ends on Saturday. I'm worried that if she speaks really fast, I'll have to prepare extra questions. Her new book, Four Blondes, is scabrously witty, even though I find it hard to agree with the blurb that she "captures the essence of our era".

In the last story, the blonde in question visits London. English women have "ratty hair, unpolished nails and flabby thighs" but can still "snag a man", which is the one and only desire of all women in Bushnell's books. English men have small willies, don't do foreplay, come in two minutes and, of course, wear socks in bed. I fully expect Candace to be glamorous, stick-thin, clad in designer clothes and soignée beyond the needs of Radio 4.

I have two bets with my friend Harry. First, I have to persuade this chic Manhattanite to join me in a trip to Catford dog track. Second, I have to write an opening paragraph in the Guardian in which I yoke together Sex and the City, Hamlet, Richard Briers, Leonard Cohen and Jayne Torvill. Damn.

webTitle: Leader: telcos and text messaging

fields.headline: A telco txt for 2day
fields.standfirst: The big phone barons should lighten up
fields.trailText: Text messaging is definitely the new rock'n'roll. It is estimated that a million messages were sent every hour last month and that come July more than a billion messages a month may be flying through the ether.
fields.body:
Text messaging is definitely the new rock'n'roll. It is estimated that a million messages were sent every hour last month and that come July more than a billion messages a month may be flying through the ether. Even that may be an underestimate, because suddenly everyone is getting in on the act. Television programmes such as Popstars and Da Ali G Show are sending messages to mobiles as trailers and other shows use interactive texting elements. And teenagers are not alone in getting involved. Companies are realising that text messaging is a cheap way to reach a big target audience, as long as they get permission first.

A couple of years ago hardly anyone, least of all the phone companies (telcos) or service providers, had any inkling of the explosion about to happen - and which came about by word of mouth. It has brought them vital revenues at a time when they are being squeezed by the cost of the third generation licences and when "virtual" telcos are buying spare capacity in bulk and undercutting their tariffs. Yet the telcos themselves are being extremely myopic in their pricing policies, which are in danger of stifling the efforts of a new young generation of potential entrepreneurs. If someone devises, say, an interactive game involving mobile phones, then the telco gets the price of the call and the cost of text messages (up to 10p each before bulk discounts), even though the maximum 160 characters takes up virtually no capacity.

Companies with clout can negotiate small revenue sharing deals - but most of these budding entrepreneurs cannot make money, since the telcos vacuum up all the revenues - even though neither the calls nor the text messages would have happened at all without the innovative business ideas. The BTs and Vodafones of this world must offer revenue sharing deals. It would create more cash in the long term than they would lose. And it would encourage a nascent industry instead of smothering it at birth.

webTitle: G2: Francis Wheen on Mandelson's friends

fields.headline: The whole truth about Peter's friends
fields.standfirst: Special report: Peter Mandelson
fields.trailText: Flayed by the media and excoriated by his cabinet colleagues, Peter Mandelson is entitled to feel puzzled. Can it be true, as they say, that he only ever had one friend, who happened to be the prime minister?
fields.body:
Flayed by the media and excoriated by his cabinet colleagues, Peter Mandelson is entitled to feel puzzled. Can it be true, as they say, that he only ever had one friend, who happened to be the prime minister? In the words of Sir Thomas Wyatt, "I have seen them gentle, tame and meek,/That now are wild and do not remember ..."

The Sun dismisses him as "a lying, manipulative, oily, two-faced, nasty piece of work who should never have been allowed near the government in the first place", yet in 1997 the same newspaper praised Mandelson as a formidable politician who should be promoted to the cabinet forthwith. Ditto the Mirror; and ditto ditto our old friend Paul Johnson of the Daily Mail. Johnson now denounces the "corrupt" and "wretched" Mandelson as "the fastest and most determined social climber I have ever come across" (a title which many of us thought Johnson himself had won outright), and chides the PM for making "the crass mistake of restoring Mandelson to office after the most perfunctory interval - an act of folly strongly criticised at the time by his own colleagues and backbenchers".

Is this the same Paul Johnson who in November 1997 wrote that "Mandelson is tall, dark, handsome and ... probably the most hard-working man in British politics today"? And who in April 1998 advised Blair to make Mandelson foreign secretary, "a job for which his discretion and astonishing industry make him well suited"? And who, a few months later, deplored "the recent vicious campaign against Peter Mandelson", advising Blair to show his confidence in this "faithful lieutenant" by "giving him a prominent place in the cabinet"?

Even at the time of Mandelson's first resignation, two years ago, Johnson's enthusiasm was undimmed: "I know Mandelson well and like him. I also admire his skill and dedication in the public service, his devotion to the prime minister and his aims, and the guts with which he has faced more than his fair share of often grotesquely ill-informed criticism ... My own view, as one who wishes to remain his friend, is clear. His political career can still be salvaged."

They flee from Peter that sometime did him seek, and all is turned into "a strange fashion of forsaking". Yet he emerges from this with rather more credit and integrity than those who feel emboldened to kick him only now that he's down. Whatever one's opinions of New Labour (and this column's attitude is, I think, pretty well known), he was at least a true believer - with the emphasis on the word true.

This made the supposedly devious Mandelson a more honest character than his colleagues who privately wince and snigger at the Third Way but nevertheless spout unadulterated Blairite jargon in public and in cabinet: people such as the senior minister who, after reading a Blairosceptic article on this page, gave me a conspiratorial wink and murmured "Keep up the good work" before heading off to a TV studio to denounce fainthearts and malcontents who doubt the New Labour gospel.

A week after his downfall, it is still difficult to see what uniquely vile offence Mandelson committed. If being chummy with the Hindujas is grounds for resignation, the front benches of both major parties would be almost empty. Ah yes, say the tinpot Torquemadas of Westminster, but he told a lie to the Observer - or, at the very least, gave a misleading answer. As Clare Short put it: "He went because he has got problems telling the truth."

If that were the real reason, many other ministers would have preceded him to the gallows. When Gordon Brown appeared on the Today programme just as the Bernie Ecclestone scandal broke, he was asked point-blank if Ecclestone had given money to Labour. "You'll have to wait and see, like I'll have to wait and see when the list is published," he replied. "I've not been told." This was a lie: Blair had told Brown about the donation the previous week.

Blair himself then submitted to a TV interrogation by John Humphrys. He claimed that Ecclestone's second donation was refused "before any journalist had been in touch," and that "the question then arose which was uppermost in my mind, what about the original donation? We decided to seek the advice of Sir Patrick Neill." Both these statements were lies: the letter to Neill was written only after journalists began sniffing around; and it asked for advice only about the second donation, not the first. (Lest we forget, this was the same interview in which the PM boasted of being a pretty straight kinda guy.)

What of Jack Straw, the sea-green incorruptible who shopped Mandelson to Downing Street because ministers have a sacred duty "to give the whole truth"? At the Labour conference in 1999 the home secretary declared that "we will be giving the police the money they need to recruit 5,000 more officers. That's 5,000 more officers over and above the police service's recruiting plans. That's not the sort of hollow promise the Conservatives used to make."

But it was. Alan Milburn, then chief secretary to the Treasury, had sent Straw a warning letter three days before the speech. "I must stress that, as has been discussed at length and agreed with your officials and contrary to your letter of September 23 to Derry Irvine, the package does not provide for 5,000 'additional' officers," he wrote. "There should therefore be no references to this package being one for 5,000 additional officers."

Milburn became health secretary soon after the party conference - and promptly revealed his own talent for creative accountancy by announcing that he intended to recruit an "extra" 410 consultants in heart disease by the year 2005. All these new doctors turned out to be people who were already working as senior heart specialists in the NHS: all he meant was that they would have qualified as consultants by 2005.

There have been dozens of these multiple announcements - and straightforwardly bogus announcements - since May 1997. Many ministers, it seems, have "a problem with telling the truth". Messrs Blair, Brown, Straw, Byers and Milburn have not resigned yet; nor has anyone seriously suggested that they should. Why, then, is Mandelson cast into the outer darkness with many a shout of "good riddance"?

The answer can be found in The World of the Favourite, a recent book of scholarly essays edited by the historians Sir John Elliott and Laurence Brockliss. Although commentators have often described Mandelson's position at the Court of Tony as "unprecedented" and "extraordinary", the minister-favourite is in fact a familiar historical type.

Edward II had Piers Gaveston, Catherine the Great had Potemkin, Louis XIV had Fouquet, Henry VIII had Wolsey, James I had Somerset and then Buckingham. Strong rulers as well as weak ones have found it useful to share their burdens with a single trusted and efficient minister. But the favourite's power and influence provoke intense ill-feeling among other courtiers, who regard him as a sinister usurping parvenu with ideas above his station, or perhaps even a sorcerer. (When the Earl of Somerset fell from favour in 1616, he was charged with witchcraft.)

As Brockliss points out, it was the favourites who "took the flak" for unpopular decisions, allowing the monarch to remain unscathed. Which is why their downfall is almost inevitable, and has been so ever since the execution of Sejanus, the supposedly untouchable chief minister of the Emperor Tiberius. Piers Gaveston was killed, as was the 17th-century's most famous Mandelsonian figure, the Duke of Buckingham.

Now that Mandelson has more leisure time, he may find some consolation from reading about his predecessors. Things look pretty bleak, but at least he won't be disembowelled: the worst fate that he can expect is a company directorship.

webTitle: Mobile internet: Next generation put on hold

fields.headline: Next generation put on hold
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Nokia, the world's biggest manufacturer of mobile handsets, cast a fresh shadow over the telecoms industry yesterday as it delayed the full release of its next-generation phones and issued a warning that revenue growth is slowing.
fields.body:
Nokia, the world's biggest manufacturer of mobile handsets, cast a fresh shadow over the telecoms industry yesterday as it delayed the full release of its next-generation phones and issued a warning that revenue growth is slowing.

While the Finnish firm was able to announce better than expected profits for the final quarter of last year at €1.77bn (£1.1bn), analysts were quick to downgrade expectations for the current year. The gloom was compounded by news that Nokia's global packet radio system (GPRS) handsets, due to reach stores across Europe within five months, will be delayed until the end of the year.

Shares in Nokia, which yesterday bolstered its board with the appointment of Pearson chief executive Marjorie Scardino as a non-executive, fell almost 6% to €37.60. The stock has more than halved since June, when the company ranked as Europe's biggest.

Clearly exasperated at uncertainty over the introduction of new technology and the level of consumer demand, chief executive Jorma Ollila told a news conference: "We just don't know exactly what is going to happen. It's just not possible to predict in the same way as it was in previous years."

He attributed a likely slowdown in profit growth to Nokia's strategy of "aggressively gaining market share", which last week forced its Scandinavian rival Ericsson to end its production of handsets and outsource the business. Nokia's handsetsaccount for a almost a third of world sales.

Worries over GPRS and its successor, 3G or third-generation mobiles, are being heightened by falling sales of handsets. Mr Ollila said yesterday that the company, which sold 128m phones in 2000, expected the industry as a whole to shift between 500m and 550m handsets this year, retreating from predictions that global sales would top 550m units.

"The anticipated shift in the mobile phone industry is now taking place and market growth is gradually settling into less exceptional levels than we have seen in the near past," Mr Ollila said.

Mobile phone penetration across Europe has reached 62%, but deep uncertainty remains over the pace at which consumers will switch to new handsets offering higher-speed internet access as well as voice calls.

Motorola is the only company with a GPRS phone available. Jitters in the industry have been exacerbated by warnings such as one from Irish mobile computer chip maker Parthus, which last week claimed that the first shipment of this latest generation of handsets have a short battery life and a tendency to overheat.

Bouygues Telecom, France's third largest mobile phone operator, yesterday pulled out of the contest for a French third-generation mobile licence - leaving only two contenders for the four licences on offer.
