webTitle: Leader: Arafat and Barak's shared interest in stopping Sharon

fields.headline: Stopping Mr Sharon
fields.standfirst:
These two weak leaders need each other

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: Yasser Arafat was back in peacemaking mode yesterday after his intemperate weekend outburst in Davos. "I'm with the peace process," he said. "We are looking to achieve real peace between the two peoples."
fields.body:
Yasser Arafat was back in peacemaking mode yesterday after his intemperate weekend outburst in Davos. "I'm with the peace process," he said. "We are looking to achieve real peace between the two peoples." His words contrasted sharply with his condemnation of Israel only two days earlier as a "fascist military aggressor" waging a "savage and barbaric war". But then, expecting consistency from the Palestinian leader has long been a futile exercise. Since backing out of the Camp David summit last July, Mr Arafat has ducked and weaved like tanzim dodging settlers' bullets, by turns defending the people's uprising, stoking its flames, and trying to cool it down. His approach to on-off-on again peace talks has been similarly windblown. It suits Israel to say he is responsible for the bloodshed of the past months. But in reality, he has been swept along by events more often than he has controlled them. The weakness of Mr Arafat's leadership has never been more evident. Even were a peace deal finally agreed, it is uncertain whether he could sell it to his own people. Like Israelis, they are not in the mood.

Lack of strong, purposeful leadership skills is also a problem for Ehud Barak, the cackhanded Israeli prime minister who will seek re-election next week. There is no denying that for those Israelis who supported him last time, Mr Barak has been a big disappointment. Politically, he changed his mind too often, alienated his allies, antagonised his foes, and lost his Knesset majority. Measured against his 1999 platform, he failed to deliver the peace he promised, last year's Lebanon withdrawal notwithstanding; and while the Oslo process advanced and may yet provide the basis for a lasting settlement, that progress was overwhelmed by Israelis' sense of betrayal as their "peace partners" plunged back into intifada. In the eyes of the world (and Israel's own Arab voters), Mr Barak is to blame, by failing to restrain Israel's army, for more than 300 Arab deaths and, among other enormities, for a policy of targeted assassination.

Yet not for the first time, these two weak, inadequate leaders, these peace-seeking enemies, need each other badly as the election nears. In another era, the opposition hawk, Ariel Sharon, might have stood before a war crimes tribunal. Now he stands at the gates of power, endangering the last, faint hopes of conciliation. Mr Arafat and Mr Barak have a shared interest in repelling him.

fields.trailText: In a letter headed Legal aid solicitors present their case, page 23, yesterday, we conferred upon Lord Irvine the title attorney general. He is, of course, the lord chancellor. The mistake was ours and had nothing whatsoever to do with the author of the letter, Richard Miller, the acting director, Legal Aid Practitioners Group. Apologies to both.
fields.body:
In a letter headed Legal aid solicitors present their case, page 23, yesterday, we conferred upon Lord Irvine the title attorney general. He is, of course, the lord chancellor. The mistake was ours and had nothing whatsoever to do with the author of the letter, Richard Miller, the acting director, Legal Aid Practitioners Group. Apologies to both.

In a report headed Ministers reveal full extent of contacts, page 6, January 27, we said the Hinduja brothers had fired their public relations firm. The firm in question, Brown Lloyd James, have asked us to make it clear that they were not sacked but voluntarily relinquished the account, even though the Hinduja brothers were asking them to continue.

In a report headed BBC1's balloon gives way to softer image, page 5, January 24, we said that the balloon image cost £5m. In fact, the cost was £500,000. The balloon has made more than 40,000 appearances. Its introduction was part of a wider rebranding exercise which cost a further £1m to £2m, according to the BBC.

In an article about memoirs, page 10, Saturday Review (books), January 27, we referred to Anne Karpf's The War After, saying that the author's parents had survived the death camps, but would never talk about them. Anne Karpf says that, in fact, they would speak freely about their wartime experiences when asked.

The house in Daphne du Maurier's novel, Rebecca, was Manderley, not Mandalay (parliamentary sketch, page 2, yesterday). "Last night I dreamt I went to Manderley again ..." (first published by Gollancz, 1938). For more information, see Daphne du Maurier.

webTitle: Leader: The Alder Hey organ scandal

fields.headline: Taken without consent
fields.standfirst:
Liverpool was not the only offender

Special report: Alder Hey hospital
fields.trailText: Two out of three people in British surveys say they would be willing to donate their organs for medical research after their deaths. This goodwill has been systematically ignored by the medical profession, which has proceeded to remove organs and retain them without informed consent.
fields.body:
Two out of three people in British surveys say they would be willing to donate their organs for medical research after their deaths. One person in five carries a donor card, which in the event of a fatal accident, allows doctors to use organs to save other patients' lives. But as yesterday's census by the chief medical officer (CMO), and the report of the inquiry into Liverpool's Alder Hey children's hospital, both grimly document, this goodwill has been systematically ignored by the medical profession, which has proceeded to remove organs and retain them without informed consent.

In Liverpool and at the Bristol Royal Infirmary, where the illegal procedures were first exposed, organs were systematically removed, most of them illegally without the consent of the dead patients' relatives. Between 1988 and 1995, when autopsies at Liverpool were under the control of a Dutch pathologist, Professor Dick van Velzen, the hospital stripped the organs of over 1,000 dead babies and children, most of which were never used for medical research but just stockpiled. The professor, now on leave from a hospital post in Holland, is wanted in Canada for a similar scandal. Yesterday's report insists he must never be allowed to practise in the UK again.

But the real scandal yesterday was less the grim story of Liverpool's rogue pathologist than the evidence of the CMO's census. This shows that illegal procedures are not restricted to just two hospitals. There are 105,000 organs retained across English hospitals, 54,000 of which were removed in the last 30 years. (Some 25 leading hospitals and medical schools account for 88%.) The report estimates that at least 16,500 have been retained in contravention of the law. As the health secretary, Alan Milburn, told the Commons: "The current law and postmortem consent forms are both ambiguous. They record 'lack of objection' rather than positive consent."

What has gone wrong? Essentially the medical profession has failed to keep in tune with changing social attitudes and medical law. Part of the problem has been a misguided belief among doctors that the bereaved should not be told the truth about autopsies, when they had only just learned of the deaths of their children. Hence the deceptive consent form which talks of taking tissues, rather than organs. But this deception has eroded the most important element of medical practice: patients' trust. Part of the trouble, as the CMO conceded yesterday, has been an unwelcome residue of medical paternalism, "belonging to an era when decisions were made for patients, not with them".

The medical profession is changing. Even before yesterday's proposed reforms, new guidelines for pathologists had been issued by the CMO, the British Medical Association, and the Royal College of Pathologists - together with a proposed code of conduct from the Bristol hospital inquiry. The health secretary has followed these up with a sensible package of enforceable statutory safeguards.What everyone should unite behind now is an education campaign emphasising the importance of organ donations. Even at Alder Hey, according to the report, 1,600 children alive today would have died but for the improvements in surgical techniques and care pioneered there. The bereaved parents have said that they would have donated organs, had they been asked. They could play a key part now in restoring public trust by encouraging people, once the new safeguards are in place, to agree to donations. Many lives depend on maintaining medical research.

Between 1988 and 1995, when autopsies at Liverpool were under the control of a Dutch pathologist, Professor Dick van Velzen, the hospital stripped the organs of over 1,000 dead babies and children, most of which were never used for medical research but just stockpiled. The professor, now on leave from a hospital post in Holland, is wanted in Canada for a similar scandal. Yesterday's report insists he must never be allowed to practise in the UK again. But the real scandal yesterday was less the grim story of Liverpool's rogue pathologist than the evidence of the CMO's census. This shows that illegal procedures are not restricted to just two hospitals. There are 105,000 organs retained across English hospitals, 54,000 of which were removed in the last 30 years. (Some 25 leading hospitals and medical schools account for 88%.) The report estimates that at least 16,500 have been retained in contravention of the law. As the health secretary, Alan Milburn, told the Commons: "The current law and postmortem consent forms are both ambiguous. They record 'lack of objection' rather than positive consent." What has gone wrong? Essentially the medical profession has failed to keep in tune with changing social attitudes and medical law. Part of the problem has been a misguided belief among doctors that the bereaved should not be told the truth about autopsies, when they had only just learned of the deaths of their children. Hence the deceptive consent form which talks of taking tissues, rather than organs. But this deception has eroded the most important element of medical practice: patients' trust. Part of the trouble, as the CMO conceded yesterday, has been an unwelcome residue of medical paternalism, "belonging to an era when decisions were made for patients, not with them". The medical profession is changing. Even before yesterday's proposed reforms, new guidelines for pathologists had been issued by the CMO, the British Medical Association, and the Royal College of Pathologists - together with a proposed code of conduct from the Bristol hospital inquiry. The health secretary has followed these up with a sensible package of enforceable statutory safeguards.What everyone should unite behind now is an education campaign emphasising the importance of organ donations. Even at Alder Hey, according to the report, 1,600 children alive today would have died but for the improvements in surgical techniques and care pioneered there. The bereaved parents have said that they would have donated organs, had they been asked. They could play a key part now in restoring public trust by encouraging people, once the new safeguards are in place, to agree to donations. Many lives depend on maintaining medical research. Talk about it Health minister live online John Hutton was live online today. Read what he said and have your say. fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
More children contest compensation awards
Spy book on sale over net
Couple to live in Castaway pod
Feline killers exposed
fields.body:
More children contest awards

Families of two children injured in the machete attack in 1996 at a Wolverhampton school are to seek increased awards from the criminal injuries compensation authority, following Monday's improved payment to their former classmate Francesa Quintyne. Ahmed Malik, eight, suffered a skull fracture and was awarded £6,250; Reena Chopra, seven, received £6,000 for cuts to her head and face.

Spy book on sale over net

Internet firm 192.com yesterday offered for sale in Britain copies of the memoirs of former MI6 agent Richard Tomlinson, The Big Breach, published in Moscow. Last week the appeal court rejected a ban on the book's contents.

Loft renovation ends in death

Peter Agar, 53, died and his son Nicholas, 33, was left critically ill when they were apparently overcome by fumes from a portable generator while renovating the loft of their shop in Harrogate, North Yorkshire.

Couple to live in Castaway pod

One of the accommodation pods put on Taransay for the BBC Castaway programme has been sold. David and Anne Jolly, of Reading in Berkshire, have applied for permission to turn it into a house and relocate it on a neighbouring island off Scotland.

Feline killers exposed

A survey for the Mammal Society found that 1,000 cats killed 14,000 other animals over five months. With an estimated UK pet cat population of 9m, this gives a total of 275m victims a year, or 33 for each cat. Mice were top, the study found, then voles; few rats were killed - probably because rats fight back.

webTitle: Seven face death for letter to Pakistan paper

fields.headline: Seven face death for letter to paper
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Pakistan www.cpj.org/Briefings/Pakistan_
Special report on Pakistan by the Committee to Protect Journalists
fields.trailText: Seven journalists face the death penalty for blasphemy after Pakistan's military regime closed down an English-language newspaper for publishing a "highly sacrilegious" reader's letter.
fields.body:
Seven journalists face the death penalty for blasphemy after Pakistan's military regime closed down an English-language newspaper for publishing a "highly sacrilegious" reader's letter.

Hundreds of protesters from a rightwing Islamic party set fire to the printing presses of the Frontier Post in Peshawar yesterday and ransacked the newspaper's offices.

Monday's edition of the paper carried a letter which accused the prophet Mohammed of anti-semitism, "total dishonesty" and "unabashed male chauvinism".

"His hatred for Jews was caused by their refusal to accept him as a prophet because of his low moral character and his lack of knowledge of the scripture and his murderous ways," the letter said.

The writer said Mohammed made revelations from God "in order to satisfy his political or personal agenda or his libido". The letter, sent by email, was signed only "BenDZac".

Police raided the building late on Monday, arrested five staff and issued warrants for two senior editors. The staff are being held under Pakistan's blasphemy law, which carries a death penalty for those who insult Mohammed.

Peshawar magistrates said the newspaper's offices would be sealed indefinitely. "The contents of the letter were highly sacrilegious," the court said in a statement.

General Pervez Musharraf, who seized power in late 1999, said his government would not allow the publication of "such objectionable material".

The Frontier Post, which was not printed yesterday, published a large apology in rival newspapers. It said that it was the victim of a conspiracy and that it had given a list of suspects' names to police.

"We bluntly claim that the conspiracy sought to close down The Frontier Post, rendering the employees jobless, and to destabilise Pakistan," it said. "The persons apparently involved have been suspended pending inquiry."

The Post has had a troubled history. There were riots outside its offices in 1988 over a supposedly blasphemous article. In 1999 its owner, Rehmat Shah Afridi, whose papers had been critical of the then government of Nawaz Sharif, was arrested for drug trafficking.

Mr Afridi has been in jail ever since as his case drags through the legal system. His son, Mahmood Afridi, who now runs the paper, is one of the editors wanted by police.

webTitle: Analysis: Devolution gathers support in cabinet

fields.headline: Divide and rule
fields.standfirst:
The benefits of regionalism are beginning to attract some heavyweight support in the government as they look enviously northward

Special report: devolution in Britain
fields.trailText: The benefits of regionalism are beginning to attract some heavyweight support in the government as they look enviously northward.
fields.body:
Until recently English regionalism was the policy that dare not speak its name. The very mention of devolution, to match the transfer of power to Scotland and Wales, set alarm bells ringing. Tony Blair dismissed talk of a north-south divide as a dangerous over-simplification. End of story.

But the party faithful in Labour's heartlands became restless as old industries closed and the economic riches of the south failed to trickle down. In local elections, once-solid Labour towns - such as Peter Mandelson's Hartlepool - went Tory. Soon Blairites such as trade secretary Stephen Byers joined John Prescott, a long-standing advocate of English devolution, in preaching the virtues of strong regions.

The deputy prime minister and Chancellor Gordon Brown began challenging the Downing Street line by publicly acknowledging north-south inequalities and calling for bolder initiatives to bridge the regional divide. In the spending review last July and then in autumn's pre-budget statement, Mr Brown underlined the importance of the eight regional development agencies (RDAs) created in 1999. These are the business-led quangos designed to improve the economic performance of underperforming regions. Mr Brown promised them a £500m budget increase to £1.7bn by 2003-4 and flexibility in how they spend it.

Insiders noted the emergence of a Prescott-Brown axis while Mr Prescott's aides began raising the stakes in the internal battle to commit the party to a strong regional dimension in its forthcoming manifesto. Late last year Richard Caborn, the trade minister and a close friend of Mr Prescott, told a Fabian Society meeting in York: "I believe the radical programme of constitutional change we embarked on in 1997 is incomplete without an answer to the so-called English question. Regions need a clear voice to promote economic development and that in my view is best achieved through (elected) regional assemblies".

This week, in more measured tones, Gordon Brown came close to saying much the same thing - although his message was more about creating a regionally-based American-style enterprise climate, underpinned with tax incentives and government grants, than an Old Labour subsidy culture propping up time-expired industries. The chancellor, once Labour's regional policy spokesman, knows that RDAs, for all their resources, cannot buck the global market place. But he also knows that strong regional policies north of the border over the past 30 years - latterly considerable pump-priming by a national development agency - have transformed the Scottish economy from basket case to one the brighter stars in European information technology.

Ever a politician with keen antennae, Mr Brown is well aware that south of the border passions are running high, particularly in north-east England - political home of Tony Blair, Mr Byers, and a clutch of other senior ministers. This region is one of the UK's poorest performers. Its MPs look enviously northwards at a rapidly diverging political culture, Scotland where there are no student tuition fees, the prospect of free-nursing care for the elderly, higher wages for teachers and a hands-on industrial policy pumping tens of millions annually into hi-tech industry. The less favoured regions of England are seen to be falling further behind. The voters are restless.

Speaking at the start of a pre-budget consultation in Manchester this week, Mr Brown spoke warmly of the deputy prime minister deserving congratulations for delivering the RDAs. He portrayed the regional agenda as a cornerstone of his American-style philosophy. He talked of giving the agencies new powers to foster innovation, develop skills for the 21st century economy and build an enterprise cul ture. Other ministers were also praised. Downing Street was not mentioned.

Significantly, Mr Brown entered the wider debate about English governance by saying the growing network of non-elected regional chambers, comprising councillors and businessmen, should be strengthened as a prelude to democratic assemblies. His was "a Britain of regions and nations" blessed with a new dynamism where diversity can become a source of "new energy and national strength".

Where all this leads is far from clear. Research at the centre for urban and regional development studies at Newcastle University shows a "highly uneven" pattern of public interest in regional government with the north east (closest to Scotland) registering strongest support. Perhaps this implies an incremental approach: areas that can demonstrate strong support such as the north-east and Yorkshire moving further ahead than, say, the south-east.

Battle is now being waged to commit Labour to move forward in its manifesto. Against the wishes of Downing Street, the party's policy forum last July wanted to recognise the "legitimate aspirations" of the regions. Decoded, that means referenda to test support for devolution, which would require legislation.

Mr Prescott would not disagree with pressure group calls to "create the conditions in which elected regional assemblies will be in place by consent within the next five years". This might appear over-optimistic. But, as Gordon Brown showed this week, it is no longer a pipe dream.

 Peter Hetherington is the Guardian's regional affairs editor.

peter.hetherington@theguardian.com

fields.headline: Too clever by half
fields.trailText: So those clever rich people in London village still think it's alright to call Welsh people taffy twat and sheepshagger, is it (Jewish broker told to wear Nazi uniform at work, January 30)?
fields.body:
So those clever rich people in London village still think it's alright to call Welsh people taffy twat and sheepshagger, is it (Jewish broker told to wear Nazi uniform at work, January 30)? And then they complain when their holiday homes get burnt down.
Catrin Jones
Llanllosgi, Gwynedd

How are employees of English origin described in the playful banter at Tullett & Tokyo? And what uniforms are they told to wear?
Dr Brian Stowell
Douglas, Isle of Man

Can we please have the date written in English please - the new G2 style is most confusing, especially for your many American readers.
Jack Griffiths
Worthing, W Sussex

I look forward to my bus journey to work tomorrow happy in the knowledge that I can now read Steve Bell and try the Quick Crossword without having to turn pages and ruffle feathers.
Dougie Newton
Leeds

Is there anyone with an unwanted CD of Oh Brother, Where Art Thou? - which was mysteriously missing from my copy of the Guardian some months ago - who would like to swap it for my unwanted Fatboy Slim CD (Letters, January 30)?
Rebe Cleveland
Brighton

Why does No Logo have TM in its title design (Letters, January 30)? Irony is an integral part of the politics Naomi Klein describes and advocates, so mocking the symbols of global brand based capitalism is a necessary part of the book's project.
Matthew Paterson
Birmingham 

Alan Evans
Bristol

webTitle: Letters: Britain's role in the Rwandan genocide

fields.headline: Britain's role in the Rwandan genocide
fields.trailText: I would like to correct some of the information contained in the column written by Geoffrey Robertson QC (Britain's own Holocaust shame, January 29).
fields.body:
I would like to correct some of the information contained in the column written by Geoffrey Robertson QC (Britain's own Holocaust shame, January 29). Given the subject matter - British policy towards Rwanda 1993-1994 - an exact record is necessary.

Robertson writes that it was the UN's independent inquiry of December 1999 that produced the evidence to show Britain's leading role in the security council in meetings that led to the withdrawal of the UN peacekeepers. However, this crucial information was available as long ago as December 12 1996 when I published an article in the London Review of Books, entitled The UN and Rwanda. The article was based on a leaked account, given to me, of the secret meetings of the council held while the genocide was taking place. I described Britain's role in detail in this piece.

Robertson then goes on to say that in my recent book on the genocide I "suggest" parliament was misled by ministers when Labour finally forced a debate on Rwanda. This is not strictly the case and I would suggest that a great deal of care is taken regarding the timing of events. On May 9 1994 parliament was told in a written answer that "more than 200,000 people may have perished in the recent fighting in Rwanda". This was an extraordinary statement. By now the fact that a genocide was underway was in the public domain. Oxfam had used the word genocide in a press release. And by now the estimated death toll had reached 500,000 victims, mostly killed in organised and large scale massacres. The killing of civilians had taken place nowhere near the renewed civil war. Furthermore, Labour did not "force a debate on Rwanda". On May 24 a late-night adjournment debate was held thanks only to Labour MP Tony Worthington, who told an almost empty house: "It is inconceivable that an atrocity in which half a million white people had died would not have been extensively debated in the House."

Robertson kindly asserts that the case for an inquiry into British policy is "further strengthened" by my book, A People Betrayed. It does more than "strengthen" the case, it sets out in detail the security council's record of gross error and serious miscalculation.
Linda Melvern
London linda@melvern.co.uk

webTitle: Letters: Happy days

fields.headline: Happy days
fields.trailText: I have never written to the Guardian before, but today's TV listings (January 29) was the final straw. Why does the media and Britain as a whole so relish the negative and dwell on trivial misfortune?
fields.body:
I have never written to the Guardian before, but today's TV listings (January 29) was the final straw. I do not have neighbours from hell. I have not visited a restaurant from hell. Within the last week I have made four satisfactory train journeys, so do not wish to share any miserable experiences. Do I have a charmed existence? (I think not.) Or do I concentrate more on positive events and remember the happy times. Why does the media and Britain as a whole so relish the negative and dwell on trivial misfortune?

Come on, track positives - this country is not the dreadful place some seem to think. There is lots that is good; look for it and talk about it.
Sarah Wallace
Burgess Hill, W Sussex

webTitle: Letters: Press virtues and vices

fields.headline: Press virtues and vices
fields.trailText: Roy Greenslade accuses us of acting as "a figleaf" for Richard Desmond by joining Express Newspapers' panel of independent directors (Media, January 22). We find his opinion surprising.
fields.body:
Roy Greenslade accuses us of acting as "a figleaf" for Richard Desmond by joining Express Newspapers' panel of independent directors (Media, January 22). We find his opinion surprising. A primary role of the panel is to maintain and uphold the editorial integrity of the titles. The board intends this to be so, as was made clear when the panel was brought into being, and its members fully intend to carry out this duty, independently of any pressures brought to bear from whatever source.

Seeking to uphold journalistic integrity can hardly be dubbed "a figleaf" for anything except a worthwhile cause. As old friends of Roy, and as equally committed to a free and diverse press, we rather expected he would support these aims.
Arthur Davidson QC
London 

Re Chris (Who?) Williams (Media, January 29). I worked with Chris on the Mail. His problem wasn't being too "laid-back", but being overfriendly with sub-editors and similar lowlifes, and not friendly enough (in a brown-nose, golfy sort of way) with his superiors. Such behaviour was not acceptable within the Mail's covert code of conduct, which also included in its list of deadly sins: smiling, humming, exchanging banter or appearing to be happy in your work. Good luck, Chris.
Jonathan Holborow
Croydon, Surrey

webTitle: Letters: Rights issue

fields.headline: Rights issue
fields.trailText: It is worrying that Russia's chargé d'affaires Alexander M Kramarenko appears to believe that it is "anti-Russian" to denounce - as the Guardian did recently - human rights abuses committed during Russia's military campaign in Chechnya (Letters, January 29).
fields.body:
It is worrying that Russia's chargé d'affaires Alexander M Kramarenko appears to believe that it is "anti-Russian" to denounce - as the Guardian did recently - human rights abuses committed during Russia's military campaign in Chechnya (Letters, January 29).

According to official Russian sources, the number of people detained in Chechnya runs into thousands. Many are reportedly tortured. Testimony from survivors includes accounts of systematic beatings, of the rape of men, women and children, of electric shocks and of teeth filed off. Some simply "disappear". Is it "anti-Russian" to point out that there has not yet been a single investigation into torture committed by Russian forces?
Anne Burley
Amnesty International

webTitle: Letters: Postmortem on Alder Hey

fields.headline: Postmortem on Alder Hey
fields.trailText: Have we lost our sense of proportion over the retention of organs at Alder Hey hospital (Organ horror report outcry, January 30)?
fields.body:
Have we lost our sense of proportion over the retention of organs at Alder Hey hospital (Organ horror report outcry, January 30)? Of course one feels sympathy for the parents and we must make sure that removal of organs is done sensitively and with informed consent in future.

Nevertheless, nothing will bring the children back and if, as a result of the exaggerated language used by politicians, there is a backlash against all medical research whom will it benefit? Surely we need to focus on helping the living.
Martha Blend
London

If a child goes into hospital for a life-saving operation which necessitates the removal of some body parts, why is it considered wrong not to let the parents know that they did not incinerate these parts, but forwarded them to where they could be made use of? I cannot see the problem in retaining some parts for study after an autopsy. (A child of mine did die unexpectedly and so I do not speak without experience.) The scandalous part to me to is that the saved body parts were not made use of, but stored. At least we know that scientific use was made of the parts "sold" to the drug company.
R Jameson
Dundee
RJdundee@aol.com

I think that removing organs for the furtherance of research is totally commendable. My mother-in-law suffered from Alzheimer's disease for several years. She offered her whole body. I myself now suffer from Alzheimer's disease and I have made it very clear to my family that any organs can be used for the furtherance of research which may enhance the life of another.
Susan Lawson
Manchester

Each month we have a mortality and morbidity meeting at my hospital where I work as a junior doctor. These meetings are designed to allow discussion of, and education from patient deaths in an attempt to prevent future oc currences where possible. This has of late become substantially compromised. At every recent meeting the cause of at least one death has remained ill-determined or unknown. This has obvious implications for our ability to reflect the circumstances of the death and progress patient care and safety.

Why? Because the current climate has resulted in such a state of paranoia that all but the most routine of organ removal for analysis has ceased. The release of the Alder Hey inquiry report is in line with this government's reputation of being led by, rather than leading, popular opinion - especially where emotionally charged issues such as death or the welfare of children are involved.

If we followed the example of France - where unless a "non-donor" card is carried, consent for organ donation is presumed in the event of death - much of the furore associated with organ donation would have been circumvented, the taxpayer would have been spared several million pounds of inquiry and litigation costs, and perhaps even the odd life would have been saved.
Angus Macdonald
Wadhurst, E Sussex
Angus.mac@ukonline.co.uk

In 1993 it was felt that consent was not required to utilise surgical waste. If the thymus glands had not been passed on to Aventis Pasteur, they would have been incinerated. As for the issue of selling the tissue, the Nuffield Council on Bioethics produced a report in 1995 which recommended that hospitals must be reimbursed for their administrative expenses. Whether £5-10 covers the undoubted costs of storage and transport is arguable, but certainly there is no evidence that any monies were used for anything other than the benefit of patients themselves.

Eight years on we have a new set of standards to meet. The public and government want us to regard surgical waste with as much respect as the living patient and as doctors we accept that. They also want medical advances. When doctors or any other group are judged retrospectively on the basis of current standards it is certain they will fail.
Mike Henley
www.doctorsmess.com

In August of 2000, at 5am in the morning, specialists from the intensive care unit at Alder Hey children's hospital came and took our six-month-old son to the only place in our region equipped to deal with his condition, a rare progressive neurological disorder, requiring permanent ventilation and 24-hour, one-to-one care.

For the 12 weeks he was in intensive care and the subsequent months that he has spent on a ward in Alder Hey, we can categorically state that he has received nothing but the very highest professional care, help, attention and love. We are still resident at Alder Hey, living in accommodation donated by charity. Doctors, therapists and nurses do all they can to make our life here with our son as good as it possibly can be, under the circumstances. We know that Tom is in the very best place for him.

I am sure there are hundreds if not thousands of parents who feel as grateful for the care their children received as we are. I urge you not to forget the children that need and receive daily the help and support that Alder Hey gives.
Gavin & Cathy Cross
Liverpool
gavcross@hotmail.com

webTitle: French troops in Kosovo clashes

fields.headline: French troops in Kosovo clashes
fields.standfirst: Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Hundreds of Albanians clashed with French troops in the Kosovan town of Mitrovice yesterday in some of the worst violence the divided town has seen for several months.
fields.body:
Hundreds of Albanians clashed with French troops in the Kosovan town of Mitrovice yesterday in some of the worst violence the divided town has seen for several months.

Riot troops serving with the Nato-led peacekeeping force, K-for, used stun grenades and tear gas to disperse the crowds. At least 18 people were treated for injuries.

The violence follows the killing of a 15-year-old Alban ian boy in a grenade attack in the Serb dominated north of the city on Monday.

UN officials are braced for more trouble in the run-up to the anniversary on Saturday of the murder of six Albanians in their homes by gangs of Serbs.

The protest started with a peaceful demonstration by students outside the city's municipal headquarters. As more people gathered, the crowd broke through flimsy barriers and ran past French troops towards the bridge over the River Ibar, which divides Mitrovice.

Some youths threw rocks and soldiers responded by firing tear gas and eventually using stun grenades. Two armoured vehicles were ransacked and set alight. A crowd of Serbs gathered on the other side of the river taunted the Albanians, but most of the anger was aimed at the French.

"The revolt is directed against French K-for because they don't respect international codes of human rights. All the crimes in the north have been committed in their presence, and often with their aid," said Milzim Krazniqi, a 40-year-old protester.

Away from the bridge, a French military base in a former hotel in the south of the city came under a hail of stones. Soldiers drew up in a line of armoured personnel carriers and fired stun grenades in response.

A spokesman for the UN condemned the violence, saying that protesters had refused to heed calls for calm. The head of the UN administration in Mitrovice, Tony Welch, said the cycle of violence was prompted by groups of Serbs in the north of the city intent on "testing the will of the new K-for brigade" who arrived two weeks ago.

He was referring to an incident on Saturday in which a group of Serbs shot at French troops as they intervened to protect two Albanians from being attacked. The attackers' car was traced by K-for to the Serbian national council, home of Mitrovice's Serb leadership. The building was later searched by K-for.

Mr Welch said the grenade attack might have been in retaliation for the search operation. "They know they can't go for K-for so they go for an easy target," he said, adding that more violence was expected if the dead Albanian boy's brother, who is critically ill, dies in hospital.

webTitle: Jeremy Hardy: The writing's on the wall in Iraq

fields.headline: The writing's on the wall
fields.standfirst: Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Perhaps the fact that it is the opponents of Saddam who are most vociferous in asking us to stop destroying their country explains why our government treats Iraqi refugees as hysterics, fools and liars.
fields.body:
One might be forgiven for imagining that the British government's line on Iraq is that it is a tyrannical hell-hole where the lives of Kurds and dissidents are intolerable. Well, that is the Foreign Office line. Perhaps then, Foreign Office ministers should handle asylum claims; after all, they should know more about other countries than does the Home Office. And perhaps Home Office ministers should decide whether we should inflict bombs and sanctions on other countries, because by its definition such treatment would surely be terrorism.

In any event, the two ministries should really get their stories straight, because one belabours critics of British (American) foreign policy with emotional pleas on behalf of the oppressed in Iraq, and the other says it's a dandy of a place you'd be a fool to leave. But perhaps the fact that it is the opponents of Saddam who are most vociferous in asking us to stop destroying their country explains why our government treats Iraqi refugees as hysterics, fools and liars.

Few refugees are rich or well connected people, pally with MPs from their own ethnic group or ministers who enjoy their company and wealth. We are not likely to hear an MP tell the waiting world: "As an obscure, in fact the most obscure, member of the Kurdish community in this country, it is quite natural that I should put in a word at the Home Office for some unknown refugee with no money."

So you won't have heard of a case that's just come through my fax machine. It is not unique. The appallingly callous brush-offs and humiliating interrogations inflicted on refugees are brilliantly portrayed in Kay Adshead's play, The Bogus Woman, which opens next week at the Bush Theatre in London. It is a play based on the experiences of many people, especially detainees, in which one actress, Noma Dumezweni, plays the all the characters: refugees, jailers, civil servants.

Any person who thinks that Adshead has overdramatised reality need only read the letters of refusal sent every day to asylum applicants. The one I have just seen was sent to an Iraqi Kurd three weeks ago. Try this: "You claim that following your arrest and detainment in August 1988, that you were advised against continuing to be pro-active for the IWCP (Iraqi Workers' Communist party). You continued to work for the party and were involved in writing political slogans on walls, although you were aware of the illegality of this activity. The secretary of state considers that you have expressed a fear of prosecution not persecution."

I would never seek to publicly condone writing on walls. Under our own new Terrorism Act, it might constitute "serious damage to property". So our government, like Saddam's, does not treat political graffiti as simple vandalism. In fact, under Jack Straw, perhaps we should all have a well founded fear of persecution. But one must always have a sense of proportion, and it is fair to say that opponents of Saddam are safer here than in Iraq.

I suppose a government department responsible for the Terrorism Act has to hold the line that all direct action should be dealt with severely. But I doubt whether even Jack Straw will preside over torture or summary execution. The writer of the letter has clearly amused himself with the fact that "persecution" and "prosecution" are similar words. Saddam's regime sees them as interchangeable concepts.

The official tells the applicant: "You claim that during your detention you where [sic] tortured" and "You have stated that you refused to attend your conscription to military service, as you where [sic] opposed to the beliefs of the military, in particular there [sic] attitude to Kurdistan."

In dismissing the idea that a Kurd might balk at being forced to participate in the crushing of his people, the official cites a UN handbook, saying, "A person is not a refugee if his only reason for desertion or draft evasion is his dislike of military service or fear of combat." It is shameful enough that the UN appears to endorse compulsory military service, but I doubt whether the intended meaning of the handbook is that a man who risks torture and death for refusing to fight for a tyrant against his brothers is a lily-livered coward or just not a morning person.

But that is probably the view of the Iraqi government who executed the applicant's brother when he refused military service. Nevertheless, the view of the home secretary is that: "The Iraqi security forces would only convict and sentence a person in the courts with the provision of proper jurisdiction," and that the applicant "could expect to receive a fair trial under an independent and properly constituted judiciary".

How many Iraqs are there?

comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Boycott call hits Barak's slim poll hopes

fields.headline: Boycott call hits Barak's slim poll hopes
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: A polling-day confrontation is looming in the Arab towns of northern Galilee as Israeli police plan a show of strength against the enforcers of a boycott of next Tuesday's prime ministerial election.
fields.body:
A polling-day confrontation is looming in the Arab towns of northern Galilee as Israeli police plan a show of strength against the enforcers of a boycott of next Tuesday's prime ministerial election.

The substantial deployments by security forces could prove explosive, with Israel's 1m Arab citizens determined to punish the prime minister, Ehud Barak, for the fatal police shootings of 13 protesters over a four-day spell last October.

Across Galilee Israeli Arab politicians and newspapers have campaigned for a boycott, or for the casting of blank ballots, stripping Mr Barak of a traditional support base for his Labour party.

In Umm al-Fahim, Arabeh, and Sakhnin protesters have plastered their cars with stickers proclaiming: "I will vote when the martyrs can."

They also plan to picket polling stations with posters of the dead.

"The 13 young men who were killed were Barak voters," said Samih al-Kasim, editor of the Kul-i-Arab weekly newspaper. "I think it is surreal to bury 13 young men, and then go straight off to vote for Barak."

Community leaders say 70% of eligible Arab voters may stay away, or cast blank ballots, delivering a lethal blow to Mr Barak's bid for re-election.

In 1999 the Israeli Arab vote helped propel him to a landslide victory. Now its disappearance could seal his defeat, with the prime minister trailing the hardline Likud leader, Ariel Sharon, by 20 points.

Which is why Mr Barak visited Nazareth last week in his first attempt to make amends. "I know how hard it is for you today," he told a stony-faced audience.

"But I want a mandate from you for three things: to continue the peace process, to promote equality, and to fight Sharon."

He did not apologise for the shootings, or for the jailing of hundreds of Arab protesters. For many people in the crowd, who cursed Mr Barak as a murderer, the visit was too little, too late.

For the people of Nazareth, the events of October marked a watershed, the first time in more than 20 years that an Israeli Arab demonstrator had been killed. "It was a very big shock," said Khowla Khoury, a gynaecologist who went to a protest with her sister, Nasreen Asili, a psychologist.

The sisters, both in their 40s, were separated in the crowd. "The next thing I knew I had a gun pointed at my chest," Ms Khoury remembers, and a dozen policemen and women had pinned her sister to the ground and were kicking and hitting her.

Ms Khoury emerged with red sores on her arms and legs; Ms Asili is recovering from a broken collar bone.

There was worse to come. On October 9 a Jewish mob descended on the Arab neighbourhoods with clubs and guns. When police arrived they shot dead two Arab men.

The next night the mobs attacked the home of Azmi Bishara, an Israeli Arab member of parliament. "If that can happen to a member of knesset, what can happen to a normal citizen?" Mr Bishara said.

"And second, can you imagine what would happen if a mob of 300 to 400 Arabs would attack the house of a Jewish member?"

The violence went largely unmourned by Israelis. Instead the display of solidarity by Israeli Arabs for their cousins in the West Bank and Gaza was seen as a betrayal, and has been punished by a Jewish boycott of Arab-owned shops and restaurants.

"There is no more trust in the system - it's not just a question of Barak or Sharon," said Ameer Makhoul, the director of Ittijah, a union of Arab community groups which is leading the boycott.

"The state that we expected to defend our rights as citizens behaved towards us as an enemy."

The leaders of the boycott admit their campaign has indirectly benefited Mr Sharon. But they say their willingness to help a man so widely reviled in the Arab world should be seen as a measure of their anger at Mr Barak.

Others, like Ms Khoury, favour blank ballots. "We worked for years to have the right to vote so it is important to take part," she said.

Mr Bishara said: "If after all the killing we vote for Barak, it would give a green light to the next prime minister to shoot and to do whatever he likes to use because he knows in the end the Arabs will vote for him."

webTitle: Polly Toynbee: Universal childcare?

fields.headline: So easy it's child's play
fields.standfirst: The government should pledge to introduce universal childcare. That would trounce the Tories
fields.trailText: The government should pledge to introduce universal childcare. That would trounce the Tories.
fields.body:
The cabinet was brainstorming yesterday. For two and a half hours - a long time in cabinet politics - they talked manifesto. Radical or steady-as-she-goes? Great leap forward or trudging solid step-by-step? We wait to see if it will be a bold proclamation of Labour's true values or a third way shuffle, another nervous unfocused bid for an imaginary middle England. The truth about middle England is that like everyone everywhere, it harbours a host of pluralist contradictions, hopes and fears, generosities and meannesses, depending which way the question is put. It is for politicians to offer strong leadership and clear choices, drawing out the best of impulses, rejecting the worst.

In all parties seasoned manifesto writers look back enviously to Margaret Thatcher's 1979 single pledge that was dazzlingly radical yet sublimely simple. It was the sale of council houses to their tenants. At a stroke a policy affecting relatively few voters struck a chord even among those who had never set foot in a council estate. It spoke eloquently of the best Conservative values: freedom from state servitude, upward aspiration for all, the Englishman's home as his castle, a property-owning democracy, concern for the respectable self-improving working class. It left Labour trapped in an old ideology that locked people into council housing for ever. It exposed Labour's dislike for upward mobility. A killer election-winner, Labour was toast.

Every party is now seeking their magic carpet policy - the one totemic winner that conveys the essence of an entire ideology, the very best of all they stand for. As it happens, Labour had one delivered to its doorstep this week, though the cabinet yesterday may not have recognised this jewel in its palm. It is the universal right to affordable childcare. The national childcare commission, assembled by the Day Care Trust, chaired by Harriet Harman and including rightwing Tory MP Edward Leigh, came up with proposals that would transform life for families.

"Motherhood and apple pie," said one sceptic yesterday. Just so and why not? This is the apple-pie vision. Rolling out from the poorest places first, every district will have a neighbourhood children's centre to house playgroups, mother and toddler groups, a creche, a nursery, antenatal clinics, health visitors, Sure Start programmes, after-school clubs and homework clubs for older children - a home from home with all children's services in one place. Imagine a state of the art, beautiful building as a hub for the local community where parents assemble regularly, breathing new life into community activity. Isolated mothers meet here to learn and train with New Deal advisers to find them jobs.

"Blue sky thinking is very useful," said one tentative but wistful Labour minister, keen but anxious about the cost. It would be very expensive - 8,000 centres at £10bn or more. Add to that the cost of the commission's other radical proposal - that every mother should be allowed to draw down the cost of childcare for the first three years, and either keep it to stay at home or spend it on a creche or childminder. Currently low-paid working mothers can claim up to £70 childcare a week - a sum that could be there for all to work or not. What the commission report shows -blindingly obvious to anyone who bothered to ask - is that even mothers high up the social scale (Daily Mail middle England heartland) struggle miserably with the lack of childcare, high cost and hard to find. It causes desperate anxiety to most of the 75% of mothers who now go out to work. Commissioners listened to women cry as they reported handing over tiny babies to minders they didn't trust to go back to long hours to pay their mortgages. At the same time 65% of mothers who stay at home want to work but can't find or fund the childcare. The current system where the state subsidises anyone but the mother to care for a child makes no sense: choice is all.

Childcare is the gaping hole in the cradle-to-grave welfare state. Like health and education it cannot be provided privately: at £180 a week it is way beyond most pockets. There is no other solution but public provision. For years the Tories tried to get employers and the private sector to do it, but it never worked. Left-behind Britain still thinks it is not the state's business, though Germany, France, Italy, Denmark and the others have had excellent nurseries for decades. Founding the NHS was a monumental public good -very expensive, very daring and very popular. By promising a radical expansion of the welfare state, Labour would underline its profound belief in public services for those things that the private sector cannot do.

Politically, it would trump the Tories. They plan tax incentives for marriage as their family policy. Universal children's centres would be far too expensive for them. Copying Labour spending on health and education (though for how long?), they could not pretend to follow here. A high spending, high profile promise is just what Labour needs. It would leave them floundering - and voters with a clear choice. Tiny tax incentives for marriage will look pathetic beside a mighty promise for what families really need.

Today the Institute for Fiscal Studies green budget will probably again discover the chancellor's surplus is far greater than he admits. "Surplus, what surplus?" Gordon Brown says crossly when anyone asks. But he is sitting on more than enough to pay for universal childcare. As Michael Jacobs of the Fabians wrote in these pages, we are £45bn underspent by the EU average. The government does have a national childcare strategy already spending sizeable sums, but with negligible political impact. It has no brand and no resonance, with excellent programmes but so far only for the poor. To promise a universal system for every baby and child would be a very different matter. If people don't know about Labour's childcare, that is because inheriting virtually none there is still only one childcare place (private or public) for every seven young children and after-school club places for only one in 14 school children.

Will it happen? The cabinet doesn't quite get its powerful potential. One obstacle, as ever, is stone-age David Blunkett who yesterday left Labour MPs spitting with fury when he said he opposed any further help as it might encourage young girls to have babies. Thinking he'd been misquoted, I checked, but his office was adamant: that is his fixed view. Under-fives' minister, Margaret Hodge, on the other hand, was touring the studios giving broad encouragement to children's centres - a natural extension of what she is doing. Will they see that universal childcare is the magic family policy the Tories can never match?

webTitle: Turkish police on trial for rape

fields.headline: Turkish police on trial for rape
fields.trailText: The trial of eight police officers accused of the rape and torture of a woman in custody began yesterday in south-eastern Turkey. Human rights groups see it as a key test of the government's promise to stamp out torture in custody.
fields.body:
The trial of eight police officers accused of the rape and torture of a woman in custody began yesterday in south-eastern Turkey. Human rights groups see it as a key test of the government's promise to stamp out torture in custody.

The 32-year-old woman, known by her initials, SO, was too frightened to appear in court in Diyarbakir. She says she has received threats from police, and Amnesty International believes she is in danger.

The eight police charged in the case, who are all still on active duty, were absent from the court. Three sent statements protesting their innocence.

At the request of the woman's lawyers, the judges agreed that she could give her formal statement at a later date to a court in Istanbul.

Her story makes disturbing reading. She says she was subjected to a catalogue of abuse after being arrested in Diyarbakir in November 1997 on suspicion of aiding and abetting an armed Kurdish rebel movement, the PKK.

She says she was raped by a police officer who she was able to identify when a blindfold slipped from her face. She was stripped, hung by her arms and burned with cigarettes. The police also inflicted electric shocks to her genitals and feet, she says.

The rapes continued over several days. Her lawyers say there is strong medical evidence to back her case. The indictment against the eight describes the torture but does not include the first act of rape.

SO spent more than three years in prison after being found guilty of helping the PKK and she tried to commit suicide in her cell. Now freed, she is living in the city of Izmir.

At first the governor of Diyarbakir had refused to allow the case to come to court, but a local prosecutor appealed.

Nevertheless, SO is under pressure to withdraw her allegations. Her lawyers say that even her family, concerned for their safety and embarrassed by the stigma of rape, have urged her to drop the case.

Amnesty International says the Turkish authorities have an obligation to ensure that both SO and her family are protected from intimidation.

The legal aid group in Istanbul which has taken up her case says it has received 133 complaints from women who say they have been raped or sexually abused in custody since mid-1997, but most allegations are never heard in court. More than 20 cases have now gone to the European court of human rights.

"Often the complaints are not properly investigated in Turkey, and everything is covered up," said Erin Keskin from the legal aid project. "That is why this case is rare, and important".

The Turkish government has vowed to put a stop to torture in custody. The length of prison sentences for convicted torturers has been increased and tougher regulations have been introduced outlawing the use of force during interrogation. However, human rights groups say that torture is likely to remain widespread as long as detainees can be prevented from making contact with outsiders.

webTitle: International news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Mafia arrest
fields.body:
Mafia arrest

Italian police stormed a house near Palermo yesterday and arrested Benedetto Spera, reputed right-hand man of the boss of the Sicilian Mafia.

Spera, top aide to Mafia head Bernardo Provenzano, was sentenced in absentia to life imprisonment for the killings of two anti-Mafia prosecutors in 1992. AP, Palermo

Strike for pay

Thousands of striking civil servants filled the streets of French cities yesterday to demand higher pay rises than the Socialist government is offering. The strike was not expected to affect transport in Paris, but could affect schools and hospitals. AP, Paris

Mugabe loses

Zimbabwe's supreme court yesterday struck down President Robert Mugabe's recent law forbidding any legal challenge to the results of a parliamentary election.

The opposition Movement for Democratic Change is challenging the results in 40 constituencies of the June polls on the grounds of state-sponsored violence, intimidation and fraud. Andrew Meldrum, Harare

Clock watching

The Australian state of Victoria ruled yesterday that clocks must be installed on one-armed bandits along with natural lighting to help gamblers keep a grip on reality. AP, Melbourne

webTitle: Appalling conditions in 'failing' jail laid bare

fields.headline: Appalling conditions in 'failing' jail laid bare
fields.standfirst:
Snap inspection condemns Brixton jail as filthy and dangerous

Special report: policing crime
fields.trailText: The full extent of the appalling conditions inside Britain's first "failing" jail is revealed in a report published today by the chief inspector of prisons.
fields.body:
The full extent of the appalling conditions inside Britain's first "failing" jail is revealed in a report published today by the chief inspector of prisons.

Sir David Ramsbotham says that far from making progress, standards at Brixton prison, south London, have deteriorated since his previous inspection, and included practices which were "totally unacceptable in any jail".

He says his inspection team found that the facilities for patients in the jail's healthcare centre were "without doubt the worst that we have seen anywhere in England and Wales".

The snap inspection was carried out last June, eight months after the prisons minister, Paul Boateng, had named Brixton as the first failing prison in the country. It was given a year to improve or face the threat of privatisation.

Sir David agrees that it is a failing prison but says it has been failed by everyone in the prison service - from the ministers and the prisons board who had failed to provide the necessary resources to the "too many poorly performing staff at Brixton who are failing to pull their weight in regard to their duties, or to do a day's work for a day's pay".

The management had simply allowed officers to get away with being lazy, dangerous and irresponsible.

He says that unlike every other local prison in England and Wales, at the time of his inspection Brixton had no workshops, no educational facilities which were worthy of the name, no gymnasium available to the vast majority of prisoners.

"In short," says the report, "there is virtually nothing with which to occupy prisoners in purposeful activity."

The director general of the prison service, Martin Nearey, last night acknowledged there were fundamental problems with the management of the prison, which holds up to 800 inmates.

The jail now has a new governor, its fourth in four years, and bids will be invited next month from reluctant private prison companies to take over the jail.

Brixton is already under investigation by the commission for racial equality for being "institutionally racist" but some of the findings by the chief inspector will cause even greater concern about what has been going on inside the prison.

These findings include:

 The system by which inmates contact staff in an emergency had been sabotaged by staff on more than one wing - this betrayed "a disgraceful attitude by staff towards those in their care". The excuse that the alarms were "too loud" was wholly unacceptable, he said.

 Standards in the healthcare centre were "nothing short of scandalous" - "filth and neglect there showed a breakdown in the chain of command".

 Meals were prepared in a kitchen which had been condemned by the environmental health authorities.

 An unofficial and unlawful "reflections" system of punishing prisoners was used by staff under which inmates were locked in their cells so they could "reflect" on their misdemeanours. The inspectors wondered how long this had gone on unnoticed or condoned by managers.

 Staff on suicide watch in the healthcare centre were falsifying their entries on monitoring sheets. At 2.45pm the inspection team found observations already entered for 4pm - "a despicable practice, displaying both a lack of care and worrying certainty that no manager would check the malpractice".

 Medicines were dispensed without signed prescriptions to inmates who had not been properly identified - condemned by the report as "highly dangerous and illegal".

Sir David says the inspectors were told that part of the difficulty was the shortage of staff but, although 10 of the 36 officers on A wing were on sick leave, the group still owed 140 hours to the prison in time for which they had been paid but had not worked.

Mr Narey said it had been announced in July, after Sir David's snap inspection, that Brixton would be market tested and in the meantime it had a new management team specifically appointed to quicken the pace of improvement. "There is a great deal more work to be done at Brixton," he said.

"I was as concerned as Sir David about the conditions in the healthcare centre and I have personally monitored performance in this area."

The new governor, Stephen Twinn, said yesterday there was now an education activities centre at the prison and, of the 86 recommendations in the chief inspector's report, work to tackle some 20% of them had already been implemented.

The healthcare centre is to undergo a refurbishment in April.

webTitle: Amazon tipped to cut jobs

fields.headline: Amazon tipped to cut jobs
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Amazon.com, the leading online retailer, is expected to announce imminently a cost-cutting plan which could involve significant job losses.
fields.body:
Amazon.com, the leading online retailer, is expected to announce imminently a cost-cutting plan which could involve significant job losses.

Rumours that Amazon would cut as many as 20% of its 9,000-strong worldwide workforce have spread through the company's Seattle headquarters and internet chatrooms in the past few days.

Few analysts expect the cuts to be as deep as feared, however. The company sacked 150 people a year ago, its first ever round of job cuts.

Bill Curry, a spokesman for Amazon, declined to comment before the release of fourth-quarter results last night. "We never respond to rumours about what may or may not happen," he said. The company demanded that one newswire retract a story that it had denied the job cuts.

Several Wall Street analysts expected the company to announce cost-cutting measures at the same time as lower revenues for the current year. Jeetil Patel, of Deutsche Bank Alex Brown, said Amazon needed to cut operating expenses to reach profitability by 2002. "The deeper the operat ing expense reductions, the better they will be regarded by Wall Street," he said.

Amazon could also cut certain product lines and close some of its eight distribution facilities in the US, he said. However, such retrenchment would represent a significant shift from the company's much-vaunted business model, which reinvests any funding in further expansion.

The job cuts, if announced, are expected to focus on distribution centres in the US as well as other back-office functions. Tim Albright, analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, said: "There are a lot of temporary employees whose jobs won't be around in the next six months."

Since the 150 job cuts a year ago, Amazon has reorganised one distribution centre by relocating most of the staff. Several customer service representatives have begun a drive to unionise the company.

The pressure to cut costs reflects the fact that most analysts expect Amazon's 2001 sales to be lower than the $4bn (£2.74bn) they envisaged three months ago. Some analysts have reduced this year's revenue forecasts to between $3.6bn and $3.8bn amid signs of an economic slowdown.

webTitle: Court upholds murder verdict

fields.headline: Court upholds murder verdict
fields.trailText: A South African woman sentenced to death in Botswana for murdering her best friend so she could marry the victim's husband appears almost certain to hang after an appeal court yesterday rejected claims her trial was mishandled.
fields.body:
A South African woman sentenced to death in Botswana for murdering her best friend so she could marry the victim's husband appears almost certain to hang after an appeal court yesterday rejected claims her trial was mishandled.

The court said there was "substantial evidence" that Marietta Bosch, 50, shot dead Maria Wolmarans in June 1996. While on bail awaiting trial, Bosch married Wolmarans' husband, Tienie.

"She was a wicked and despicable woman," said the appeal court president, Timothy Aguda. "The murder had been planned over a long period, no doubt as a result of jealousy and infatuation."

No date has been set for the execution but her only hope of avoiding the gallows now lies with the president, Festus Mogae, who has the power to commute her sentence.

Bosch, who has said she believes God will save her, might draw some comfort from the fact that no one has been hanged in Botswana for three years; no woman has been hanged for 30 years. About half of all death penalties in the last 10 years have been commuted.

But those pardons were granted by Mr Mogae's predecessor and the country's latest leader is a strong supporter of the death penalty. "I am a retributionist," Mr Mogae told a news conference last year.

At her appeal, Bosch's British barrister, Desmond de Silva, argued that there were grave flaws in the conduct of the original trial. Bosch admitted bringing the murder weapon into Botswana illegally but said she did it at the behest of Mrs Wolmarans's employer, Hennie Coetzee. The defence alleged that Mr Coetzee was the murderer because he wanted to cover up a financial fraud that Mrs Wolmarans was about to reveal.

But the appeal court said that Bosch had concocted an incredible and implausible story in an attempt to convince it of her innocence. The judges agreed with the original verdict that Bosch began an affair with Mr Wolmarans after her first husband was killed in a car crash, and then committed the murder so she could remarry.

webTitle: Poisonous legacy of Romanian gold rush

fields.headline: Poisonous legacy of Romanian gold rush
fields.trailText: The waiting room of the doctor's surgery in the Romanian town of Sasar, about 30 miles from the border with Ukraine, is full of villagers, most of whom complain of stomach problems. Amalia Valenas, seven, has been brought in by her mother, Maria, because she cannot keep her food down.
fields.byline: Nick Thorpe in Baia Mare, northern Romania
fields.body:
The waiting room of the doctor's surgery in the Romanian town of Sasar, about 30 miles from the border with Ukraine, is full of villagers, most of whom complain of stomach problems. Amalia Valenas, seven, has been brought in by her mother, Maria, because she cannot keep her food down.

"There are also illnesses of the digestive system, chronic stomach aches, anaemia - diverse illnesses of this kind," says Anica Strempel, the doctor.

One year ago today a lake containing waste from a gold mine burst its banks, pouring 130,000 cubic metres (about 35m gallons) of cyanide-tainted water into the river systems of central Europe.

Local villages such as Sasar have not only borne the brunt of the accident, they have paid the price for 50 years of intensive gold, lead and copper mining in the region. A north-easterly wind brings constant pollution from a huge chimney towering over the copper smelter belonging to Allied Deals Phoenix, even in the driving rain.

To add insult to injury, the municipal waste dump for Baia Mare, a city about 10 miles west of Sasar, is situated close to the village. An ever-erupting mountain of rubbish lines its roads, fields and rivers.

No detailed medical studies on the effects of the pollution in this area have been made. Dr Strempel does not link particular symptoms to cyanide poisoning specifically but says that the immune systems of local children are weak, worn down by life in a polluted environment.

Another villager, Ana Ghisa, says she has given up taking her milk, eggs, and vegetables to the market in Baia Mare because no one will buy produce from her area. She hopes the international attention that last year's accident attracted will bring funds to clean up the region.

Rain pounds the thickened surface of a lake which acts as a receptacle for waste from a local gold mine. It is perched precariously between the Sasar and Lapus rivers.

Trucks bring loads of soil to the shore which bulldozers use to reinforce the dykes holding back its poisonous contents.

The smell of bitter almonds - caused by cyanide, a chemical used in the gold extraction process - fills the air.

This year the management of Aurul, the company which owns the gold extraction works, is taking no chances. Men walk up and down the eight miles (12km) of piping which brings the cyanide solution from the processing plant in Baia Mare, checking for leaks.

Iuliu Chiorean, a director of Aurul since August, lists the measures he has taken to prevent a new accident: stronger dykes, a new retention pond and permanent supervision. But he chuckles when asked if his faith in the use of cyanide for gold mining has been shaken by last year's disaster.

"Cyanide has been used in the mines here since 1938," he says. "Without cyanide, you cannot obtain gold."

Local people do not challenge gold mining in general. But they do rail against what they say is the company's greed; Aurul, they say, uses higher and higher concentrations of cyanide to extract more gold from poor rock.

Baia Mare sits beside a gold seam which is about four miles long. One tonne of rock, however, produces less than a gram of gold.

"Aurul should be closed down until they enforce the necessary level of environmental safety," Sasar's mayor, Maxim Popovici, a former mine manager, says.

Others disagree. In a hotel lobby in Baia Mare, Les Thomas, an Australian former senior manager at Aurul, is taking a trip down memory lane.

"The media destroyed a lot of good people here," he says, declining a proper interview. "There's nothing wrong with cyanide. It's better than hydrochloric acid."

webTitle: Quarrying threat to landscape

fields.headline: Quarrying threat to landscape
fields.trailText: Environment campaigners claim today that some of England's finest landscapes are threatened by quarry operators with the legal right to dig on vast tracts of land.
fields.body:
Environment campaigners claim today that some of England's finest landscapes are threatened by quarry operators with the legal right to dig on vast tracts of land.

The Council for the Protection of Rural England says county council and national park planners are being held over a barrel by quarry owners who have permission to extract far more material than is needed for house or road building.

The CPRE says research shows that the industry has enough land banks to build more than 112m homes or 85,000 miles of motorway.

Operators can quarry 6bn tonnes of aggregates (sand, gravel and crushed rock).

"The government needs to take urgent action to reduce these land banks," said Henry Oliver, the CPRE's quarrying specialist. "They are a timebomb ticking at the heart of some of our finest landscapes."

Last week planners in the Peak District national park reached a deal to protect Stan ton moor, an ancient upland tract dotted with bronze age stone circles and other monuments. It has not satisfied local residents or eco-campaigners.

A quarrying company can extract more on the edge of the moor in return for giving up its permissions on two other sites, one close to the Nine Ladies stone circle. It has also agreed to build a road to keep traffic away from villages, and to limit lorry movements to 10 a day.

In last year's budget Gordon Brown, the chancellor, announced his intention to introduce an aggregates levy.

But Mr Oliver said ministers' good intentions to protect the countryside and communities from unnecessary quarrying could be "fatally undermined if they fail to get a grip on this problem".

 Jail sentences of up to two years and £5,000 fines are among penalties that came into force yesterday for people who endanger wildlife.

The Countryside and Rights of Way Act also allows horse riders and ramblers to use pathways more easily.
