webTitle: Arts: The Liverpool Playhouse reopens

fields.headline: Don't look back
fields.standfirst: Liverpool Playhouse is reopening after years in the doldrums. And it looks set to do great things, says  Lyn Gardner
fields.trailText: Liverpool Playhouse is reopening after years in the doldrums. And it looks set to do great things, says Lyn Gardner.
fields.body:
At Liverpool's Lime Street station I ask the way to the Playhouse. "Williamson Square," a man says cheerfully. "The Playhouse is at the heart of the city. Nice to hear it's open again."

The Playhouse may be at the heart of Liverpool, but when it finally went into liquidation in 1998 after a decade of financial problems, few imagined that it would ever open again. One of Britain's oldest repertory theatres, founded in an old music hall in 1911, was history.

Not any more. Just before Christmas, the Playhouse reopened its doors after a £1.5m EU-funded refurbishment. That was the easy part. Now the hard work begins under the direction of Jo Beddoe, a jolly but steely woman who was enticed back to Britain from New York's Theatre Workshop to head the newly created trust that brings the Playhouse and the Everyman, Liverpool's other main theatre, together under one administration.

Beddoe is no stranger to the city. She was a teacher here in the 1960s and the administrator of the Playhouse in more glorious times when Liverpool's theatres were awash with home-grown talents such as Willy Russell and Alan Bleasdale.

But she knows that the theatres cannot live on their pasts, and has appointed Robert Delamere and James Kerr, two young directors with growing national reputations, to deliver the trust's artistic ambitions. Only after she gave them their jobs did she discover that both came from Liverpool. All very auspicious - as is the talk of finding new ways of running regional theatre and attracting new audiences. One imagines that Beddoe might personally go out on to the street and drag them in if needed.

Beddoe is canny enough to know that there is far more than just her own and her associate directors' reputations riding on the success of the Playhouse and Everyman. Every major regional theatre in the country will be watching what happens in Liverpool. If she can successfully throw away the rule book, why can't others?

Already the past couple of years has thrown up intriguing new models of how regional reps can operate. In the ensemble-led companies in Newcastle and Colchester, for instance, the notion of theatres as cultural palaces has given way to a set-up where art, education and community are intimately entwined.

Coming fresh from an American theatre culture where, as she puts it, "the only thing that matters is the work", Beddoe will be resisting regional theatre's propensity to be funding-led. "Funding bodies tend to find it hard to say that the work is good or bad. But they do say, 'We're going to cut you because your marketing strategy or your audience development or your business plan isn't good enough.' "

If the Playhouse had reopened a couple of years back, one might have wondered whether, with regional theatre in such crisis, it might have been better to let the dead rest in peace and concentrate on saving those theatres still showing signs of life.

But last year's Boyden report into the state of British theatre, and Gerry Robinson's subsequent success in wresting money from the government, have changed all that. Beddoe is disappointed to discover that not all of the initial £25m will be going to the regional reps. "We had hoped it would all go to the regions. It would have given the regional theatres a chance to solve their problems and then to become lobbyists on behalf the rest of the theatre ecology.

"The danger is that if they don't put sufficient money into regional theatre, they will in effect be funding us to fail again, and if we fail then the rest of theatre - touring, small scale, new writing - will go down when we go down."

But Beddoe is not interested in playing Cassandra. She's got more important things to do, such as opening the Playhouse and Everyman seasons that include Kerr's production of Twelfth Night, Delamere's production of Playboy of the Western World and visits from top touring outfits such as Out of Joint and Shared Experience.

But if the Playhouse's success is important to regional theatre, it is crucial to the future of Liverpool. At the moment the city is in a state of complete transformation. The waterfront is receiving a £200m facelift and hotels are springing up. Just before Christmas the city's first £1m apartment was sold. The city centre population, which fell to under 3,000 in the 1990s, is on the up.

This financial buoyancy is also reflected in a cultural optimism of which the Playhouse is the most obvious symbol. A vast £25m has been spent on art galleries, the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic has received £5m in stabilisation funding, and both the city council and Northwest Arts have thrown themselves behind the new administration at the Playhouse and Everyman. Liverpool is busy preparing its bid to be European City of Culture in 2008 and an attempt is well advanced to have the city twinned with New York.

It used to be the case that the further Scousers got away from Liverpool, the more they loved the city. But Beddoe, Delamere and Kerr are a sign of the changing times. Like the Playhouse, they came back.

 Twelfth Night is at Liverpool Playhouse from tomorrow. Box office: 0151-709 4776.

webTitle: TV and Radio: Radio picks of the day

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Memories Are Made Of These | Disease Detectives | Kirsty MacColl's Cuba
fields.body:
The curious quirkiness of what the mind can recall is explored by Ian Peacock in Memories Are Made Of These (11.0am, Radio 4). Why can some people remember faces but fail to put a name to them? Professor Martin Conway of Bristol University says it's analogous to having a head full of tuning forks. If you are lucky, someone's face will set one of these forks humming and others will gradually resonate in sympathy to release the mind's associated memories. Tough, of course, if your brain is tone deaf.

Just 50 years ago Sir Richard Doll completed a statistical project which reverberates around the world to this day. In his second portrait of Disease Detectives (9.0pm, Radio 4) Jolyon Jenkins describes how, after three years' research, Doll finally established the link between smoking and lung cancer. He began by thinking it was caused by car exhausts until he realised that years of hospital records showed that non-smokers hardly ever developed the disease.

A month after the presenter's accidental death brought its hurried postponement, Kirsty MacColl's Cuba (10.0pm, Radio 2), a history of the island's music, reappears on the schedules. This introductory programme features the Buena Vista Social Club, whose recordings have so far sold more than 7 million. While researching the series MacColl was given access to virtually unheard material in the official archives, going back to the 1940s.

webTitle: Main findings of the Redfern report

fields.headline: Main findings of the Redfern report
fields.standfirst: Special report: Alder Hey hospital
fields.trailText: • Professor Dick van Velzen ordered unethical and illegal retention of all children's organs when he took up post in 1988 and falsified records and postmortem reports. He failed to catalogue organs and took away medical records when he left
fields.body:
 Professor Dick van Velzen ordered unethical and illegal retention of all children's organs when he took up post in 1988 and falsified records and postmortem reports. He failed to catalogue organs and took away medical records when he left

 Alder Hey and Liverpool University knew there were risks in appointing Professor Van Velzen but failed to supervise him

 They failed to monitor his work or follow up complaints and missed numerous chances to discipline him. Close scrutiny of his work would have revealed unethical organ retention, but it never happened

Recommendations of Redfern report and chief medical officer:
 Independent commission to oversee cataloguing and return of 105,000 organs retained by hospitals in England

 New law on informed consent

 Review of coroner's system

 Trusts to employ bereavement counsellors

 Review by the education secretary of arrangements for joint hospital/university posts

webTitle: Schwab orders staff to take Fridays off

fields.headline: Schwab orders staff to take Fridays off
fields.trailText: Charles Schwab & Co, the United States' leading discount online brokerage firm, will ask some employees to take Fridays off over the next two months as it tries to cut costs because of a drop in trading commissions.
fields.body:
Charles Schwab & Co, the United States' leading discount online brokerage firm, will ask some employees to take Fridays off over the next two months as it tries to cut costs because of a drop in trading commissions.

The firm, which has about 7.5 m brokerage accounts, will ask some of its 26,000 employees to take unpaid leave or a holiday on February 2, 16 and March 2, Schwab spokesman Dan Hubbard said.

Earlier this month, Schwab said fourth-quarter profits fell 27%, below expectations, largely due to a drop in brokerage commissions.

The move follows rival Ameritrade's announcement that it would cut 230 jobs, about 9% of its workforce.

Cost-cutting efforts have come to the fore recently in the highly competitive brokerage business as share trading has slowed across the board in the face of an economic slowdown and weak corporate profits.

Mr Hubbard did not say how many employees would be affected by the compulsory leave-taking or how much Schwab hoped to save.

The plan would not include essential or customer service staff and would not affect Schwab's service levels, he added. Branch offices dealing with the public and the online dealing service would not be affected.

"We are asking full-time and part-time domestic employees to take time off," Mr Hubbard said. "They will not be paid unless they choose to take it as vacation time."

Mr Hubbard also emphasised that the decision did not amount to permanent dismissal of employees.

The novel move is an extension of Schwab's cost-cutting plans announced last month, which included reducing travel expenses and senior staff taking pay cuts.

Schwab stock was down $1.29 at $27.29 in New York, a decline of 4.51% on the day.

Branch offices dealing with the public and the online dealing service would not be affected. "We are asking full-time and part-time domestic employees to take time off," Mr Hubbard said. "They will not be paid unless they choose to take it as vacation time." Mr Hubbard also emphasised that the decision did not amount to permanent dismissal of employees. The novel move is an extension of Schwab's cost-cutting plans announced last month, which included reducing travel expenses and senior staff taking pay cuts. webTitle: Leak reveals crisis at World Bank

fields.headline: Leak reveals crisis at World Bank
fields.trailText: The World Bank is an institution in crisis with staff living "in fear" of the organisation's autocratic boss, James Wolfensohn, according to a secret memo seen by the Guardian.
fields.body:
The World Bank is an institution in crisis with staff living "in fear" of the organisation's autocratic boss, James Wolfensohn, according to a secret memo seen by the Guardian.

At a time when the bank is coming under unprecedented criticism from leftwing protesters opposed to globalisation and rightwing Congressmen in the US demanding budget cuts, the document provides a savage indictment of the world's largest development institution.

Mr Wolfensohn went to the bank in 1995, determined to reverse its reputation for arrogance and for dictating economic reforms to governments in developing countries as a condition for loans.

But the memo accuses the former Wall Street banker of being "isolated from reality", intolerant of dissent, and quick to humiliate senior managers in front of outsiders. "The atmosphere of fear that pervades the bank is based on numerous day-to-day experiences of staff and managers in their interaction with Mr Wolfensohn," it says. "He does not practice the values and behaviours he espouses for the rest of us."

The bank, set up 55 years ago to help the post war reconstruction of Europe, is the biggest provider of cheap loans to developing countries. The money, used for infrastructure, health and education projects, is provided by the governments of industrialised countries, including £170m a year from Britain.

Mr Wolfensohn has made a point of opening the institution up to its critics in the development community. But the memo says Mr Wolfensohn does not welcome criticism from within the bank and that staff have learned not to disagree with him.

The bank is also facing a budget crisis which is putting staff jobs at risk, according to the memo. In 1997 Mr Wolfensohn promised western governments he would overhaul its management systems in return for three years of extra funding. The budget is to be reduced to 1997 levels this year, but the memo says the new management systems are not working and that staff cuts will have to made to pay for new projects personally sponsored by Mr Wolfensohn.

A bank spokeswoman said the memo was one of many received by Mr Wolfensohn on morale and was not typical of staff views. "He's a reformer, and they win friends but also make enemies."

webTitle: Time for a joined-up approach to housing asylum seekers

fields.headline: Time for a joined-up approach to housing asylum seekers
fields.standfirst: Lack of coordination between local and national agencies on housing asylum seekers is leaving refugees feeling unwelcome, isolated and vulnerable, says Deborah Garvie, policy officer for housing charity Shelter
fields.trailText: Lack of coordination between local and national agencies on housing asylum seekers is leaving refugees feeling unwelcome, isolated and vulnerable, says Deborah Garvie, policy officer for housing charity Shelter
fields.body:
People seeking asylum are among some of the most vulnerable people in our society. Often fleeing persecution and sometimes torture, they should not be placed in accommodation where they are subject to harassment or appalling conditions. Shelter believes everyone should be able to live in a home that is decent. We work to ensure that all homeless people have housing that meets their needs and does not place their health or welfare at risk.

In establishing a national service to deal with the needs of asylum seekers, the government sought to ensure that responsibility was shared by local authorities throughout the country. However, a balance must be struck between providing a national response to the needs of people who flee to this country requiring refuge and support, and the importance of planning for and providing housing at a local level.

By highlighting the appalling housing conditions of people seeking asylum in this country, Shelter has illustrated what can go wrong when local councils lose strategic control of the housing being provided for homeless people in their areas. By allowing the responsibility for housing destitute asylum seekers to fall, first, to local social services departments and then to a National Asylum Support Service, the strategic role of local housing departments in the provision of housing for homeless people has been bypassed.

Shelter has greatly welcomed the proposals in the current homes bill that local authorities will have to formulate strategies for ensuring that sufficient accommodation and support will be available for homeless people in their district. But, if such strategies are to be realistic and effective, it is essential that they are not undermined by the arrangements being made nationally.

Transporting homeless asylum seekers to provincial areas, without involving the relevant local authorities in planning for and monitoring accommodation, creates problems. Without the participation and support of local people, via councils and local agencies, asylum seekers housed in this way will be left feeling unwelcome, isolated and vulnerable.

Local involvement is particularly important when the majority of accommodation being contracted by the Home Office is from private landlords, often through sub-contracting arrangements. Owing to the ineffective regulation of private rented housing, the worst accommodation in the sector is dangerous and unhealthy. In response, a number of proactive local councils have made huge efforts in recent years to improve the standards of private rented housing in their areas.

There are examples of good practice. The best strategies have taken a two-pronged approach: encourage and work with those landlords who are interested in providing decent accommodation, and take strong action against those who ignore minimum standards. Some areas had started to reap the benefits of such approaches to the point where the worst landlords were being driven out of business.

But there is a danger that these improvements will be undermined by the new system: by sub-contracting housing from local landlords without working closely with local councils, the Home Office is in danger of providing a steady flow of occupants to the very death traps that local councils were trying to close down.

Shelter has long campaigned for the introduction of legislation requiring private landlords, and particularly those providing houses for multiple occupation, to be licensed in order to let accommodation. This would place the responsibility on landlords to inform local authorities about the dwellings they are letting, and should make it much easier for standards to be inspected and enforced. Shelter hopes to see such legislation - which has been supported by all three main parties - introduced in the next Queen's Speech.

If the Home Office is to continue to rely on private rented accommodation to house the majority of asylum seekers, it is vital that legislation to license private lettings is introduced as a matter of extreme urgency. In the meantime, Shelter would like to see an urgent and thorough review of the accommodation and support provided to asylum seekers.

webTitle: Reality check on the Tories

fields.headline: Reality check on the Tories
fields.trailText: When the Mandelson eruption subsides, the Tories will still be in serious trouble: deeply divided, far behind in the polls, an incoherent policy agenda. What will they do? What they are doing now?
fields.body:
When the Mandelson eruption subsides, the Tories will still be in serious trouble: deeply divided, far behind in the polls, an incoherent policy agenda. What will they do? What they are doing now? Attacking on three main fronts: taxation, crime and race. As this pre-election period is even more crucial than the election proper in determining public attitudes, here are three fact checks.

Taxation: William Hague's main tax message has been unequivocal: the Tories are the champions of hard-working, low or average paid people. He condemns Labour for taking 40% of their income in taxes.

Fact check: under the Tories, tax as a proportion of gross household income for the poorest fifth, rose from 27% to 39%, at the same time that it fell from 41% to 36% for the top fifth. Under Labour the tax "take" of the lowest fifth has fallen through a 10% starting rate, working family tax credits, child credits, child care allowances. Poor families will be £1,500 better off by April, 2002. But poor people without children have fallen behind.

Crime: the Tory attack concentrates on rising crime and falling police numbers. Fact check: overall crime has fallen for seven consecutive years. Burglary and car crime have dropped dramatically - burglary by 33% in the last seven years, 28% under Labour; car crime by 33% over 12 years, 20% under Labour. Violent crime has gone up for nine out of the last 10 years. Robberies have gone up even faster - by 45% in the decade, 25% under Labour.

Police numbers have fallen for six years. They are now beginning to rise, but they have little impact on crime. Remember only two out of 100 crimes end with a conviction, that is why doubling sentences has little effect. Crime prevention programmes - more secure homes and cars - have far more effect.

Race: asylum numbers and the labelling of the Met as "institutionally racist" by the Macpherson report are twin Tory targets. Remember Tory cynicism. Andrew Lansley, as Tory research director, openly enthused about the way immigration in the 1992 and 1994 elections for the European parliament "played particularly well in the tabloids and has the potential to hurt".

Could asylum be improved? Yes. Consider 2,500 refugee children not in school, poor housing, inadequate health care, interminable delays, shameful backlog, unnecessary detentions. Yet both big parties wrongly point to the Geneva convention of 1951 (when millions were displaced) for reform.

Macpherson has generated a much needed drive against racism, not just in the police. It is being rewarded, by rising ethnic trust in the police.

webTitle: Lottery board appoints leading charity director

fields.headline: Safe bet for top job
fields.standfirst: Lottery board appoints leading charity director
fields.trailText: Lottery board appoints leading charity director
fields.body:
Richard Gutch, chief executive of charity Arthritis Care and a leading light of the voluntary sector, is to become director for England of the national lottery charities board.

His appointment has been announced simultaneously with news that Timothy Hornsby, the board's chief executive, is to step down at the end of March. A replacement is expected by the end of the year.

Gutch, 54, has been with Arthritis Care since 1992, having joined from the National Council for Voluntary Organisations. Under his leadership, the charity has built a strong profile and consolidated a network of more than 600 branches and groups.

When he joins the charities board at the end of April, he will be replacing Janet Paraskeva, who left last October to become chief executive of the Law Society.

Hornsby says: "I am delighted the board has appointed someone of Richard Gutch's experience and stature." Gutch declares himself to have "long admired the capacity of the charities board to set high standards in grant making".

At 60, Hornsby has steered the board from its first days. Over six years, it has distributed more than £1.8bn to some 37,000 charities. Under a planned rebranding in April, it is to become known as the community fund.

Nigel Pittman, a secondee from the Department for Culture, Media and Sport, will act as chief executive until a new appointment is made.

webTitle: Tackling the problems that rural isolation brings

fields.headline: Missing links
fields.standfirst: John Cunningham visits a council that isn't prepared to wait for government action on tackling problems that rural isolation brings
fields.trailText: John Cunningham visits a council that isn't prepared to wait for government action on tackling problems that rural isolation brings
fields.body:
Throwing resources into an area in need of regeneration, and declaring an action zone to target health, education or the economy, is a favourite form of intervention by government. But now the idea has been pinched by a local council, boldly turned on its head, and is proceeding without any fat promises of funds to make it work.

As designated by central government, action zones tend to be in towns or cities. But in Lincolnshire, South Holland district council has unilaterally decided to make the whole isolated area adjacent to the Wash a rural action zone (Raz).

Elements of the scheme have been running for several months, but next week it will be formally launched in the main market town, Spalding. The council has invited junior environment minister Chris Mullin, hoping two of its ideas in particular will impress the government.

One is for the area's six secondary schools to form what would be the first rural equivalent of city academies. From September, a computer network and pooled teaching resources should mean that a wider range of subjects can be offered to schools where small numbers of pupils limit what is available.

Another innovation is for a "healthy village" project: consultants for Sport England are trying to find ways of building and offering a sport and recreation programme for isolated villages. In some locations, it would be geared to sedentary older people; in others, it would be designed to offer youngsters an alternative to boredom, drugs and vandalism.

South Holland reckons its projects could qualify for almost £5m of European funds over the next six years. It also wants some start-up help from Westminster. But as well as talk of pump-priming, officials are keen to use partnerships: the emphasis is on agencies, community groups and employers all pitching in.

At first, it seems surprising that South Holland has any problems at all. Only 80,000 people live here. There is a strong tradition of self-sufficiency; car ownership is very high; only 15 per thousand of the workforce are unemployed; top class companies - Geest, Marks & Spencer, Northern Foods - have food production interests here; to meet their labour needs, some factories have to bus in workers up to 80 miles from Nottinghamshire and South Yorkshire; and the farmland is highly fertile.

So what is there to gripe about? Quite a lot, according to Ivan Annibal, of Lincolnshire county council's development unit. Wage rates are 20% lower than elsewhere; the top rate for piecework in food processing is £5 an hour. There is an over-dependence on low-skill jobs in this sector (it absorbs 60% of the workforce); educational attainment in NVQ3 is 20% below the national average; there is a shortage of young people and an over-representation of the elderly (a third more than the national average); and there is no bus service for one in four parishes.

These statistics become reality a few miles east of Peterborough, which has relaunched itself as a post-industrial city, with covered shopping malls. Beyond, it's a dramatically different England: Fenland, seared by drainage dykes, but few farmhouses; huge medieval churches guarding straggling villages; and long, lonely roads with few houses beside them.

This isn't fanciful; it's a dreary, wintry workscape. Community health, social care and education teams are familiar with long distances when visiting isolated clients. South Holland has just under 100 people per sq km, compared to a nationalaverage of almost 250; there is one voluntary organisation for every 3,700 people, compared to one for every 996 in the rest of the country.

The council has decided to act on several fronts, bundling its initiatives into the action zone package. Jobs-wise, chief executive Chris Simpkins says that because local food processors use produce from all over the world, there is always a danger they could relocate. To forestall this, the locality must be prepared: employees must be reskilled and upskilled. South Holland is making a £2m bid to Europe for a training programme to support the food sector.

Some fresh local produce goes to national supermarket chains, but their influence is often far from benign. The council wants them to put something back into the commu nity and is talking to Sainsbury's about a plan to make some of its lines available via a network of existing village shops, to keep such local outlets viable. On a smaller scale, farmers whose incomes are threatened will be led down the path of diversification: South Holland wants to remain on the tourist trail long after the end of the tulip season, for which it is famous.

Other quantified targets for the next five years have a crusading ring: the council wants to increase the productivity of the workforce "to the point where local wages will have risen by 20%". It also wants to persuade the government to set up a fund for redistribution of the equivalent of 5% of fuel duty paid by local residents, to go on economic regeneration.

Such goals seem audacious. Less so, but probably more realistic, are other targets to create 500 more childcare places by 2006 - so more women can become wage earners - and to encourage 1,000 more people to do voluntary work.

Change is coming, with signs that the thraldom of agriculture is slackening. Significant numbers of couples from the south-east are retiring to the area, attracted by the low cost of living, and are pushing for public services of a quality they are used to in Essex or London.

One area where the partnership mode is working is in the pooling of resources by health and social services for care of elderly people. So far there is a modest £300,000, but it has led to a multi-disciplinary project which allows people to be cared for at home rather than automatically being sent to hospital, whenever this is appropriate.

Sheila Downey, who manages elderly care services, says the sheer remoteness of villages and hamlets, and the poor standard of some cottages where older people live, has made this a challenging task - longer journeys by care and support staff; more expenditure on home adaptations for the frail. But joint planning has made clients more satisfied, and freed up much needed hospital beds.

Other instances of change involve only one or two people with a bright idea. There is the retired policeman who runs the local victim support group in an area worried by crime in isolated villages. There is the farmer, wanting to diversify, who realised that the garden centre next door did nothing to entertain children and so set up a play centre - rare in a rural area.

Some things will be harder to solve. Part of the answer to transport problems could come through internet shopping. Home deliveries of groceries would be a boon to many village-bound customers and there is also the possibility, at least in theory, of a joint transport link for passengers and goods. But this, at the moment, is merely one of many ideas which the planners are discussing.

Right now, a winter crop of admirable intentions is being sown in this sparse bit of Lincolnshire. But the biggest force for change will be the locals raising their demands, declaring that living in a quiet part of the country need not mean existing in a backwater.

webTitle: How elderly rough sleepers lose out to youth in homelessness aid

fields.headline: Left out in the cold
fields.standfirst: Elderly rough sleepers lose out to youth in homelessness aid
fields.trailText: How elderly rough sleepers lose out to youth in homelessness aid
fields.body:
The focus on youth homelessness in the past decade has obscured the difficulties older rough sleepers face in getting off the streets. More than three times as many people over 50 as under 20 have slept rough, according to research out today.

The release of the research, commissioned by homelessness charity St Mungo's, coincides with the opening by Prince Charles of a St Mungo's hostel in London for 40 rough sleepers aged 55 and over. The charity has also launched an appeal for £2.3m to set up projects for elderly and long-term rough sleepers and heavy drinkers, as well as the refurbishment of two care homes in the capital.

It is impossible to collect reliable figures on how many older people sleep rough in Britain. However, today's research report, Our Forgotten Elders, by Maureen Crane, of Sheffield University, says that at least 834 people aged 50 and over slept rough in London between April 1999 and March 2000, compared to 224 people aged under 20 during the same period.

In addition, a one-night survey in May last year estimated that 25% of rough sleepers in London were aged over 50, while only 13% were under 25.

Compared to the general elderly population, older rough sleepers have severe unmet needs - many have physical or mental health problems - yet little or no contact with mainstream housing, health and social services, according to the report. Sleeping out in the cold and eating discarded food leads to stomach and leg ulcers, gastritis, scabies and tuberculosis.

The research suggests that many older people are reluctant to use general services for rough sleepers. While some are unaware of their location, others are fearful of staff and younger users or suspicious of the offer of help.

Researchers found that in London there were five day centres and 17 drop-in hostels for people aged 30 and under, yet there were no drop-in hostels exclusively for older people. Crane, a registered general and mental nurse, says: "You can count the number of projects for older people around the country on two hands. Since the early 1990s, the emphasis on youth homelessness has created a number of new services, which I don't say is a bad thing, but there's a need for different services for different aged people."

The research also found a lack of resettlement programmes for older people. Older residents tend to be in large hostels and to remain there for years. According to the report, only 3% of young residents surveyed had been in a hostel for more than a year, compared to 76% of older people. Many of the latter had stayed in their hostel for more than 10 years - and two had spent more than 60 years in one hostel.

Crane argues that outreach work is desperately needed for people who may have been isolated for years and become suspicious of anyone offering help.

The government's rough sleepers' unit says it gives St Mungo's £2.9m a year towards projects geared to help older people. "This is one of the biggest grants we give," says a spokeswoman, "because we recognise that the majority of rough sleepers tend to be older and St Mungo's has a history of providing a specialist service."

webTitle: Profile: Timothy Hornsby

fields.headline: Faith, jokes and charity
fields.standfirst: Profile: Timothy Hornsby Lottery's outgoing Lord Bountiful
fields.trailText: Profile: Timothy Hornsby Lottery's outgoing Lord Bountiful
fields.body:
In one of the curious and comic juxtapositionings of businesses in London, the front door of the national lottery charities board and the stage door of the Haymarket theatre are both in a tiny street near Trafalgar Square. That tall, dandyish figure hurrying along it is surely an actor on his way to a performance.

Wrong. Though Timothy Hornsby is witty enough to ad lib in a Sheridan classic, his role is Lord Bountiful, presiding over the process of deciding which voluntary organisations get lottery grants. But now, after six years as the board's chief executive, it has been announced that he will retire at 60 in March.

Behind the bon mots, barbs and rather genteel bawdy, Mr Hornsby has organised and run the machine which last year sifted around 26,000 requests, distributing £450.6m to 11,347 applicants. Figures, however, give no idea of the order that had to be created out of chaos when the scheme started in 1995; or of the controversies - and satisfactions - along the way.

They began with a Niagara of applications. Mr Hornsby recalls: "We looked at all these bloody milk crates stacked up to the ceiling and said: 'How on earth are we going to get out of this any half-decent grants in the end?'" Sir David Sieff, then board chairman, insisted that money should flow within three months - the first birthday of the lottery - or critics "would be on to us like hounds on a dying stag".

Mr Hornsby, who graduated with a first in modern history from Oxford, and spent 30 years as a civil service high-flyer, has a pride in fulfilling his brief. When the national audit office later looked at the first round of grants, it concluded that the overwhelming number had been effective. "We had a number of casualties, but it was remarkably small," he recalled. "Two or three per cent don't go into full implementation; rather like small business start-ups."

He relishes some of the "absolutely off the wall" applications for money. His favourite was a bid from an ex-nun, convinced that western Europe was going to be wiped out by an asteroid shower as divine punishment for human wickedness. Her solution - "the delivery mechanism", said Mr Hornsby, parodying the jargon - was to ask for funding to put full-page advertisements in the media telling everyone to mend their ways. She had even worked out the cost and written the text for the ad.

The charities board did not dare dismiss her application as cranky because, as he put it, "if you're a statutory body, you have a nervous twitch about judicial review". He recalled that a colleague pointed out: "If she's right, what more effective use of our money?" So they gave it a proper assessment; no grant, though.

Many more down-to-earth projects have pinned hopes on big and, critically, on-going lottery fund assistance. What about the tricky matter of the much resented three-year funding limit?

"I'd really like to see if there isn't a way of eliminating a bit of the ritual hypocrisy you're faced with," Mr Hornsby said. "People say to us: 'Three years, we'll pretty much crack this; then we'll get lots of funds from elsewhere.' But in our heart of hearts, we both know it's optimistic; we collude with each other." There is a case for 10 or 15 year grants in some instances, he reckons, but such a reform will be a campaign for his successor.

While Mr Hornsby has been on the receiving end of much tabloid ire over grants for gays and lesbians, asylum seekers and travellers, he has at least been spared the media cosh over big spending. The average charities board pay-out is £150,000 - modest compared with millions for a theatre or stadium - and the board looks for no-frills applications. "It's no good," he said, "saying to us: 'Sue, Grabbit, Ripoff and Runne have filled in our application form.'"

There was a time when Mr Hornsby regarded ministers as a bit like Sue and Co. That was in 1998 when they added the sixth good cause - the new opportunities fund (NOF), breaching (as some would see it) the principle that lottery cash should not be used as a substitute for state spending. The NOF now gets one-third of the kitty.

He still wonders if some of the health and education projects that NOF picks up should really be a government responsibility. "I think the jury's out on that," he reflected. "Some NOF schemes are the sort of things we used to fund; but some of the stuff, it seems to me, gets close to the knuckle - MRI scanners in hospitals; the training of teachers on IT."

There is also performance rivalry with sister funds for arts, heritage and sports, admits Mr Hornsby. "We normally come top in the monitoring - well, top equal with Sport England.

"They're a funny bunch in Sport England. Look at the way they were winding up every athlete in the business to look straight into camera after the Sydney Olympics. You know, you breasted the finishing tape and there was a red-hot poker up your arse. You said [Mr Hornsby gives a shriek of mock pain]: 'I am so grateful to have won the 2,000 metres. It's thanks to the - ouch - lottery.'"

It's a mandarin's mildly malicious ribbing. But he can do it: he has the finishing tape in his sights, too.

webTitle: How to break the never-ending cycle of abuse in the NHS

fields.headline: Where the buck stops
fields.standfirst: How to break the never-ending cycle of abuse in the NHS
fields.trailText: How to break the never-ending cycle of abuse in the NHS
fields.body:
There are residential dementia homes in Britain where standards are low, indifference reigns, and where we would prefer any loved relative not to be placed. Perhaps, according to the rule of thirds, one in three units falls into this category. But in how many are older patients with dementia sworn at, ridiculed as "past their sell-by date", denied normal food, deliberately left outside in cold weather, inadequately clothed, strapped on to commodes for hours, or physically assaulted?

The answer, surprisingly, is that we do not know - for two reasons. First, recent investigations have shown such practices can go on for years, without relatives, managers or other visiting staff knowing about it. Second, even when abuse does come to light, there is great variety in how it is investigated - even within the NHS. The problem can be seen conveniently as entirely to do with the unit, or even an individual; alternatively, a wide-ranging review of the trust (rarely beyond) may result. There is no national reporting system for these episodes and their investigations, so general lessons for the NHS cannot be learned.

Without data, anything said about the institutional abuse of vulnerable people in the NHS is anecdotal. But one summer, as part of an independent team reviewing one such episode, three things struck me.

The first was that nearly everyone involved, at every level of the organisation, seemed decent, honourable, hard working and kind. The second impression was of the pain caused to staff by the process of independent review. A pall of misery hung over the reviewers as well; I felt tainted. But the main impression was one of mystery. If my impression is correct that almost all NHS staff are basically kind, how does the culture in a unit develop in so deviant a way and why do remarkably similar episodes continue to happen across the country?

I now think that abuse - in the original meaning of the word as "using incorrectly or improperly" - is not just in isolated pockets in the NHS, but widespread in the service and beyond. NHS staff dealing with dementia, and perhaps others too, are at risk of abusing because they themselves are continually abused.

They are abused by being obliged to work in inadequate buildings, in inadequate numbers, with inadequate support, inadequate disciplinary boundaries, and inadequate training. They deal with patients with dreadful, progressive disorders who present emotional challenges often ignored. Working with inadequate numbers of colleagues is the worst abuse. Staff want to do their best, but they rarely can because there is no economy of scale in personal care and attention.

Who is abusing the staff? Their managers. Why? Because they are abused, too. Again, they are given huge responsibilities, inadequate support and inadequate training; task after task is piled on them by their superiors, often in a very strong, "no whinge" culture. Judged almost entirely by their budgetary control, they strive to please by constant working and reworking of "skill-mix", whittling down the number and quality of their staff.

Who is abusing the managers? Trust boards. Why? Because they are abused, too. Purchaser, regional and NHS executive imperatives pour down, each priority being piled on others. Now, impossibly, "clinical governance" joins responsibility for the quality of treatment and care to its opposite - cheapness. Trust chief executives who show a regional chief executive anything other than calm competence in the face of chaos are not destined for greatness.

Who is abusing the NHS executive? Ministers. And who is abusing them? Press and MPs. And who is buying the newspapers and voting? We are, and it is our relatives who are abused by NHS staff. Thus does the wheel of abuse turn.

Why, then, is any unit ever free of abuse? My optimism about NHS frontline staff as basically decent and well-meaning extends to all those involved in this chain, including ministers and even the press.

If all this is right, what can we do? Perhaps We are so immured in abuse we don't know when we're being abused, let alone when we are abusing others. The first step may be to speak up when we feel abused. Whingeing? Perhaps, but there are worse crimes. We should resist passing on abuse ourselves, if necessary by deceit. Subversive? Arguably, but there are worse crimes. Finally, we must praise more, vote for polite parties, and eschew abusive newspapers and TV. We won't reduce the risk of extreme collective abuse by fiddling with the system; only by increasing resistance to it.

 Alastair Macdonald is professor of old age psychiatry at Guy's, King's and St Thomas's Medical Schools, London. The original article on which this is based was published in the Journal of Dementia Care

webTitle: Reports from two forums on globalisation

fields.headline: Worlds apart
fields.standfirst: Tony Juniper in Davos and  Hilary Wainwright in Porto Alegre report on two forums on globalisation that symbolise the widening gap between rich and poor
fields.trailText: Tony Juniper in Davos and Hilary Wainwright in Porto Alegre report on two forums on globalisation that symbolise the widening gap between rich and poor
fields.body:
Wearing comedy business suits, complete with fat cigars, dark glasses and outrageous jewellery, "Franc Suisse", "Mark Deutsch" and "Dave Dollar" stride purposefully towards the barbed wire and lines of riot police. Surrounded by TV cameras, they walk straight into the security zone of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

Mingling with the chief executives of the world's biggest corporations and their invited high-level political guests, they distribute leaflets that set out alternatives to the global economy. The police finally catch on and arrest the Marx Brothers-style executives and their "lawyer". They are dragged out into the snow and questioned by policemen deeply embarrassed that their ring of steel was so easily penetrated.

The action highlights how, in Davos at least, symbols count. People wearing jeans could not get within miles of the Swiss ski resort; yet suits, even comedy ones, could march straight in. So determined were the police to block out the voices of dissent that the mighty now conduct their discussions behind police barricades that spread for miles through the valley.

As outside the halls of Davos, so inside, where the meetings were closed to the public, with just a few carefully chosen non-government groups and individuals invited to address the delegates, who were mainly male, north American and European. This year, one World Economic Forum (WEF) delegate suggested that if our world was visited by beings from outer space, then the elite gathered in Davos should be responsible for speaking for humanity. If Planet Earth had a board of directors, this would be it.

The WEF is the deeply influential international club for big business. Its past political successes include starting the Uruguay round of the Gatt, and the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta). Most of globalisation's leading players were there. Sir John Browne and Mark Moody-Stuart, of BP and Shell, rubbed shoulders with the heads of state of the main oil producing nations. Yet these architects of globalisation are clearly worried, not so much by the protesters in the street but the new ideas emerging from dozens of citizens' movements from all over the world. The comfort once found in the old ideas is crumbling, and their rhetoric of growth, markets, liberalisation and competition - still reassuringly exchanged between the executives and leading public figures - was not like in previous years.

For once, there was a real sense that globalisation is in trouble, and the "board of directors" was neither asking the right questions nor had a clue what to do.

How are the ecological limits of a finite planet to be respected in the face of policies designed to promote never ending growth? How is the widening gap between rich and poor to be closed when many of the signals that companies respond to are designed to reward greed? How can the needs of the 10bn people who may inhabit this world in 2050 be met without drastic changes to consumption patterns? These and other critical questions were not on the Davos agenda.

Only Public Eye, a non-governmental group not invited to participate in the main meeting, had any answers. Hiring an asthma clinic and staging debates on trade liberalisation, corporate control and financial policy, its panels and workshops were open, and the clear message was that a new alternative economics is crystalising from the global NGO networking. It has at its core sustainable development, environmental protection and social justice. It is, people confirmed, gathering momentum in all places.

Witness Porto Alegre, 5,000 miles away in the radical capital of Rio Grande do Sul, southern Brazil. Here, running concurrently with Davos, 12,000 people were last weekend meeting for the first Social Forum. If Davos was for the elite only, this meeting of 12,000 people, of all ages and from 120 countries, was the opposite. Gathering in vast lecture halls of the Catholic University, their debate was passionate and pointed. There was a tangible sense of an emerging global movement, with a striking diversity of age, political traditions, practical experience and cultural background.

The Porto Alegre event came at a time when the institutions of the global market face a crisis of legitimacy. The Seattle, Washington and Prague protests have triggered it by drawing public attention to organisations that have long been just bewildering initials - such as IMF, WTO, Gatt and Nafta - and to the corporations that drive them, and to the unaccountability of the politicians who go to their meetings.

It is the economic reality, and its devastating social and ecological con sequences makes the more far-sighted members of the global elite uneasy. At Porto Alegre, the reality of how most of the world must live was presented with angry passion by the very people who are suffering it.

Trevor Inguane, part of the South African delegation, reinforced a constant theme of the conference: that the levels of inequality and injustice are continuing to rise, and it just has to stop. He gave the latest UN figures. The 20% at the top end of the global income scale earn 86 times more than the 20% at the lower end. In 1997, the figure was 74; in the 1960s, it was 30.

Similarly shocking figures on trade were presented. As forecast, world trade has expanded rapidly: it is now 17 times greater than 50 years ago. But, over that period, Latin America's share of world trade has gone down from 11% to 5% and Africa's from 8% to 2%. No wonder there was such contempt in the many workshops and huge plenaries of this social forum for the mantras coming from Davos that economic growth will eliminate poverty.

Where the elite talked to the elite in Davos and danced the night away in clubs, the anger at Porto Alegre was channelled into practical organisation. Apart from exchanging information about local alternatives and how to work collectively on trade, financial institutions and sustainable production, the many movements there - such as Via Campesina, the international movement of peasant and small farmers movement, and CUT, the giant radical Brazilian trade union federation - were already planning their next actions.

Their presence will be felt this year at Quebec for negotiations over Nafta, and at the G8 summit in Genoa.

Most dramatically, "the long march" - from the Brazilian city of São Paulo to "the wall of death" separating Mexico from the US - was being planned for 2003. More people have been shot trying to enter the US at this frontier than died attempting to get through the wall dividing Berlin. "We take their goods but they don't like our people so we are taking our people to them ourselves," says one of the organisers of the march.

Some solutions were close at hand. Porto Alegre, an industrial port, is a working example of what can be achieved. The radical Brazilian Workers Party has governed the city for 12 years through a sophisticated and deeply-rooted participatory process based on neighbourhood assemblies. These decide priorities and elect delegates who must apply city-wide criteria to draw up a budget, finally agreed upon by the municipality.

They have rid the city of corruption, led to a redistribution of wealth and earned the city a UN Habitat prize for the best governed city of the world. It is just one working pointer to "another world" in the proclamation of the forum.

&#149Tony Juniper is campaigns director of Friends of the Earth, UK. Hilary Wainwright is editor of Red Pepper magazine.

People wearing jeans could not get within miles of the Swiss ski resort; yet suits, even comedy ones, could march straight in. So determined were the police to block out the voices of dissent that the mighty now conduct their discussions behind police barricades that spread for miles through the valley. As outside the halls of Davos, so inside, where the meetings were closed to the public, with just a few carefully chosen non-government groups and individuals invited to address the delegates, who were mainly male, north American and European. This year, one World Economic Forum (WEF) delegate suggested that if our world was visited by beings from outer space, then the elite gathered in Davos should be responsible for speaking for humanity. If Planet Earth had a board of directors, this would be it. The WEF is the deeply influential international club for big business. Its past political successes include starting the Uruguay round of the Gatt, and the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta). Most of globalisation's leading players were there. Sir John Browne and Mark Moody-Stuart, of BP and Shell, rubbed shoulders with the heads of state of the main oil producing nations. Yet these architects of globalisation are clearly worried, not so much by the protesters in the street but the new ideas emerging from dozens of citizens' movements from all over the world. The comfort once found in the old ideas is crumbling, and their rhetoric of growth, markets, liberalisation and competition - still reassuringly exchanged between the executives and leading public figures - was not like in previous years. For once, there was a real sense that globalisation is in trouble, and the "board of directors" was neither asking the right questions nor had a clue what to do. How are the ecological limits of a finite planet to be respected in the face of policies designed to promote never ending growth? How is the widening gap between rich and poor to be closed when many of the signals that companies respond to are designed to reward greed? How can the needs of the 10bn people who may inhabit this world in 2050 be met without drastic changes to consumption patterns? These and other critical questions were not on the Davos agenda. Only Public Eye, a non-governmental group not invited to participate in the main meeting, had any answers. Hiring an asthma clinic and staging debates on trade liberalisation, corporate control and financial policy, its panels and workshops were open, and the clear message was that a new alternative economics is crystalising from the global NGO networking. It has at its core sustainable development, environmental protection and social justice. It is, people confirmed, gathering momentum in all places. Witness Porto Alegre, 5,000 miles away in the radical capital of Rio Grande do Sul, southern Brazil. Here, running concurrently with Davos, 12,000 people were last weekend meeting for the first Social Forum. If Davos was for the elite only, this meeting of 12,000 people, of all ages and from 120 countries, was the opposite. Gathering in vast lecture halls of the Catholic University, their debate was passionate and pointed. There was a tangible sense of an emerging global movement, with a striking diversity of age, political traditions, practical experience and cultural background. The Porto Alegre event came at a time when the institutions of the global market face a crisis of legitimacy. The Seattle, Washington and Prague protests have triggered it by drawing public attention to organisations that have long been just bewildering initials - such as IMF, WTO, Gatt and Nafta - and to the corporations that drive them, and to the unaccountability of the politicians who go to their meetings. It is the economic reality, and its devastating social and ecological con sequences makes the more far-sighted members of the global elite uneasy. At Porto Alegre, the reality of how most of the world must live was presented with angry passion by the very people who are suffering it. Trevor Inguane, part of the South African delegation, reinforced a constant theme of the conference: that the levels of inequality and injustice are continuing to rise, and it just has to stop. He gave the latest UN figures. The 20% at the top end of the global income scale earn 86 times more than the 20% at the lower end. In 1997, the figure was 74; in the 1960s, it was 30. Similarly shocking figures on trade were presented. As forecast, world trade has expanded rapidly: it is now 17 times greater than 50 years ago. But, over that period, Latin America's share of world trade has gone down from 11% to 5% and Africa's from 8% to 2%. No wonder there was such contempt in the many workshops and huge plenaries of this social forum for the mantras coming from Davos that economic growth will eliminate poverty. Where the elite talked to the elite in Davos and danced the night away in clubs, the anger at Porto Alegre was channelled into practical organisation. Apart from exchanging information about local alternatives and how to work collectively on trade, financial institutions and sustainable production, the many movements there - such as Via Campesina, the international movement of peasant and small farmers movement, and CUT, the giant radical Brazilian trade union federation - were already planning their next actions. Their presence will be felt this year at Quebec for negotiations over Nafta, and at the G8 summit in Genoa. Most dramatically, "the long march" - from the Brazilian city of São Paulo to "the wall of death" separating Mexico from the US - was being planned for 2003. More people have been shot trying to enter the US at this frontier than died attempting to get through the wall dividing Berlin. "We take their goods but they don't like our people so we are taking our people to them ourselves," says one of the organisers of the march. Some solutions were close at hand. Porto Alegre, an industrial port, is a working example of what can be achieved. The radical Brazilian Workers Party has governed the city for 12 years through a sophisticated and deeply-rooted participatory process based on neighbourhood assemblies. These decide priorities and elect delegates who must apply city-wide criteria to draw up a budget, finally agreed upon by the municipality. They have rid the city of corruption, led to a redistribution of wealth and earned the city a UN Habitat prize for the best governed city of the world. It is just one working pointer to "another world" in the proclamation of the forum. •Tony Juniper is campaigns director of Friends of the Earth, UK. Hilary Wainwright is editor of Red Pepper magazine.

webTitle: How to break the never-ending cycle of abuse in the NHS

fields.headline: Where the buck stops
fields.standfirst: How to break the never-ending cycle of abuse in the NHS
fields.trailText: How to break the never-ending cycle of abuse in the NHS
fields.body:
There are residential dementia homes in Britain where standards are low, indifference reigns, and where we would prefer any loved relative not to be placed. Perhaps, according to the rule of thirds, one in three units falls into this category. But in how many are older patients with dementia sworn at, ridiculed as "past their sell-by date", denied normal food, deliberately left outside in cold weather, inadequately clothed, strapped on to commodes for hours, or physically assaulted?

The answer, surprisingly, is that we do not know - for two reasons. First, recent investigations have shown such practices can go on for years, without relatives, managers or other visiting staff knowing about it. Second, even when abuse does come to light, there is great variety in how it is investigated - even within the NHS. The problem can be seen conveniently as entirely to do with the unit, or even an individual; alternatively, a wide-ranging review of the trust (rarely beyond) may result. There is no national reporting system for these episodes and their investigations, so general lessons for the NHS cannot be learned.

Without data, anything said about the institutional abuse of vulnerable people in the NHS is anecdotal. But one summer, as part of an independent team reviewing one such episode, three things struck me.

The first was that nearly everyone involved, at every level of the organisation, seemed decent, honourable, hard working and kind. The second impression was of the pain caused to staff by the process of independent review. A pall of misery hung over the reviewers as well; I felt tainted. But the main impression was one of mystery. If my impression is correct that almost all NHS staff are basically kind, how does the culture in a unit develop in so deviant a way and why do remarkably similar episodes continue to happen across the country?

I now think that abuse - in the original meaning of the word as "using incorrectly or improperly" - is not just in isolated pockets in the NHS, but widespread in the service and beyond. NHS staff dealing with dementia, and perhaps others too, are at risk of abusing because they themselves are continually abused.

They are abused by being obliged to work in inadequate buildings, in inadequate numbers, with inadequate support, inadequate disciplinary boundaries, and inadequate training. They deal with patients with dreadful, progressive disorders who present emotional challenges often ignored. Working with inadequate numbers of colleagues is the worst abuse. Staff want to do their best, but they rarely can because there is no economy of scale in personal care and attention.

Who is abusing the staff? Their managers. Why? Because they are abused, too. Again, they are given huge responsibilities, inadequate support and inadequate training; task after task is piled on them by their superiors, often in a very strong, "no whinge" culture. Judged almost entirely by their budgetary control, they strive to please by constant working and reworking of "skill-mix", whittling down the number and quality of their staff.

Who is abusing the managers? Trust boards. Why? Because they are abused, too. Purchaser, regional and NHS executive imperatives pour down, each priority being piled on others. Now, impossibly, "clinical governance" joins responsibility for the quality of treatment and care to its opposite - cheapness. Trust chief executives who show a regional chief executive anything other than calm competence in the face of chaos are not destined for greatness.

Who is abusing the NHS executive? Ministers. And who is abusing them? Press and MPs. And who is buying the newspapers and voting? We are, and it is our relatives who are abused by NHS staff. Thus does the wheel of abuse turn.

Why, then, is any unit ever free of abuse? My optimism about NHS frontline staff as basically decent and well-meaning extends to all those involved in this chain, including ministers and even the press.

If all this is right, what can we do? Perhaps We are so immured in abuse we don't know when we're being abused, let alone when we are abusing others. The first step may be to speak up when we feel abused. Whingeing? Perhaps, but there are worse crimes. We should resist passing on abuse ourselves, if necessary by deceit. Subversive? Arguably, but there are worse crimes. Finally, we must praise more, vote for polite parties, and eschew abusive newspapers and TV. We won't reduce the risk of extreme collective abuse by fiddling with the system; only by increasing resistance to it.

Alastair Macdonald is professor of old age psychiatry at Guy's, King's and St Thomas's Medical Schools, London. The original article on which this is based was published in the Journal of Dementia Care (www.dementia.careinfo.org)

webTitle: NHS conduct procedures pass key test

fields.headline: Rights verdict
fields.standfirst: NHS conduct procedures pass key test
fields.trailText: NHS conduct procedures pass key test
fields.body:
A threat of imminent disciplinary chaos throughout the nursing and medical professions has been lifted by a judgment in the Scottish Court of Session, giving a not quite clean bill of health to procedures followed by the nurses' regulatory body, the UKCC.

But the decision is certain to have far-reaching implications for the way nurses, doctors and others are treated when allegations are made against them.

The case involved a complaint that the United Kingdom Central Council for Nursing, Midwifery and Health Visiting was acting as investigator, prosecutor, judge and jury in its handling of allegations of professional misconduct.

The Royal College of Nursing petitioned the Scottish courts for a judicial review to test whether this infringed Article 6 of the Human Rights Act guaranteeing the opportunity of a fair trial. The UKCC froze disciplinary action against other nurses in Scotland until the outcome was known.

If the RCN had won the case outright, there is little doubt that the disciplinary bodies in every other part of the UK health service would have felt obliged to suspend hearings pending clarification in the courts of appeal.

Lord Mackay of Drumadoon heard the evidence in the Scottish outer sessions in the week before Christmas and delivered his judgment last Thursday.

He said the UKCC procedure was not an infringement of the right to a fair trial because a nurse who was disciplined by the council's professional conduct committee could appeal to the court of session in Scotland or the high court in England, Wales and Northern Ireland. That meant that no nurse could be struck off the professional register without the opportunity of a fair trial (at appeal).

But Lord Mackay said his conclusion would have been different if he had been required to decide whether the UKCC part of the procedure gave nurses adequate protection. The council's professional conduct committee did not constitute an independent and impartial tribunal, meeting all the requirements of Article 6(1) of the Human Rights Act, when viewed on its own (without consideration of the appeal process).

The test case was brought by the RCN on behalf of Marguerite Tehrani, a nurse charged with misconduct for failing to be in attendance at a nursing home she was in charge of in Scotland for a minimum of 35 hours a week and for failing to maintain adequate staffing levels. She denies misconduct and the judge will on Friday consider further procedure .

Tom Bolger, RCN assistant general secretary, says: "It is now important that the UKCC reviews its procedures as a matter of urgency in the light of the judge's observations. We must ensure that patients are put first and properly protected, while ensuring that nurses are treated fairly."

A spokeswomen says the RCN will be looking for separation of the UKCC's investigatory and adjudicatory systems.

Sue Norman, UKCC chief executive, says she is pleased with the outcome of the case. "Our priority now is to rearrange the postponed hearings in Scotland in order to meet our obligations both to the public, whom we protect, and to practitioners, for whom we ensure fair treatment. We will study very carefully, and as a matter of urgency, the judge's observations."

webTitle: Front...to back

fields.headline: Front...to back
fields.trailText:
Sex in the city
Research has shown that pigeons living in cities have seven times more sex than their countryside counterparts but live only a fifth as long.
Birmingham Evening Mail, 13.1.01 (David Spilsbury, Birmingham)
fields.body:
Sex in the city
Research has shown that pigeons living in cities have seven times more sex than their countryside counterparts but live only a fifth as long.
Birmingham Evening Mail, 13.1.01 (David Spilsbury, Birmingham)

Fighting talk
A group set up to tackle sexism in the Scottish fire service is considering ditching the title 'firefighter' as it is deemed to be too aggressive.
Sunday Independent, 14.1.01 (L Peters, Cullompton)

Hard evidence
A dealer in pornographic films has been ordered to pay nearly £6,000 in fines and costs because the hard-core videos sold at his shops in York and Grimsby were not blue enough.
Manchester Metro, 19.1.01 (R Bladen, Stockport)

Lotta bottles
A man from Hambledon, Hampshire, has built an extension to his house so he can store his collection of 3,100 whisky bottles.
Sunday Independent, 14.1.01 (Hetty Fletcher, Budleigh Salterton)

Dying trade
A pub in Liverpool has become the second one in the same street to be converted into a funeral parlour.
Liverpool Echo, 11.1.01 (S Yates, Liverpool)

Now the good news . . .
A 45-year-old woman gave birth 30 minutes after being taken into a Blackburn hospital for investigations into what was thought to be an ovarian cyst.
Lancashire Evening Telegraph, 10.1.01 (Peter Tapper, Burnley)

Supermarket sweep
A special bus service laid on to take villagers from Wilsford, Lincolnshire to stores in Grantham allows them only 16 minutes to do their shopping.
Shropshire Star, 13.1.01 (JR Simblet, Shrewsbury)

Spot of luck
The spotlight from a police helicopter was used to guide a man to safety after he had become stranded in a flooded meadow in Hermingford Abbots, Cambridgeshire, while on his way home from the pub.
Southern Daily Echo, 16.1.01 (John Hobbs, Southampton)

Something borrowed?
A man accused of stealing a wedding dress for his bride-to-be was arrested after the proprietor of the shop in Totnes, Devon, recognised the gown on their wedding photograph in the local newspaper.
Plymouth Evening Herald, 9.1.01 (D Brown, Yelverton)

Holy cost
Traders in the centre of Barnsley, Yorkshire, claim that custom drops when a street preacher delivers her regular Wednesday lunchtime sermons.
Yorkshire Post, 15.1.01 (John Rossington, Bradford)

Abominable risk
The head of an adventure travel company in Wells, Somerset, is insuring customers trekking in the Himalayas against the possibility of attack by a yeti.
Western Morning News, 19.1.01 (Jack Luttman, Kingsbridge)

Mighty mouse
A 91-year-old Midlands pensioner who thought she had mice in her attic discovered that a squatter had been living up there for nine months.
Birmingham Evening Mail, 12.1.01 (Simon Briggs, Warley)

Fair point
Conwy council in north Wales has decided that the motto Tegwch i bawb (Fairness for all) should appear only in Welsh on its new coat of arms, despite criticism that it is unfair to English speakers.
East Anglian Daily Times, 15.1.01 (John White, Clacton-on-Sea)

Kitnabbed
A constable asked to model some soccer kit to help try to trace the owners of a bag full of gear found in Ferring, Sussex, recognised it as belonging to the local team he plays for.
Shoreham, Lancing and Steyning Guardian, 12.1.01 (E Leslie, Shoreham-by-Sea)

webTitle: Profile: Timothy Hornsby

fields.headline: Faith, jokes and charity
fields.standfirst: Profile: Timothy Hornsby Lottery's outgoing Lord Bountiful
fields.trailText: Profile: Timothy Hornsby Lottery's outgoing Lord Bountiful
fields.body:
In one of the curious and comic juxtapositionings of businesses in London, the front door of the national lottery charities board and the stage door of the Haymarket theatre are both in a tiny street near Trafalgar Square. That tall, dandyish figure hurrying along it is surely an actor on his way to a performance.

Wrong. Though Timothy Hornsby is witty enough to ad lib in a Sheridan classic, his role is Lord Bountiful, presiding over the process of deciding which voluntary organisations get lottery grants. But now, after six years as the board's chief executive, it has been announced that he will retire at 60 in March.

Behind the bon mots, barbs and rather genteel bawdy, Hornsby has organised and run the machine which last year sifted around 26,000 requests, distributing £450.6m to 11,347 applicants. Figures, however, give no idea of the order that had to be created out of chaos when the scheme started in 1995; or of the controversies - and satisfactions - along the way.

They began with a Niagara of applications. Hornsby recalls: "We looked at all these bloody milk crates stacked up to the ceiling and said: 'How on earth are we going to get out of this any half-decent grants in the end?'" Sir David Sieff, then board chairman, insisted that money should flow within three months - the first birthday of the lottery - or critics "would be on to us like hounds on a dying stag".

Hornsby, who graduated with a first in modern history from Oxford, and spent 30 years as a civil service high-flyer, has a pride in fulfilling his brief. When the national audit office later looked at the first round of grants, it concluded that the overwhelming number had been effective. "We had a number of casualties, but it was remarkably small," he recalls. "Two or three per cent don't go into full implementa tion; rather like small business start-ups."

He relishes some of the "absolutely off the wall" applications for money. His favourite was a bid from an ex-nun, convinced that western Europe was going to be wiped out by an asteroid shower as divine punishment for human wickedness. Her solution - "the delivery mechanism", says Hornsby, parodying the jargon - was to ask for funding to put full-page advertisements in the media telling everyone to mend their ways. She had even worked out the cost and written the text for the ad.

The charities board did not dare dismiss her application as cranky because, as he puts it, "if you're a statutory body, you have a nervous twitch about judicial review". He recalls that a colleague pointed out: "If she's right, what more effective use of our money?" So they gave it a proper assessment; no grant, though.

Many more down-to-earth projects have pinned hopes on big and, critically, on-going lottery fund assistance. What about the tricky matter of the much resented three-year funding limit?

"I'd really like to see if there isn't a way of eliminating a bit of the ritual hypocrisy you're faced with," Hornsby says. "People say to us: 'Three years, we'll pretty much crack this; then we'll get lots of funds from elsewhere.' But in our heart of hearts, we both know it's optimistic; we collude with each other." There is a case for 10 or 15 year grants in some instances, he reckons, but such a reform will be a campaign for his successor.

While Hornsby has been on the receiving end of much tabloid ire over grants for gays and lesbians, asylum seekers and travellers, he has at least been spared the media cosh over big spending. The average charities board pay-out is £150,000 - modest compared with millions for a theatre or stadium - and the board looks for no-frills applications. "It's no good," he says, "saying to us: 'Sue, Grabbit, Ripoff and Runne have filled in our application form.'"

There was a time when Hornsby regarded ministers as a bit like Sue and Co. That was in 1998 when they added the sixth good cause - the new opportunities fund (NOF), breaching (as some would see it) the principle that lottery cash should not be used as a substitute for state spending. The NOF now gets one-third of the kitty.

He still wonders if some of the health and education projects which NOF picks up should really be a government responsibility. "I think the jury's out on that," he reflects. "Some NOF schemes are the sort of things we used to fund; but some of the stuff, it seems to me, gets close to the knuckle - MRI scanners in hospitals; the training of teachers on IT."

fields.bodyText: In one of the curious and comic juxtapositionings of businesses in London, the front door of the national lottery charities board and the stage door of the Haymarket theatre are both in a tiny street near Trafalgar Square. That tall, dandyish figure hurrying along it is surely an actor on his way to a performance. Wrong. Though Timothy Hornsby is witty enough to ad lib in a Sheridan classic, his role is Lord Bountiful, presiding over the process of deciding which voluntary organisations get lottery grants. But now, after six years as the board's chief executive, it has been announced that he will retire at 60 in March. Behind the bon mots, barbs and rather genteel bawdy, Hornsby has organised and run the machine which last year sifted around 26,000 requests, distributing £450.6m to 11,347 applicants. Figures, however, give no idea of the order that had to be created out of chaos when the scheme started in 1995; or of the controversies - and satisfactions - along the way. They began with a Niagara of applications. Hornsby recalls: "We looked at all these bloody milk crates stacked up to the ceiling and said: 'How on earth are we going to get out of this any half-decent grants in the end?'" Sir David Sieff, then board chairman, insisted that money should flow within three months - the first birthday of the lottery - or critics "would be on to us like hounds on a dying stag". Hornsby, who graduated with a first in modern history from Oxford, and spent 30 years as a civil service high-flyer, has a pride in fulfilling his brief. When the national audit office later looked at the first round of grants, it concluded that the overwhelming number had been effective. "We had a number of casualties, but it was remarkably small," he recalls. "Two or three per cent don't go into full implementa tion; rather like small business start-ups." He relishes some of the "absolutely off the wall" applications for money. His favourite was a bid from an ex-nun, convinced that western Europe was going to be wiped out by an asteroid shower as divine punishment for human wickedness. Her solution - "the delivery mechanism", says Hornsby, parodying the jargon - was to ask for funding to put full-page advertisements in the media telling everyone to mend their ways.
