webTitle: Why it may take years to fully assess the Galapagos oil spill

fields.headline: Life in the balance
fields.standfirst: Why it may take years to fully assess the Galapagos oil spill
fields.trailText: Why it may take years to fully assess the Galapagos oil spill
fields.body:
Since the seas around the Galapagos support much of its ecosystem, both marine and terrestrial, the consequences of the oil spill are likely to be far reaching. While the spill in world terms is relatively small, the Galapagos archipelago is equally small (occupying an area similar to that of southern England). Sea birds diving through the oil will loose the ability to fly or swim. Even small amounts of oil on birds or other animals can be toxic when ingested while grooming.

Along the shores and shallow waters, life exists as a thin veneer on the volcanic rock. Seaweeds and corals can be smothered, depriving dependant organisms (crabs, molluscs, sea urchins) of a food supply, or these animals may be simply poisoned by eating the oil. The low numbers of unique species make them vulnerable; for example, there are only 400 pairs of the Galapagos lava gull.

The isolation of the Galapagos archipelago has created a natural laboratory of evolution, recognised by Charles Darwin after his visit in the 19th century. For a marine scientist, it is equally fascinating as it lies at the confluence of major ocean currents - tropical warm waters from the north, deep up-welling currents from the west, and cold Antarctic waters from the south. These last two bring in nutrients which cause plankton to grow and support a rich and diverse marine life. The land is volcanic and largely barren but supports vast numbers of birds, and other animals which depend on the sea.

I first visited the Galapagos in the aftermath of the 1982/83 El Niño event and then again during the height of the 1997/98 event. These are periodic phases of warm, clear waters when the cold water input dies away, leaving the local seas devoid of food to support the dependant Galapagos animals. Birds, sea lions and marine iguanas died of starvation. Underwater, corals died because they could not withstand the high temperatures and light intensities. Such events have been occurring for thousands of years and the animals and plants seem able to recover from such natural catastrophes.

However, the influence of man is putting an increasing additional strain on this delicate, unique ecosystem. The popularity of tourism (66,000 tourists visited in 1999) has far reaching effects. At first sight, this is well managed, with tour groups being led by trained guides along a limited number of marked trails on the islands. Much of the archipelago is a national park with restricted access.

The higher standard of living in the Galapagos, in part derived from tourism, has attracted large numbers of immigrants. Indeed, the population is now 16,000; in 1950, it was just 1,000. This has led to increased imports of plants and animals. Imported rats, dogs, cats and goats have caused havoc with the natural ecosystem, which developed in the absence of predatory and grazing mammals.

Successful attempts have been made to exterminate these on some islands and attention is being turned towards the eradication of exotic plants which are ousting native species, a far more costly exercise. Quarantine and inspection of imported cargoes is being implemented to stop this flow of alien species. Tourism alone provides limited employment, and immigrants have looked to the sea to support themselves, since most of the archipelago's land is unsuitable for agriculture.

Various species - such as the grouper fish, lobsters and, most recently, sea cucumbers - have been over-fished in the pursuit of export dollars. Fishing bans have been imposed and an illegal shark fin fishery is gradually being curbed. The value of live sharks for continuous tourist diver income is worth many times that of a one-off payment for dead shark fins.

The creation of the Galapagos marine reserve in 1999 was the result of a long struggle by many people, particularly those at the Charles Darwin Research Station, who recognised that the only way to effectively manage the reserve was with the agreement and participation of all, including the fishermen. The local small-scale fishermen actively supported the reserve concept, hoping to exclude the large, industrial fishing vessels from mainland Ecuador which are still resisting any curbing of their activities. Limited fishing for sea cucumbers and lobsters was permitted last year.

But local lobster fishermen soon exceeded their initial and extended quotas. Last December, they rioted when told to stop, destroying scientific and park offices. This temporary breakdown of local management of the Galapagos fishery has serious consequences for the future livelihood of the local population.

This oil spill has imposed yet another burden on an already stressed, delicate environment. Fortunately, it has been carried away into deeper water and is likely to be broken up before it reaches other islands with scattered impacts. The ecosystem will hopefully recover, but it will take a long time to fully understand the effects.

There is a desperate need for international funds to support the oil clean-up, and to monitor and better prepare for future disasters. Ecuador is a poor country and the organisations already working to preserve the unique Galapagos environment for future generations have very limited resources.

webTitle: Letters

fields.headline: Letters
fields.trailText: letters
fields.body:
Sinking feeling

Your article on listening to young people (Wassup with kids?, January 24) was excellent. It highlighted really good and innovative work in the area of Manchester in which I both live and work.

What I wish to highlight is the local council's blindness to the holistic needs of local communities. We operate under a government which says it is keen to see joined-up, coherent thinking across departments and initiatives. Clearly this is correct. However, approximately one mile (if that) outside the featured New Deal area is a relatively new (12 years old) local swimming pool, Gorton Tub, that the council is seeking to close at the end of March.

The pool is in a deprived area and is unique. It has sloping access which enables those with disabilities, mobility problems and the very young or frail to walk into the pool. The over-50s sessions regularly attract more than 60 people. Other facilities include a closed session for people with more profound special needs, a "parents and tots" session, aqua-fit with creche, and swimming lessons.

All I can say is that I wonder at the real meaning and intent of initiatives such as Sure Start, New Deal, healthy communities, health action zones, social inclusion and so on if Manchester city council can close such a popular and valued resource for the sake of £75,000.

Lynda Shentall
Manchester

Crisis to come

As a long time mental health survivor and former director of North-west Mind, I read with incredulity your article on the departure of Mind's chief executive (Mind's big loss, January 24).

Mind faces a huge crisis, with regional offices closed down, reputation in tatters and staff morale at the lowest levels.

I wish Judi Clements the best possible health, but let's not put a gloss on her leaving by denying the possibly terminal sickness of what used to be the leading mental health voluntary body.

David Brandon
Visiting professor of community care, Nottingham Trent University

An ill wind

As a former senior manager employed by Wakefield and Pontefract Community Health trust, I recall receiving a monthly list of the "Bradford index" absence scores for the staff I managed (Cold chills, January 24).

A cartoon was printed to the right of each department area based on these scores: a happy smiling face for an "acceptable" score and a frowning, unhappy face for a department that had had sickness absence. Senior managers delighted in following the cartoon for the chief executive's department as this always seemed to record a happy face, despite sickness absence.

In addition to the cartoon annotated lists, managers received a monthly list identifying specific staff who were failing on the index. The expectation was that managers would invoke the sickness absence policy for them.

I do not recognise the comments of Alan Davis, the trust's human resources director, that other factors were taken into account, and I would endorse the views expressed in the article that "staff are suspicious and fearful of the technique". This resulted in many instances of staff attending work when they were clearly not fit to do so and spreading illness across whole departments.

Name and address withheld

Prescription for disaster

Community pharmacists are closing down at an alarming rate, but, contrary to Alistair Yule's assertion (Letters, January 24), one of the main causes of closure in rural areas is the presence of dispensing doctors.

Doctors have a statutory right to dispense if patients live more than one mile from a pharmacy, but most patients will first have to travel to a village or town to see the doctor - often passing the community pharmacy to do so. If doctors dispense, then pharmacies are deprived of a large part of income which adds to problems of competition from large multiples or supermarkets.

Doctors do not have to invest large sums in setting up dispensaries; the local health authority funds most of this. Furthermore, doctors receive help with their computer costs and staffing and are able to buy drugs at more attractive discounts. The pharmacist also has to carry large stocks of drugs in order to dispense whatever a doctor prescribes, whereas the dispensing doctor will obviously dispense only those he has in stock.

All things considered, it seems surprising that so many pharmacies are still around to serve the public - a comprehensive review is indeed long overdue.

Tina Brindle
Stansted, Kent

Healthy relationship

You provide an excellent introduction to the new public health observatories (Open to Observation, January 24). The article, however, misquotes me in suggesting we are in any way at odds with the Office for National Statistics (ONS). The observatories are working in close partnership with the Department of Health and the ONS to solve the problems of access to information.

The article gives the impression that ONS is not being cooperative, but this is far from the truth. It revised its charging policies last year to make electronic copies of statistics more freely available. And it is working with us to find ways of providing the detailed statistical information needed for public health purposes without compromising legal and ethical constraints on confidentiality.

We are all working towards a common goal of improving health by ensuring that information on the health of the public can be made freely available.

Alison Hill
Chairman, Association of Public Health Observatories

webTitle: Reports from two forums on globalisation

fields.headline: Worlds apart
fields.standfirst: Tony Juniper in Davos and  Hilary Wainwright in Porto Alegre report on two forums on globalisation that symbolise the widening gap between rich and poor
fields.trailText: Tony Juniper in Davos and Hilary Wainwright in Porto Alegre report on two forums on globalisation that symbolise the widening gap between rich and poor
fields.body:
Wearing comedy business suits, complete with fat cigars, dark glasses and outrageous jewellery, "Franc Suisse", "Mark Deutsch" and "Dave Dollar" stride purposefully towards the barbed wire and lines of riot police. Surrounded by TV cameras, they walk straight into the security zone of the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.

Mingling with the chief executives of the world's biggest corporations and their invited high-level political guests, they distribute leaflets that set out alternatives to the global economy. The police finally catch on and arrest the Marx Brothers-style executives and their "lawyer". They are dragged out into the snow and questioned by policemen deeply embarrassed that their ring of steel was so easily penetrated.

The action highlights how, in Davos at least, symbols count. People wearing jeans could not get within miles of the Swiss ski resort; yet suits, even comedy ones, could march straight in. So determined were the police to block out the voices of dissent that the mighty now conduct their discussions behind police barricades that spread for miles through the valley.

As outside the halls of Davos, so inside, where the meetings were closed to the public, with just a few carefully chosen non-government groups and individuals invited to address the delegates, who were mainly male, north American and European. This year, one World Economic Forum (WEF) delegate suggested that if our world was visited by beings from outer space, then the elite gathered in Davos should be responsible for speaking for humanity. If Planet Earth had a board of directors, this would be it.

The WEF is the deeply influential international club for big business. Its past political successes include starting the Uruguay round of the Gatt, and the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta). Most of globalisation's leading players were there. Sir John Browne and Mark Moody-Stuart, of BP and Shell, rubbed shoul ders with the heads of state of the main oil producing nations. Yet these architects of globalisation are clearly worried, not so much by the protesters in the street but the new ideas emerging from dozens of citizens' movements from all over the world. The comfort once found in the old ideas is crumbling, and their rhetoric of growth, markets, liberalisation and competition - still reassuringly exchanged between the executives and leading public figures - was not like in previous years.

For once, there was a real sense that globalisation is in trouble, and the "board of directors" was neither asking the right questions nor had a clue what to do.

How are the ecological limits of a finite planet to be respected in the face of policies designed to promote never ending growth? How is the widening gap between rich and poor to be closed when many of the signals that companies respond to are designed to reward greed? How can the needs of the 10bn people who may inhabit this world in 2050 be met without drastic changes to consump tion patterns? These and other critical questions were not on the Davos agenda.

Only Public Eye, a non-governmental group not invited to participate in the main meeting, had any answers. Hiring an asthma clinic and staging debates on trade liberalisation, corporate control and financial policy, its panels and workshops were open, and the clear message was that a new alternative economics is crystalising from the global NGO networking. It has at its core sustainable development, environmental protection and social justice. It is, people confirmed, gathering momentum in all places.

Witness Porto Alegre, 5,000 miles away in the radical capital of Rio Grande do Sul, southern Brazil. Here, running concurrently with Davos, 12,000 people were last weekend meeting for the first Social Forum. If Davos was for the elite only, this meeting of 12,000 people, of all ages and from 120 countries, was the opposite. Gathering in vast lecture halls of the Catholic University, their debate was passionate and pointed. There was a tangible sense of an emerging global movement, with a striking diversity of age, political traditions, practical experience and cultural background.

The Porto Alegre event came at a time when the institutions of the global market face a crisis of legitimacy. The Seattle, Washington and Prague protests have triggered it by drawing public attention to organisations that have long been just bewildering initials - such as IMF, WTO, Gatt and Nafta - and to the corporations that drive them, and to the unaccountability of the politicians who go to their meetings.

It is the economic reality, and its devastating social and ecological con sequences makes the more far-sighted members of the global elite uneasy. At Porto Alegre, the reality of how most of the world must live was presented with angry passion by the very people who are suffering it.

Trevor Inguane, part of the South African delegation, reinforced a constant theme of the conference: that the levels of inequality and injustice are continuing to rise, and it just has to stop. He gave the latest UN figures. The 20% at the top end of the global income scale earn 86 times more than the 20% at the lower end. In 1997, the figure was 74; in the 1960s, it was 30.

Similarly shocking figures on trade were presented. As forecast, world trade has expanded rapidly: it is now 17 times greater than 50 years ago. But, over that period, Latin America's share of world trade has gone down from 11% to 5% and Africa's from 8% to 2%. No wonder there was such contempt in the many workshops and huge plenaries of this social forum for the mantras coming from Davos that economic growth will eliminate poverty.

Where the elite talked to the elite in Davos and danced the night away in clubs, the anger at Porto Alegre was channelled into practical organisation. Apart from exchanging information about local alternatives and how to work collectively on trade, financial institutions and sustainable production, the many movements there - such as Via Campesina, the international movement of peasant and small farmers movement, and CUT, the giant radical Brazilian trade union federation - were already planning their next actions.

Their presence will be felt this year at Quebec for negotiations over Nafta, and at the G8 summit in Genoa.

Most dramatically, "the long march" - from the Brazilian city of São Paulo to "the wall of death" separating Mexico from the US - was being planned for 2003. More people have been shot trying to enter the US at this frontier than died attempting to get through the wall dividing Berlin. "We take their goods but they don't like our people so we are taking our people to them ourselves," says one of the organisers of the march.

Some solutions were close at hand. Porto Alegre, an industrial port, is a working example of what can be achieved. The radical Brazilian Workers Party has governed the city for 12 years through a sophisticated and deeply-rooted participatory process based on neighbourhood assemblies. These decide priorities and elect delegates who must apply city-wide criteria to draw up a budget, finally agreed upon by the municipality.

They have rid the city of corruption, led to a redistribution of wealth and earned the city a UN Habitat prize for the best governed city of the world. It is just one working pointer to "another world" in the proclamation of the forum.

Tony Juniper is campaigns director of Friends of the Earth, UK. Hilary Wainwright is editor of Red Pepper magazine. Further information at www.forumsocialmundiale.com

They are dragged out into the snow and questioned by policemen deeply embarrassed that their ring of steel was so easily penetrated. The action highlights how, in Davos at least, symbols count. People wearing jeans could not get within miles of the Swiss ski resort; yet suits, even comedy ones, could march straight in. So determined were the police to block out the voices of dissent that the mighty now conduct their discussions behind police barricades that spread for miles through the valley. As outside the halls of Davos, so inside, where the meetings were closed to the public, with just a few carefully chosen non-government groups and individuals invited to address the delegates, who were mainly male, north American and European. This year, one World Economic Forum (WEF) delegate suggested that if our world was visited by beings from outer space, then the elite gathered in Davos should be responsible for speaking for humanity. If Planet Earth had a board of directors, this would be it. The WEF is the deeply influential international club for big business. Its past political successes include starting the Uruguay round of the Gatt, and the North American Free Trade Agreement (Nafta). Most of globalisation's leading players were there. Sir John Browne and Mark Moody-Stuart, of BP and Shell, rubbed shoul ders with the heads of state of the main oil producing nations. Yet these architects of globalisation are clearly worried, not so much by the protesters in the street but the new ideas emerging from dozens of citizens' movements from all over the world. The comfort once found in the old ideas is crumbling, and their rhetoric of growth, markets, liberalisation and competition - still reassuringly exchanged between the executives and leading public figures - was not like in previous years. For once, there was a real sense that globalisation is in trouble, and the "board of directors" was neither asking the right questions nor had a clue what to do. How are the ecological limits of a finite planet to be respected in the face of policies designed to promote never ending growth? How is the widening gap between rich and poor to be closed when many of the signals that companies respond to are designed to reward greed? How can the needs of the 10bn people who may inhabit this world in 2050 be met without drastic changes to consump tion patterns? These and other critical questions were not on the Davos agenda. Only Public Eye, a non-governmental group not invited to participate in the main meeting, had any answers. Hiring an asthma clinic and staging debates on trade liberalisation, corporate control and financial policy, its panels and workshops were open, and the clear message was that a new alternative economics is crystalising from the global NGO networking. It has at its core sustainable development, environmental protection and social justice. It is, people confirmed, gathering momentum in all places. Witness Porto Alegre, 5,000 miles away in the radical capital of Rio Grande do Sul, southern Brazil. Here, running concurrently with Davos, 12,000 people were last weekend meeting for the first Social Forum. If Davos was for the elite only, this meeting of 12,000 people, of all ages and from 120 countries, was the opposite. Gathering in vast lecture halls of the Catholic University, their debate was passionate and pointed. There was a tangible sense of an emerging global movement, with a striking diversity of age, political traditions, practical experience and cultural background. The Porto Alegre event came at a time when the institutions of the global market face a crisis of legitimacy. The Seattle, Washington and Prague protests have triggered it by drawing public attention to organisations that have long been just bewildering initials - such as IMF, WTO, Gatt and Nafta - and to the corporations that drive them, and to the unaccountability of the politicians who go to their meetings. It is the economic reality, and its devastating social and ecological con sequences makes the more far-sighted members of the global elite uneasy. At Porto Alegre, the reality of how most of the world must live was presented with angry passion by the very people who are suffering it. Trevor Inguane, part of the South African delegation, reinforced a constant theme of the conference: that the levels of inequality and injustice are continuing to rise, and it just has to stop. He gave the latest UN figures. The 20% at the top end of the global income scale earn 86 times more than the 20% at the lower end. In 1997, the figure was 74; in the 1960s, it was 30. Similarly shocking figures on trade were presented. As forecast, world trade has expanded rapidly: it is now 17 times greater than 50 years ago. But, over that period, Latin America's share of world trade has gone down from 11% to 5% and Africa's from 8% to 2%. No wonder there was such contempt in the many workshops and huge plenaries of this social forum for the mantras coming from Davos that economic growth will eliminate poverty. Where the elite talked to the elite in Davos and danced the night away in clubs, the anger at Porto Alegre was channelled into practical organisation. Apart from exchanging information about local alternatives and how to work collectively on trade, financial institutions and sustainable production, the many movements there - such as Via Campesina, the international movement of peasant and small farmers movement, and CUT, the giant radical Brazilian trade union federation - were already planning their next actions. Their presence will be felt this year at Quebec for negotiations over Nafta, and at the G8 summit in Genoa. Most dramatically, "the long march" - from the Brazilian city of São Paulo to "the wall of death" separating Mexico from the US - was being planned for 2003. More people have been shot trying to enter the US at this frontier than died attempting to get through the wall dividing Berlin. "We take their goods but they don't like our people so we are taking our people to them ourselves," says one of the organisers of the march. Some solutions were close at hand. Porto Alegre, an industrial port, is a working example of what can be achieved. The radical Brazilian Workers Party has governed the city for 12 years through a sophisticated and deeply-rooted participatory process based on neighbourhood assemblies. These decide priorities and elect delegates who must apply city-wide criteria to draw up a budget, finally agreed upon by the municipality. They have rid the city of corruption, led to a redistribution of wealth and earned the city a UN Habitat prize for the best governed city of the world. It is just one working pointer to "another world" in the proclamation of the forum. Tony Juniper is campaigns director of Friends of the Earth, UK. Hilary Wainwright is editor of Red Pepper magazine. Further information at www.forumsocialmundiale.com

webTitle: Lottery board appoints leading charity director

fields.headline: Safe bet for top job
fields.standfirst: Lottery board appoints leading charity director
fields.trailText: Lottery board appoints leading charity director
fields.body:
Richard Gutch, chief executive of charity Arthritis Care and a leading light of the voluntary sector, is to become director for England of the national lottery charities board.

His appointment has been announced simultaneously with news that Timothy Hornsby, the board's chief executive, is to step down at the end of March. A replacement is expected by the end of the year.

Gutch, 54, has been with Arthritis Care since 1992, having joined from the National Council for Vol untary Organisations. Under his leadership, the charity has built a strong profile and consolidated a network of more than 600 branches and groups.

When he joins the charities board at the end of April, he will be replacing Janet Paraskeva, who left last October to become chief executive of the Law Society.

Hornsby says: "I am delighted the board has appointed someone of Richard Gutch's experience and stature." Gutch declares himself to have "long admired the capacity of the charities board to set high standards in grant making".

At 60, Hornsby has steered the board from its first days. Over six years, it has distributed more than £1.8bn to some 37,000 charities. Under a planned rebranding in April, it is to become known as the community fund.

Nigel Pittman, a secondee from the Department for Culture, Media and Sport, will act as chief executive until a new appointment is made.

webTitle: The risk of gas leaks from disused mines

fields.headline: Deep concern
fields.standfirst: The mass closure of Britain's pits left many bad legacies, but none worse than the gases seeping up from disused mines.  Paul Humphries  on the need to protect people living in former pit villages
fields.trailText: The mass closure of Britain's pits left many bad legacies, but none worse than the gases seeping up from disused mines. Paul Humphries on the need to protect people living in former pit villages
fields.body:
Generations of Britain's miners knew only too well the dangers of blackdamp and firedamp, the gases which posed a constant risk of poisoning or explosion to those toiling underground. Working mines may now be almost all gone, but the threat lives on - and is coming up through the soil.

Geologists and mining experts fear that an ogre is stirring in the disused pits of this country. They warn that nowhere near enough is being done to identify where it could strike. Their expertise, they say, should be being used by local authorities to pinpoint areas at risk of gas seeping from old workings.

Christopher Noonan would still be alive if a local authority had done just that and put in place safety measures. Last month, Barnsley council admitted two breaches of health and safety regulations by not checking the risk from mine gas when work was planned near the site of a former pit. The authority was fined £20,000 at Sheffield crown court. Yorkshire Water, which contracted out the job to the council, and the council's contractors were each fined £2,500 after both admitted one breach of regulations.

Noonan, 22, suffocated as he went to the aid of his father, Stephen, who had collapsed in a trench filled with blackdamp while they were laying sewer pipes near Barnsley in 1998. Blackdamp is a heavy, suffocating mixture of nitrogen and carbon dioxide which may accumulate in abandoned mine workings. Experts found it had seeped into the trench from a disused colliery nearby. Workmates managed to haul Stephen out of the trench, but by that time Christopher had also collapsed and they were too late to save his life.

Barnsley council maintains that "at the time of the accident, the risks associated with blackdamp were not fully understood in the civil engineering profession". Since then, it says, it has taken thorough steps to amend procedures and training to ensure such an incident never happens again.

But even if Barnsley has tightened up, what about every other coalfield area? In abandoned pits across the country, almost all the pumps which prevented mines flooding have been turned off. As the water level rises, it pushes upwards the gas trapped in labyrinthine old mine workings. It may take years for the gas - firedamp or methane, as well as blackdamp - to reach the surface, possibly travelling many miles through tunnels and rock before it finds an escape route to the surface. If it breaks out in an open field, there is no problem: it disperses harmlessly into the atmosphere. But if it comes up under the foundations of a house or a factory, then there is danger.

In the Derbyshire pit village of Arkwright, this is exactly what happened in 1988. Methane, believed to be from the local colliery which had closed earlier that year, was found seeping into houses in the village. After investigations by the local council and British Coal, it was decided that so many homes were at risk from the explosive gas that the entire village should be demolished. Arkwright's school, chapel, pub and club, corner shops and almost 200 terraced houses were razed and a new village built nearby on land pronounced safe.

The previous year, a few miles from Arkwright, Don Gent had gone to bed in his detached, two-storey cottage in Sutton Scarsfield. A retired British Coal manager, he was no stranger to methane. In the early hours of the morning, he was woken by an explosion. As he opened his eyes, he saw the gable end of his cottage fall away - blown off, according to the fire service, by a build-up of methane, in the cupboard under the stairs, that had been ignited by the central heating timer switching on. Methane is so sensitive that the tiny spark generated by the electric current of a telephone ringing or a doorbell chiming, can ignite it. Gent escaped with his life, but the ensuing fire destroyed his home.

This same gas was discovered in 1980 in houses in Barnsley, where homes on The Smithies council estate were regularly evacuated. Twenty years on, methane is still triggering alarms installed in houses by the local authority. The gas has also been found on an adjacent private housing estate. In nearby Rotherham, methane has been found on Kimberworth Park, a council estate of more than 2,000 homes. There, as in Barnsley, some houses have been permanently boarded up, unsafe for human habitation.

In 1995, blackdamp claimed the life of Donald Tollett in the Northumberland village of Widdrington. He had been at his brother's furniture factory, housed in old colliery buildings at the top of a disused drift mine. One of the small, brick sheds on the edge of the site was used as a makeshift stable and Tollett had gone to feed the horse. Minutes after walking into the stable, he and his dog were dead. The gas forms in layers close to the ground. It is thought that the dog was overcome on entering the stable. Tollett probably bent down to see what was wrong and he, too, was suffocated. The horse, standing upright, was unaffected.

This fatality, and further incidents in the north-east, prompted a Commons debate during which the then environment minister, Sir Paul Beresford, told MPs that a study had been commissioned in light of the increasing threat posed by mine gas emissions. In 1996, the report was published, warning local authorities and developers of their legal duties and of what needed to be done before planning consents were granted.

Since then, however, there has been a deafening silence. As Steve Dumpleton, of the British Geological Survey (BGS), says, few councils have taken advantage of available skills in the mapping of mine gas movements. "The main task, as I see it, is to develop awareness ahead of the problems occurring," he argues. "The next step would be to map out the most likely areas and locations for gas emissions. Local authorities, property developers, construction engineers and planners should be aware of the potential hazards."

One of the few authorities to use the expertise of the BGS is Castle Morpeth, in which Widdrington lies. George Reeves, head of the engineering geology department at Newcastle University, has also been involved there. He passionately argues that the public does not know enough about the threat of mine gas. "There must be more public awareness," he says. "There is an apparent lack of national concern. We need planning maps covering every potential area for mine gas emissions. We need to pinpoint where the gas could strike next."

The health and safety executive, which brought last month's legal action against Barnsley council, is adamant that local authorities must accept the reality of the mine gas threat. Health and safety inspector Brian Arnold, who worked on the case, says councils in former coalfields have a statutory duty to assess the risk. "This problem is not going to go away and could very well escalate," he warns. "Councils should realise this and act accordingly. This is a serious health and safety matter."

With more and more pressure being placed on local authorities to use brownfield sites for development, including housing, such warnings ought to be ringing in the ears of every coalfields council. It is not only new development that is at risk: existing housing estates have been infiltrated by gas. If the experts are right, nowhere near an old mine can beassumed to be safe unless gas is tracked and workings are safely ventilated.

Protecting every home, factory, office and shopping centre in every mining area would be a mammoth task. And where would the money come from? Responsibility for mine gas has never been established. British Coal and its successor, the Coal Authority, have assisted when mine gas has caused problems, but they have acted on a "good neighbour" basis. They have never admitted responsibility and no local authority has dared take its chance in the courts to prove the issue.

When the coal industry went into sharp decline after the 1984-85 strike, one of the few silver linings for mining communities was release from the dreadful occupational hazards faced by generations of colliers. How cruel a legacy that the jobs have gone, but the hazards remain.

Real threat of an invisible killer

There are, says George Reeves, "tens of thousands" of old coal mine openings in Britain. And that's not counting abandoned underground workings in limestone, sandstone, Bath stone, copper, lead, zinc and tin - among others.

"In County Durham alone in the late 1800s, there were 400 large operating mines, ignoring all the smaller ones," Reeves says. "That gives you an idea of the scale of what we're talking about."

In the north-east, blackdamp is known as "stythe". It is a gas, odourless and colourless, produced by the natural reaction of air with coal and timber used as pit props. As well as being forced to the surface by underground flooding, it can escape from mines during severe weather when the barometric pressure drops sharply.

Householders in coalfield areas should be alert to difficulty lighting fires or cookers, problems with heating systems, breathing difficulties, dizzy spells or persistent headaches, babies experiencing distress when crawling, and sudden, unexplained deaths of pets.

David Brindle

webTitle: A new project turning foster care into a permanent solution

fields.headline: The fast track
fields.standfirst: With adoption in the news again,  Kendra Inman reports on a project turning foster care into a permanent solution
fields.trailText: With adoption in the news again, Kendra Inman reports on a project turning foster care into a permanent solution
fields.body:
When Paul was taken into care at only six weeks old, he was sent to live with a foster carer with a difference - one who agreed at the outset that if the courts decided his birth mother should give up the little boy, then she would adopt him.

The baby was placed with his carer through the Coram Family concurrent planning project, a London-based pilot scheme which sets out to ensure that young babies and children who come into care find a permanent family from the earliest possible date.

While Paul (not his real name) is busy getting to know his new carer, his birth mother has been given one last chance to win him back. If she is able to convince the court she had dealt with her problems - including drugs - which put her child at risk, she stands a chance of keeping him. If not, Paul will be adopted.

The government wants to see more children in care adopted - an increase of at least 40% by 2004-05. An adoption white paper and draft national standards, published before Christmas, called for local authorities to look harder and quickly for permanent solutions for children. The controversy over internet adoptions has further raised the stakes.

A growing number of adoption professionals believe that concurrent planning is the answer for a significant number of younger children in care. Babies in the care system can face delays of up to two years before they are adopted, or returned to live with their birth parents or with a relative. Concurrent planning sets out to minimise the number of moves children make by placing them with foster carers until the courts decide their future. If the birth parent fails to convince the courts they are able to offer their child a safe and loving home, the foster parents already caring for the child will adopt.

The approach is in its infancy in this country. The Manchester Adoption Agency was the first organisation to put a toe in the water when it opened the Goodman project - a concurrency team that made its first placement in September 1998 and has placed 11 children to date. Manchester was followed by Brighton & Hove council, which added concurrency planning in August 1999.

In the US, the approach has been used for about 15 years with children up to age eight. The London scheme, run by Coram Family, a children's charity, receives referrals from Islington and Camden social services and targets children under the age of two. So far, it has placed two boys (both born drug-dependent) and hopes to place another child shortly.

Gill Gray, project leader at Coram, says concurrent planning is driven by "attachment theory". Babies who come into care via the traditional route may live in a series of foster homes before they find an adoptive family. "Children who don't get the opportunity to make close attachments, or who have those attachments disrupted early on, can have difficulties forming relationships in later life or can develop emotional problems," she says.

Government research shows that the average time spent "looked after", before a decision is made on adoption, is 16 months. The average time from decision to placement is another seven months. Everyone agrees that this is too long for an already vulnerable child to spend in limbo.

Nina Gardner, manager of the Goodman project, says concurrency focuses the minds of all the adults involved in decision-making. While the legal processes are essentially the same as other care proceedings, decisions are made within a set time scale. Concurrency cases are heard by a judge who is familiar with the concept, and final hearing dates to determine the child's future, are usually set at the first full hearing of the case. Gardner says: "We placed a child on December 4 and we have a final hearing date of July 23."

While the child is being "fostered", staff assess the birth parents or any other member of the child's family interested in caring for the child. The assessment can last for anything from six to nine months and, during that time, the birth parents have regular contact with their child - usually three times a week. They are also offered support to help them deal with their problems, and only parents who show some hope of reforming are referred. "If the parents, say, can't do what we're asking them to do, it forces a decision," Gardner says. "We use the word 'adopted' to ensure that they're perfectly clear about the conclusion of the process."

Potential adopters willing to sign up to a concurrent planning project need to be made of strong stuff. They have to face the possibility that a child they become attached to could return to his or her birth parents; and, during the assessment time, they have to meet and form a relationship with birth parents. They must also, says Gardner, "believe children are best off being brought up by their own families, if at all possible".

The professionals admit that recruiting carers prepared to embrace concurrency is difficult. Gardner's team had to turn down a referral last month because of a lack of appropriate carers. But altruism is not the sole motive. Gray says: "There might be a couple who want to adopt a small baby, but are unwilling to wait. If they become a concurrent family, they will have a bigger chance of adopting a baby, so self interest is involved."

Not everyone supports concurrent planning. Some professionals - usually lawyers - have condemned it as "adoption by the back door" and claim the odds are stacked against birth parents winning their children back. Critics point to the fact that, in Britain, most children referred for concurrency planning are adopted. In Manchester, the Goodman project has returned just one child (out of 11 placed) to its birth parents.

Concurrency supporters say these critics are missing the point. Birth parents get more help from a concurrency project than from mainstream services, Gardner argues. "We're talking about last-chance scenarios here, and we can give them the very best last chance."

Another criticism is that, as the same agency is working with both "sides", birth parents are unlikely to get a fair hearing. To maintain fairness, the Coram Family project allocates separate workers to the birth mother and the foster carers.

Sharon Donnelly, manager of the Brighton & Hove team, says that the birth parents need to make huge changes in their lives to win their children back. "They need time to do that, contact is only one part of the jigsaw. And visits are increased if significant improvements are made."

There is worryingly little research comparing concurrency outcomes with those of children placed by usual means. Elizabeth Monck is trying to fill this gap with research - funded by the Nuffield Foundation - which is monitoring the concurrency pilots.

At present, Monck is ambivalent about the future. The projects have so far dealt overwhelmingly with babies - the easiest children to place in any case. And when the first projects started, delays and drift characterised the care system. But she says the introduction of the Quality Protects targets and the adoption white paper are already having an impact.

Whichever route is taken, achieving a permanent solution early on in the process is key, says Donnelly. "Throughout the system, we need to make decisions within a time scale that is right for the child," she says.
fields.bodyText: When Paul was taken into care at only six weeks old, he was sent to live with a foster carer with a difference - one who agreed at the outset that if the courts decided his birth mother should give up the little boy, then she would adopt him. The baby was placed with his carer through the Coram Family concurrent planning project, a London-based pilot scheme which sets out to ensure that young babies and children who come into care find a permanent family from the earliest possible date. While Paul (not his real name) is busy getting to know his new carer, his birth mother has been given one last chance to win him back. If she is able to convince the court she had dealt with her problems - including drugs - which put her child at risk, she stands a chance of keeping him. If not, Paul will be adopted. The government wants to see more children in care adopted - an increase of at least 40% by 2004-05. An adoption white paper and draft national standards, published before Christmas, called for local authorities to look harder and quickly for permanent solutions for children. The controversy over internet adoptions has further raised the stakes. A growing number of adoption professionals believe that concurrent planning is the answer for a significant number of younger children in care. Babies in the care system can face delays of up to two years before they are adopted, or returned to live with their birth parents or with a relative. Concurrent planning sets out to minimise the number of moves children make by placing them with foster carers until the courts decide their future. If the birth parent fails to convince the courts they are able to offer their child a safe and loving home, the foster parents already caring for the child will adopt. The approach is in its infancy in this country. The Manchester Adoption Agency was the first organisation to put a toe in the water when it opened the Goodman project - a concurrency team that made its first placement in September 1998 and has placed 11 children to date. Manchester was followed by Brighton & Hove council, which added concurrency planning in August 1999. In the US, the approach has been used for about 15 years with children up to age eight. The London scheme, run by Coram Family, a children's charity, receives referrals from Islington and Camden social services and targets children under the age of two. So far, it has placed two boys (both born drug-dependent) and hopes to place another child shortly. Gill Gray, project leader at Coram, says concurrent planning is driven by "attachment theory". Babies who come into care via the traditional route may live in a series of foster homes before they find an adoptive family. "Children who don't get the opportunity to make close attachments, or who have those attachments disrupted early on, can have difficulties forming relationships in later life or can develop emotional problems," she says. Government research shows that the average time spent "looked after", before a decision is made on adoption, is 16 months. The average time from decision to placement is another seven months. Everyone agrees that this is too long for an already vulnerable child to spend in limbo. Nina Gardner, manager of the Goodman project, says concurrency focuses the minds of all the adults involved in decision-making. While the legal processes are essentially the same as other care proceedings, decisions are made within a set time scale. Concurrency cases are heard by a judge who is familiar with the concept, and final hearing dates to determine the child's future, are usually set at the first full hearing of the case. Gardner says: "We placed a child on December 4 and we have a final hearing date of July 23." While the child is being "fostered", staff assess the birth parents or any other member of the child's family interested in caring for the child. The assessment can last for anything from six to nine months and, during that time, the birth parents have regular contact with their child - usually three times a week. They are also offered support to help them deal with their problems, and only parents who show some hope of reforming are referred. "If the parents, say, can't do what we're asking them to do, it forces a decision," Gardner says. "We use the word 'adopted' to ensure that they're perfectly clear about the conclusion of the process." Potential adopters willing to sign up to a concurrent planning project need to be made of strong stuff. They have to face the possibility that a child they become attached to could return to his or her birth parents; and, during the assessment time, they have to meet and form a relationship with birth parents. They must also, says Gardner, "believe children are best off being brought up by their own families, if at all possible". The professionals admit that recruiting carers prepared to embrace concurrency is difficult. Gardner's team had to turn down a referral last month because of a lack of appropriate carers. But altruism is not the sole motive. Gray says: "There might be a couple who want to adopt a small baby, but are unwilling to wait. If they become a concurrent family, they will have a bigger chance of adopting a baby, so self interest is involved." Not everyone supports concurrent planning. Some professionals - usually lawyers - have condemned it as "adoption by the back door" and claim the odds are stacked against birth parents winning their children back. Critics point to the fact that, in Britain, most children referred for concurrency planning are adopted. In Manchester, the Goodman project has returned just one child (out of 11 placed) to its birth parents. Concurrency supporters say these critics are missing the point. Birth parents get more help from a concurrency project than from mainstream services, Gardner argues. "We're talking about last-chance scenarios here, and we can give them the very best last chance." Another criticism is that, as the same agency is working with both "sides", birth parents are unlikely to get a fair hearing. To maintain fairness, the Coram Family project allocates separate workers to the birth mother and the foster carers. Sharon Donnelly, manager of the Brighton & Hove team, says that the birth parents need to make huge changes in their lives to win their children back. "They need time to do that, contact is only one part of the jigsaw. And visits are increased if significant improvements are made." There is worryingly little research comparing concurrency outcomes with those of children placed by usual means. Elizabeth Monck is trying to fill this gap with research - funded by the Nuffield Foundation - which is monitoring the concurrency pilots. At present, Monck is ambivalent about the future. The projects have so far dealt overwhelmingly with babies - the easiest children to place in any case. And when the first projects started, delays and drift characterised the care system. But she says the introduction of the Quality Protects targets and the adoption white paper are already having an impact. Whichever route is taken, achieving a permanent solution early on in the process is key, says Donnelly. "Throughout the system, we need to make decisions within a time scale that is right for the child," she says.

fields.headline: Players and their pages
fields.standfirst: Eat, drink and play a neat one-two with your favourite footballers as our roving eye peruses their personal websites
fields.trailText: Steve Carr reassures White Hart Lane "I know that there are probably a few very worried Spurs fans out there right now, but let me put some minds at rest. He [Andy Booth, who else?] was on fire yesterday in training so if his first day is anything to go by, I wouldnÕt worry too much."
fields.body:
Steve Carr reassures White Hart Lane "I know that there are probably a few very worried Spurs fans out there right now, but let me put some minds at rest. He [Andy Booth, who else?] was on fire yesterday in training so if his first day is anything to go by, I wouldnÕt worry too much."

And Darren Anderton gets defensive tooÉ "That move might have surprised some people but IÕve always thought he was [surely is?] a very good player. Andy fits the bill and IÕm sure he will do well."

Party on, Jorg (Albertz) "Yesterday I turned 30. Many people say that it«s something special when you turn 30. Well, I don«t think so. It«s just a regular day and nothing special happened. I spent the whole day at the doctorÕs and afterwards I went home. At home we clinked glasses with Stefan Klos and Heike, then later a friend and his family visited us. Unfortunately, they had to say goodbye after 30 minutes because their child got sick. In the evening, I watched TV and spent a lot of time surfing the web."

But never a dull moment with Michael Reiziger Recently a man was arrested for attempting to kidnap our team-mate Ivan De La Pena. There was a car chase and the man, who had escaped from prison, shot and injured a policeman. It's like something out of the Wild West! When I drive to the ground these days I tend to watch the cars behind me to see if I'm being followed. I always set the alarms in my house too. ItÕs horrible.

Gilles Grimandi: play the QPR way - please! I know that sides sometimes think that negative, dirty tactics are the only way to overcome Premiership opponents, but that isn't true. Although QPR weren't rewarded by going about the game the correct way, I hope that won't deter other managers from being positive.

webTitle: Arsenal 2 - 0 Bradford

fields.headline: Gunners ease into second gear
fields.trailText:
Arsenal 2 - 0 Bradford
Gunners go second as Lauren gets his first.
fields.body:
Arsenal forsook a second turkey shoot in the space of four days here last night, achieving instead a modest 2-0 win which flattered Bradford City but was still sufficient to restore Arsène Wenger's side to second place in the Premiership.

When Ray Parlour and Lauren scored twice in the opening half-hour Highbury sat back in eager anticipation of a victory approaching the size and substance of Saturday's 6-0 rout of QPR in the FA Cup. Arsenal, however, are still apt to let themselves down through wayward finishing and they should have at least doubled their winning margin.

As it was they hit the posts three times in the second half. The points were more or less safe once Arsenal took the lead but, if they lose a place in next season's Champions League on goal difference, always assuming they do not win the European Cup in May, this sort of performance will be to blame.

Then again it may be harsh to criticise professional footballers for taking advantage of an easy night in the midst of a busy season. And for Arsenal days or nights will not come as easy as this. When Robert Pires, a mild-mannered Frenchman, starts knocking defenders over, the contest really is one-sided.

The best that can be said about Bradford is that they did not lack willpower. They did lack practically everything else needed to give Arsenal a contest - accuracy in passing, organisation in midfield and defence and, above all, pace.

Under Jim Jefferies Bradford's results have improved slightly. In fact they came into this match with a better league record in 2001 than Arsenal. But Wenger's side were always expected to win comfortably and their impoverished opponents could not afford to ignore the sort of hand-out they were offered after four minutes.

A quick through-pass from Peter Atherton caught the Arsenal centre-backs Tony Adams and Igors Stepanovs square and spreadeagled, leaving Ashley Ward to beat David Seaman from less than 10 yards. Ward calmly chipped the ball past the Arsenal goalkeeper but also wide.

With Bradford crowding the midfield and regularly withdrawing eight men behind the ball Dennis Bergkamp and Thierry Henry were always going to find a few bodies blocking their way. All the same, with the defence stretched by Arsenal's wide men, Lauren and Pires, Bradford were never going to prevent scoring opportunities for long.

Sixteen minutes, in fact, and Arsenal did not have to see the whites of Gary Walsh's eyes in taking the lead. A pass inside by Bergkamp and Parlour did the rest, driving a skidding shot home from 25 yards.

With Parlour and Patrick Vieira able to bring the ball well over halfway before being seriously challenged Arsenal had little difficulty maintaining whatever tempo they fancied. Bradford are a hard-working side but are no less one-paced than last season.

The point was reinforced when Arsenal went further ahead after 26 minutes. Lee Dixon, hardly a spring chicken, scampered around Eoin Jess and Lauren rose well to head down inside the far post with Walsh showing the reflexes of a sack of coal.

Bradford brought Seaman into urgent action at the end of the first half, Wayne Jacobs appearing in space on the left to drive in a shot which the goalkeeper turned round the near post. But there Seaman's meaningful employment finished.

Walsh, on the other hand, turned a Parlour shot on to a post, Lauren wafting the rebound into the crowd, and later denied Pires with equal agility. Henry also clipped a post and Ashley Cole was similarly out of luck after his cross-shot had beaten the goalkeeper.

 Peterborough came from a goal down to beat the Second Division's bottom club Oxford United 4-2. After taking a 19th-minute lead, Oxford slumped to 3-1 before Peter Fear reignited the contest in the 88th minute. The excitement did not last, though, as Leon McKenzie restored Posh's two-goal advantage in injury-time.

webTitle: Fifa calls Japan to order

fields.headline: Fifa calls Japan to order
fields.trailText: Japan and South Korea are entrenched in an embarrassing row over what to call the 2002 World Cup final.
fields.body:
Only a fortnight before tickets go on sale for the 2002 World Cup finals the co-hosts Japan and South Korea are entrenched in an embarrassing row over the most basic of basics: what to call the tournament.

The two historical rivals are butting heads over which country's name should appear first on official documents, merchandising and promotional materials.

This is a serious setback after four years of work aimed at projecting next year's finals - the first to be held in Asia - as a symbol of modern-day harmony between former enemies.

"I think both sides need some time to cool down," said Moon Dong Hoo, general secretary of the Korean organising committee (KAWOC) after heated discussions with his Japanese counterparts and Fifa executives in Cannes this week.

The row dates back to 1996, when Fifa forced the two countries to share the tournament after the bitterest of bidding competitions.

Under a compromise after that decision Fifa awarded the final to Japan (Yokohama, June 30). As a consolation South Korea was given the opening game (Seoul, May 31) and the honour of having its name put first on the official English title: the 2002 Fifa World Cup Korea/Japan.

No detailed record has been kept of those negotiations but Japan insists a gentlemen's agreement was reached that would allow it to switch the order of the two countries' names when written in kanji characters (Japanese script) for the domestic market.

But after complaints from South Korea this month, Fifa has prohibited Japan from putting its name first in any form on tournament tickets. Fifa's general secretary Michel Zen-Ruffinen said: "We are aware of the sensitivity of the situation in Japan but we have decided it should be the same in any language."

But a Japanese organising comittee spokesman said: "We had a mutual understanding that we have been applying for more than three years with no problems," said a spokesman for the Japanese organising committee. "But now the Korean side are making claims against us."

Japan has retaliated by dropping the names of both countries on the 675,000 tickets going on sale from February 15. The cheapest will be £40 and the most expensive £480. There are 64 games, split equally between the two countries, although one or two may yet be played in North Korea.

Japan is still demanding that South Korea and Fifa recognise the unwritten agreement but KAWOC is digging in. "We don't think there was such an agreement. There are no documents," said a KAWOC spokesman. "We insist Korea's name should always come first. It was part of the package deal under which we conceded the final match."

Behind this tough stance is Chung Mong-joon, KAWOC's chairman and a Fifa vice-president. Chung, who is also a member of South Korea's parliament, has acknowledged that he sees the tournament as a springboard for a possible presidential election bid in 2002. A firm attitude towards Japan, which colonised Korea for 35 years until 1945, is likely to go down well with elderly voters.

 Saudi Arabia's captain Sami Al-Jaber has left Wolves after a five-month loan. He was offered an extended spell by the manager Dave Jones but chose to return to the Saudi champions Al-Hilal.

 The former Brazil World Cup defender Junior Baiano has tested positive for cocaine, the Brazilian Football Confederation said yesterday. The Vasco de Gama centre-back, who played every game for his country during France 98 but has not won a cap since, failed a drug test after the final of Brazil's Joao Havelange Cup between Vasco and Sao Caetano two weeks ago, which his side won 3-1.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to editor@footballunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: The hidden role of the Home Office

fields.headline: The hidden role of the Home Office
fields.trailText: January 31 2001: Will the Hammond inquiry into the passport affair be a cover-up?
fields.body:
Who better - from the government's point of view - to conduct the inquiry into the Hinduja passport affair than Sir Anthony "Wally" Hammond, a man who has spent most of his career protecting Whitehall from embarrassment?

Moreover, the recently retired Treasury solicitor, chief defender of state secrets, was legal adviser to the Home Office itself at a critical stage of his Whitehall passage.

Whatever the pressures placed on them, the decision to grant two Hinduja brothers (Gopichand and Srichand) British passports was the responsibility of Home Office ministers. Yet it was the home secretary who sealed Mandelson 's fate last week when he told Blair that the former Northern Ireland secretary had misled the prime minister.

Straw told Blair there were "problems" with Mandelson 's statements that he had no "recollection" of a phone call to Mike O'Brien, the home office minister, in June 1998.

For Hammond 's inquiry to be at all meaningful it must answer rather more serious questions about why Mr Straw or his fellow ministers granted the passports than Mandelson 's careless response to a call from the Observer newspaper about a call he made to O'Brien two and half years earlier.

The allegation of corruption over the sale of Bofors guns to India had been hanging over the Hinduja brothers for 13 years. It was a huge scandal in India involving claims they used their influence with the late Indian prime minister, Rajiv Gandhi, to secure the Bofors contract allegedly in return for bribes worth $10m placed in secret Swiss bank accounts codenamed Lotus, Tulip, and Mont Blanc.

Ann Widdecombe, Straw's shadow, has stirred the pot by asking Hammond to inquire what the British high commission in Delhi told London about the Indian criminal investigation into the Hindujas, and more pertinently, whether ministers had ignored warnings from MI6 about the dangers, and implications, of giving them British passports.

It would be very odd indeed if the high commission, and other Whitehall departments for that matter, had not given the Home Office warning signals. As for MI6, security sources insist it is not that agency's job to make policy decisions. Maybe not, but MI6 reports are supposed to inform ministers to enable them to make proper decision in the national interest.

Indian prosecutors link the Hinduja brothers' request for British passports to the bribery charges. Their charge sheet issued in New Delhi this week states that "the change of nationality of both these Hinduja brothers is directly linked to the stages in execution of the Letters Rogatory [requests for information by the Indian investigators] in Switzerland".

The chronology of events, as the Indian prosecutors point out, is not entirely coincidental. The brothers' application for British passports were rejected by Kenneth (now Lord) Baker, then home secretary, in 1991, (and the time when Hammond was the Home Office chief legal adviser).

In March 1997 Gopichand reapplies, and four months later offers financial support for the dome. In November that year he gets his passport. In June 1998, a Swiss court agrees to disclose details of bank accounts to Indian investigators, the Hindujas confirm their offer to contribute pounds 3m to the dome's "faith zone", and Mandelson makes his fateful phone call. In October 1998, Srichand reapplies for a British passport and gets it in six months, compared to the average delay of 18 months. In August 1999 a Swiss court dismisses their appeal against the disclosure of the bank details.

There is no doubt that Hammond knows his way around Whitehall. He was legal adviser to the Northern Ireland Office as well as the Home Office, and later legal adviser to the Department of Trade and Industry. But he is not a judge, and was appointed an "honorary" QC only in 1997. The question is whether he will ask the awkward questions and look behind the papers officials in the Home Office, his former department, prepare for him.

Going by his past record, he will not. Evidence to the Scott arms-to-Iraq inquiry revealed how Hammond urged Baker to sign public interest immunity certificates - gagging requests - designed to suppress information, notably about the intelligence agencies, that was to prove vital to the defence in two criminal trials. Lord Scott chided Baker for not questioning the PII claims drawn up by Hammond . More to the point, he criticised Hammond for failing to take into account the impact of his gagging request on the defence.

The episode, and Hammond 's history, raise the question whether we should have any confidence in his inquiry. It needs an independent minded judge of Scott's calibre to investigate the murky world of a Whitehall so adept at sophisticated cover-ups.

He was legal adviser to the Northern Ireland Office as well as the Home Office, and later legal adviser to the Department of Trade and Industry. But he is not a judge, and was appointed an "honorary" QC only in 1997. The question is whether he will ask the awkward questions and look behind the papers officials in the Home Office, his former department, prepare for him. Going by his past record, he will not. Evidence to the Scott arms-to-Iraq inquiry revealed how Hammond urged Baker to sign public interest immunity certificates - gagging requests - designed to suppress information, notably about the intelligence agencies, that was to prove vital to the defence in two criminal trials. Lord Scott chided Baker for not questioning the PII claims drawn up by Hammond . More to the point, he criticised Hammond for failing to take into account the impact of his gagging request on the defence. The episode, and Hammond 's history, raise the question whether we should have any confidence in his inquiry. It needs an independent minded judge of Scott's calibre to investigate the murky world of a Whitehall so adept at sophisticated cover-ups.

webTitle: Touting agents face crackdown

fields.headline: Crackdown on 'touting' agents
fields.trailText: Plans are afoot to limit the power and influence of agents and prevent them from touting players to other clubs while they are stsill under contract.
fields.body:
The covert transfer deals, bungs and illegal payments that have damaged football's reputation and brought down some of the game's leading names could become a thing of the past under radical proposals that signal a war on the power and influence of agents.

With the entire European transfer system changing next month to comply with European Union labour laws, giving players greater freedom of movement, officials are concerned that agents could encourage players to move clubs regularly, thereby earning themselves greater commissions.

David Dein, vice-chairman of Arsenal and the FA, said a new system could be in place by next season which would force agents to sign a declaration promising not to tout players to other clubs while they are under contract.

The FA would become a central clearing house, handling all money from domestic transfers and passing it on to clubs, agents and players once it was convinced the deal was done properly. Uefa or Fifa would act in the same manner for international transfers.

If the FA is not satisfied at the conduct of the agent, or there is evidence of irregularities, it could withhold money due to the agent, player or club. The proposals are being drawn up jointly by the FA and the Premier League.

Dein, speaking here at Football Expo, the game's global trade fair, revealed that following the Nicolas Anelka saga he makes all agents sign a declaration and swear on the bible that they will act properly and not attempt to offer contracted Arsenal players to other clubs.

Anelka's brothers Claude and Didier, who acted as his agents, offered him to a number of European clubs 18 months ago while he was still under contract at Highbury. Arsenal were eventually forced to sell him to Real Madrid for £23m after Anelka refused to play, insisting that he wanted to move.

Under current regulations there is no monitoring of football agents and their dealings unless firm evidence of irregularities is produced, which is rare. Anyone can register as an agent provided a bond of 100,000 Swiss francs (£41,000) is deposited with Uefa.

Dein said: "Football has to take control and there has to be some discipline. At the moment it's the wild west show. Agents are everywhere. It's like Christmas every day for them.

"The FA is looking very carefully at how it can discipline agents who do not behave properly. All transfer money must be routed through the national association. It has to be satisfied that everybody involved in the transfer has acted properly. We are currently producing a document that we hope will be a prototype for the rest of Europe."

He added: "We have to undress the entire transfer system and make it more transparent. The FA should not release any money unless it is satisfied that things have been done properly. I am hoping that this system will be in place by next season. The transfer system is going to change and players are going to move more readily. We have to put controls on agents to preserve the integrity of our industry."

A joint Fifa-Uefa task force is due to meet the European Commission on February 16 to finalise how the transfer system can be amended to comply with European law.

Dein shared the platform with the leading agent Jon Holmes, whose SFX company represents many of England's leading players including David Beckham. Holmes, who supported Dein's call for transfers to pass through the FA, said: "Using FAs, Fifa or Uefa as clearing houses seems an eminently sensible suggestion. I am also in favour of toughening up on agent legislation. The only qualification for being an agent seems to be whether you have enough money for a guarantee."

webTitle: English football set to have two transfer windows

fields.headline: New limits on British transfers
fields.trailText: English football will have two transfer windows under changes being considered by Fifa and Uefa as part of its review of how the transfer system can be amended to comply with European labour laws.
fields.body:
English football will have two transfer windows, one in the winter and another in the summer, under changes being considered by Fifa and Uefa as part of its review of how the transfer system can be amended to comply with European labour laws.

Michel Zen-Ruffinen, Fifa's general secretary, revealed at the Football Expo conference here yesterday that Fifa, Uefa and the European Commission had reached agreement on five crucial changes to the transfer system and that once a new system was in place it would apply to the whole world, not just Europe.

Those five areas of agreement are: two transfer windows; no transfer fees for players aged 23 or over who move at the end of their contracts; a prohibition - with certain exceptions - on transfers for players aged under 18 which Fifa claims will stop the exploitation of players from South America and Africa; compensation for all clubs involved in the development of a player transferred before reaching the age of 23; and a new arbitration system to deal with disputes and to set levels of compensation.

A joint Fifa/Uefa task force on transfers is due to meet commission officials in Brussels on February 16 to iron out remaining differences, and Zen-Ruffinen warned that it was likely to be a make-or-break meeting.

Zen-Ruffinen said: "Everybody will know on February 16 whether there will be agreement or not. We have already reached a number of agreements with the EC. We want to get this matter resolved as quickly as possible. If all goes to plan then the new regulations will be integrated by mid-March but obviously we will allow for a large transitional period."

Fifa also revealed that it wanted to reach agreement before two cases which challenge the legality of the transfer system are heard before a Brussels court.

One of the cases is being brought by the Hungarian footballer Tibor Balog and involves freedom of movement within Europe for players who come from countries that have special trade links with the European Union. If Balog wins, then it could open the door to many players from outside the EU, giving them the right to play without work permits.

Zen-Ruffinen said: "These cases could have disastrous consequences for football. They could be worse than Bosman. The second case is challenging the legality of the transfer system. We want to settle the whole transfer system issue before these cases are heard."

If there is no agreement next month, then changes to the transfer system could be imposed by the European Commission, which has demanded that footballers be allowed the same freedom of movement as other workers in Europe.

The main area of disagreement continues to be the minimum time players must honour contracts. Fifa and Uefa want players to honour five-year contracts for a minimum three-year period. This, however, is being opposed by Fifpro, the international players' organisation, and representatives of some leagues.

Zen-Ruffinen also revealed that representatives of the G14 clubs - the group of Europe's biggest and most influential clubs which includes Arsenal, Liverpool and Manchester United - have been invited to a meeting next week to discuss the new transfer system. If the various football bodies reach an agreement, the proposals will be submitted to the commission ahead of the February 16 meeting.

Zen-Ruffinen added: "We are working very actively towards producing a final document. We want to get everybody involved - G14, the players and even some of the leagues that have not taken part so far. The players have not yet been consulted but they have been invited to the forthcoming meeting. We are confident that we will be able to reach agreement with everybody."

webTitle: Birmingham City fed up over Worthington Cup

fields.headline: City fed up over cup
fields.trailText: The Birmingham City chairman David Sullivan yesterday criticised the Football League for allowing their Worthington Cup semi-final against Ipswich to be marginalised by the Premiership.
fields.body:
The Birmingham City chairman David Sullivan yesterday criticised the Football League for allowing their Worthington Cup semi-final against Ipswich to be marginalised by the Premiership.

Ipswich take a 1-0 lead into the second leg, to be played at St Andrews tonight. The match was postponed from last Wednesday to allow for Aston Villa's game against Leeds to be played at Villa Park.

"It was totally wrong for the semi-final of a major cup competition to be pushed back because there was a Premiership match in Birmingham that night," said Sullivan. "We were disappointed by that. Our supporters have been messed around so much I am amazed they even know what day the game is being played."

They most certainly do - a capacity crowd will encourage the First Division side as they aim to add another Premiership scalp to those of Tottenham and Newcastle, already beaten this season.

"The players have responded to playing these types of clubs and are ready to do so again," said Trevor Francis, the Birmingham manager. "I think that Ipswich are going to find it hard to play on our pitch and they will have to modify their game for the playing surface."

Francis's attempts to hamper Ipswich's passing game with a poor pitch and a muscular approach have disappointed George Burley, his opposite number.

"If I was the Birmingham manager, I would feel a little bit embarrassed to admit that my team does not prefer to play on a good surface," Burley said. "You can undertand it from a non-league club, but look at the money they have spent in recent years and they are still talking of a battle. Our style of play has won us promotion and taken us to fifth in the Premiership. We won't be changing it."

The Ipswich captain Matt Holland will make his 200th consecutive appearance, but they will be without the cup-tied Alun Armstrong while Titus Bramble faces a late fitness test on a calf injury.
