webTitle: Classical review: Vengerov/ Papian

fields.headline: Vengerov in a blur at the Barbican
fields.standfirst:
Vengerov/ Papian
Barbican
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Vengerov/ Papian
Barbican
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
I feel sorry for Maxim Vengerov. After a programme that explored the unfamiliar byways of the violinist's repertoire - sonatas by Mozart and Richard Strauss, the C major Fantasy by Schubert, and miniatures by Fritz Kreisler - the loudest ovations were reserved for his encores.

These were the familiar garnishings of many Vengerov concerts: arrangements of two of Brahms's Hungarian Dances, and that ghoulish Bazzini lollipop, the Goblin's Round-Dance. The epic range of the rest of the recital was forgotten in this virtuosic blur.

For all his adventurousness, there was no doubt that the delicious irreverence of the encores contained Vengerov's finest playing. Thanks to his extraordinary technical wizardry, Vengerov is unequalled in his ability to transfix with the most hackneyed music. In his hands, Antonio Bazzini is a composer of genius, while Fritz Kreisler is elevated to the realm of the immortals.

Vengerov's performance of Kreisler's two-minute-long Caprice Viennois conjured a complete world of sumptuous nostalgia, however. That he chose to include it as part of his main programme signalled a serious attempt to rehabilitate Kreisler's reputation. And next to Strauss's E flat major Violin Sonata, Kreisler did sound like a model of compositional control and good taste.

Strauss's sonata is an early work of unbuttoned romantic abundance. Vengerov and his accompanist, Vag Papian, played the work with total conviction, even if they tended to exaggerate Strauss's already overblown rhetoric.

This performance was in a different league from Vengerov's earlier interpretations of Mozart and Schubert. Schubert's Fantasy may contain passages of unbridled showmanship, but this is intimate salon music at heart. Yet Vengerov transformed the desolation of the work's opening into a sentimental, operatic lament. Schubert's delicate passage-work became a vehicle for his virtuosity. Similarly, Mozart's B flat major sonata, K454, was overwhelmed by Vengerov's mannered phrasing and over-groomed style.

Throughout the concert, it was as if Vengerov wanted to imbue all of the music with the communicative brilliance of his encores. Paradoxically, he only diminished Mozart and Schubert in trying to project them with his characteristic vividness and elan.

For all his undoubted mastery, Vengerov was in danger of building a whole concert on the flimsy foundation of its encores.

webTitle: Pop review: Laptop

fields.headline: Laptop
fields.standfirst:
Spitz
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Spitz
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
It's potentially a refreshing combination on stage: a singer, a guitar, a 1970s shirt, a mike and a pair of laptops. You normally expect that kind of tech with the electronics and bulletproof vest brigade, not the good old-fashioned man with a guitar singing about his girlfriends.

Well, not so much singing about his girlfriends as exorcising the exes, some of whom seem to have gone into terminal decline since the break-up - "I'm not the reason you screwed up", "Your collapse is not my fault", "I hate your clothes and your hair". From the wry, knowing smiles Jesse Hartman gives to himself on stage, we are probably supposed to dig between the lines and find a deadpan wisdom. But "You hate those awkward breakfasts but that don't matter 'cause I hate them too" didn't reveal much in the way of inner truth, although "I have nothing to declare" had a good point. For one bloke in the crowd all was revealed when Laptop introduced one number by saying, "I wrote this song about this trip I've just taken" - "Ah, trip, that's why he looks so mashed."

There were some nice fusion moments that combined the guitars, electronics and voice in roughly the same proportions as Beck in tracks such as I'm So Happy You Failed. And his habit of doubling the voice through an octaver effect, which adds a ghostly lower version (as Squeeze used to do with real voices) works well to bridge the gap between acoustic and electronic in some numbers, but starts to sound like Lou Reed gargling at bedtime in the guitar-only tunes.

What makes it sound more like the Beck Shop Boys, though, is the New Romantic synth beats that the computers are churning out. It's not that there's anything especially wrong from a musical point of view, but why use a laptop? Hartman just hit "go" and left them to it, like a backing band on a hard drive. Even the gaps between songs were automatic - the machines just counted a few seconds and ploughed on. At times it felt like Bontempi for the 21st century.

If you're going to use computers as instruments, why not play them, use them to manipulate sounds live? Otherwise you might as well just stick on a backing tape.

webTitle: Jazz review: Ken Peplowski Quartet

fields.headline: Ken Peplowski Quartet
fields.standfirst:
King George's Hall
Blackburn
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
King George's Hall
Blackburn
Rating: ***
fields.body:
It is interesting to speculate on what is going through American saxophonist Ken Peplowski's mind as he stands on stage in Blackburn, facing a sea of silvery perms and thick spectacles. Peplowski, who once played in one of Benny Goodman's orchestras and has recorded material by Coltrane and the Beatles, eases his quartet into their first number while a few people - some with walking sticks - are still taking their seats. For a man who maintains that there is more to him than vintage mainstream traditionalism, he must accept that tonight he is playing to people who are unlikely to have embraced the works of Ornette Coleman.

Yet his choice of material indicates that on this occasion he has consciously opted to play the nostalgia card, and we are massaged by warm and loving renditions of pieces by Cole Porter, Coleman Hawkins and Duke Ellington.

The supporting musicians also evoke a cosy, bygone age. Statuesque drummer Pete Cotterill embodies a delicate rhythmical quaintness that knows and cares nothing about the Elvin Joneses of the world. Pianist Chris Holmes is more exuberant than explorative, and double bass player Dave Lynane happily walks those swinging quaver notes while exuding the rosy good health of a grandfather on a bowling green.

They make up for what they cannot offer in turns of world-class playing by filling the stage with their infectious delight at still being able to give their all. Holmes is particularly energetic, appearing on one occasion to surprise himself, and consequently falling off his stool in numb-wristed exhaustion.

Peplowski's sax chatters away amiably, but it is only when he switches to clarinet on Ellington's Mr Gentle and Mr Cool that his delicately poised expressiveness really takes flight. On Porter's You Do Something For Me, he sounds as full of joy as a bumblebee on the first day of spring.

Jazz for cardigan wearers, possibly, but it would be mean to feel anything but respect.

 At the Shepperton Jazz Club (01784 435396) on February 1.

fields.headline: Treasury limit on the cards
fields.standfirst: Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government could drive down interest bills for millions of credit card holders by imposing a maximum limit on the amount that can be charged under plans announced yesterday to shake up the £80bn industry.
fields.body:
The government could drive down interest bills for millions of credit card holders by imposing a maximum limit on the amount that can be charged under plans announced yesterday to shake up the £80bn industry.

Ministers at the Treasury outlined proposals for minimum standards for credit cards designed to outlaw the annual fee paid by millions of cardholders and set limits on "small print" charges such as late payment fees and penalties for exceeding the credit limit.

The most controversial idea is to cap the interest rate by insisting it stays no more than a fixed amount above the bank base rate. The Treasury is seeking comments on this and may opt instead for the less onerous requirement that interest rates must follow base rates.

While the planned regime will be voluntary, the government will be hoping a large proportion of card issuers adopt the standards. It is hoped the new standards can be in place by the end of the year.

The Treasury used yesterday's announcement to launch a strongly worded attack on the sector and the wider financial services industry, accusing many firms of being "cynical about their customers' interests" and misleading people with advertising that is often "designed to deceive".

It also announced minimum standards for basic bank accounts, and revealed it was looking at how the regime could be extended to products such as current accounts and travel insurance, and even to financial advice. It has already introduced "Cat standards" for individual savings accounts and mortgages.

The new rules for credit cards could result in dramatic cuts in the rates charged by some of Britain's leading card providers. Barclaycard, the UK's biggest card company with 7.8m cardholders, charges 19.4% APR - more than three times the bank base rate of 6%. NatWest's rate is 18.9% APR. Yet there are cards available with 0% introductory interest rates.

The Consumers' Association welcomed the plans, saying they should save consumers "millions". However, the British Bankers' Association urged the government not to get involved in setting prices for banking services.

webTitle: Jazz review: Gerard Presencer

fields.headline: Gerard Presencer
fields.standfirst:
Jazz Cafe
London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Jazz Cafe
London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
A few years ago, Keith Jarrett remarked in the Guardian that the trouble with so much contemporary music was that too many people were trying to write their own. Jarrett's views can be unforgiving, but - like his arch-enemy Wynton Marsalis - he is a phenomenal improviser, one who mostly devotes that gift to the reinterpretation of other people's music. Jarrett and Marsalis would not have such big reputations if they had had to stand or fall by their writing rather than their playing. Gerard Presencer, the young British trumpeter - though the flugelhorn is his favourite option - is also a virtuoso improviser, as he was expected to confirm when he appeared at the Jazz Cafe with his fusion group Platypus, playing music from their new album, The Optimist.

Presencer's spontaneity, freshness of phrasing and rhythmic astuteness have recently moved to a level even higher than the standards he has applied since his mid-teens. On Tim Garland's tour with his British/American ensemble last year, the trumpeter sounded as if he could have played all night without repeating himself. Much the same happened in his solos at the Jazz Cafe.

He likes the upper register of the flugelhorn, but the more mellow instrument rounds the sonorities of the high notes. He mingles fragmentary, insinuating Miles Davis-like phrases with deft flourishes and squeezes embellishments into spaces they ought not to fit, without diminishing either their shapely designs or the momentum of the solo.

The pieces, however, tended toward rather uneventful and undeveloped jazz-funk: fast boogieing shuffles with dominant bass drum sounds, mid-tempo groovers with the same emphatic low-down thumps, riffs reminiscent of the Headhunters, clipped late-Milesian themes over bass guitar vamps that somehow missed the urgency Presencer is effortlessly able to inject into his solo playing.

John Parricelli's rhythm guitar work was as springy as ever, but the true fusions between funk and straightahead jazz are so creative and surprising these days that as musicianly an artist as Presencer must soon wake up to those developments.

webTitle: Opera review: Palestrina

fields.headline: Palestrina, opera with a fatal flaw
fields.standfirst:
Palestrina
Royal Opera House
London
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Palestrina
Royal Opera House
London
Rating: **
fields.body:
Palestrina, Pfitzner's "musical legend", polarises opinion more sharply than almost any other opera. Its admirers claim it as a masterpiece: a profound exploration of the nature of creativity and the artist's role in society. Its detractors view it as a historical monstrosity, tendentious and disastrously tainted by its composer's later allegiance to the Third Reich. British opera-goers got a proper opportunity to make up their minds four years ago, when the Royal Opera put on the first professional staging in this country; the production returns now, so that anyone undecided, and willing to give the gargantuan piece a second chance can do so.

Christian Thielemann is again the conductor, and no one could put the case for the score more convincingly; he seizes every opportunity to make it come alive. The revival is more strongly cast than before, with the central roles of Palestrina and Cardinal Borromeo - whose confrontations are the real thrust of the work - this time sung by Philip Langridge and John Tomlinson. Having such powerfully committed stage performers at the heart of Nikolaus Lehnhoff's production undoubtedly tightens its focus, though by this director's high standards it is not a particularly memorable show.

Langridge maps Palestrina's self-doubt and religious dilemma with painful accuracy, and Tomlinson puts the case for Borromeo's bullying with power and conviction: every word matters.

There are yet more distinguished names in the cast - Kurt Rydl as the ruthless Madruscht, Graham Clark as the eccentric Bishop of Budoja, Anthony Rolfe-Johnson as the enfeebled Patriarch of Assyria, and the great Kurt Moll in a cameo appearance as Pope Pius IV.

There is a real authority about the performance this time, but it is not enough. Even if one puts aside the whole political dimension of the work - and it's a big "if" - Palestrina is still a hopeless piece of music drama, lumbering and unwieldy. The huge, 105-minute first act, which ends with angels dictating Palestrina's new mass to him, is so one-paced that it cannot sustain itself, while the swarm of clerics in the second, which depicts the Council of Trent's debate on church music in the Counter-Reformation, are only sketchily characterised.

The music is filled with schoolmasterly cadences and rambling, unfocused melodic lines; everything is over-extended.

In the end, the whole ethos of the work is unacceptable. It's not even necessary to invoke Pfitzner's later career, his rabid nationalism or his anti-modernist writings, culminating in the Nazi concept of "degenerate music", to find something profoundly pernicious in Palestrina. The depiction of the central character as a god-fearing, conservative composer who triumphs against the forces of new music (by means of a work dictated to him by the angels, for heaven's sake) is such an obvious piece of self-identification on Pfitzner's part that it cannot be ignored.

There he was, a deeply conservative composer in the years of the first world war, seeing himself passed over in favour of the new generation of modernists, and what fuels and fatally diminishes his "masterpiece" is that bilious sense of injustice.

 In rep until February 8. Box office: 020-7304 4000.

webTitle: MPs press for inquiry into Lloyds TSB takeover of Abbey National

fields.headline: MPs press for bid inquiry
fields.standfirst:
Lloyds TSB may be forced to delay Abbey plans

Money Unlimited
fields.trailText: Lloyds TSB may be forced to delay Abbey plans.
fields.body:
An influential cross-party group of MPs will today urge the government to order a full-scale competition investigation into the proposed £20bn takeover of Abbey National by Lloyds TSB.

Their call is intended to exert pressure on the government ahead of its crucial decision on whether it should give Lloyds TSB the green light to take over its smaller rival

If Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, decides to refer the bid to the competition commission for a detailed investigation, it could delay Lloyds TSB's ambitions by as much as six months.

Today's early day motion in parliament will be tabled by MP Martin Salter on the same day that he calls an emergency session of his cross-party group of MPs on community banking to discuss the impact of the merger in more detail.

The MPs want the competition authorities to "ensure that the competition commission has the opportunity to examine in detail and at length the many and serious issues of public interest that the merger raises".

They are concerned that 600 Abbey National branches may be vulnerable to closure because they are within half a mile of a Lloyds TSB branch and that 8,000 jobs will be shed.

Lloyds TSB has yet to bid formally for Abbey National, while Abbey is also waiting to hear the government's decision on its proposal to merge with Bank of Scotland. All three banks appear to be waiting for the verdict from the competition authorities before pressing on with their plans.

Abbey and BoS are believed to have argued to the competition authorities that combined they create a "fifth force" in high street banking. They claim that if Abbey is taken over by Lloyds TSB, this would prevent such an organisation being created.

Acquisition-hungry Lloyds TSB has axed 16,724 jobs in the four years since Lloyds took over TSB, according to the MPs, who will meet members of finance union Unifi and Abbey's staff association later today.

webTitle: Art review: The Wake

fields.headline: Edinburgh gallery's Wake is a big yawn
fields.standfirst:
The Wake
Fruitmarket Gallery
Edinburgh
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
The Wake
Fruitmarket Gallery
Edinburgh
Rating: **
fields.body:
I took a packed lunch. With an eight-hour silent film based on Finnegan's Wake in prospect, sustenance might be called for. It remained untouched. Not, sadly, because the day flew by and the visuals were so transporting that prosaic matters such as food were forgotten, but because The Wake - an installation by Danish artists Christian Lemmerz and Michael Kvium - is a film you can just about enjoy between meals but not for any longer.

Like the James Joyce novel it faintly echoes, The Wake is a work of the night and of the world of dreams. Illogical, non-linear and cyclical in its structure, its landscape is darkly subliminal, and deliberately unintelligible. On a two-screen DVD projection in an L-shape along adjoining walls, it brings to life the kind of nightmares you have only after really strong cheese, the queasy dreams you can never quite recall in the morning.

Here are lipstick-sporting dandies in judges' wigs; a woman with bunches holding up soiled knickers; a gap-toothed man brandishing a clock. People sit with sticky tape across their faces: it looks a bit like disfigurement, but a lot more like strips of sticky tape. They writhe around as if in a rudimentary dance class doing stormy seas or the wind whooshing through trees.

A blue section - in lighting and subject - has orifices pounded, a studded tongue and a very erect penis. To really put you off your tuna ciabatta, this is intercut with images of a man in big, scary Y-fronts having sex with what looks like a woman's body made of excrement. He smears himself and pokes his fingers in holes full of what looks like blood. And so it goes on, oddly dull despite the flicking from weirdness to weirdness, the X-rated scenarios and horror.

There's a serious problem, too, with the installation here. Designed to be flexible, to work in different spaces (a bar; an external light show against a building; an internet broadcast), in the gallery it is impossible to see both screens at once. A column in the middle restricts the view of one screen, maddeningly cutting right through it wherever you view from.

Ultimately, though, it's the self-conscious unintelligibility of The Wake that sends you to sleep. When Joyce wrote his epic, almost unreadable book, he was smashing convention, breaking the legacy of the 19th-century novel. It's not clear what this film challenges. Hollywood and the predictability of mainstream film? We've been there, done that - without the mucky Y-fronts and the dreary self-indulgence.

 Until February 10. Details: 0131-225 2383.
